author: {'steamid': '76561198043471985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4611, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4611, 'last_played': 1665934722}
review: I enjoyed Blackguards.  From the fully voiced dialog, to the solidly developed characters, to the tactical combat, this is well worth the time of a fan of RPGS that mix turn-based tactical combat.  At first glance,  the systems in the game seem just a bit daunting, but once you begin to play they make sense.  I did get a nice "D&D Vibe" from this game as your character stats page is called a character sheet and reads like one.  RNG on spells can be a bit of a heart breaker, but once you understand how to invest the correct amount of AP (Experience currency) into a spell and back it up with supporting base stats, the casting is no longer an issue.  This game is all about specializing and really thinking how you are going to flesh your character out.   By the way, it is okay to hold onto those AP points until you really know which way your are going to take your character.  Overall, this is a good way to spend anywhere from 30 to 80 hours of your time on a solid RPG.  Blackguards is an enjoyable 4/5.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971838196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 356, 'playtime_forever': 1978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1978, 'last_played': 1663895982}
review:
Spielwertung: 7.5/10
Spielzeit: ca. 33 Stunden
Spieldurchl√§ufe: 1 (Ende)

Ich war, nach Lekt√ºre einer guten Handvoll Rezensionen hier bei Steam, schon 100% √ºberzeugt, dass ich das Spiel weder spielen noch m√∂gen w√ºrde und h√∂chstens f√ºr die Karten 2 Stunden idlen lasse, aber, welch Wunder, hat mich das Spiel vom 1. Moment an am Haken gehabt!

Wer mit Baldurs Gate, Icewind Dale, Planescape Torment etc. aufgewachsen ist, der f√ºhlt sich in Blackguards sofort wohl. Nein, nat√ºrlich unterscheiden sich die Spiele und noch mal nein, Blackguards ist nicht mal ein m√ºder Abklatsch der Klasse eines 20 Jahre alten Klassikers (was das wohl aussagt...), aber: Das Spiel ist trotzdem nicht √ºbel. 

Rundenbasiertes Kampfsystem mit sehr viel Tiefe, interessante Charaktere, das DSA-System, etwas abgefeilt. Die Graphik ist ok, die Zeichnungen sch√∂n. Die Story wird immer hervorgehoben, sagen wir mal so: Anfangs ist sie stark. Im Kern ist der Plot keine Offenbarung, aber durch viele Windungen entfaltet sie sich lange sehr stark, man ist durchaus gefordert, interessiert und emotional gebunden. Das Grinden und generelle Finden von Nebenquests ist gut, fast jeder Kampf eine Herausforderung f√ºr die grauen Zellen, das St√§rker-Werden dank unz√§hliger verschiedener Talentb√§ume, das Spiel hat viele St√§rken, aber leider auch viele Schw√§chen:

- das Ende f√§llt gnadenlos ab. Sorry, aber das Spiel wirkt wie "Geld ausgegangen" oder "Publisher zieht das Releasedatum vor". Wie man so schwach abschlie√üen kann, ist schon wirklich eine Kunst. Niemand erwartet m√§chtige, millionenteure Cinematics, aber das Ende ist wirklich schaurig. 
- Items: Die Items in dem Spiel sind durchgehend monoton. In jedem anderen Rollenspiel w√§ren das Sachen f√ºr die ersten 1-2 Stunden, die man hier im Lategame tr√§gt. "Namenlose Lederr√ºstung mit 2 Zeilen Lore-Text", "Kettenhemd-Set", "Gelehrten-Stoffkleidung" etc. Ich meine, f√ºr das Setting vielleicht gar nicht √ºbel, dass bewusst verzichtet wird auf "Kunens Power-Set" oder "Carmens Siegelring" oder "Neptulons Dreizack", zumal es diese "besonderen" Items tats√§chlich gibt, aber nur sehr wenige, die auch kaum wertetechnisch hervorstechen. Sie haben weder andere Farbstufen noch das Gef√ºhl, man w√ºrde hier was Einzigartiges finden. Mein Zwerg, Naurim, hatte bis kurz vor Schluss seine eigene Axt aus den Anfangszeiten, einfach weil es nichts Besseres gab, auch der Zauberer Zubaran trug ewig "seinen" eigenen Stab von der Einf√ºhrung. Puhhhhh... in Baldurs Gate konnte man schon in den ersten St√§dten riesige Sachen finden oder bei H√§ndlern kaufen (oder klauen), hier, in Blackguards, f√ºhren die H√§ndler nur langweiliges Zeug... ich bin v√∂llig einverstanden damit, dass das Spiel komplett auf s√§mtliche Diebesf√§higkeiten verzichtet, aber dann lasst uns doch wenigstens gute Sachen finden + in Quests verdienen + KAUFEN. 
- Map/St√§dte: Unz√§hlige Mappunkte/D√∂rfer bestehen nur aus 1, 2 NPCs, die man √ºberhaupt ansprechen kann, meistens nutzlose H√§ndler oder Gastwirte. Ich verstehe das nicht, wozu? Um die Welt auszudehen, damit es nicht nur 6, 7 Orte gibt? Warum nicht wenigstens 1-2 Nebenquests in jedem Ort?
- Party: Blackguards l√§sst dir NIE die Wahl, wer in deiner Party ist. Nicht nur das, man verliert sogar regelm√§√üig Mitglieder nach Skript. Buh! F√ºr die Story mag das reizvoll sein, f√ºr ein Spiel wie das ist es eine Katastrophe. Man denkt sich noch, hey, diese Rolle X hat Person Y, der Rest skillt also Z und 2 Stunden sp√§ter, ZACK, Y ist tot. Und nein, kommt auch nicht bald wieder oder wird ersetzt durch Q. Einfach weg. Und ebenfalls nein, man kann nie irgendwelche Partymitglieder einladen/ausladen. Da waren wir schon mal weiter...
- Nebenquests: In Kapitel 3 gab es eine riesige F√ºlle, da konnte man allein 10 Stunden damit verbringen, aber in allen anderen Kapiteln nur sehr wenig bis gar keine. Sicher, ein 30-Stunden Spiel, das f√ºr manche wohl auch 40 und mehr gegangen ist, muss man vielleicht nicht NOCH MEHR strecken, aber trotzdem f√ºhlt sich das Spiel in der meisten Zeit sehr "leer" an. Eine riesige Karte, zig Ortschaften, aber nirgendwo passiert irgendwas. 
Immerhin war alles bugfrei und die Erkl√§rungen zu den Shortcuts, Hotkeys, Tastenbelegungen, Regelwerk etc. sind sehr einsteigerfreundlich gehalten, genau wie das Tutorial. 

Fazit: Ein Spiel, dass ich eigentlich "wegwerfen" wollte, hat mich 30 Stunden+ gefesselt und bis auf das Ende √ºberwiegend positiv √ºberrascht. Ich denke, es wurden ein paar massive Fehler im Design gemacht, die f√ºr viele SpielerInnen langweilig oder sogar schlecht her√ºberkommen k√∂nnten, aber ich m√∂chte Blackguards trotz der vielen schlechten (insgesamt "nur" ausgeglichenen) Rezensionen dennoch - mit Einschr√§nkungen - empfehlen!

author: {'steamid': '76561198029122438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2544, 'last_played': 1662899314}
review:
I've used this product for 42 hours. Interesting system - character creation and combat but this title feels bare bones. Feels beta still, like it got a great start but has maybe 10% of the content it should. Trainers are almost useless. They might train a single ability. Maybe because I'm use to titles like Diablo 3, Path of Exile, Assassin's creed Valhalla, Odyssey, Origins, etc. These titles have a lot of content and their worlds are robust. This title doesn't feel robust and its far to linear. I really enjoyed the stats system, the way you could use a slider with your weapons to use them for defensively or offensively in increments. I found this a lot of fun and worthwhile to use and have never seen it in other titles. Loved the dialogue in the conversations. It felt real, legit, as if the people were being honest and their banter was worthwhile to listen to. Loved the voices in the conversations. The conversations weren't dry or dead but I wanted to see what everyone was going to say.  So many titles are the same old boring conversations. This story was interesting! 

The combat I found to be very limited and a bit too slow paced - again maybe because I am use too action rpgs. The number of spells was far too limited and I found my options in combat to be very one dimensional. OH! Combat - fireball - fireball - fireball - flame burst - flame burst - flame burst - toss in the ice ray and the magic missile and that was a casters grand list of options. Sure a few buffs and debuffs, some heals, and cleansers but done! It would all easily fit inside a single spell book and there for left no reason to search the "world" for more power. 

I would have liked to see the weapon defense/offense sliders also adjust damage. Seems to me that if someone is fighting more defensively that they would do less damage and not just in misses because of a lower attack. Perhaps a 3:1, 4:1, 5:1 ratio of attack increase to added damage. The current system gave you more attack and parry (a single parry each round) and it ran out of steam fast. I didnt need all the attack I had, there was no added incentives to add more attack, so I used more defense and found that very limited because of the combat system. 

Some good. Some bad. But all in all this title feels unfinished and VERY limited in combat so much that after a few dozen hours its losing its interest to the player. I see the limitations and it becomes dull. The growth that is presented to the player is too limited and thus becomes devalued, poor incentive, undesirable. All of which doesnt encourage further play but led me to find something else to place my interest. 

This title has some good things and some shortcomings.I wouldnt recommend it because I found it too unfinished, unrefined, lacking, and that is why I called it a beta.

author: {'steamid': '76561198261326127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 1839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1038, 'last_played': 1670987754}
review:
Honestly tried to like it, but it just isn't fun. The game has potential. The world design is quite good. However, the biggest problem is that it has too much 'breadth' and not enough 'depth'. There are too many towns that have 2 or 3 NPCs. The loading screen feels like a recurring phantom. This is all amidst frequent crashes during combat, which makes it worse. The story is lackluster, the gameplay is mediocre. There are plenty of better CRPGs out there, with actual *role playing*. This is not a true role playing game since there really isn't much of a character choice other than the superficial combat builds that don't really do much to distinguish the characters. 

The game crashes a LOT. It's a glitch fest...

author: {'steamid': '76561198078962538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4032, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4032, 'last_played': 1660105765}
review:
Nach langer Zeit habe ich Blackguards eine zweite Chance gegeben. Das war die richtige Entscheidung. Nach dem Kauf hatte ich es bald links liegen lassen: Es erschien mir oberfl√§chlich und ohne jede Beinfreiheit gestaltet, da es wenig Bewegungsfreiheit bietet und die Charaktere recht generisch sind. Dennoch hat es mich inzwischen √ºberzeugt. Das Kampfsystem entfaltet sich nach und nach, ebenso wie die Spielwelt. Die Charaktere sind weniger flach gestaltet, als ich zuerst angenommen habe, etwas mehr Bewegungsfreiheit stellt sich ein und die Story ist interessant. Am Ende macht das Spiel einfach Spa√ü und ist selten frustrierend oder √§rgerlich.

Was mir fehlt ist der Survival-Aspekt, der in den ersten DSA-Games ausgepr√§gt war. Blackguards ist durchaus mit diesen vergleichbar in mancherlei Hinsicht, auch wenn es an vielen Stellen eingeschr√§nkter - man k√∂nnte auch sagen: fokussierter - ist. Der Surivival-Aspekt fehlt jedoch v√∂llig. Ich h√§tte mir gew√ºnscht, dass Zeit vergeht, w√§hrend ich auf der der Karte mit meiner Gruppe herumreise und dass Krankheiten, Wetter und Rationen ein Bestandteil des Spiels sind. Zudem fehlen Talentproben au√üerhalb des Kampfes. Dennoch bin ich zufrieden, das Game nach Jahren in der Steam-Bibliothek noch einmal angeschaut zu haben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035808481', 'num_games_owned': 1625, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 336, 'last_played': 1660088022}
review:
There are issues with the game freezing and dying documented since 2014. They have not been fixed, they will not be fixed. And community solutions only work sometimes.

it doesnt matter what this game is like, there is a good chance you won't ever be able to properly play it without crashing in the middle of a battle you sat in for far too long.

author: {'steamid': '76561198821619279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 2570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1662098648}
review:
OK I changed my review as I manage to get it to run. Have to compatibility mode it to Windows 7 but still there are some crashing issues and manage to finally finish this game.

I say this as a casual in Tactical game this is an alright game. Characters are likeable enough for me.
In terrms of gameplay there are features in old tactical game that are absent here and makes the game really slow and frustrating. 

OK the last tactical game I have played is Vandal Hearts 2 but I can safely say that game is way better than this one and its an older game.
 In VH2 your character can go through other allies occupied space and the latter will just side step in the way in Blackguards you can't do that. 
You also can't use range spells or missiles if your allies in the way of Line of sight if I remember correctly VH2 doesn't have that you can shoot enemies even if your ally is in the line of sight.
Other thing is in VH2 moving and attacking are separate, what I mean is you can move then attack but you can also attack and then move which is really good. In Blackguards once you attack that character's turn is done you can't move and I find it makes the game really tedious and slow.

When it comes to battles at least Blackguards have some redeeming aspects, there are some varieties like go from point A to point B doesn't matter if you don't kill all the enemies. And when say one of your ally get knockdowned you can just leave him and just continue to point B and once all the surviving characters get to it it's mission accomplish that is good.
Some missions are like rescuing people. or getting some stuff and escaping which really mix up the battle in a good way.
There are missions though that are so mindlessly designed to be frustrating just to spite the players. I remember 2 of them. One is in the arena where you go in this maze like area full of neverending lice enemies unless you cover their nest hole. They put a lot of single hex area so just look up what I said on the QoL of VH2 vs Blackguard as it can really show the glaring issues. Same as the Neetha graveyard there are single hex lane with infinite enemy ghouls. Those 2 missions make me pissed as those battles are not really hard just tedious and frustrating in a very bad way and most likely your game will crash anyway and I won't waste my time.

Anyway I give this game a small thumbs up, its short alright game but don't give such high expectation if you give this a chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996462851', 'num_games_owned': 756, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2750, 'last_played': 1658612383}
review:
Game's not difficult if you're used to turn based games such as these.  As for the story, I'm not really sure what happened even after beating the game... 

Also, several achievements are bugged so you can't get them so don't get this game thinking you can get 100% achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985654160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 403, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1652892116}
review:
Finstere Typen wollen die Welt retten

Hier geht's zu meinem Waetsch's Play:
https://youtu.be/1o7beSdiGX4

Zugegeben, das Spiel hatte es schwer. Kurz zuvor hatte ich Wasteland 3 und XCOM: Chimera Squad angespielt. Beide sind nat√ºrlich auch erheblich j√ºnger als dieses hier, aber Blackguards hat mich einfach nicht gepackt. Die Grafik ist ganz sch√∂n gemacht, aber die K√§mpfe sind irgendwie dr√∂ge. Die Bewegung zwischen den K√§mpfen finden auf einer nicht sonderlich sch√∂nen Karte statt und auch nur in der Form, dass man auf ein Symbol klickt (man steuert hier also keine Figuren durch die Landschaft). Hat man einen Kampf gewonnen, gibt es ein paar Erfahrungspunkte, Geld und evtl. Ausr√ºstung. Viel mehr f√§llt mir auch schon gar nicht ein, schaut euch einfach das Video an ;-)

Folgt mir auch gerne bei Steam:
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41912197-waetschs-play

author: {'steamid': '76561198193925438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2402, 'last_played': 1658346268}
review:
ich hab zwar keine Ahnung von DSA aber rein spielerisch ist dieses Spiel sehr gut die Charaktere sind nett geschrieben das Tutorial erkl√§rt einem wie das Spiel funktioniert ohne etwas auszulassen wie manch anderer Vertreter seiner Art und das Skill bzw Charakterentwickungs-System ist auch gut umgesetzt auch wenn ab und an bei 99% eine Attacke Fehl schlug 2-4 mal hinterander hmm Pech sag ich mal.
f√ºr das Geld das ich gezahlt hab es war f√ºr 3.50 Euro im Angebot kann ich nichts gegen es sagen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968075552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 9000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9000, 'last_played': 1597731621}
review: Diamond in the rough! I really grew to love this RPG. Battles are fantastic and devious. Plot is almost amazing, with a few unsatisfying parts, sometimes meanders and gets confusing. The characters themselves are some likeable, quirky bastards.  Long game, lots of content. Character leveling is confusing at first, but very custom and tweakable. Magic is one of the best parts of the game, all sorts of spells with very intresting effects. You can make a shadow duplicate of yourself, do all kinds of fire damage, create impassible barriers, pretty great stuff.  love all the traps and interactions with the battlefield environment. Lots of fights you can't win straight up, you have to get creative with spells and the battlefield itself. trap the monster in a cage, THEN kill it. Difficulty is high in most battles, very easy in some. Buy the second game too

author: {'steamid': '76561198305990004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3261, 'last_played': 1657446375}
review: Cool story, that is leading you through the various battlemaps, where sometimes especially intriguing solutions are required. Even the normal difficulty can be challenging, and it is worth to take care of the expenses. You'll need more gold for the healing potions probably than for an armor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053169661', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1112, 'last_played': 1656865689}
review:
I played this game more than two times and even tried liking this game, but in the end it let me down in game-play.

Trouble-
-Not strong story but the quests make it weaker and at times for a hack and slasher the boss were unreasonably tough stopping progress.
-in gladiator fights of chapter 2 this game came out very bad in game-play, after every fight you can not refresh your magicians keeping it unnecessary tough even in easy game mode.
-many fights are inconsistent with bosses being unnaturally difficult to very easy fights and problem was that the upgrades don't seem to help you out in every fight either 
-inconsistencies in fights, as you can loose a fight couple of times times but with luck you can win that fight very easily sometimes. 

I gave enough time for me to get over inconsistencies in game play but in the end I gave up.

review: This game has real simple graphics, everything looks cheap and ugly. And more importantly gameplay is just boring. After just a few fights, I feel like there is nothing else to do here, every move feels like a chore. It's surprising a game like this one has been produced in 2014, as there were so many quality turn-based RPG's  that were already produced till 2014. Even if there is a sale don't buy this game, there is really nothing worth paying for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973718869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2178, 'last_played': 1650660649}
review:
I can't recommend the game as it's just not good.

A lot of the battles are RNG based and most of them are frustrating as all the enemies have poison for no real reason.
From chapter 3 most poisons enemies use are level 3, so you can only remove them with a max ranked Clarum Purum as the Witch's Spirit spell can only remove up to level 2.
Oddly enough Clarum Purum rank 1 removes "up to level 1", rank 2 "up to level 1", rank 3 "level 1-2" and rank 4 mass cures all poisons, which is just silly.

Several actions such as drinking potions, applying poison and changing weapons (unless you have 18 points in warfare) take away your entire turn and some poisons are gone after a few attacks/turns making it even more silly.

The inventory management is also a giant pain in the ass and the loot is actually quite limited.
There's few sets of armor most are sets which don't cover all slots.
The special weapons seem to be mostly daggers for mages and crosbows only.

And furthermore a lot of the achievements are bugged

author: {'steamid': '76561197985266914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2071, 'last_played': 1649462463}
review: Blackguards is below average in almost every respect. The gameplay is samey, buggy, and opaque. The story is acceptable but uninspiring. The characters are passably written and well-voiced. But its most important failing is that it doesn't deliver on its pitch: to tell a story centered on a group of bad people. The protagonist is portrayed primarily as lazy in flashbacks. The party as a whole is chaotic neutral, but the game is quick to point out that they're typical in this setting. Ultimately, there just isn't much to recommend Blackguards as a place to spend your time, even if it is on a steel sale. Look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048159623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1479, 'last_played': 1648582264}
review:
I unfortunately cannot recommend this game. I tried to like it, but could not in the end.

Pros :
-Reasonable price

Cons :
-The graphics are average (I can easily live with that given the low price of the game)
-The story is pretty boring, I did not feel very engaged.
-The combats are not very interesting, and the hit % are weird (I can miss 5+ times in a row hits that have 90% hit chances)
-The characters customization is boring. You have a LOT of options, which is nice, but most of them feels borderline useless and you need to invest a lot of points to feel a tiny difference.
-Some combats are incredibly easy while others feels very challenging. I love challenges, but I don't like the inconsistency of the game.

Final tought :
I'm not saying this game is horrible, but it feels very bland. I played the game quite a reasonnable amount of time, and I did not enjoy many of the hours I was playing. Since the game does not cost much, you don't lose much by purchasing it to try, but for me, it's a 4.5/10 game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058459688', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 3283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3283, 'last_played': 1646613972}
review:
[h1]Gameplay: 7/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 7/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 7/10[/h1]

‚úîÔ∏è Interesting plot, with an engaging world. The story is a bit edgy sometimes, but succeeds not to be absurdly grimdark.
‚úîÔ∏è Good depth of mechanical customisation for your characters. Being based on a tabletop RPG system helps.
‚úîÔ∏è The companions manage to have a fair amount of personality, which is rare and enjoyable.
‚úîÔ∏è A good deal of effort has been done to provide a wide variety of battles, with special interactions, interesting layouts, and alternative goals.
‚úîÔ∏è The overall balance feels very fair, providing an adequate level of challenge, while rarely being unbearably difficult. This probably depends on how well you managed to handle the character building system though.
‚úîÔ∏è Nice sense of detail on character models, equipment, and world map.
‚úîÔ∏è Enjoyable music, and fully voiced dialogues.
‚úîÔ∏è The game seems to use its graphical resources in a smart way - it doesn't seem to have a huge amount of different models and illustrations, but it arranges it in ways that avoid to feel repetition too much. The "fixed view" location displays help a lot in that direction, and have some charm of their own.

‚ùå The game lacks mechanical clarity. [b]A lot.[/b] Many effects are not explained, the way encumbrance works is barely hinted at, and the UI is very unclear about what bonuses your armor actually provides you. Nothing explains you how exactly your spells' efficiency relies on your attributes. Nothing even explains you how your attacks are rolled and why 100% accuracy attacks may miss. Nothing explains you how perception works exactly. The game provides tons of numbers but gives no indication of how they fit together. This is my biggest grudge with this game. I had to recreate a character five times before I understood how I'm supposed to build it - and it's very kind from the game to provide prebuilt characters to avoid that mess, but you still have to deal with it on your level ups, so it only delays the problem, and I would much rather the game gave you an actual tutorial on the combat system it uses.
‚ùå Some specific battles suffer from a similar lack of clarity, where you have to fail the battle once to understand what exactly is going on there.
‚ùå Despite the effort put in differentiating the battles and creating refreshing arenas, you really feel that the battle system behind it is quite a bit boring. Luckily battles don't tend to drag, but still the lack of diversity of combat actions for non-magic characters tends to get a bit annoying over the course of the game. [b]I definitely recommend to build a magic user for the player character, even if the magic isn't their main focus[/b], otherwise I think that you'll find that your character turns get quite a bit monotonous - and the game already provides two non-magic characters that fill up the roles of basic melee fighters very well.
‚ùå At some points the narration gets a bit weak, and it lacks some degree of player choice to my taste.
‚ùå The interface is pretty ugly and not user friendly.

Overall [b]despite its awful onboarding and user experience[/b] I recommend this game, because it provides a rather interesting turn-based RPG experience, supported by an enjoyable story, and actually seems to have a soul, given the amount of little details that have received a surprising amount of care by the development team. Don't expect a polished gem, the game is rough about the edges, but still an entertaining and engaging experience over the course of 50-ish hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000313700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 810, 'playtime_forever': 954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1646481271}
review:
Vorsicht, lieber Leser! Jetzt wird polarisiert! Ja, auch Du, versuch nicht, Dich zu dr√ºcken!

Bzzzzztt....

Sp√ºrst Du schon, wie sich die feinen Haare an Deinen Armen langsam aufstellen? Gut so, das ist genau die Art von Anspannung, die Dich erfasst, kurz bevor vor Zorn explodierst, weil die RNG G√∂tter Dir in einem Spiel wie diesem mal wieder nicht hold waren.

"PUFF!", und das wars dann mit Dir, schade, aber so spielt das Leben...

Aber vielleicht bist Du ja wie ich, total ausgeglichen und stets Herr √ºber Deine Emotionen.... so richtig "zen" eben...
Tja, selbst dann wirst Du hier irgendwann durchdrehen, denn das hier ist eben eine tolle Umsetzung des DSA Universums und da wird viel viel viel, sehr viel gew√ºrfelt. 

Und Du wei√üt ja, wie das so ist, "Alea iacta sunt" und so, oder wie der Nicht-R√∂mer sagen w√ºrde: "Arghhhhh! Diese vermaledeiten Drecksw√ºrfel!!! Jedesmal die gleiche ver- piep piep piiiiiep piep, soll doch der Teufel diese ver - piep piiiep piep piiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiep.. holen!!!!

Keine Sorge, lieber Leser, f√ºr Dein unschuldiges, sanftes Gamer Gem√ºt ist dieser Wutausbruch extra neu vertont worden. Aber bevor Du jetzt wieder die b√∂se Zensur um Gaming Bereich beschw√∂rst, lass Dir gesagt sein: Du wirst die eben noch zensierten Textzeilen sicher beim Spielen von Blackguards auf h√∂chst kreative und Jugend gef√§hrdende Weise selbst intonieren  ;-)

Und damit haben wir den Knackpunkt auch schon entdeckt, die b√∂sen W√ºrfel sinds diesmal. Und die rollen exakt immer eine Drehung zu weit, zu kurz oder purzeln gleich ganz vom Tisch, sodass man rein gar nichts gebacken bekommt in dem Spiel. Welches noch dazu so richtig sauschwer ist, was den Eindruck der absolut unfairen Unfairness noch verst√§rkt. 

Da kommt auch flott mal Frust auf, die Bewertungen sprechen eine deutliche Sprache. Die H√§lfte mag die Herausforderung und ist emotional so gefestigt, dass ihr alles piepegal ist und die andere H√§lfte bei√üt in die Tastatur und dr√ºckt den Deinstall Button schneller, als ein betrunkener Zauberer nen Ignifaxius raus r√ºlpsen kann.

Drum frag Dich selbst, lieber Leser: "Bin ich so hardcore DSA Fan, dass ich mir das zumuten will?" 
Schau in Dein Gamerherz und ergr√ºnde, ob Du die wirklich wundersch√∂ne Story erleben willst, die von Kameradschaft und Verrat erz√§hlt, von Liebe und Hass, von Intrigen und Magie und all das in einer bildsch√∂nen Welt voller Wunder.

Und als wenn das nicht ein bisschen Frust schon wert w√§re, dann sinds die tollen Charaktere allemal. Vom pyromanischen Zwerg Naurim √ºber den zaubernden Schweren√∂ter Zurberan bis zur LSD Drogen Elfe Niam gibts hier Charakterk√∂pfe, einer schrulliger und sympatischer als der andere. Und alle haben sie ihren eigenen liebenswerten Geschichten zu erz√§hlen, agieren und interagieren untereinander wie ein echtes Team und wachsen Dir sicher als Weggef√§hrten unendlich ans Herz.

Und ja, auch die Welt tut ihr √úbriges, um Dich in den Bann zu ziehen. Die Orte, die Du bereist, f√ºhlen sich plastisch und lebendig an, die Grafik ist erstaunlich gut gealtert und der Sound eine Wucht. Die Vertonung der Protagonisten ist genial on point und auch Musik und Umgebungssound wissen zu gefallen. 

Eigentlich ist also alles bereitet f√ºr ein wahrhaft gro√ües Taktik RPG, doch erinnerst Du Dich noch an die Passage mit dem Polarisieren? 
Die kommt genau jetzt! B√§m!

Der Kampf ist genial. 
So, ich habs gesagt, jetzt kann jeder loslegen mit flamen und verdammen. Mir gefallen die Hexfeld Schlachten auf den toll designeten Karten, mir gef√§llt der wahnsinnig hohe Schwierigkeitsgrad und mir gef√§llts, dass nicht immer alles nach Plan l√§uft, wenn die W√ºrfelgeister mal wieder so richtig ihre klebrigen Finger im Spiel haben.
Ich mag die knappen Ressourcen und dass man jeden Erfahrungspunkt dreimal ausquetschen muss. Es ist sch√∂n, dass man sich auch mal √ºbel verskillen kann, denn sowas kennen wir heute nicht mehr. Man muss eben aufpassen, wie man seinen Build beginnt und wissen, wohin man schlussendlich damit will.

Und ja, ich kann auch vollkommen verstehen, wenn man all das so richtig eklig findet. Und dann bezeichne ich auch keinen als Weichgesp√ºlten Hobby RPG Noob, blo√ü weil er sich mehr Komfortfunktionen und ein einfacheres Gameplay w√ºnscht. (Denken tu ichs aber schon, Du Noob, hihihi...)

Aber da scheiden sich eben die Geister, ich will ein Hardcore RPG mit Taktikk√§mpfen, bei denen ich mir die Haare b√ºschelweise ausraufe. Das krieg ich hier und noch mit toller Story und coolen Charateren obendrauf. 

Und wer das nicht will, naja... der kann immer noch was anderes zocken. Doch wurde hiermit immerhin vorgewarnt.

Aber ausprobieren sollte eigentlich jeder Blackguards mal, denn f√ºr einen l√§cherlichen Goldtaler im sale kann ja nun wirklich gar nix schief gehen, oder?

Also ab in die Welt von DSA mit Dir und Du wirst ja merken, ob Du beim Zocken nur Frust oder...

... viel Spa√ü hast  ;-)






Und hey, wenn¬¥s Dir gefallen hat, ne Runde von mir zu lesen, dann klick hier
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41622336/
und da gibts mehr von mir auf meiner Curator Seite. Schm√∂kern for free: Also stell Dir nen Tee bereit und viel Spa√ü beim lesen...

author: {'steamid': '76561198048003678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1527, 'last_played': 1407719446}
review:
Really good Turn-based-combat with great Character costumization.
It uses the REALMS of ARCANIA ruleset, but you DO NOT need to know the
system in order to play it (but it is helpful)
The game got a decent story, but the highlight are clearly the turn based battles.
It is a goog looking game with hand painted grafics and good combat animations.
Fans of DUNGEON of NAHEULBEK or X-COM should try this.
Really good fantasy setting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994065493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1644980268}
review:
this'll read like some unrelated rants, but it's just some things i said on discord somewhere:
the blackguards game is almost making me wanna find the dark eye RPG rules just so i can work out what the hell is happening! why does the caster that's not me have much less accuracy by like 20%? why are 3 dice rolled whenever a spell is cast? what the hell are talent points? it seems to be using some form of THACO like AD&D2e did, making it confusing to work out whether stuff that changes my numbers is good! does bonus init help? does penalty to att help or hinder? i'm mostly choosing which wep/shield/armour are better based on which costs the most atm!
i think i get why the other caster is less accurate mechanically, his scores are 1-2 lower, but why thematically - no idea - and 3d20 seems an overly complex system - gotta try to remember which 3 score are for which spells, try to not use other spells etc. the main character is created using the auto-generated stats, and he has a spell which is consistently 45% success rate, compared to a couple which are 97%, why would i ever use the former?! the other caster has a 49% spell that's like small equiv to fireball, i use it sometimes, but damn is 49% success rate annoying!
last night i had to do a combat about 5 times as i needed to pass 2 bridges to save the girl! kept getting past the bridge them everyone died right afterwards!
there was another combat where you fought maybe 4 easy creatures, then progressed a bit further and there were another 4, then a bit further and there were another 4 (i think maybe 4 sets!), but you didn't provoke the next set until you moved forward, and your mana equiv regens, and ofc you have healing spells, so at least once i just ended turn 10 times while mana regenned and i healed everyone to full!
restarted the game and looked at some build guides - which ofc didn't help the really annoying combat i mentioned above - which ofc also has unavoidable 1 hit kill environmental effects, which i apparently just happened to miss all of last time i did it - done it twice now and each time 1 of my PCs killed by falling rocks if you don't happen to notice the dripping water, you're dead, if you notice it too late and can't move in time, you're dead -quit for the night - so frustrating! 
restarted the game after i tried a combat maybe 5 times where there's a crystal behind 5 enemies that you have to charge to with your tank and smash it, cause until you do, it heals all enemies to 100%, it takes 2-3 turns to get to it and smash, can't hit from range i think - so you have to do nothing for 3 turns, then after that, your tank is stuck behind 5 enemies, trying to not die, and cause of the stupid sight lines (if there's any person inbetween, there might as well be a brick wall) you can't heal them without moving pretty close - also that was maybe the 5th fight without resting, so you have to use mana pots to get mana back (there's a healer for hp), which ofc there's not an infinite supply of!
UH - i long for a PF 2e RPG game where every fight is winnable without having to do it a few times and it's not possible to build so badly you're bad at combat!
i might get a trainer program to cheat, or just sack it - couldn't find a trainer that was free or upto date, so sacking it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198030874290', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1518, 'last_played': 1644592059}
review:
(attention: minor spoilers about existing events, areas and party members) 

I wanted to like this game.

Unfortunately the game is making it impossible for me to. First a little background information: I know nothing about the system this game is based on. I do enjoy playing tactical RPGs, usually playing on hard mode in most.

First let me list what I like about the game:
- Save system is good, frequent auto saves and battle restart option give you the ability to combat bad RNG
- I like the system used and the gameplay mechanics in general
- Difficulty can be adjusted on the fly
- The story seems decent, though I didn't get very far (played up to the second arena)

And of course, it being by Daedelic made me give the game a try multiple times, uninstalling and reinstalling 4 times in total.

So why don't I like it?
Well, mostly it comes down to a few points that make the game impossible to play:
- First and foremost, most things aren't described, aren't described in detail, described wrong or not completely.
- The game does not forgive mistakes easily. Because there is not respec function you better hope that you luck out on spending your AP.

Mostly it's these two points. So what's the problem with that?
Let me give you some examples:
You're building your hero. You want to make some kind of mage and take abilities that you think are going to be useful. But wait, how would you know which abilities are going to be useful straight away and which ones aren't? There is no way to know what you're going to be facing early on so the first instinct is to be prepared for anything, right? Dead wrong. From what I've read in a few forum posts you *have* to spec into a few optimized skills, ignoring most of the character sheet in favour of ultra-specialized roles. Alright, so you've started a game, found out all of your half-assed skills are usless, and make another character with a few strengths. The first few battles go great, you've done it.
But wait, I get a new character that has the exact same spells already leveled? Congratulations, you have wasted most of your hero's (or new companion's) AP on having duplicate spells and have to start over to avoid that. I guess I was only about half an hour to an hour into the game at that point, not as bad. Since we already get a mage and a fighter archetype, I know, let's make a rogue!
But... you've guessed it, you'll get a better one down the line, making you have duplicate spells and abilities again. Oh well, not too bad, you can always use more arrows in the air.
But oh no! Now you're fighting a series of close-quarters battles in tight arenas with no usable terrain where your archers immediately get hunted down in melee or burst by mages! If only I'd made a second melee character instead.

See a pattern? This is how it goes through the whole game; "If only I'd known the next combat is going to have enemies that have limitless knock-down attacks! If only I'd known the next combat has tons of enemies with poison! If only I'd known if the next area required me to speed across the whole map in a turn or two!"

This game requires you to already know exactly the details of what the game is going to look like before you play. There is no interesting decision-making, foreshadowing or information gathering, you're just expected to *know* when to rest, when you'll get healed for free, when you have time to rest between combats and when you don't, what enemies you're going to face in what battlefield yada yada yada yada.

Add to that that most of the character sheet is made up of abilities you absolutely must not take (on account of them being fairly useless) and half of them not saying what they do exactly?

This game needed:
- An enzyclopedia on how everything works *in detail* (not the brief introduction you get with that one weirdly long text window you can open,)
- Much more detailed and many more tooltips
- The ability to spec your party members when you get them to suit a role you haven't already filled
- Actual details in the detailed battle log
- The ability to gather information about upcoming battles/enemies so you don't have to "scout" ahead using save games

I don't use guides for video games; I expect them to be balanced in a way where you can gain all required insights in the game to be adequatly prepared for the challenges ahead. I don't like meta-dicerolls if the abilities you picked are actually going to be useful.

So as I see it, this game can only be played with a guide, or with luck, or on easy mode. I don't enjoy the game on easy mode (because all it seems to do is lower enemy health so the enemies fall over after you look at them funny) and I don't enjoy reloading the game a thousand times because a critical spell or ability failed/some enemy managed to knock down a character until you get all the important dice rolls you need.

So, if you enjoy being challenged on your ability to snuff out the path ahead, enjoy a story line while being challenged tactically and tend to play games once only, play something else instead.

Play this game if:
- You're intimately familiar with how to build an optimal character in the used system and/or
- You have watched a let's play or read a walkthrough on the game (or plan to)

author: {'steamid': '76561198248408328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2388, 'last_played': 1596547008}
review:
Blackguards is a deeply conflicted game: On the one hand, it wants to be a tactical skirmish game, but lacks the nunace and options to make the battles feel like scenarios to tinker with. Added on top is the terrible probabilities, which vary wildly, often for no apparent reason, and straight up don't work out at all. This makes every fight a chore. An obstacle to be shoved out of the way, so you can finally make some progress. There is also the lack of truly interesting environmental effect and the visual aesthetic of the scenes being (at best) generic as hell. In terms of such effects, some are extremly disabling, if you don't have the correct skill on a high enough level, or straight up laughable, because you cannot use it properly in the heat of battle or it is completely ineffective to do so. 
On the other hand, it tries to be a sprawling fantasy epic, using the world and lore of the German TTRPG system as the backdrop. Characters talk a lot and then some, while never having an actual point to make. Their motivations are interesting in the abstract, a mage hoping to be more than he is born into, a dwarf serching for companionship after being pushed away by his own family (as examples), but don't amount to anything more than this very literal reading. They're static and have no push and pull with the antagonistic forces, because those are simply evil cultist eviling for evil purposes. As a small spoiler: There is a powerful litany of the nameless god involved, while some political struggles relate to this - allegedly.
The skirmishes are lacking in options, have some truly unfair and terrible design to them, while the plot is so convoluted, it manages to lose its way a few times with an unmotivated ending. Here you go. At least you get to fight the antagonists yourself, more than the sorce material allows you for the most part.

review:

F√ºr DSA-Fans, die rundenbasierte RPGs lieben, ist das Spiel ein gro√üer Spa√ü! DSA-Neulinge verzweifeln allerdings unter Umst√§nden an dem komplexen Regelsystem. Das Spiel ist ziemlich linear aufgebaut - nach all den immer gr√∂√üer werdenden Open-World Spielen der letzten Jahre, war das f√ºr mich durchaus erfrischend und positiv.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059746253', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1943, 'last_played': 1639021245}
review:
I really liked this game right up to the gladiator chapter. I mean, I get it. Basically an interruption to your goals to play a game within a game, complete with a mini progress to success. Really cool idea. You are stripped of all your items, weapons, and armor and thrown against other gladiators in combat for your freedom. Now you gotta learn how to wield a club and fight with your hands to survive.

But...

Instead of having the same limits as your equally enslaved opponents and the tactics that entails, you wind up against opponents that can do things you can't do. Like drink healing potions and lose arrows at far more range. You'll have a guy surrounded, pounding away with all your limited might while he literally drinks potion after potion. All this appears to be so the experience is drawn out longer. How does healing yourself as a gladiator even fit the fantasy? I could have drummed on with this and googled the solution, but it just got too boring to care. It was a cool idea, but I don't think the devs were all that excited about it. It just felt like filler to me.

Could have been really cool, though. Simple tactical battles with simple weapons, no heals, no magic, and no gross advantages to overcome. And once freed, you would have all those extra melee skills to brag about.

review:
I deleted this because I was running low on disk space...sooooo it's kinda hard to recommend it.

On the other hand, you can get it on sale for $1-2 so it's worth trying if you have more patience than me. The character creation system is cool - like old school RPGs, but I can't comment on how much it actually impacts gameplay.

If you don't care about story, I'd recommend another strategy RPG called Demon's Rise.

If you want a strategy RPG with a story, there's an old PS2/xbox game called Gladius. I don't know the legalities of emulating these type of games on PC so I only recommend playing it on console...

author: {'steamid': '76561198338942446', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 1205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1205, 'last_played': 1634070905}
review:
Bland representative of its genre, that is nevertheless somewhat enjoyable at least at first, mostly due to some interesting characters and an intriguing, if pretty predictable story. However, the game balance, that is at first passable, devolves into absolute crapfest by the second half of the game and turns most end-game encounters into patience-testing slogs which have nothing to do with skill or tactical thinking as the game showers you with infinite battles with respawning enemies, mini-boss spam, several repeated major bosses and a slew of other annoyances - minor to major.

The game is lauded as complex by the developers and some players, but it really is not, aside from some aspect of skill management. No combos - magical or otherwise, no bonuses for positioning in combat, for flanking or surrounding and a couple abusable skills that allow you, for example: to stun enemies for double digit number of rounds, giving you ample time to regenerate mana and just permastun enemies - or for them to permastun you. There isn't much tactics at play, aside from basics, and its a damn shame especially because the enemy AI is actually surprisingly good, it mostly positions well and can easily surround and pick off single heroes if you give it an opening, it can abuse some of the broken spells as well. With proper balance and more tactical options, it could genuinely prove to be a fun challenge, but with the limited scope of the game's combat, it's held back a lot and only shows glimpses of brilliance here and there.

In regards to spells, the game has a decent selection, though a bit unimaginative, but equipment selection is very poor, and even the "legendary" pieces you will find here and there are very bland and just stats+ with nothing special going for them.

If you can get the game for very cheap on a sale and manage your expectations, the first 3 acts of the game will be mostly fun - I'd say somewhere around 6-7/10. From act 4 onwards, things will spiral out of control, and though there were some decent encounters still, there were many very bad ones to counter tham - and they were very, very bad. I didn't actually finish the game, because the last "run" towards the last boss is just so bad, I just gave up. It would have probably taken me about 5 more hours to finish the game, if you want an estimate, and I played on the default difficulty (medium/normal I think).

Also, as cherry on top, the game is pretty poorly optimized - while, due to the nature of the game, it has very little impact on the gameplay, it is still pretty noticeable and annoying when your frames randomly, but repeatedly, drop by 20, even when nothing special is happening.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031187361', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3158, 'last_played': 1633861206}
review:
A rather bad game. I'd give it a 2/10. I played it, because it felt like I owed it to the friend who gifted it to me. And cause I enjoyed the leveling system.

The Pros:
- I received it as a gift
- interesting leveling system

The Cons:
- horrible controls (circle menus)
- the unpolished visuals are okay for a TBS game, but all the cut zoom in and are painfull to watch
- I witnessed several 100% hit chance attacks miss
- some fights reveal their winning condition after 2 turns
- some of the achievements are either broken or the description is bad, so doing what the achievement sais won't lead to getting it
- most of the achievements feel dumb and require a very bad playing style. For example: Having one character who is mediocre at all fighting skills does not make any sense in a party based RPG!
- the game punished me hard for not understanding all mechanics during character creation. For story telling reasons, it works with flashbacks, in which you play your protagonist as you created them. All the flashback scenes where painfull for me to play, since I learned the mechanics during the first hours of gameplay and not before
- everything apart from the fights feels loveless: travel happens on a map, cities feel like a point&click, the merchants all sell incredibly boring stuff (if any..)

author: {'steamid': '76561198042003782', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2871, 'last_played': 1639956868}
review: Flawed, definitely not a masterpiece, but has its merits. The blend of point and click in town with a psuedo-XCOM combat system is something I personally appreciate. What makes me hesitate to recommend this title are the clunkier aspects of the game. Backtracking for skill trainers, bizarrely fluctuating difficulty, notoriously frustrating RNG that contradicts the input the game is giving, and really buggy achievement unlocks. All in all these are just a few of the many scuffed aspects of what I had hoped, back when I played it, would be a good romp of an RPG with the kind of turn-based combat I've come to enjoy. I'm sorry to say, you won't find that here if you can't look past the myriad of flaws I couldn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009624602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3222, 'last_played': 1628456856}
review:
Rezension f√ºr Blackguards
geschrieben im August 2021

Ich empfinde Blackguards als deprimierendes Spiel, zum Ende hin qu√§lte ich mich durch dieses.

Die gr√∂√üten √Ñrgernisse waren f√ºr mich die mieserable Auswahl bei den H√§ndlern ( kaum R√ºstungen und es wird nichts nachproduziert, hatte immer mal keine Pfeile mehr ), das man zu Hiebwaffen gezwungen wird ( Skelette und viele andere erhalten keinen Schaden durch Schwerter/Speere, k√∂nnte Dolche ja verstehen, aber Schwerter? ), nicht genug Hotkeys, √§rgerliches Kreismen√º der Charaktere, schlechte K√§mpfe. Keine M√∂glichkeit durch Zufallsereignisse irgendwo Erfahrungspunkte zu generieren ( man folgt einfach nur der Geschichte ). Dazu ein vorgegebenes Team. Nur der Hauptcharakter kann selber erstellt werden. Achja die ungenaue Steuerung im Kampf, der Mauszeiger wechselt immer wieder mal zwischen Boden und dem Gegner, der auf dem Boden steht hin und her.
Ausserdem sind weiterhin viele Errungenschaften verbuggt. Hatte mit dem Hauptcharakter 20 Mut ( 18 +2 durch Schwert ), Errungenschaft wurde nicht freigeschaltet, selbst nicht dann, als ich den Mut durch einen Trank f√ºr einen Kampf auf 30 steigerte.

Dazu ist die Geschichte nicht die beste und die Pr√§sentation derselben gef√§llt mir auch nicht.

Durchschnittlich ist die Musik, die Grafik veraltet, bekam aber keinen Augenkrebs.

Was fand ich in diesem Spiel also gut?
Die traurige Antwort ist, ausser dem erstellen des Hauptcharakters irgendwie gar nichts.

Ich gebe dem Spiel hier mit viel Wohlwollen gerade 52%.

F√ºr mich sind gute DSA PC-Spiele nur :

Von der Nordlandtrilogie das uralte Dos Spiel : Die Schicksalsklinge ( DSA 1 )
Weiter dann zu Drakensang
Und Drakendang - Am Fluss der Zeit

Alle anderen kann ich leider nicht empfehlen.

MfG
Redbull102

author: {'steamid': '76561198367517804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 1252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1252, 'last_played': 1627933806}
review:
Summary:
Very special game. Some love it, some hate it. Very cheap on sale, but at the point that you realize you don't like it, you already lost some precious hours of your life in a frustrated state. If you love it, you can easily live with it's problems and it will be an absolute bargain.

Main problems:
- Ruleset. Intimidating at first. And after some hours, when I know how it all works, I want to build a new character and restart. Possibly great as pen and paper but unnecessarily clunky for a pc game.
- Uneven difficulty: Often very easy, sometimes very hard. I was rarely in my comfort-zone (challenging, but not frustrating)
- Slow pacing (combat itself is quick and has no issues, but I had to keep track about which trainer is where and what does he train. Also, there open up tons of different shops early in the game, everybody sells different stuff. Travelling around a lot is slow due to loading times)
---> RESULT: It needs a lot of dedication for unnecessary reasons

Main Advantages:
- Every combat feels different, challanges offer lots of variation
- A lot of raw content (playtime)
- Every village looks different, nice music, great voice-acting, solid story (no "find 4 crystals"-shit)
- The way I got loot here was awesome! I got EXACTLY enough to feel progress, but not too much to be oversaturated. I was HAPPY about every coin, every item I found. THIS IS HOW YOU IMPLEMENT LOOT!

I would have enjoyed it much more if they reduced the content by 20% and gave more attention to the remaining 80% (especially getting access to shops/trainers on the overworld map and evening out the difficulty a bit)
See for youself if you could live with the disadvantages. I stopped playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071059426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2933, 'last_played': 1627814799}
review: Une adaptation du JDR papier "The dark Eye" ou "Das Schwarze Auge" ou encore "L'oeil Noir" par chez nous. DOn a tout ce qui fait le charme d'une partie autour d'une table, que ce soit les personnages, leurs caract√©ristiques, le syst√®me de jeu et bien √©videmment l'histoire. Cette derni√®re, bien que desservie par une narration bancale et quelque peu abrupte, elle a ce petit go√ªt de r√©v√©lation qui nous pend au nez et qui marche √† chaque avanc√©e, procurant un v√©ritable sentiment de gratification. Et ce sentiment, il va falloir aller le chercher, car les combats tr√®s riches et tactiques √† souhait, sont perp√©tuellement g√¢ch√©s par UN truc: les statistiques compl√®tement fum√©es (vous allez tr√®s souvent rater des actions √† 90% de chances de r√©ussites, et ce plusieurs fois d'affil√©e). La rage est pr√©sente dans ces moments l√†, surtout que le jeu ne nous laisse parfois aucun r√©pit en nous faisant encha√Æner 3 combats sans avoir la possibilit√© de faire reposer le groupe. Mais quelle n'est pas notre joie lorsque l'on arrive √† surmonter les √©preuves! S'il ne r√©ussit pas tout, ce jeu vous promet cependant quelque chose qui nous poussera toujours plus avant: une v√©ritable Aventure!

author: {'steamid': '76561198093378763', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 6207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6188, 'last_played': 1656847619}
review:
So, I actually like this game. Well, less the game and more the battle system it uses alongside some of the allowances the developers created for tactical battles. Part of my problem, however, is that you really need to know what you're doing to create effective characters that don't 'waste' xp on crap.

Another issue, is that no one in America really has access to the lore of the world of the 'Dark Eye' and its associated connotations. Including the 'grim dark' elements that pop up pretty quickly.

My last issue, however, is the story. The overarching elements are great, but the details are shit. The implementation is shit, and if we're really playing the evil/bad guys as a great many of the quests and title push for, there aren't enough evil options. Including the equivalent of deliberately knocking people out to send them (sell them) to the arena among other options.

My advice to the developers: Work on Blackguards 3, in the process overhaul everything including adding an in game weapon tab so that you can see how a weapon is affected by strength. When making Blackguards 3, come back to this game and 2, interconnect them, add further options like choosing to fight your way out of being turned into a slave (as killing off Niam should always be the bad route and not actually part of the base story), and just generally make a wholly good game rather than use cheap and crappy story tricks to try and add emphasis on your world being grim dark, cheap, and edgy (I mean, really, half the reason why people even like Niam is because she gets 'Move like Lightning' long before you ever find a teacher for that absurdly powerful spell).

I'd also recommend elaborating on the MC's history with Lysander and making it so that he genuinely hates the MC for Eleanor deciding he was a love interest. Hell, I'd even recommend the first branch of the 'alternate' story being the player getting 'killed' by the wolf for refusing to fight it and waking up in prison regardless.

Also, it might be a good idea for you guys to hook up with the 'realms of arkania' remix group and work alongside each other. They work on the non-combat elements of the game with their engine, while your engine/layout is used for the combat segments.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080331463', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 868, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 868, 'last_played': 1627335031}
review:
Blackguards' menus are clunky and unhelpful, and the game generally fails to communicate information to the player in an efficient way. On a small level, this makes basic tasks like comparing weapons more tedious than they should be. On a larger level, it makes building suboptimally a much easier mistake to make. For example, you can place up to 18 points into any spell or non-weapon talent. However, there are only 4 discrete levels for any spell; if the spell only levels up after 8 points, there is no point in putting any resources into it until you can afford the full 8 points, otherwise you've simply wasted the experience.

Building suboptimally is lethal in this game. You've lost before combat has started. This, combined with the inability to respec and the aforementioned poor communication with the player, is why I think the reviews that tell you to treat each combat like a puzzle to be solved rather than a fight to be rolled first try are misguided. Yes, it is true that you can fail a level due to poor strategy, only to "figure it out" for the second go and perform much better. However, it is also possible that you've simply loaded the level with a build that cannot hope to win without a significant amount of RNG. In a true puzzle game, solving a level you've been stuck on for many attempts is satisfying, you think "Aha! That's what I was doing wrong!" Sometimes you get that from Blackguards, but sometimes it's just "Finally, I got the rolls I needed to get past this garbage." 

Those of you who are familiar with turn-based tactics games may be drawing the connection to games like XCom and Darkest Dungeon, which are also frequently criticized as RNG-heavy. I would argue that these games provide far more consistent options to the player. Pretty much every spell in Blackguards has a %chance to fail, including those that don't target the enemy like healing spells and buffs. Compare with the aforementioned games, which at the very least provide limited sources of consistent damage or healing in the form of consumable grenades and dedicated healers. Even curing debuffs is RNG-based: my mage's poison cure spell had only a 60% chance of success, and the ability to cure wounds (which are also incurred randomly from regular attacks) with a bandage is also seemingly random. My friend once joked that XCom should feature a random chance to randomly trip and fall when you move one of your soldiers‚ÄîBlackguards pretty much has that too, in the form of terrain hazards like pools of water you can slip on or swamp holes you can be completely immobilized in for several turns. In one particularly egregious example one of my characters spawned in a corner separated by a running stream, then slipped and fell as I tried to make her cross, then fell again on the very next tile as I tried to get her away! I'm sure an optimal build will mitigate some of these chances, through levelling up weapon skills to increase chance to hit, and Body Control to prevent some of these knockdowns, and whatever you level up to increase the success rate of the best spells, but playing blind was a fairly miserable experience at points.

The level design highlights the weaknesses in the progression and combat systems. If your party isn't optimally built, the levels that randomly take away your gear or party members are going to be brutal difficulty spikes. If you didn't know to get Perception levelled up enough before a level with lots of invisible traps, prepare to savescum: they don't move between reloads, so rather than an interesting point of strategy, they become a minor nuisance and a source of tedium. That's pretty much my biggest complaint with the game as a whole, there's so much emphasis on optimizing character sheets that the game's challenges stop feeling like actual tactical gameplay and more like stat checks. What's the point of having five pages of numbers to play around with if you're at such a handicap for picking anything than what's optimal?

There are also a few technical problems with the game, ranging from minor bugs like characters T-posing in the background of cutscenes to very annoying ones like the save button being unresponsive and the game crashing after alt-tabs.

I want to like this game, there are genuinely interesting elements to it, but my experience thusfar is that it simply is not a fun game. If I choose to pick this up again, it will be with a build guide‚ÄîI suggest you do the same if you choose to play this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006435797', 'num_games_owned': 1238, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1625823665}
review: After owning this game for ages finally decided to give the game a real shot and started to play. Went with mage probably worst mistake. As usual before reading any other reviews i thought this was going to be a normal RPG so i allocated to my mana pool . Got myself 2 damage spells Cold and lightning. Thought i had covered my basics mana + destruction spells since i did not know what to expect got healing spell too and mana regen. Each spell has its governing attributes usually 3 attributes turns out the destruction spells i choose one of the attributes was to low and because of that i could barely cast spells after tons of grinding and getting the AP i started to level those stats and finally my casting percentage started to increase FINALLY!!! or so i thought NOPE!!!! BIG NOPE!!!! the game has no clue what 50% or 95% means is just a number turns out casting spells with higher % it as bad as lower % you miss the same or even worst you cast the spell and does diddly squat. After few hours started to realize it was not getting any better. the % was increasing which made the miss even more spectacular. Get hawkeye on my archer and +5 damage on one turn and does an WHOPPPING 3 damage .... or 95% of shooting with success it does and does no damage. So the combat which is the main of the game is a failure a complete failure. which is a shame. Music is good ...story was going ok ..voice over i was enjoying  it. Everything was set for a good game they just failed on the most important thing the combat that was a mess.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998658140', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 6272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5287, 'last_played': 1625934165}
review:
The story and game is quite fun, the characters do actually have different interests and opinions. However, the fact that one can time and time again deliver results that have a chance less than one in one billion, as the game doesn't display the actual % of likelihood, along with the fact that one miss on an aoe-attack is a total miss, is BS.

About 5-7 achievements seem to be bugged and still haven't been fixed, despite BG 2 being released.

A lot of people complain about the difficulty. I don't see why, as the game isn't difficult, unless you're stupid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030474312', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 286, 'last_played': 1626064701}
review:
A curious title. While I had to refund it the first time because I could not figure out a weird thing, now that I fixed the weird issue it works fine.

It relates to a scroll zoom in. I didn't know how to bypass it, so I asked for a refund because I needed some back. But now that I gotten a better mouse, I can easily enjoy the game. There's something about a lightly hard to get into game that is kinda fun.

There's something odd about it, but while I struggle to totally get the series, I'm having fun with the stage like strategy game. I can set stuff on fire, set my guys on fire and watch as NPCs set themselves on fire going through a busted box.

There's a tricky part, so no shame if you need a walkthrough. But otherwise, I'm having fun. Try this if you want a curious title, want to try some Euro dev games or like The Pillars of the Earth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023180744', 'num_games_owned': 237, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 5750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5749, 'last_played': 1623616780}
review:
Warning : in about 35 years of playing video games, mostly RPGs and tactical games, this is one of the hardest I have ever played.  You *will* fail some fights the first time, as you will have to discover strategies and some "puzzles" so-to-speak (traps on maps, etc.).  That said, I always succeeded my second attempt much more easily.  There is a sweet Retry button, which makes the pain sting less.  

Still, if you do not feel like getting kicked brutally between the legs while playing a game, I really do not recommend you start this game.  It is important for your enjoyment and frustration management that you know this in advance. 

In the final stage of Chapter 2 (out of 5 chapters), I was considering giving up; which I generally do not.  And that is after spending hours viewing guides and videos to make my character builds decent.  But builds do not cut it: you need to try, fail, and find a new tactic.  It turned out the final fight of Chapter 2 was actually easy once you understand the "puzzle". 

[h2]Combat and difficulty : bloody hard by design ![/h2] 
One could say it is unforgiving, but in truth :
1) fights are designed to be challenging and risky, but winnable.  It is *not* a design flaw nor chaotic: this adventure rarely gives you easy fights.  So you really have to pay attention to what skills/spells you level.  
2) when you win a battle, your companions have not died, and healing Wounds is not very hard (low cost in a town, spells, Treatment skill) ;
3) there is always a nice Retry button (with an autosave before each fight). 

The two first chapters are rather hard as your characters are gaining skill and spells.  You gain Adventure Points (similar to XP) somewhat slowly.  So take the time to look at the skill choices and focus.  

[h2]RPG aspects[/h2]
While the main story is very linear, you have side-quests that offer dialogue choices and you can travel freely between the towns you have already visited (for gear, training, etc.).  The game is more of a tactical challenge rather than deep in story choices.  Yet some dialogue choices can have a consequence near the end...

The progression system is based on the Dark Eye (L'Oeil Noir) tabletop RPG system.  This is both a good and bad thing.  The good is that you have a lot of options and flexibility, and you must choose what you will focus in along the way.  The bad is that this tabletop system is convoluted (not user-friendly).  For example, you start with 10000 AP and you can spend points freely in the many attributes, weapons, talents, spells and abilities.  Instead of having a potion say it gives +4 to Parry & Dodge, it will say +20 Agility for example. 

While there are no classes, you must choose at the start if you will have access to spells.  Being able to use spells cost about 500 or 700 AP (out of 10K).  You will have one or two companions who can do magic, so it is really a free choice, but I recommend your main character have the magic option open (Mage).

On the other hand, you can pick one of the three presets (Hunter, Mage, Warrior).* 

[h2]Time[/h2]
Most claim to finish the main quest is about 40 hours.  I did ALL the side quests, including the DLC, in 90 hours.

[h2]General Tips[/h2] 

a) Do not try to be good at everything. Having ten spells that you cannot succeed does not help. Having spells with only 50% chance of success will get you killed. Same for choice of weapons.   

b) Some Talents are important for all characters, notably Body Control (resistance to knockdowns) and Willpower (resistance to Wounds).  

c) I found having 3 casters (i.e. making your main character a mage) made the fights much more winnable, but you can do fine with 2 mage companions.  As you wish, but magic can turn enemies against each other, create an illusionary duplicate, heal Wounds, etc. I also found giving ranged weapons to my mages was efficient and sometimes crucial (bows and crossbows are powerful in this game).  Instead of using "mana" (Astral points) to do a damage spell, you can do a better average with a bow and keep your "mana" for much more tactical spells.  Some poisons will drain your "mana", so you need a Plan B weapon. 

d) The Talent Warcraft is excellent on many levels, notably for the capacity to swap weapons freely once your have mastered it. Swapping weapons allows you to adapt damage type or switch to ranged weapons without losing a turn! 

Nb : my main character was a mage focused on healing (removing Wounds and poisons) and buffs (mostly Dodge and Attack bonuses).  Two of your companions are very capable warriors. 

* Official video to introduce character building :
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Fv8Pksq7YFA&ab_channel=DaedalicEntertainment

review: Sometimes overly challenging but overall not a bad game.  Lots of character in some of the NPCs.  The story is good for the most part...the ending is a bit wonky but was tolerable for me.  The framework is basically moving from tactical battle to tactical battle within the story...so if you are good with that, it's worth a look.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996273719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 797, 'playtime_forever': 104, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1390501227}
review:
[h1] Information / Review English [/h1]

Blackguards is a tactical strategy game developed by Daedalic Entertainment.

[h1] Gameplay / Story [/h1]

The action begins in the city of Neetha in the game world Aventurien. The main character is the player character who was wrongly imprisoned for the murder of his girlfriend. On the run from his persecutors and in search of the real murderer, he meets other characters who also have problems with the law. The player has the opportunity to make decisions at important points and thus influence the game. In Blackguards, the player can assume different classes, such as warrior, magician and hunter. Both the fights and the entire game are turn-based. The game is controlled with the mouse and keyboard. A special feature of the game are the visible hexagonal grid fields.

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ Pen & paper flair through battles, locations and travel
+ varied, interactive arenas
+ Decisions with consequences
+ solid round tactical battles
+ interesting, sometimes funny side tasks
+ well thought-out, clear menus
+ Achievements and trading cards

[h1] Contra [/h1]

- stereotypical characters
- No own group composition possible

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Blackguards offers you a captivating story with gripping battles. Clear buy recommendation in this genre.


[h1] Information / Review Deutsch [/h1]

Blackguards ist ein taktisches Strategiespiel, welches von Daedalic Entertainment entwickelt wurde. 

[h1] Gameplay / Geschichte [/h1]

Die Handlung beginnt in der Stadt Neetha in der Spielwelt Aventurien. Hauptfigur ist der Spielercharakter, der zu Unrecht wegen des Mordes an seiner Freundin eingesperrt worden ist. Auf der Flucht vor seinen Verfolgern und der Suche nach dem wahren M√∂rder trifft er weitere Charaktere, die ebenfalls Probleme mit dem Gesetz haben. Der Spieler hat die M√∂glichkeit an wichtigen Punkten Entscheidungen zu treffen und so das Spielgeschehen zu beeinflussen. In Blackguards k√∂nnen vom Spieler verschiedene Klassen, wie Krieger, Magier und J√§ger angenommen werden. Sowohl die K√§mpfe als auch das gesamte Spiel laufen rundenbasiert ab. Gesteuert wird das Spiel mit Maus und Tastatur. Eine Besonderheit des Spiels sind die sichtbaren Sechseckraster-Felder. 

[h1] Pro [/h1]

+ Pen&Paper-Flair durch K√§mpfe, Schaupl√§tze und Reisen 
+ abwechslungsreiche, interaktive Arenen
+ Entscheidungen mit Konsequenzen
+ solide rundentaktische K√§mpfe
+ interessante, teil witzige Nebenaufgaben
+ durchdachte, √ºbersichtliche Men√ºs
+ Errungenschaften und Sammelkarten

[h1] Kontra [/h1]

- stereotype Charaktere
- keine eigene Gruppenzusammenstellung m√∂glich

[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Blackguards bietet dir eine fesselnde Geschichte mit packenden K√§mpfe. Klare Kaufempfehlung in diesem Genre.

review:
Other than an intriguing storyline, I see little redeeming points about this game.

1. Non-existent character creation.
2. High miss rates even with character stats being maxed out.
3. The odds are literally stacked against you in all aspects even on 'easy' settings.
4. Everything from the simplest potions to a basic set of armor and weapons cost a bomb while money is scarce.

All-in-all, I'm not sure if the game can be finished before you lose your mind trying to...
