author: {'steamid': '76561198055770441', 'num_games_owned': 368, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7720, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7720, 'last_played': 1620058523}
review:
This was a tough decision for me about recommending.   I decided on Yes but only if it's on sale, and if the type of gameplay appeals to you.

So here's the deal, the game is advertised like it's an RPG but it's not.   It fundamentally plays like an older FB or Flash game with very set progression and no real choice.  The story is linear and you can only really choose to skip a few optional battles.  But to progress the story/game you have to go through a specific set of battles, each on a specific map and in most cases giving very specific AP (experience) points and items as a reward.   Even the vendors have an exact inventory and never replenish their stock.  

You have a large variety of ways you can configure your character and party to try to win these battles - but that's literally all it is.   It's also easy to screw it up and make it extremely difficult to win a particular battle.  And you have to win to move forward.   You can start the battle over as often as you like, but until you win you can't continue the game.    There's no perma-death either as any of your party that are knocked below zero HP are just disabled until the next battle (although you usually have 3 turns to try to heal them).

So it's more of a tactical combat game on a hex map.   The RNG during battle can be cruel and made me yell at the screen a few times, but if this is your type of game then it can be enjoyed at your own pace.  And the last BIG negative note is that some of the achievements seem to be bugged.

I feel like I've beat up on the game a lot but the story and writing is fun, the voice acting is really good, and it works well as a tactical game.  I certainly put in a fair amount of hours so lots of value if you get it on sale.

I highly recommend reading through the various guides.   It'll help with configuring your party to win/progress with each of the battles as if you're set wrong you'll have to load an earlier save, change a few things/gear, and then do the battle again.    

An Archer/Mage main character is probably the most optimal for getting through all the battles.  Basic tactic is to cast Shadow Clone, then Move like Lighting 3, and then machine-gun everything with Triple Shot between the clone and main.   The Clone starts with the same type (and amount) of arrow your main has equipped but doesn't actually use any of your arrows from inventory.   This is a great way to make use of Arrow Storm on those really large and annoying enemies toward the late game.   You can one-shot some of the worst of them this way.

One last thing is that I don't see any of the guides or posts talk about Magic-Resistance enough.  Your non-spell casters will have tons of AP to spend toward the end and I'd recommend dumping points into MR.  I had the Dwarf up at 27 by the end battles and if you look at the descriptions for many of the area effect damage and de-buff spells they use the HIGHEST MR of the targets to resist.  I looked at the battle log and the toughest enemy spell-casters only had a 5% (absolute minimum) to 19% chance of success for their spells.  Effectively neutralizing some of the worst effects in the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198114919184', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2075, 'last_played': 1620482065}
review: I like! It's a very straight forward turnbased rpg. I bought one and two, playing one first and I'm hoping 2 has some more indepth functions, mostly in the character building. I like that the story is easy to follow and it doesn't get all complicated and diluted. Side missions are quick and for XP building. Unique leveling system which I'm ok with  outside of the fact that it's really hard to get the HP and MP needed to have long fights.  The coolest part is that every character is what you want it to be. While some come stock with a focus, it's not hard to refocus them.  I'm not a huge magic fan so I'm running with 3 DPS melee and then two archers that can heal. I like it! Magic seems cool but without being able to really invest in the magic and also MP, it has been difficult to sustain. MP runs out WAY before enemies die in large battles.  First time through though, I'm sure I could respec and figure it out. Worth the purchase (I bought it at like 99 cents).

author: {'steamid': '76561198009393197', 'num_games_owned': 1831, 'num_reviews': 289, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 119, 'last_played': 1619600388}
review:
This game seems to be a sequence of one endlessly boring and turn-based battle after the other.  Where's the fun, seriously? Not one of Daedalic's better efforts.  A 25/100 effort.

[b]The good[/b]

It has trading cards
The game didn't crash for me
Characters have some personality

[b]The bad[/b]

Doesn't scale to higher resolutions
Battles are endless and they're utterly boring
And due to the turn-based nature of it, you can spend a lot of time waiting for a battle to resolve
And, most of all, it's just not fun

review:

Reste la jouabilit√©...
La difficult√© est clairement √† revoir, un exemple: comment battre des guerriers redoutables (qui vous mettent √† terre √† chaque coup et qui ont tous des armes empoisonn√©es qui font descendre votre vie 10 par 10 et qui attaquent √† deux cases de distance) second√©s par un chaman qui peut les soigner, paralyser un membre de votre groupe ou m√™me le faire changer de camp? Et tout √ßa avec des pi√®ges qui jalonnent le champ de bataille et qui emp√™chent aux bourrins de votre √©quipe d'arriver au contact sans tomber dans le coma? Et bien s√ªr en moins de sept tours de combat sous peine de recommencer une √©ni√®me fois...

Quand la situation s'est pr√©sent√©e j'ai quand m√™me v√©rifi√© que j'√©tais en niveau facile...
D√©pit√© et apr√®s plusieurs branl√©es m√©morables, je me suis rendu compte que je ne pouvais pas finir ce jeu, bloqu√© √† cette rencontre que l'on ne peut √©viter.
Dommage mais √† force de trop charger la mule, on finit par en d√©go√ªter les joueurs...

review: Ich bin zwar zuerst ein wenig hin und her gestolpert, habe unn√∂tige Wege gemacht in der Hoffnung, auf dem Weg mal in ein Gefecht zu geraten, wie ich es von "Das Schwarze Auge" aus alten DOS-Zeiten kannte (gibt es hier wohl nicht). Wenn man den Haupt-Queststrang verfolgt, kein Gespr√§ch meidet und offenen Auges durch die Gegend marschiert, entdeckt man alle unterhaltsamen Nebenschaupl√§tze. Die Geschichte ist fesselnd und gut erz√§hlt, ob sie sich mit den getroffenen Entscheidungen wandelt, kann ich nach dem ersten Durchspielen nach 30 Stunden nicht sagen. Macht aber auch nichts. Das Spiel ist gut gelungen, die K√§mpfe nicht all zu z√§h (die Gegner k√∂nnten sich vielleicht einen Zacken schneller bewegen) und die Story gut. Mehr braucht es nicht. Klare Empfehlung.

review: Sorry, das Spiel geh√∂rt zu den schlechtesten Rollenspiele, die ich jemals gespielt habe. Alleine die K√§mpfe sind nicht balanciert bzw. unfair. Das es gute Auszeichnungen bekommen hat ist mir leider unverst√§ndlich.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064315577', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 4081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1625926245}
review:
Ein TRPG, also es geht eher in Richtung Schachspiel und Table-Top-Rollenspiel als blindes Draufloskloppen. Story ist eher nebens√§chlich, allerdings haben einige Quests einen roten Pfaden. Die Dialoge sind ziemlich kurz gehalten, die Vertonung der Dialoge ist gelungen. 

Die einzelnen Kampfpl√§tze sind jeweils handgestaltet und nicht zuf√§llig generiert. Dadurch entf√§llt Alles, was ich auch eher langweilig finde, also das Herumgelatsche von Punkt A nach B. Die Kampfpl√§tze haben jeweils ihre speziellen taktischen Herausforderungen: Z.B. spezielle Schalter, Fallen, enge G√§nge, Schutz, herabfallende Gegenst√§nde, Burgmauern, Gifte, die speziellen Zauberfertigen, Ausr√ºstungsgegenst√§nde und Talente der Gegner und Helden. Ich brauche also f√ºr schwierige K√§mpfe mehrere Anl√§ufe.

Es setzt einiges an Erfahrung voraus, welche Gegner mit welchen Waffen zu besiegen sind. Au√üerdem in welchen Bereichen man seine Erfahrungspunkte optimal einsetzt bzw. welche Gegenst√§nde / Fertigkeiten man sich am Besten kauft. So dass ich mich oft frage, ob ich hier die richtige Entscheidung getroffen habe, vielleicht k√∂nnte einem das Spiel hier noch mehr Hilfe anbieten.

Die Grafik abgesehen von den Kampfschaupl√§tzen ist wirklich minimalistisch aber stimmungsvoll gehalten. Die Grafik der Kampfschaupl√§tze ist nicht besonders detailliert, aber v√∂llig ausreichend und lenkt nicht vom Wesentlichen ab. Die Kamera l√§sst sich nicht beliebig drehen, nur kippen, was anfangs verwundert, aber die handgestalteten Szenerien machen einen 360-Grad Umsicht eigentlich auch gar nicht n√∂tig.

Der Preis ist √ºberraschend niedrig.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990311774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2960, 'last_played': 1620508713}
review:
Uno dei migliori RPG tattici a turni cui abbia mai giocato. Tecnicamente eccezionale e curatissimo nei dettagli. Ho apprezzato molto i fattori ambientali che regalano esperienze divertenti nei combattimenti.
Ho letto tantissime recensioni DOPO averlo acquistato e molti si lamentano della storia e del comparto grafico.
Io sono basito. Non √® che mi aspettassi chiss√† che ma le situazioni sono intriganti e ogni missione ha un qualcosa che sorprende piacevolmente. Se una narrazione magari semplice mi spinge comunque a voler continuare la trovo una missione compiuta.
In quanto alla grafica non capisco a cosa la gente sia abituata, √® OTTIMA e perfettamente funzionale. E' tutto 3D ma a telecamera fissa (puoi solo inclinare) e nelle citt√† √® bloccata fissa.
Scelta che, spiegavano, permette di concentrarsi sull'immersione ed evita lo spaesamento di dover andare fisicamente nei negozi tipo Skyrim. Hanno anche tolto le variazioni dei prezzi tra le citt√† per evitare spostamenti inutili. Grande cosa, non voglio giocare ad un gestionale, voglio giocare un RPG!

author: {'steamid': '76561198069556989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7033, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7033, 'last_played': 1617047033}
review:
I recommended this game only if you like lots of challenge in games and turn-based-hexagon-strategy is one of your favorite genres of games! 

This game kind of feels like old-school Amiga-RPG with better graphics etc. Blackguards 2 seems much more accessible than this so I'd recommend that before this to less-hardcore players. However, I was stuck with this for a long time because I wanted to finish it before playing 2. It feels like a mistake almost to be a completionist with this. 

Basically the game is 'just' battles with some pretty repetitive pictures of towns as the inventory and character development screen. The characters' leveling up skills and attributes is  pretty unique and I kind of liked it when I finally understood it but most of the time it felt vague and confusing.

Battles usually have lots of puzzle element in the tactics and they might feel unfair and even impossible at first (on medium difficulty) but there's usually a catch in how to even the odds (there's some really difficult ones still!), for example you need to use objects found in the environment or you learn the weaknesses of enemies and soon it's possible. There's some epic battles that I still remember (swamp spirit plant!) but I also remember the annoying repetition: even in the last battles you fight such boring beasts as skeletons, zombies and ghouls. Feels like grinding a lot when there aren't any interesting attacks or new monsters to see. The variety of weapons and armor feels quite limited too compared to most RPGs I've played. 

The story is not very important but it's ok. However it's disappointing if you expect too much from the progression of the game and I felt even betrayed at times when the quest didn't affect almost anything. Characters are memorable because of the voice acting.

I believe I finished every quest in Blackguards and the DLC. But still wasn't sure of my chances in the last dungeon that you can't escape to main map even when it's the longest and one of the most tedious ones. I recommend easy difficulty to avoid such feelings. 

Music and some of the town graphics are beautiful and create great atmosphere but it's just broken promises: there isn't anything deep beyond it and besides the battles that offer deep thinking and sometimes frustration. I'd rate this game 2,5 / 5.

review: This game is challenging for me, but enjoyable. I'm not familiar with the rule-set from the rpg this game is based on, but it's easy to get behind. The hex-map element is comfortable, as it seems identical to table-top rpgs that use hexes for combat. Aspects of the game, such as the zones between battles, is a fun change from the standard in the genre. Takes a bit of getting used to, as not all things may be obvious. I recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198994796062', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 290, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 290, 'last_played': 1589283124}
review:
This game saved my life.

I am 43.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008665521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 6436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1640252579}

author: {'steamid': '76561198313477330', 'num_games_owned': 589, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 3396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2985, 'last_played': 1653066408}
review:
Den Zw√∂lf zum Gru√üe lieber Abenteurer, in diesem Spiel erwartet euch eine Reise durch Aventurien und ihr erlebt ein Abenteuer nach dem DSA Regelwerk. 
Ihr erstellt euch einen Helden ganz im sinne der Charaktererstellung mit Abenteurerpunkten wie in DSA. Dieses ist wie im DSA 4. Man hat freie Wahl aber Vorsicht Verskillen ist m√∂glich.
Das Spiel legt gro√üen Fokus auf die K√§mpfe und die Story bleibt Teilweise leider hintern vor, dabei bietet Das Schwarze Auge gro√ües Potential f√ºr viele packende Geschichten.
Das Spiel ist auch nicht sehr einsteigerfreundlich. Es legt grundlegende Kenntnisse voraus z.B das Skelet immun gegen Stich schaden sind. Mich St√∂rt das nicht da ich 1.andere Spiele in die Richtung wie Divinity oder Baldurs Gate gespielt hab und 2. Auch DSA und D&D Erfahrung habe. Ich halte es dennoch f√ºr erw√§hnenswert.
Die Musik ist Anfangs recht sch√∂n aber wird leider nach einiger Zeit eint√∂nig. Die Karten sind auch eher Mittel zum Zweck manchmal sch√∂n gestaltet aber gr√∂√ütenteils eher nicht.
Ein Paar kleinere R√§tzel sind dabei und auch neben Quest,diese sind auch recht nett gestaltet aber jeweils nix anspruchsvolles.
Ich kann das Spiel aber nur Empfehlen, ich hatte recht viel Spa√ü und der Fokus der auf den Taktischen K√§mpfen liegt war auch gut gew√§hlt. 
In dem Sinne "In Notmark wird die Dunkelheit gemacht, aber in Pervin bl√ºhen die Rosen"

author: {'steamid': '76561198826764118', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1649211022}
review:
I cant understand Blackguards is a good base turn based strategy/tactics gamer that I have seen... When some people, (me of course and others.) play a game 
Emersiveness, play-ability, pleasing to the eye...injection of some humor into it...It has all of these in varying degrees of quality..but its in there...I recommend if you have played the the full spectrum of what STEAM has to offer...then BLACKGUARDS is a thumbs up...
Its when you look at the higher end of the spectrum and compare then BLACKGUARDS falls behind but not to the extent that you dont want to play it. 
Its the packages that they offer you regarding a game you have purchased Below is a prime example of why buy a package when its cheaper to buy individually......????? 
ITEMS INCLUDED IN THIS PACKAGE

Its like an epiphany....How much are they ripping us off...Bring back REGANOMICS lol STEAMONOMICS kinda blows...

author: {'steamid': '76561198422199704', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 429, 'playtime_forever': 3478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3469, 'last_played': 1614496875}
review:
Okay... normally when it comes to SLG game (turn based tactic), there's always a mix of love and hate from the players. So it's not really a safe genre for game making and the reason why we are seeing less and less of this genre nowadays... the word "SLG" is not even heard of for a lot of newer game players. Mainly because this genre being invented by the Japanese to compete with the up rising trend of RTS back in the days. And most players often mix the 2 together for comparison while they are actually both completely different game play.

SLG's game play idea is a basic old school JRPG game skill set mixed with a Chess Board game. It's a game that gives you all the time to wait and implement your moves (just like the Chess) while RTS is real time and more exciting in a way to some players. So "Strategy" has been divided into 2... SLG isn't really widely accepted even in Japan, as most preferred RTS, and the trend actually being picked up by Taiwan back then and caused a bloom there, due to their love of chess in the culture.

With that said... If you like Chess board game, be it Japanese/Chinese/International (aka Western) Chess or even Checker, then SLG is probably something you can swallow and looks good on your plate. For players who hated chess... well SLG probably has all the reasons you hated Chess there.

SLG used to be my favorite food until i can't find anyone selling it anymore... until Final Fantasy Tactic set another bloom of this genre and finally crack its way into the west... even still... there's chess lover and hater so yeah... these type of games often ended up with mixed rating not because of the game but preferences of the player. One who enjoyed Chess can enjoy a SLG game even without a story base. One who can't simply won't enjoy it at all no matter how good the story is.

For Blackguard... as a hexagon SLG game.. this is to be expected... but... setting that aside... the game still has its own problem. (Comparing to other SLG)

The tactic battle are great and challenging. A real fun for chess lover. But the rest of the game is a bit shabby... like the old trend of SLG, devs like adding branches in story to let the players replay the game adding replayability (replay value) to their game. but those are branching up to different battles and different story time line... Blackguard couldn't grab hold the of the concept and the whole story and quest line is messy. They even have unfixed bug after all these years.. and bug that's intolerable like a future dialog popping up and become a spoiler before you even started the quest. (eg. the carpenter)

And this game is walking on tightrope under a fan base title of the "Dark Eye" series... so it attracts fan no matter the genre of the game and those who doesn't like chess will just hate.
For SLG lover, the implementation of the Dark Eye dice roll system (similar to D&D) is another burden as the whole chess battle become unstable over RNG stuffs, like playing chess moves and throwing dices at the same time every turn. Not a good mix if they want to really bring the true fun of SLG to their player... plus.. Dark Eye rules is based on 5 characters. So we only get 5 max all the way in the game. While other SLG provide an army of selection to fully utilize our tactical needs. So yeah, this game has it's limits and can't provide the same fun as other SLG games imo... But they did cover up with stage planning and all making it challenging and fun so it's still worth the buy... but will i call it a top SLG game? No. Because too much depends on Luck makes this more of a gambling game than strategy game. The stages are fun but the links between the stages are a mess, makes this game looks more like a "testing prototype" of a game idea.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994850102', 'num_games_owned': 1314, 'num_reviews': 195, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1613108148}

author: {'steamid': '76561198207928645', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2329, 'last_played': 1613390558}
review:
Finished the game in around 40hrs. In general, it was a nice strategy game, and i've been looking forever for a similar dungeon crawl with hexes and turn-based party game.
Pros:
- Good story. I felt engaged with the characters. Whenever I got a chance to play the game, i played 4 hours at a time (minimum) and up to 8 hours in a row. I just couldn't get myself to stop at the cliff hangers.
-Music is amazing
-Likable characters with diverse dialogue options
-Interaction with environment during battles is a plus for me

Cons:
-Combat is somewhat basic and straightforward.
-Inventory managements sucks! (wish there were filters in this clumpfest of clutter)
-A couple of quests trigger before their intended timing, so I had to google them to figure out what was going on.

In the end, BG1 is a pleasant time passer game, with good story and nice nostalgic strategic flair to it. If it is on sale, i recommend buying it.

Les villes se limitent a un √©cran ou aubergiste et marchand sont tous repr√©sent√©, j'ai l'impression de retrouver les jeux des ann√©es 80-90 qui a d√©faut de puissance palliaient par ce genre d'artifices, ou certains jeux web.

review:
[h1] ‚Ñùùïñùïûùïñùïûùïìùïñùï£ ùï•ùïôùïíùï• ùïòùïíùïûùïñ ùïóùï£ùï†ùïû ùï•ùïôùïñ ùüöùüòùüòùüòùï§ ùïîùïíùïùùïùùïñùïï ùîªùï£ùïíùïúùïñùïüùï§ùïíùïüùïò? "ùîπùïùùïíùïîùïúùïòùï¶ùïíùï£ùïïùï§" ùï£ùïñùïíùïùùïùùï™ ùï§ùï¶ùïîùïîùïñùïñùïïùï§ ùïöùïü ùïîùïíùï°ùï•ùï¶ùï£ùïöùïüùïò ùï•ùïôùïñ ùïñùï§ùï§ùïñùïüùïîùïñ ùï†ùïó ùïí ùïùùï†ùïüùïò-ùïóùï†ùï£ùïòùï†ùï•ùï•ùïñùïü ùïîùïùùïíùï§ùï§ùïöùïî. [/h1]

If there is one thing Drakensang did RIGHT was how open, deep and complex characters' customization was. The truth is, no matter how many tried to clone Drakensang (especially River of Time), nobody ever could. Your options were literally limitless; you could be a ninja who'd cast Fire Spells, a Sorceress so tanky she could take down a whole golem, a ranger who would just instantly flip out on you and swiftly brings you down with a two-melee weapons wield... Plus, the story was quite nice; it was new back then to drop the "Chosen One" bomb on your created character and have these greatly written NPCs follow you to glory. Let's talk about Blackguards now. You get the gothic feel of Drakensang games and all that jazz, except the battles do not happen in real time (as is the case in Drakensang games) but when there's a battle coming up, you're taken to the GRID TACTICAL COMBAT SCREEN. Let me tell you, you will fail, miserably and countless times... and it certainly doesn't help anyone's case that there isn't any "Speed Up" option you can activate through the menu screen... So if you lose a battle, which will probably happen many, many times, you have to sit through tedious enemy movements again... and again... and again... until somehow, the RNG God smiles upon you and you land a spell. Let's talk storyline; this is your typical "chosen hero" tale that you probably know all too well by now; the dialogue is completely voiced and voice acting is actually quite good for an Indie game. The characters are likeable, but not permanent (Try not to equip anyone with high-end gear until the last chapter). Some characters WILL die, some WILL leave and the only person you can rely on is yourself (almost like in real life). You can be one of three MAJOR classes, that are customizable in the way I stated above! You can be a ninja who casts spells, or a dual-wielding druid; it is ALL up to you. Mechanics-wise, this game is RUTHLESS but for all the wrong reasons: Spells getting miscast at 100% success rate, enemies literally cheating (some carnivorous plants will knock out your heroes despite having a resist check of 100%), the same AP system in Drakensang for leveling up applies here but not tuned and all over the place etc... The graphics are also not THAT good and the side quests do little to provide a sense of understanding for this world or how it's become this gloomy.

All in all, this is a great Tactical RPG that relies heavily on RNG sometimes. Other times it feels so unfair you think about dropping it, yet will indubitably keep playing. The bugs that plague Steam achievements for this game are ridiculous, so if you're one of those Achievement Hunters you might want to steer clear as some achievements will unlock for some players, but not all players. I guess I'm one of the lucky few who unlocked those achievements early in the game by means of outsmarting the game's code, but more on that in the discussions. It's a 7.1/10 game that all TACTICS fans will love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032729422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 4306, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4306, 'last_played': 1611657236}
review:
SHORT REVIEW.
Blackguards is a cRPG / strategic turn based combat game with the emphasis very much towards the strategic turn based combat rather than cRPG elements of the game.  Blackguards is a okay to good game that could have been an excellent game but is ruined by a few exceedingly poor decisions on the part of the developers.

1:  Linked combats with no opportunity to manually save between then.  (If you get hammered in the second fight of a set of three and you have to play the whole lot again.  The game autosaves after each section and as you got hammered in the second fight the autosave the game takes is useless to you.)
2:  Far too much use of poison.  (Seems to be used as a cheap way to increase monster damage and makes the Clarum Purum spell essential.)
3:  Some fights are just too long (1-2 hours for a single fight).

Overall definitely worth picking up despite the issues.  Pricing is pretty competitive anyway but watch out for offers.

LONG REVIEW.
Blackguards is a cRPG / strategic turn based combat game with the emphasis very much towards the strategic turn based combat rather than cRPG elements of the game.  Blackguards is a okay to good game that could have been an excellent game but is ruined by a few exceedingly poor decisions on the part of the developers

PLOT:  The plot is reasonable but is extremely linear.  The is one extremely lousy point at the end of Chapter 2 which I won't elaborate on to avoid spoilers.

COMBAT:  Combat is strategic turn based combat and is based on The Dark Eye role playing game (which I am not familiar with).  Overall the combat isn't too bad but it can be a bit slow with some fights taking too long (1-2 hours for a single fight).  There is one really bad thing about combat which is the overuse of poison.  This makes the Clarum Purum spell ‚Äúessential‚Äù.

GRAPHICS & SOUND:  Good, nothing spectacular but more than adequate for the game and quite pleasing.

REPLAY VALUE:  Virtually none.  (Plot is extremely linear.)

ISSUES AND BUGS:  The game runs ‚Äústraight out of the box‚Äù without any difficulties.  It does very occasionally ‚Äúhang‚Äù (I think twice in about 70 hrs of game play) but is pretty stable.  The same cannot be said for the steam achievements which are extremely buggy.

ACHIEVEMENTS AND TRADING CARDS:  There are achievements and trading cards for those interested but the steam achievements which are extremely buggy and tend not to trigger when they should.. There is a reason for the low completion rate on a lot of the achievements in this game, Top of the Food Chain, Iron Bladder, Hand of Boron, Three times the Fun, Traveller, Red Salamander and A True Stoerrebrand are all know to be buggy, there may be others.

VALUE FOR MONEY:  Pretty good value for money anyway as its competitively priced.  Better price if bundled with Blackguards 2 in the Blackguards Franchise Bundle.  Often gets discounted in sales so watch out for special offers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018575527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3500, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1695, 'last_played': 1614995596}
review:
I've played lots of tactical RPGs and this is one of the harder ones. I really want to like it, but there are not very many good guides for it out there and you need them if you want to play this game. Best piece of advice, don't play a mage. Maybe once you really understand the game and figure out the very particular ways you can level and still get anywhere.

I'm used to some punishing games, but this games saying it's got a flexible leveling system is bs, you have very few ways you can level your character and if you don't you'll have to restart the game or load a game from pretty far back. I don't have the patience for that anymore.

I really want to like this game, but it is just too unbalanced. It's more of a puzzle game that you have to do exactly the right character build or go back pretty far/restart the game. Good luck trying to be anything but a warrior in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198280183507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2098, 'last_played': 1610988932}
review:
This game had a lot of potential. It starts off well enough. Decent characters and voice acting. Seemed like there was some good potential story. 

 Where the games goes to heck in a hand basket is combat. The game has one of the most horrible hit calculators I've ever seen. You can have 100% chance to hit something and it just is immune. No invulnerabilities, no special abilities, no buffs. Nothing. They will just MIRACULOUSLY dodge everything. I had literally my entire team attack one generic guard NPC for 3 turns and not hit him ONCE! Every attack/spell had a 90%+ hit/cast chance and they just dodge. But a standard enemy NPC has a 90%+ hit/effect chance on your characters. I maxed out 2 characters resistances to knockdowns and negative effects, but they still had a 100% knockdown rate on ALL my characters. In 2 turns, my entire team was not only knocked down, but they were completely unable to get up. so the AI just casually walked around and slaughtered all my characters. I ran this fight dozens of times and this pattern is almost identical every time. I have all my characters target them or try to move to a different area.. ALL my attacks miss. they casually stroll across the battlefield. Knock ALL my characters.  Then just slaughter me. If this games s*** hit system didn't just destroy combat, this game would be good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971937473', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 18944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8080, 'last_played': 1613420623}
review:
Nach 134 Stunden kann ich nun ein Fazit ziehen.

Ja, das Spiel gef√§llt mir insgesamt sehr gut.
Ich freue mich auf den DLC und den zweiten Teil.
Au√üerdem werde ich noch einen Durchlauf auf hohem Schwierigkeitsgrad in Angriff nehmen,
weil ich nun wei√ü, was ich besser machen kann, und gegen Ende viele K√§mpfe doch recht leicht waren.

Ich bin riesiger Fan der Original DSA Nordland Triologie aus den 90er Jahren,
und trotzdem finde ich Blackguards gro√üartig.

Ich habe viele Dinge NICHT vermisst:
- fehlgeschlagene Steigerungen
- zerbrechende Waffen
- zerschlissene Stiefel
- zuf√§llige Krankheiten
usw.

Ich habe neben den K√§mpfen gern viel Zeit mit Party-Optimierung und Skillplanung verbracht.

Das Kampfsystem finde ich sehr vielseitig und die meisten Talente und Zauber lassen sich sinnvoll einsetzen.
Auch gibt es viele Karten, in denen man mit 08/15 Taktiken nicht weit kommt, und neu denken muss.

Das Setting und die Story finde ich eine sch√∂ne Abwechslung.
Das man in einer b√∂sen Welt, immer wieder versucht wird, selbst b√∂se zu sein, oder eben gut und daf√ºr Nachteile zu erfahren hat seinen Reiz.

Nun zu den negativen Dingen.
Den ersten unaufhaltbaren Verlust eines Partymitglieds fand ich √ºberfl√ºssig und unplausibel.
Den zweiten Verlust eines Partymitglieds habe ich auch nicht kommen sehen.
Das h√§tte man in der Geschichte deutlicher machen k√∂nnen.
Zum Gl√ºck l√§sst sich der Verlust abwenden, wenn man noch ein passendes Savegame hat, und Dinge anders entscheidet.

Die Interaktion zwischen den Partymitgliedern h√§tte deutlich ausgebaut werden k√∂nnen.
Wenn sie n√§mlich mal stattfindet, fand ich das h√∂chst unterhaltsam.

Dass Einsteiger und Casual-Gamer mit dem Spiel nicht richtig warm werden, verstehe ich.
Hier h√§tte ein ausf√ºhrliches Tutorial sicher geholfen.
Die Beschreibungstexte von Zaubern und Talenten fand ich ok, aber man muss dazu Einarbeitungswillen und vielleicht auch Vorwissen mitbringen.
Au√üerdem h√§tte man im leichten Schwierigkeitsgrad einen Reskill gestatten k√∂nnen.

Die Kritik am Kampfsystem kann ich nicht nachvollziehen.
Ja, in vielen K√§mpfen kommt man mit Standard-Taktiken durch.
Aber bei welchem Strategiespiel ist das denn nicht so?

Es bleibt gen√ºgend Abwechslung √ºbrig, wie ich finde.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044546614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 9997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7601, 'last_played': 1610239605}
review:
Hi, wenn man runden basierende Spiele mag, ist das hier eines davon. 
Das Spiel hat Tiefe und eine gute abwechslungsreiche Story. 
Gelegentlich ist es von Vorteil, h√§ufig zwischen zu Speichern.
Weil einige K√§mpfe echt herausfordernd sind und man so manches mal auf den falschen Fu√ü erwischt wird. Aber das macht es gerade spannend und der Ehrgeiz ist geweckt. 
Der Skill-Baum ist gut √ºberschaubar und man kann mit gen√ºgend Abenteuerpunkten (AP) alles m√∂gliche verbessern. 
So das man auch die K√§mpfe gut und mit einem blauen Auge bestehen kann.

Ich w√ºnsche euch viel Spa√ü damit, f√ºr Wintermonate ist es ein guter Zeitvertreib wie ich finde.

review:
Ok this game is actually fairly good but the lack of items cause a rinse a repeat feeling. 
This could have been awesome if the game had more items to switch about and constantly let you improve but you will find that you have the same items in your inventory and using the same skills each battle until you get bored. 
I didn't make it to the end myself before I started a new game but the mechanics are good just shallow on the content for characters.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063942102', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 486, 'playtime_forever': 1408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1623745520}
review:
Bought a bunch of games during the sale.  Didn't think much of this game but it has sucked me in and its the one I keep coming back to.
  It's addictive.  The overworld part has an old Sierra game vibe.   Combat is strategic like Hitman go but as an RPG.

Whole game can be played with a mouse and it's turn based strategy so the pacing is pretty relaxed. While still feels like it has a lot of depth.

Voice acting and story are good.  Characters have personality.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049823783', 'num_games_owned': 1712, 'num_reviews': 1265, 'playtime_forever': 129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 129, 'last_played': 1608690577}

author: {'steamid': '76561198352828985', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1609365127}
review: Great turn-based RPG. It's also cheap and often on bundle. So I don't really understand the negative reviews. If you find it too difficult there's an EASY option. Yes, it has a slow pace, but if you find it boring maybe it's just not your genre, or maybe a walkthrough can help (check this one out: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2077916462).

author: {'steamid': '76561198038922945', 'num_games_owned': 1137, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 3351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3349, 'last_played': 1608095336}
review:
A nice little gem of an SPRG. Gameplay is what you would expect from the screenshots. You more-or-less take the same group of people through 200~ fights, powering them up with experience points and loot. Fights are a hex-based, turn-based affair, you can gain a variety of spells and skills, each with their own uses and drawbacks. 

Character building is interesting in that it's a classless, level-less system. You gain experience points but they don't go into character levels, instead being used directly in improving stats, skills, weapon proficiencies, or gaining perks. The result is a decent amount of freedom in how you build your party. It can potentially be easy to gimp your characters, but I don't know much about The Dark Eye's ruleset and I did just fine making a magic user.

Unfortunately the party lineup is a bit strange, to keep things relatively spoiler-free, your main party will consist of your custom character, two people built for melee and two people built for magic, nobody starting specifically with bows will be in your main group unless you make your custom character that way. Due to the character system its relatively easy to pivot somebody into a ranger but it's still strange. Fortunately even with three mages you can keep things relatively varied due to the number of spells on offer.

Maps and combat scenarios are the game's strong suit. Every map is hand-designed, no random encounters/trash mobs here. There's still a fair number of straightforward "kill them all" missions, but there's also a lot of other objectives too. Some are what you would expect like defend the point and cross the map missions, some a little more unique like luring and trapping a great ape in a suspended cage. Even the more straightforward hack and slash maps tend to have things that make them stand out bit, like shooting down beehives to do more damage to the enemy, evening the odds just a bit. A few maps are duds, but the variety in maps, combined with the high difficulty, kept me on my toes for most of the game.

Now for the bad stuff, the story is poor. Proceedings are dragged out by everyone being an idiot, the main characters are less blackguards and more ruffians, and the whole thing just kinda devolves into generic save the world stuff you've seen a hundred times before. Several plot points are underexplained or just outright ignored and the game ends jarringly.

If you want exploration, or really much outside of combat and character building, then there's not much here for you. Most chapters are very linear, with only the third one giving you a decent amount of selection in sidequests. The world map is barebones and towns consist usually of one screen. Dungeons are the same, they're static screens with a few nodes that always contain fights. There's several choices during quests to make throughout the game but only a few have any real impact. If you're a loot-fiend you'll also be disappointed, there's not a lot of unique armor and weapons, and the ones that exist are very strangely placed throughout the campaign. Some characters may go for dozens of hours without an equipment upgrade.

Last, and probably my biggest problem, the combat animations are very slow and you can't speed them up in any way outside of casting a temporary buff to a character's movement range. That sounds petty, but it really is irritating when you can go for minutes without any input just because the 8 slow crocodiles on the map take their time waddling to their chosen spots. Some of the worst maps in the game are that way just because of how long they take due to the animations of (respawning) enemies.

I would recommend Blackguards in the end, it has flaws and is fairly small in scope, but what it focuses on it does well. The game is also dirt-cheap, it regularly goes on sale for under a dollar. Really, what's there to lose at that point?

author: {'steamid': '76561197998763702', 'num_games_owned': 48, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1225, 'last_played': 1574891089}
review: I jumped in with a lot of excitement and enjoyed the process of building out the protagonist. After a few failures in learning the battle system, I got a good MO and worked my way through the game. This was fun. But I stopped playing after hitting a certain point that felt a little pointless... contrived, even. It's probably a fine experience and I may pick it up again to complete the game but for now, I've moved on with other titles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019450993', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4212, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4212, 'last_played': 1607079404}
review:
I completed this game last night. Could have made a review then but will come back to why I didn't later. Blackguards is polarising, as there's certainly a lot of heart in this game, but it has issues. Early game is slow, your characters ineffectual in combat. There are several types of damage in this game and it is tough to know what the cause is when you're hitting for low numbers. Some missions are also frustrating in that you don't know if it is simply you being unlucky or not using the right approach or whether indeed your damage is too low.

I did look up guides on at least two occasions out of complete frustration. Once during the arena with the caimens where the walkthrough video was part of a series by some Czech guy and the other was when I came back to save a maiden and had to pivot what my characters could do. That's another thing. You have these points that you spend on a wide variety of things sure as passive and combat actions, some which effect the world outside of combat. The possibility of spreading a character's points too thin so that they become completely useless in certain situations is all too real. If I had not been saving up my character's points I would have never had enough to make my characters useful. Hint, it was ranged combat.

The worst thing about this game isn't any of that though. The noise for consuming a potion is the most annoying sound you will hear and not a noise anyone would be able to tolerate from any person, say, sitting next to you. The rage inducing gulping is made worse because you've just watched several turns worth of progress evaporate before your eyes and is barely more bearable making your characters use potions. The fact that you can still come back from a foe chugging does teach you to take things a bit slower, but it becomes difficult to truly gauge how strong your characters are when two fights back to back can have such large performance differences with them in how fast a battle goes. This game is also more of a puzzle game sometimes than a rpg, working out the puzzle you didn't know existed all along is interesting...sometimes.

During the midpoint of Chapter 3 I got stuck and didn't want to proceed any further. I left this game alone for nearly FIVE YEARS. Then I came back this November. I was wondering about the story, I wanted to finish it. I could have looked it all up online but decided to give this game another go and glad I did. The character banter is excellently directed and a joy to listen to. The VA's really make the characters feel real and true to themselves. Characters will have conflicting options come up and you can pick them to say something to guide a conversation with an npc. It was nice getting back into that. The playable characters are all full of personality but some performance of more important npcs come across a little flat at times. For bored shopkeepers, disinterested traders and rescued npcs this actually adds some character though and makes the more brightly directed characters stand out a bit more.

Unfortunately a particular party member doesn't seem to have had all the needed lines recorded so just used the default male voice from time to time, which is unfortunate. The further I got the more I was hearing lines I hadn't heard before, and they are infrequent enough so that you're not going to hear a character cry out or laugh at the defeat of their target every single time, which was nice.

After coming back, the further in the game I went, the more the cracks in the game begin to show. NPCs would talk about rewards but I wouldn't receive anything, extremely important information was left to be discovered in the quest log, not told to me as important exposition that the character I was just talking to should have just told me. As far as I'm aware, branching possibilities open up much, much more Chapter 5 onwards. That means you're going to either save at that point and create a whole lot more saves for each branch or replay the game...how many times? Anyway, back to tonight. Or last night, rather.

So on the final mission my party all died. 'Oh well, I wonder if there will be a losing cutscene?' I wondered. And there was.  While neat, I wasn't entirely ready to give up. Unsatisfied, I decided today to go back and do the mission again, shore up a few things and give it another go. Zurbaran got mobbed immediately before he could act and went down. *Restart*. I think it was on the fourth attempt where I managed to win the final mission, which was nice, wasn't actually that hard, but you know what? The cutscene was the same! I'm not angry, just disappointed.

This is a game where you can probably play it once for the story and if you want to see how things might have gone a little differently you can play it again. But a lot of that challenge is random chance and loading screens. While I can't speak for the source material, the world of Blackguards is very interesting and I would be interested in more, only it is a shame to read what happened with the second game. Maybe they did not know what they had. And you might not know what you have, if you don't try out this game. Blackguards as a whole is not greater than the sum of its parts, but those parts can be enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997176474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2874, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1592, 'last_played': 1607207982}
review:
Gli sviluppatori dovrebbero assumere qualche tester nabbo prima di rilasciare i giochi. 
PROBLEMI:

1. COMPRENSIONE
Il gioco √® troppo permissivo e in questo caso √® un male non fa capire al giocatore che all'inizio √® assolutamente necessario focalizzarsi in 1-2 skill al massimo e un arma.
Se iniziate questo gioco e non lo conoscete finirete per essere costretti a reiniziarlo dopo poco a causa delle scelte sbagliate nel potenziare il personaggio.

2. DIFFICOLTA
Io normalmente gioco a normale o difficile i giochi di strategia ma in questo caso l'ho abbassata a facile... l'esperienza viene diminuita parecchio con la difficolt√† e quindi anche meno skill e personalizzaizione, non preoccupatevi per la difficolt√† dei combattimenti... alcuni rimarranno difficilissimi e sarete costretti a ritentarli pi√π e pi√π volte, colpa anche delle poche spiegazioni sui nemici  e di un sistema alla D&D incentrato al 99% sulla fortuna pi√π che alla strategia.

3. BILANCIAMENTO
Come in parecchie altre recensioni che ho letto concordo sul fatto che il gioco sia parecchio sbilanciato e snervante e in alcune situzioni troppo demoralizzante peggio di dark souls.
Se avete intenzione di fare il mago sappiate che dovete specializzarvi comunque in un arma per essere un pelino utili in combattimento e non diventare semplici healer inutili quando finisce il mana, e vi consiglio di focalizzarvi solo su incantesimi utili di potenziamento/debilitanti o ad area, gli incantesimi a danno singolo sono inutili, √® meglio un arco piuttosto. 

Per trama e mappe ambientazione √® carino (classica ambientazione fantasy alla d&d) ma per le tre grandi problematiche che ha sento di doverlo sconsigliare a qualunque amico che mi chieda se vale la pena perderci tempo...  cercher√≤ di completarlo se ci riesco non so se ne valga la pena.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117464623', 'num_games_owned': 93, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 889, 'last_played': 1606687637}
review:
Dificultad: Dificil, est√° desbalanceado, obtienes pocos puntos por misi√≥n y a la mitad de la campa√±a sigues con los hechizos b√°sicos con los que empezaste, teniendo que seguir pasos muy est√°ndar y pauteados para completar las misiones, no puedes hacer grandes variaciones en las alineaciones o estrategias, por lo que se vuelve mon√≥tono. La historia avanza muy lentamente y es bastante simple y tosca. 
Para ser un juego de estrategia x turnos poca variabilidad tiene con tan pocas habilidades al nivel m√°ximo de dificultad. En nivel f√°cil por batalla te dan la cantidad de puntos que en dif√≠cil te tomar√≠an 5 batallas.
Los mapas son una mrda, las ciudades tienen poco que ofrecer en cuanto a contenido o misiones extras. No hay mazmorras o lugares por descubrir, la historia te desbloquea los puntos espec√≠ficos de combate, los que una vez completados no puedes volver a repetir.
La cantidad de armas que ofrece el juego son muy pocas y aburridas, al igual que las armaduras. No hay encantamiento de armas o raricidad de objetos.
Es una mrda en todo sentido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007532127', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 574, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 354, 'last_played': 1606277940}
review:
Just an absolute waste of time. The tutorial is worthless. You're given missions way beyond your skill set that I assume you're supposed to come back to later, but if that's the case, the game seems to be one long list of things you're supposed to do later, because I don't know which fights these incompetent idiots are supposed to be able to win.

EDIT: For the sake of thoroughness, I tried this game again. Very close to the beginning is a mission called Dwarf Games. Your opponents never miss. One has poison, the other has knockdown arrows. Both have 40+ HP and, as far as I can tell, unlimited healing potions. IF my guys manage a hit, it's for four HP at a time. They, of course hit me in the teens every time.

Uninstalled, not looking back, and not giving them any more money. Don't waste your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131484913', 'num_games_owned': 459, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 2799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2799, 'last_played': 1570225816}
review:
In short super hard even on normal difficulty but I loved every moment of it. A lot is offered here in the character creation section and maybe it can become really confusing to people who try it for the first time and have no patience to continue. 

A lot of people complained that it's a boring/difficult/soulless game but I think such whiners are better off playing CoD or some other games where they barely have anything challenging to deal with. Storywise the game is also okay nothing great but nothing bad either. But What makes the story interesting is the interactions that these party members they have amongst themselves. Really really enjoyed it(Unfortunately the same level of interaction is almost absent in Blackguards 2). 

Yes, the game can be punishingly difficult at times but to beat this game is not something which isn't possible. And right now at this price it's definitely a buy. 

I hope someday I get to see another Blackguards game in future. My fingers are just crossed.

TO DEVS: Don't give up bros. We love Blackguards. You guys did a fantastic job in developing this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072169428', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2977, 'last_played': 1605046851}
review:
Sadly i have to give the game negative review. The game starts up nicely, with good pacing and a mystery murder plot. The first fights are easy, and introduce you to the tactical part of the game. As the story progresses so do your characters, gaining AP that you can spend on many skills. Skills are generally balanced, with some unbalanced spells and abilities. Cities are very generic, and graphically speaking the game is really unimpressive -it's Unity engine after all. Music is allright, with few tracks being really good, like the main theme. The gameplay loop consists of battles->loot and money->buy better armor, find unique weapons->quest->repeat again. At 2/3 of the game i already become bored, because the battles were often similar, similar enemies and you basically max your abilities and spells. So you repeat the same tactics over and over again.This is main reason why i gave negative review -i was forcing myself to end the game, because of this drag. The plot has holes everywhere, just to push the narrative, often with 180 turn.  Voice acting is good, for this kind of budget game. 
Speaking of running the game -the game freezes constantly, unless you add "-d3d9 -force-gfx-direct" to startup options. And then it stutters when cutscenes appear, or enemies. 

Overall it's a 6/10 maybe 6+ game, it's decent but nothing special. If you are bored, give this one a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024707408', 'num_games_owned': 2339, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 2131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2131, 'last_played': 1602656559}
review: I have just finished Blackguards and I have to say that I have never been so flabbergasted by a game getting Mixed rating on Steam. This is probably one of the best tactical RPGs I have ever played, and I am a sucker for turn-based combat. When the developers advertise that there are more than 180 battlegrounds, those are not just empty words. Literally every single fight in the game is handcrafted and to some extend different from the others, including vast diversity of objectives (not just 'slay all the baddies'), twists related to the environment and situations where you have to adapt your strategy to the circumstances. Difficulty levels of this game are peculiar and need to be explained in detail. The major (if not only) difference between difficulty levels is that the higher the difficulty, the less experience points you get. Min-maxing is not my thing, and after realizing I made some questionable choices of skills to upgrade, I downgraded the difficulty to easy - and I recommend to do it if you are not a hardcore gamer. This way, you will not break your characters by poor leveling choices as there are experience points abound. The reason why this is important is that the first few hours are pretty much for experimenting with the character development system, which is quite complex, even overwhelming at first. The curiosity about it is the fact that you have the same XP pool for increasing base values, talents, spells and special skills, so it is quite easy for it to get overwhelming. What I love about this game is that as I progressed, I understood the upgrades better and better, until I was fully comfortable that I knew what I was doing. So if you are repulsed by the character development screen in the beginning, just keep with it - it will hopefully grow on you as it grew on me. Moreover, the characters are likable, the Dark Eye setting (dark fantasy) is a nice touch, there is good variety to inventory and generally I have zero complaints to make about this game. Some folk may probably not like the fact that there is no open world to roam freely. You move between battles on overhead map which has very little visual representation of what's going on. The only thing besides battlegrounds are towns and cities, all of which are static screens with interactive characters and spots - I did not mind that at all. All in all, if you like turn based combat, you owe it to yourself to at least try out Blackguards for a few hours - a first glance is not enough to let this game really shine.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968658621', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 447, 'playtime_forever': 11835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7287, 'last_played': 1602220196}
review:
Ignore my playtime.  Hours are inflated because I leave the game running in the background.  (I suspect that I'm 3/5 or 4/5 of the way through the game at the time of review).

Tactical turn-based, squad-based combat with big d&d vibes.  Plenty of skill points to allocate, which you'll accumulate after a few fights.  Good atmosphere, amusing dialogue.

Very relaxing yet absorbing to play.  Wholly recommend.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198201620245', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 608, 'playtime_forever': 148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 148, 'last_played': 1601200344}
review:
Devs with small brains make games with small fonts.
This is painfully legible, in any screen resolution.

Character creation is fine, although half the necessary info will come out later, in tutorial windows (in tiny fonts.)

You can save/load manually, whenever you find an opening to do so. Just be patient if you want to reload a fight, because you'll have to fast-click dozens of (small font) lines of dialogue that you don't care for before you regain a modicum of control. What? You would like to save just after a fight, before the branching dialogue in small fonts that ensues? Bwah ah ah!

Freedom is lacking at every step after the character creation (in small and often red fonts.) That the (particularly stupid) storyline holds you by the hand might be fair enough, but the tactical maps also tell you (in small fonts) what their only path to victory is. So long for tactics.
You also have local maps, and then a world map. On all of these, all you can (and must) do is click on the unique next location you can reach. For a boring dialogue or a boring battle.
I don't bloody care if the game will get better in 2 hours, I'm already 2 hours in and I'm bloody bored.

Mechanics are of the same calibre: The game gave me a mage companion, with pretty much the same spells as I. Including a fireball. Never seen such a lame fireball in my life. First you need to correctly align a caster to the point of impact, because the spell is highly restrictive on its destination. Then you watch casting failure upon casting failure, while your mana drops (and it ain't a cheap spell.) Finally, the dynamic duo lands one (by this time the weaponless unique fighter has already fell at least four opponents.) Just one, and the mana of both mages is now depleted. And you read the damage the fireball causes, and you start crying.

Well, what can you expect from a text-heavy software that doesn't grasp the notion of readability?

At least the voicing is very good. They should have left the actors design the game as well...

author: {'steamid': '76561198091118696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 394, 'last_played': 1638079726}
review: This is a great game! Not sure why it received so many negative reviews and it plays like a rpg to me which is basically the only type of game i play.  There were some areas where I was getting randomly killed by falling objects etc. but the guide  gave me clues to get through those areas, I have had to repeat a fight or two so far so you should save before fights.  Some of the games mechanics I really don't get ( I'm one of those players who bought the first nintendo for my kids) so i'm probably not playing it optimally, but i am enjoying it and I would definitely recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113293081', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 139, 'last_played': 1600557899}
review:
Alors ! .... je n'ai que 2,3 heures de jeu et √ßa ne changera plus. ah non pas de soucis le jeu fonctionne .... euh enfin .... il se lance et je peux jouer mais c'est de la daube. du coup on peut se poser des questions. je n'ai pas pour habitude d'√©valuer un jeu auquel je n'ai pas jou√© longtemps mais clairement celui ci m√©rite que je me retrousse les manches et fasse craquer mes doigts histoire de lui coller une bonne tartine dans sa face. je vais noter ce que j'ai vu jusqu'ici points par points :

1) commen√ßons par le "positif", les graphismes et la musique (en tout cas de ce que j'ai entendu en deux heures) c'est correct pas dingue mais juste correct. √ßa essaye de se donner une ambiance mais bon √ßa r√©ussit pas vraiment (apr√®s j'ai deux heures de jeu donc bon). bref j'ai trouv√© √ßa plut√¥t insipide, je veux bien que ce soit "m√©di√©val fantastique" et "sombre"  mais les ma√Ætres de la dark fantasy comme Moorcock n'h√©sitent pas a peindre leur univers de mille couleurs chatoyantes, ici on tombe juste dans le clich√© des paysages gris avec des coupe-jarrets a chaque coin de rue. la d√©finition m√™me d'insipide. et franchement les environnements se ressemblent tous, les villes sont vides a part un ou deux pnj qui une fois leur dialogue √©puis√© ne servent plus que de d√©cor (bien pi√®tre d'ailleurs). euh .... zut c'√©tait cens√© √™tre un point positif pour le jeu ahah ...

2) L'histoire : .......... aaaaaahhh ....... y'en a une ? il semblerait mais le d√©but est tellement nul .... en gros votre personnage est un (ou une) garde et ami(e) de la fille d'un mage important et noble √©galement, un baron, et l'intro c'est litt√©ralement la fille du mage qui se fait manger le bide par un loup et vous qui arrivez (trop tard) pour la sauver. et l√† dessus un de vos amis communs a vous et la fille du baron (oui pas un ami du loup) arrive, vous voit pr√®s du corps de la fille et du loup et en conclut que vous etes coupable, vous fait enfermer et torturer pour avouer un nom (hein ?) et se tire et au final un nain compl√®tement au pif vous d√©livre (oui un nain prisonnier √©vad√©) et vous d√©livrez aussi un mage et vous vous barrez de l√† pour comprendre ce qu'il s'est pass√© eeeet vos deux joyeux loustics que nous appelleront plot twist et deus ex d√©cident de rester avec vous parceque .... pourquoi d√©j√† ? ah oui ! parceque ! =\_(o v o)_/= aucune raison ahah.

3) le gameplay : fade, comme l'univers et ses personnages. pourtant j'adore les jeux de r√¥le papier et la gestion des stats, des √©quipements, les jets de d√©s hasardeux etc etc, oui mais l√† non c'est vraiment TROP random ! je m'explique ! vous ous souvenez du magicien qu'on a lib√©r√© ? ouiiii Deus Ex c'est bien √ßa vous avez suivi ! ahah bha figurez vous que non content d'avoir les caract√©ristiques habituelles des mages, a savoir peu de vie et quasi aucune comp√©tence d'arme, le fameux loustic se permet le luxe de rater ses sorts au moins la moiti√© du temps ahah .... y compris son sort de soin ! comment on peut rater un heal ?!?!? comment √ßa se passe ? ton alli√© est trop fier et il esquive ton sort en pr√©textant qu'il peut se soigner tout seul ? alors d√©j√† un mage qui rate des sorts offensifs c'est pas jojo mais si en plus il rate aussi ses sorts sur des alli√©s ! et voyez le probl√®me du mage, bha mettez le aussi sur les autres personnages (TOUS) m√™me les ennemis, tout rate la moiti√© du temps ce qui donne de beaux petits combats d'autiste qui dure dix plombes. par contre des fois on a des critiques aberrants genre d√©g√¢ts de base a 5 et critique a 22 ? .... c'est juste mal √©quilibr√©. pareil au d√©but la moindre pi√®ce d'√©quipement co√ªte hyper cher, et tout est identique dans les magasins ou presque. 

4) les tutoriels : oui c'est pas habituel d'en parler mais l√† c'est n√©cessaire ! vous avez 50 choses par page mais si 5 vous sont expliqu√©es sur les 50 vous serez d√©j√† bien content, les comp√©tences ne sont pas claires on sait pas quoi faire de tout √ßa ni quelle importance a quoi. b√¢cl√©.

En r√©sum√© c'est naze. vraiment. si vous aimez ce qui a de la profondeur et/ou ne serais-ce qu'un brin d'originalit√© .... bha √©vitez ce titre .... ou alors je me plante et l'ambiance d√©colle plus tard mais faudrait supporter un d√©but insipide avec un gameplay fini a la truelle et des personnages tellement non charismatiques qu'une hu√Ætre asthmatique serait plus fun a jouer. ah euh .... j'ai pas l'impression qu'il y ait de "choix" non plus dans la trame sc√©naristique, y'a des options de dialogue mais √ßa n'a l'air d'avoir aucun impact donc bon si vous aimez vivre VOTRE aventure, allez voir ailleurs. des bisous n'achetez pas le jeu y'en a sans doute des mieux comme pillars of eternity (bon ok pillars c'est pas du tactique au tour par tour mais c'est mieux foutu quand m√™me)

review:
The game looks somewhat fun but he constantly freezes, requiring restarting the computer (or end task if not in full screen mode). I found forum posts online from like 2015 in which people complained about the problem and were asked to send crash reports by the devs (which acknowledged it as a known issue). They still  didn't fix it apparently and all the fixes suggested by users in these forums didn't work either.
I can't recommend that experience

author: {'steamid': '76561198322698374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3455, 'last_played': 1600588159}
review:
It's a good game, love it or hate it vibes

+ Hybrid mage/warrior or mage/archer, totally viable (much useful than pure imo)
+ Characters that are not those unrealistic heroes that are fed on good alone

+/- Character Optimization- Can't have it all (thankfully), specialize in less than 3 things or risk 60% chance of hitting anywhere
+/- All are unique battles/ no grinding- You can't just go to a boring grindfest to overpower everything
+/- Managing resources- can't make everyone hold the best weapons if it's only 1 per type
+/- Mages are not overpowered(ish)- Buffs/debuffs are strong but damage spells are meh

- Some battle maps take too long to finish (1-2 hours)
- Bugs, had to restart a really good fight
- Very dependent on RNG

author: {'steamid': '76561198064989401', 'num_games_owned': 606, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 2773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2619, 'last_played': 1596042998}
review:
It might seem strange to not recommend a game I've played for 40+ hours but seriously, stay away. It's incredibly slow, grindy, full of inconsistencies, doesn't seem to have been bug tested and has a terrible inventory system. That's not touching on the fact that it's a game of *incredibly* small numbers. There's absolutely no fun to be had in a RPG that doesn't allow significant progression of your character.

The battle system isn't too bad but the fights themselves, while starting out fairly fun, become nothing but frustrating and monotonous. Rather than add new fight mechanics, the developers have come up with the oh-so-wonderful and unique ideas such as infinite monsters, tasking you to make your way to one side of a map on one hex long "corridors" with said infinite monster spawning in the way every turn.

I haven't even touched on the interactive parts of the battle maps; objects that you can only push one way, traps that don't have any effect on enemies, the occasional trap that doesn't appear for you despite having max perception. The list goes on but frankly, I'm already drained from making a final push towards the end of the game. I decided to take a break and write a review after running into yet another range-or-die or fight towards the end of the game. Seriously, there are no new enemies, just ever increasing numbers of crossbowmen/archers.

The story is fairly interesting at points. In fact, it's the only reason I've clocked 40+ hours. It's a classic good vs evil fantasy story, set in a grimdark world with - some, not all - morally grey characters.

I know some gamers like to spend hours min/maxing, grinding out even the tiniest character improvements and to them I say there are far, far more rewarding games to play if that's what you're into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036975156', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1424, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 544, 'last_played': 1687380524}
review:
It's a good game but looks can decive you, it is NOT an RPG, and it is NOT a game for you if you want quick fun or jump straight in to the things. Game starts proprerly in chapter 3(7-8h in game), till there it is fairy linear experience and propper storyline don't start till somwere around end of chapter 2 (around 5h in game). If i would need to describe what a game plays like it is something like mix of cRPG, X-Com and battles from Heroes M&M 3. controls in battles are to be honset pretty bad but quick tab save's a lot of pain since digging thro UI to use certain attack or spell is painfull, but you can put it at quick tab, wich i strongly suggest since it speed's up everything by a lot and makes game more enjoyable. Since i mostly played this game offline on my laptop (its great for short sessions of 20-45min) the biggest problem with the game and why it have mixed revievs is, first - Act 1 and half of Act 2 nothing rly happens and it is pretty lenghtly 5-7h depends how well you will do, second - it's overwellming and very hard to grasp and do wellat first conntact, third - it is more like X-Com in terms of fights than any turn based RPG which makes ppl dissapointed in what they expect and what they get.As for a good things, game have branching story and oportunity to end quests in diffrent ways and sometimes changing outcome in story depending if you do some sidequests or not (there is even one side quest that depending if you do it or not you'll end up with diffrent companion), game can feel pretty unfair sometimes, but changeing strategy can change brick wall to a piece of cake, but probably the biggest thing is environment, dropping chandoilers on enemies, using loud spells to drop stalagmites(or stalactytes, i never knew which is which), setting on fire clumps of dried grass enemy is standing in, looring enemies in to a puddles of mud so they'll slip and be exposed to attacks (everything have 100% chance of hitting when enemy is stunned or on the ground) or even fighting wih a behemoth of an enemy for a side quest that is way overlevel than you and defiting him by exploding pockets of gas in the swamp with fire arrows and fireballs. And this is just a tip of an iceberg. To sum things up, if youre looking for an turn based RPG... don't bother, this is not game for you, if you want a tactical game based in fantasy world with makeing your on character and in fantasy world but youre not a masochist then you'll like this game, but beware, game starts in chapter 3 so you'll need to slog on to it and then game rly opens up.

(sorry for spelling errors, i'm not a native speaker)

author: {'steamid': '76561198006493602', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4013, 'last_played': 1593639671}
review:
tl;dr
I'd recommend it only for enthusiasts, hardcore TBS gamer and DSA player or a mix thereof.
--------------------------------------
General:

Game is obviously based on the DSA rulesystem, which can be quite confusing, if you have no prior knowledge of it.
Sadly, it also lacks certain explanations, of how your attributes, skills & talents all intertwine. Several checks are not displayed and are done in the background - something a roleplayer does not necessary like.
On top of it, a few rules are implemented but now shown, like the scaling weapon-damage modifier with its strength-bonus, or are otherwise simplified for the games' purpose.
Can be checked with the weapon rulebook or other sources, though - as they are standardized.

Story:
I wonder ... have beaten the game now 2times (DVD + steam) and the story is definitely not the main selling point; you could as well place a lil' pony as quest giver and it wouldn't bother me.
(there is a story present, but often felt as confusing as the implemented crippled rules.)

Gameplay:
turn 1:
*casts corpofrigo @98%* - fizzles
- other party members move
- enemy has successfully poisoned your whole party
turn 2:
*casts mass Klarum Purum* - yay
- other party member miss their 94% to-hit roll
turn 3:
- everyone gets poisoned again
- your fighter could not save the 2 wounds and is now an easy-to-hit target
turn 4:
you decided, it would be probably just better to restart the whole friggin' fight
........
In a nutshell :P

On top of it, the difficult curve is a strange one, and obviously a reason, that not more than 18% of _all_ player have even advanced to chapter III. Because the game is so unfair (*chuckles*), that it presents you one of the toughest and most ridiculous challenges right off the bat in chapter II. One word or rather 2: Louse Queen! You'll hate her like nothing else....

The latter is by far the most annoying and RNG dependent fight in the whole game and even harder than the final fight.
This was also the one time my game crashed or I had to force a crash, because my mage was locked in his action-move and I could not advance - needless to say; I'd have won that battle in 2 turns~. Another 10 battle-restarts later the queen is dead - long live the king!
Good thing about that fight, it's needed to jump into act III - where the 'real' game begins, like 70% of it. Kinda reminded me of vanilla WoW and Naxxramas. Louse (lice? whatever)-queen == Patchwork.

Itemization:
Nothing you need to buy, but a few items to complete the set-bonus - everything else should be poured into potions & poisons! Poison is the KotH in this game - literally. Some of the 'unfair' combat encounter can be done in 1-2 turns just by using poisons....it reads: duration - whole fight; effect: knockdown (!). These is one of the rarer ones and maybe only 8 items of it exist.
Most armor & weapons will be a loot option otherwise.


The game rewards the patient ones, while it punishes the others! It's not a game, where you will deal uttermost ridiculous amounts of damage, but rather cripple and weaken your enemy or poison them ^.^
Reading-skills might be required for some skills & talents to understand, what exactly they do.

Average completionist time is around 40hours with every quest done on normal gameplay. Sadly a few achievements are still bugged...but better them, than either the act III main plot or a rather significant important sidequest in the same chapter for one of the most powerful weapons ingame.
That happened prior to patch 1.3 several times and forced me to reboot the campaign occasional ^^

Now that I spent quite a few time writing this, it's safe to assume, that I actually like the game, given 2 finished runs as well :>

6.5/10

[DSA / Dark Eye basic knowledge really helps to turn the game from a grind-experience into an actual gaming experience. Wish the developer would have paid more attention on the 'Drakensang' release and how it is done properly.
With a better story and less nonsensical simplified rules it would be higher rated.

Oh, and the bloom-effect; really?]

One shall not wound or poison a skeleton! Never ever
At least they messed up their weapon damage formula to such extent, that the magical attribute on a weapon nullifies it main-source of damage and converts it into a complete new one. Oi, look - it's a legendary speer....*uhm* why does it not do piercing damage? - because the game decided it should do magical damage instead, which 98% of all enemies have 0% resistance against. (that could serve as a hint =^.^=)

Did I mentioned poisons?

review:
I mostly play rpgs for the story but this game is geared towards the strategy minded, pain loving crowd. I want to see where the story goes but my head hurts too much from banging it against the brick wall of combat on easy mode. This game really needs a story mode for people who just want to enjoy an interactive story and sip lemonade while propping their feet up on squishy pillows.

Ditto what others have said about great voice acting, the dialogue in general is smooth like butter on hot pancakes.
