author: {'steamid': '76561198119272484', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 1837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1837, 'last_played': 1592675086}
review:
[h1]Premessa[/h1]
Il titolo, sviluppato e pubblicato da Daedalic Entertainment, √® un gdr strategico a turni basato sul gioco da tavolo tedesco ‚ÄúThe Dark Eye‚Äù, che in Germania ha superato in vendite D&D.
[h1]Storia[/h1]
Il nostro personaggi sar√† accusato dell‚Äôomicidio di una principessa e per tale ragione verr√† imprigionato. Consapevole della sua innocenza decide di fuggire insieme ad altri due prigionieri. Da qui si dipaneranno vicende che lo coinvolgeranno in cose pi√π grandi di lui.
La storia non brilla per originalit√† ed i personaggi seppur alcuni siano ben caratterizzati, non sono mai troppo approfonditi. La trama √® abbastanza lineare e concede solo alcune deviazioni per delle missioni secondarie. L‚Äôambientazione fantasy √® propria di ‚ÄúThe Dark Eye‚Äù.
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Le battaglie si svolgono su griglie esagonali di mappe relativamente piccole. Seguono le regole del gioco di ruolo da tavolo e dunque tutte le azioni(in base alle statistiche del personaggio) avranno una certa percentuale di riuscita, come in un lancio di dadi, e ci si muove in turni basati sull‚Äôiniziativa. Ogni personaggio ha a disposizione le stesse finestre di abilit√†, capacit√† e magie degli altri personaggi. Star√† al giocatore creare una squadra equilibrata distribuendo i punti abilit√† necessari allo sblocco di una determinata abilit√†, capacit√†, magia o semplicemente usarli per aumentare le statistiche base. Ogni personaggio inoltre √® interamente modificabile nell‚Äôequipaggiamento, non molto diversificato, che rende disponibili una serie di bonus se si indossano set di armature completi. Pi√π varie le armi che avranno anche loro diverse peculiarit√†. E‚Äô possibile interagire con elementi della mappa che cambiano l‚Äôambiente di gioco, ma sono elementi raramente opzionali e messi a disposizione perch√® studiati appositamente per la battaglia che si svolge. Il livello di difficolt√† √® alto, ed √® facile morire e dover riprovare un combattimento cambiando tattiche, tuttavia questa difficolt√† √® pi√π sintomo di una mal gestione della stessa pi√π che di una oculata scelta di nemici e elementi ambientali. Nel mondo di gioco ci si sposta in una mappa di luogo in luogo con uno spostamento rapido, dove √® possibile interagire con personaggi e intraprendere quest secondarie, fare acquisti o riposare. Sono disponibili scelte multiple nei dialoghi che tuttavia cambiano poco e niente gli avvenimenti se non lo sviluppo di determinate scene e determinate secondarie, ma senza mai alterare la trama principale. Solo alcune decisioni verso la fine del gioco definiscono il finale.
[h1]Comparto Tecnico[/h1]
Graficamente modelli poligonali, texture ed effetti sono sotto la media. La personalizzazione del personaggio √® estremamente povera e limitata. La gestione della telecamera poteva essere fatta meglio, risultando fastidiosa e poco d‚Äôaiuto in determinate mappe. Il comparto audio rimane anonimo nonostante le melodie di stampo fantasy accompagnino decentemente l‚Äôavventura.
[h1]Conclusione[/h1]
Sia dal punto di vista narrativo che tecnico il titolo pecca di qualit√†. Trama abbastanza lineare e senza particolare pathos mista ad un comparto grafico deludente e una colonna sonora per nulla incisiva. Dal lato del gameplay invece vi √® un chiaro impegno nel rendere profondo uno strategico a turni con tante abilit√†, capacit√† e magie disponibili per i personaggi nonch√© un uso interessante dell‚Äôambiente a favore del giocatore. Tuttavia la difficolt√† √® mal gestita risultando spesso in combattimenti frustranti dettati pi√π dalla fortuna del lancio di dadi che dalla tattica. Ci√≤ si riassume in un titolo mediocre che tuttavia vale la pena provare se amanti del genere e se si perdonano certe pecche.
[h1]Voto[/h1]
[b]66/100[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198411209811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 391, 'last_played': 1592676339}
review:
I am 6 hours into the game and I have to say I am enjoying it very much. What I like the most is that this game is straight to the point: combat. Sweet turn-based combat on a grid; no running around town like a headless chicken looking for/talking to NPC's, no reading walls of text and lore. You have a world map where you travel from one location to another by one click. In some locations another smaller dungeon map (a la Darkest Dungeon) pops up and you can decide which room to visit next.

A few short cut-scenes here and there with voice acted character interaction. The story is basically on autopilot but you sometimes are presented with choices.

So if you are like me, not much time to play games because of work and/or family and just want to enjoy some quality turn based combat with some light story interspersed this game is a good choice.

Inventory management is okay, you are given some loot after battles. You are not flooded with cheap, useless garbage though. Most of the stuff you get is useful and what you don't need can be sold in the next town for a pretty decent price so that you can fill up on provisions and potions.

Can be played with mouse only. The only key on the keyboard you might need is 'V' to highlight interactive object on the battlefield. You can't customise buttons in the game but you can do what I did: I just remapped 'V' to one of my thumb buttons on my mouse and I don't even need to touch the keyboard when playing.

---

12 hours in, changing it to not recommend: playing on normal, the game is impossible, can't even make a dent in enemies, poorly balanced pure frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116211741', 'num_games_owned': 920, 'num_reviews': 220, 'playtime_forever': 1822, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1822, 'last_played': 1592084717}
review:
Blackguards is a tactical RPG in a dark fantasy setting.

I mostly enjoyed my time with Blackguards. The aesthetics of the game are pretty cool!  They also did a good job in varying battles.  One of the high points of the game is how battlefields all have things going on with them beyond being just a normal grid.  There is a surprising variety of traps, pressure plates, environmental hazards, things falling from the sky, etc.

Ultimately, though, I don‚Äôt recommend the game.  Some of the battles get unnecessarily draggy.  There are a fair number of battles where the objective is to move your entire team from point A to point B.  In these battles, they give you extremely narrow corridors and respawning enemies, which tend to clump in front of you.  One of these battles takes place in a literal maze and uses extremely tedious pressure pads with gates that open and shut ‚Äì not well suited to a combat SRPG.

Another questionable decision was the weight-based inventory system that limits the player from collecting too many weapons or armor.  It did not add to the game and introduced an element of unnecessary micromanagement.  I also found the equipment stats to be confusing ‚Äì it is unclear which armor is superior, and there‚Äôs not a whole lot of selections for mages, who are mostly in leather for the whole game.

Finally, as with other games from this publisher, there are bugs.  A game breaking bug in chapter 3 prevented a key NPC from giving me a quest needed to advance.  I had to reload an old save a replay a section of the game.  Also, several of the achievements are broken.

Finally, after all of that‚Ä¶ despite a strong start, the story didn‚Äôt really go anywhere satisfying, in the end.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028749362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 72, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1428861355}
review:
I enjoyed the hex-based tactical gameplay in the King's Bounty games and bought Blackguards in a Steam sale as I enjoy CRPGs and thought this would be more of the same. It uses the Dark Eye RPG rules in the game, the same as some previous CRPGs like Drakensang and the Arkania series. I've spent around 20 or 30 hours playing the game so far, and this review is based on my impressions while playing the first quarter or so of the game.

Pros:
- Storyline seems quite interesting. After a rather short, strange, surreal intro, you find yourself trying to escape from prison. At that point, you have no idea what is actually going on in the game, but later flashback sequences start to fill in the blanks for you, and this keeps you going (despite the game's other shortcomings) as you strive to find out more about the game's background story.
- Some decent voice acting and funny moments in the game's dialogue. Love the dwarf Naurim!

Cons:
- The game mechanics. This game uses the ridiculously complicated Dark Eye RPG rules, which I'm not going to go into here. Suffice to say that most actions in the game involve a check against the relevant attributes of the character performing the action to determine whether it succeeds or not. Spells, for example, are not cast automatically, but are subject to this check. This system seems unfairly biased towards your enemies, who seem to land melee hits and cast spells in combat successfully way more often than what your characters do. Enemies also seem to land critical hits more often too. A lot of the fights are set up to be played a certain way and the game punishes you if you don't toe the line. It punishes you anyway as the random number rolls are almost never in your favour though.
- Lack of clarity. For example, nowhere does it seem to show you what the chances are of some of your talents (like treating wounds or setting traps) succeeding or not. If you use poison on your equipped weapon before a battle, it doesn't show anywhere that your weapon has actually been poisoned. if you have a high strength score, it doesn't indicate what difference this makes to your weapon damage.
- Clunky and tedious gameplay. You can't use a healing potion, mana potion, trap, or poison in battle unless these have been added to your belt, which, depending on the belt's quality, can only hold 1 to 4 of these items. You can't use anything that still happens to be in your backpack during a battle, so if you forgot to change the contents of your belt slots, tough luck. You have 3 different weapon sets you can change between during a battle, but it takes a whole action to change your weapon set, and if you want to switch to a weapon currently in your backpack instead, too bad.
- The sheer stinginess of the game. It may improve later on, but most of the early part of the game, you find yourself using whatever you salvaged from the prison you escaped from as most other gear is way too expensive. Merchants only sell a handful of different (and expensive) items so it can be difficult to equip your characters with decent gear. Combats reward you usually with a small amount (25 or 50) adventure points which you use to improve your characters' skills and attributes. You get a piss-poor amount of treasure from a typical combat. For example, early in the game, you go off scavenging on some old battlefield for armour and weapons, and promptly get attacked by 4 or 5 bandits in leather armour, 2 of which are using bows. At the end of the fight, you get a bastard sword and a couple of other small items. Yippee. What happened to all the gear the bandits were carrying?
- Exploration sucks. Your main map is an overland map which you use to travel to various towns and villages there. Each town has a single screen which shows the various people (blacksmith, healer, merchant, trainer, quest giver etc) which you can click on to access. That's it. Dungeons consist of a simple line map with a number of different locations which you can click on to go to instantly, and this takes you straight to a battle map where you slog through another (usually tedious) battle.

In concluding, I'm giving this game 5/10 as it has its good moments, but is let down mainly by the utterly frustrating combat mechanics, overall difficulty level, lack of equipment, and general lack of any fun factor. Unless you're a hardcore Dark Eye RPG fan who doesn't mind constantly reloading saved games to get through some of the combats, I'd advise looking elsewhere for a decent CRPG in this price range.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992079096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1825, 'last_played': 1591668820}
review:
Enough is enough...
This game has nothing to do with tactics. Every battle is basically a puzzle you need to figure out.
I was playing on hardest difficulty, and I was screwed too many times.
I hoped for the better, spent hours to overcome stupid situations, because I like characters and story.
And here I am, can't complete this game, because its just unfair and crazy. I have no patience anymore nor the desire to reload the same battle hundreds of times.
Just skip it, or play on easy to enjoy characters and story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021742016', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 617, 'last_played': 1592674482}
review:
I've had this game for some time in my collection but never actually gave it a go. It is a decent turn-based RPG/Strategy, based on the Dark Eye world (pen & paper RPG).

Graphics 6/10

Nothing particularly exciting, functional, they could definitely have done a lot more with them, even if the game is now six years old.

Sound 7/10

I think the best part of the game, decent background music and also good voice acting! 

Gameplay 6/10

It takes a bit of time to get into the game, but it does feel rewarding after a while.  The game mechanics are not particularly well explained and sometimes that can cause a bit of frustration. The biggest issue, something that others have mentioned is the continuous misses or the spells fizzing out several times in a row, even if the chance of success if very high.

Story 7/10

The story is good, it gives you a good understanding of the plot, and makes effective usage of the voice acting in the game.

Generally speaking, I would recommend the game, if you are a fan of the RPG universe. If not, there are other genre games that are probably better.

Edit: There seems to be an issue with the game saves. Basically while I save the game at a particular stage (for example, after completing the third act), the next day those saves load progress from much earlier in the game (in my example, before completing the third act). This so far has happened twice. I made sure that I have control of the folder the game saves (admin rights), and before I exit the game, I autosave and also save on a separate file.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159033138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4095, 'last_played': 1591379665}
review:
Great game and highly recomended for RPG fans!

*No spoilers here =)

The plot is cool and the game is challenging. It takes a little time to understand the characters sheet and know what skills are worth or not, but you can only trully understand its complexity at almost half the game so read some tutorials first if you don't want to waste time. With that said, probably the hardest part is to creat a balanced party that can witstand all kinds of troubles. You can clearly see some D&D roots, specially in the games atmosphere, but he system itself is quite diffent and this is not a negative point.

The game presents  lots of challenges, escpecially in battles, some moral decisions and choices that influence the outcome of events.

Graphics are quite fine, not super refined, yet you can see that the authors have put some effort on it. The audio creates a good atmosphere for the game and i did not found any glitches or bugs on my run, altough some users on forums warn about some bugs, but i'm not sure on which versions and if they're all fixed.

I'm eager to play the sequel game Blackguards 2 and enjoy more of that nostalgic D&D universe that is hard to find around these days!

GL & HF!

author: {'steamid': '76561198133337109', 'num_games_owned': 49, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3418, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2463, 'last_played': 1590528801}
review:
I had a really hard time deciding wether I'd give this game a thumps up or not. The game is set in the Dark Eye Universe and because I'm a huge fan of that franchise and enjoyed the game at some point, I'll give it a thumps up.

How can I summarize this game? In one word; UNFAIR. Or at least unreasonable.

While the game might look like a tactical turn based RPG, it really is just luck. You can be the best tactician in the world and would still have a very hard time playing it. A lot of the enemies have unreasonable resistances, some can only be fought with ranged fighters, some are immune to any type of magic etc. So, yes, you can skill your character whatever you want but you'll have to follow a specific build sooner or later if you actually want to win (I had to find that out the hard way). 

Another thing is the 'chance to hit', which already has been criticized in other reviews. The game might tell you, you have a 95% chance to hit. Sounds good, right? But the 5% chance to miss are still there and in a lot of the time you WILL miss, no matter how high the percentage is. And yes, this is how random values work, but in a game like that, it just made the whole character leveling system gratuitous and the fights unnecessarily frustrating.

Also, the second chapter was very annoying, hard and boring AND will take your probably best teammate away from you. At that part I was really close to quitting the game but decided to push through. One last thing is the soundtrack that is actually good but only consists of 5 tracks or so, so it starts haunting you after some time.

So what are the good things? First things first; the setting. For every fan of the Dark Eye franchise this is a must try as it  is really lore friendly in my opinion. I, for myself, also liked the story. It drew me in from the first second on. But if you'll like the story or not depends on your taste. 
The dialogue was also good and very funny some times. I played it in German and a lot of the voice lines were perfectly done, by even some of my favorite voice actors. Other actors on the other hand did a really poor job that made some serious scenes unbearable.

Your group members are more or less interesting rather than original. They mostly consist of the average fantasy archetype. Angry/greedy dwarf, flirtatious/womanizer spy, snarky witch etc. Still, listening to their dialogues can be fun (but at times I had the feeling the writers tried too hard).

So, should you buy this game? Yes, but only if it's on a discount and you like games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034510163', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 3052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1204, 'last_played': 1601038508}
review:
Not a RPG, nor a strategy game, but a puzzle game with plenty of random pitfalls without counterplay. Feels like a mobile game. Move room, fight. Move room, fight. Lots of Power Word: Quickload required & expected by the dev. For instance, placement of traps and damage immunities are only learned by trial & error, and a single missed round can swing the fight.

Great voice acting, decent sound design and music.

Horribly overblown bloom effect, that cannot be toggled on its own, rather have to disable all post-processing, which turns the world very drab.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069402855', 'num_games_owned': 1106, 'num_reviews': 220, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 913, 'last_played': 1588884652}
review:
It had such good reviews. Shame it is shit. Characters are uninteresting and annoying, boring story, confusing or even downright cryptic controls especially with interactive items (why does the default point of interaction with a stack of barrels cause them to fall ON TOP of my character instead of to the side or in the opposite direction like a normal person would push them. Does the character pull the barrels towards them knowing they'll be crushed. Why? Because the game just wants to punish you for interacting with things.), annoying leveling system which requires a huge amount of time and effort just be able to reliably use one spell or skill without fail, weird glitch that causes the game to freeze during load screens and guess what? The game is filled with load screens. Obviously when loading a game, restarting a battle, going to a new town, area, everything! I don't know what causes this glitch, but the game will randomly lock up during load screens. Locks up the computer too when it happens so I can't even ctrl+alt+del out of it or close it with the task manager.

Man it has been ages since the last time I played a game that actually managed to wreck my whole computer when I played it but here it is. You got that going for your Blackguards. I have a personal agreement with myself where I don't have to feel bad cheating a game that is a broken pos. A game that is both not fun to play and breaks my computer at random times counts as a broken pos. This game is a broken pos.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079215091', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 15547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15547, 'last_played': 1588817142}

author: {'steamid': '76561198028767482', 'num_games_owned': 1130, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1588596409}
review:
Admittedly only played 94 minutes of this game but it was enough. I was  quite hopeful for this game as I enjoy hex turn based combat and I like RPGs. I've put in a fair amount of hours on similar games and enjoyed them thoroughly. Sadly Blackguards was a disappointment.

Combat mechanics: Meh. It is fairly standard, turn based, flanking, random hit/miss chance. It's OK, nothing innovative at all.
Inventory/class/skill systems: Equipment is very generic, there are much more robust systems out there. The skill systems for the 3 classes does look quite robust. It does however look like there are obvious better choices which you need to pick otherwise you'll struggle.
Story: The major turnoff. Linear, obvious, boring. 2-dimensional companion characters. Gives you choices which aren't choices as they all lead to the same thing.

Overall: There is nothing innovative in this game. I could overlook this if the story was good, the characters were interesting or the combat was compelling but the fact it all aspects of it are mediocre at best and poor in other areas there is really no reason to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973786715', 'num_games_owned': 1942, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1587874843}
review:
I have over 1300 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #67 - Blackguards

When I see that a game is both RPG and Tactical, it's hard to know going in if it's going to be more of one or the other.  In the case of Blackguards though, it doesn't waste any time making it's RPG influence evident, as the first thing you do upon starting a game is to create a new character.

It gives you the option between Basic and Expert mode for creating a character, which isn't normally something I see in RPG games.  Apparently it's based on a ruleset called The Dark Eye, so the idea being if you don't have any background in that, you can choose the basic mode, and it will distribute your stats automatically.  

I picked basic mode, and the only things I ended up having to set was my  Profession and Gender.  Based on what profession you pick, you have a selection of 5 looks for your character.  So anyone looking for an in-depth character customizer will be disappointed.   Finally I named my character and proceeded to start the game.

After a confusing cutscene, you are put in the tutorial, where it guides you through the basics of moving on a hex-based tactical map, and killing a wolf.   After the battle, you are taken through another cutscene, and the story starts by having your character accused of murder.

Again, you'll see the heavy RPG influence here.   In between cutscenes, your character is narrating what's going on, and soon he meets a few other prisoners, with whom you engage in a multiple choice dialog.  Afterward, it's prison break time, and a chance for the tutorial to introduce you to more of the tactical elements of the game.

The game uses what it calls a ring menu that pops up when you right click, and it give you various options based on what profession you are.     First you have the Warrior who is good with weapons and damage dealing, but poorly trained in other areas.   The Hunter is good with ranged weapons, and most other disciplines except magic.  And finally the mage is your magic casting profession, who has limited ability to use melee weapons, and no ranged weapons.  

The tutorial also takes this time to explain how certain objects you can interact with during the fight.  So for example my character moved to a spot and pulled a switch, which caused a conveniently placed chandelier to fall right on top of one of the guards I was fighting.    Blackguards seems to really want to play up the interactive environments.

After winning the battle you are rewarded with some items that you loot off the guards.  Ah yes, inventory management, another RPG staple.    At this point I'd have to say that Blackguards really feels like an RPG that happens to have some tactical turn-based fighting in it.

Each subsequent fight I got in, the tutorial introduced me to some additional tactical elements, like casting a barrier spell.  Once I broke out of the prison, I was introduced to the World Map, where I headed to a nearby city.  Cities are basically just an animated background that allow you to select from a few different places to do business.  For instance you can buy weapons from the Blacksmith, or rent a room from the Innkeeper.

Before leaving the city, the game prompts me to spend some time improving my skills.  Skills are improved by spending Adventure Points (AP).  I mentioned earlier how this game was based on a rule set called The Dark Eye.  That influence is evident here, as the character sheet is a bit overwhelming at first.  You have stats that are split across 5 different areas:  Base Values, Weapon Talents, Talents, Spells, and Special Abilities.   Everything costs AP to improve, with lower level stats costing less to improve, and the cost increasing each level.

Base Values cover your core stats, and here you'll see standard options like Strength, Constitution, Charisma, and Dexterity.  Although strangely it also splits stats that are normally the same stat, such as splitting out Agility from Dexterity, and Vitality from Constitution.  

One interesting thing about Weapon Talents.  Most RPGs just have a base skill for your weapon type that you increase (think Skyrim).  But in Blackguards, you can spend AP to increase your ability to attack or parry with the weapon.  You have a slider which determines how the points are spread, so you can adjust it to focus more on attack and less on defense.  And each melee weapon has this same option.

Talents cover various skills that you can level up by spending AP.   Spells you can also level up, but only if you already know the spell.  Otherwise you have to find a trainer to learn it.  And lastly, Special Abilities are divided into different areas (Melee, Ranged, Magic, Passive).  Some special abilities work in a tree where you have to unlock the lower abilities before you can get the higher ones.  Other abilities are standalone and have no prerequisite.

After leaving the city, I got into one last fight where the tutorial introduced the concepts of line of sight and cover.   Then my 60 minutes was up.

Overall I had a decent bit of fun with Blackguards, and I was surprised at how RPG heavy it ended up being.  At the time I played it, it happened to be on sale at a whopping 90% off, so the game was only a dollar.   That sale is over now, but even at the regular price of 10 dollars, it seems like a good value to me.

Because I didn't make it far into the game, be sure to read some other reviews to see what people felt about the tactical options  and the later game.  But that said, I'd happily recommend this based on my first hour of play.  This is a game I'd happily spend more time in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166741960', 'num_games_owned': 476, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 2195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2192, 'last_played': 1591213353}
review:
Blackguards isn't a particularly great game, but for fans of the universe/genre it might still be worth checking out. With that said, I don't really have any praise, mostly complaints.

[b] Graphics: [/b] for a title from 2013 it's fine; the world map looks awesome
[b] Soundtrack: [/b] it's alright, but nothing exceptional
[b] Voice acting: [/b] actually pretty good, with some weaker moments (an elf with a Brittish accent is kinda funny)
[b] Story: [/b] worldbuilding is pretty decent, characters are fine and the story itself is nothing exceptional, but still interesting; player input mostly doesn't affect anything
[b] Gameplay: [/b] slow and not particularly enjoyable, too much RNG
[b] Replayability: [/b] storywise there's only really like one fork and combatwise your experience probably won't be too different; pretty much none

My main complaint is the combat, given that's why you'd play this sort of a game. It's pretty slow and the absence of any sort of speed options is definitely a miss. Usually it's fine, but in some missions it's downright infuriating.

RNG is part of combat in this kind of a game, but here it was a bit too much. Even fully upgraded characters have trouble hitting with their advanced skills (less so with spells, in most fights), forcing you to slug it out with the lesser ones.

You don't get very many active combat skills and most of the time you'll be using one or two, anyway. (Either due to low chances to hit or due to the fact that some skills are just not worth using.) Compare that with magic, which has like 30 spells (most of which you probably won't need to ever use), where you can expect to max out around 4-5 by the end.

There's quite an extensive selection of weaponry (probably too extensive/broken up into individual categories) and you can reasonably have a good melee/ranged character (but not so much melee/mage). You get three weapon loadouts and it's not a bad idea to have two types melee weapons (due to plenty of mobs having immunities) + a ranged option. It sucks that swapping weapons takes up a whole turn, so you probably won't be doing that too often.

Magic is awful early on and even later on you get into fights where your spells have terrible chances to actually go off. Lower rank spells are pretty meh and all ranks are a tad too expensive relative to the total mana pool of mages (50-60 in late game with regen of around 5 per turn, higher rank spells cost 20-30), but most fights aren't long enough for this to really matter. There are some fights in succession and there you just have to suck it up and spend a turn drinking potions.

Outside of this I have only one complaint regarding the story:[spoiler] killing off Niam for nothing but a cheap shock moment felt pretty bad, especially as there's no real payoff to it (you kill the two slavers that captured you, big whoop), and even though you've only had her for a while by then, she was a likeable stoner elf; if you want to have an archer you're going to have to spec someone else into that role, unless you're one yourself[/spoiler]

review:
Sur les simili-jeux de tactique bas√©s sur la RNG et non la tactique, une seule variable permet de savoir si le jeu est recommandable : son syst√®me de RNG.

Prenons les combats contre les lys et regardons les chiffres r√©els que j'ai obtenus :

- Chances de toucher indiqu√©es ; 60% pour tout le monde avec tous types d'attaques.
- Nombre de coups tent√©s : 207
- Nombre de coups touch√©s : 64

Combat d'ar√®ne comportant 4 archers gobelins : regardons les tirs subis par mes personnages :
- Chance d'√™tre touch√© 5% : sur 37 coups re√ßus, 8 touch√©s.
- Chance d'√™tre touch√© 10% : sur 28 coups re√ßus, 10 touch√©s.
J'ai arr√™t√© de compter l√†.

Alors bien s√ªr, quand √ßa se reproduit encore et toujours, et √† l'infini, le r√©sultat est simple : fuyez ce jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990090707', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 2519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2519, 'last_played': 1586774849}
review:
(Not quite) Finished Blackguards. Played all on Linux.
Blackguards is the battle mechanics of The Dark Eye. You are commanding a party of up to 5 different heroes and engage in various figths throughout the story which itself lets you visit various places in southern Aventuria.

Granted, the game has some nice ideas and the battles themselves are quite entertaining. But the game suffers from many drawbacks:

* First, the difficulty level in ‚Äúeasy‚Äù is very high. That‚Äôs why I quit the game at the end boss, Urias. Since at this stage it‚Äôs more a matter of luck than tactics.
* You can easily skill your heroes in a very wrong. You have no chance to re-skill.
* The story is somehow confusing and not very intriguing.
* The graphics in some places are quite good, which makes the bad rendering in the cut-scene even more obvious.

To sum up: a nice idea with potential, sadly wasted: 5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999921146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 423, 'playtime_forever': 3228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3228, 'last_played': 1586176201}
review:
Alors ce jeu de r√¥le au tour par tour est plut√¥t sympathique mais pourra en laisser plus d'un sur le carreau tant certains √©l√©ments demandent un temps d'adaptation. 

Tout d'abord vous avez... plein de choix pour d√©penser vos XP (enfin PA, Point d'Aventure ici), cette complexit√© dans les possibilit√©s de progression sont les biens venues mais j'avoue avoir √©t√© un peu perdu au d√©but. 

Ensuite, il-y-a des combats puis, des combats et... encore quelques combats. Il faut noter qu'un effort a √©t√© fait pour tenter des variations dans les situations, l'utilisation du d√©cors faisant parfois la diff√©rence dans certains... combats. Oubliez l'exploration, vous passerez d'un fight √† un autre (parfois gr√¢ce √† votre charisme vous pourrez en √©viter).

Et enfin, c'est difficile, surtout au d√©but. Il faut pers√©v√©rer, en une bonne 50aine d'heures j'ai du faire toutes les qu√™tes et envoyer le grand m√©chant dans... l'outremonde o√π il doit mieux se sentir d√©sormais :)

Question √©quipement c'est plut√¥t limit√© comme pour les armures, on ne croule pas sous une tonne d'objets. Il-y-a toutefois pas mal de vari√©t√©s dans les potions, les pi√®ges et les poisons. On peut donc tenter plusieurs approches ainsi que certaines sp√©cialisations.

L'interface est discr√®te et plut√¥t bien pens√©e, les sorts avec leur 4 niveaux ont des effets progressifs. Les comp√©tences sont bas√©es √©galement sur la m√™me id√©e de 4 niveaux.

Les graphismes et les animations ne sont sans doute pas extraordinaires mais font le job. Tout comme la musique tr√®s m√©lancolique. 

Pas forc√©ment facile d'acc√®s, manquant peut √™tre un peu de relief dans les relations/personnages, la tentative de Daedalic est quand m√™me correcte. C'est en jeu qui est actuellement souvent √† prix brad√©, ne bouder pas votre plaisir et tenter l'aventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047454673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1584547569}
review: An interesting hex-grid turn based strategy game. I was not familiar with the IP or the game rules before playing. So far the game has been enjoyable with the high points being character building and combat and the low points being the dialogue choices and non-intuitive UI.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004188918', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 663, 'last_played': 1584704096}

author: {'steamid': '76561198209498701', 'num_games_owned': 1156, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1584380566}
review: Hex-based TBSRPG, with some customisation and good aesthetic. Where it fails is immediately shown on your first battles: 95% chance is a fucking lie, everything and your spells come with miss chance (and it doesn't even hit that hard! 10 damage or so when enemies regularly has 50+ hp on your first hour), obtuse costumisation (any newbie will just blank out with amount of game mechanics _text_ dumped on you), and worst of all this takes 22 GB. For comparison, Divinity costs just 10GB complete edition, Witcher 2 18.4 GB and Amalur just 12GB. All that with X360 era brown and bloom GFX. Yes Blackguards is regularly on sale and easily found as bundle fodder, but there's a reason it becomes bundle fodder.

review:
[h1] Points positifs [/h1]

- Prise en main rigoureuse
- Sc√©nario tr√®s √©labor√©
- Excellente dur√©e de vie (environ 100h)
- Graphismes agr√©ables et c√¥t√© artistique plaisant
- Bonnes id√©es de gameplay et tr√®s bonne diversit√© des ar√®nes et de leurs √©l√©ments interactifs
- Dimension tactique efficace
- Des combats sc√©naris√©s !

- √âvolution, progression √©quilibr√©e des diff√©rents protagonistes
- Nombreux d√©fis sympathiques
- Quelques pointes d'humour !
- Bande-son magnifique !
- Gratifiant...

[h1] Points n√©gatifs [/h1]

- ... Mais exigeant !
- Difficult√© trop bas√©e sur la probabilit√© !
- Quelques probl√®mes de visibilit√© en combat
- √âquipement peu vari√©
- Quelques soucis de localisation

- Certains personnages sont trop en retrait !

[h1] En conclusion... [/h1]

[i] Si Daedalic voulait nous pondre le Demon's Soul du RPG tactique, c'est r√©ussi. Dans Blackguards, la difficult√© des combats en tour par tour est autant un mal qu'un bien, il faut donc l'acheter en connaissance de cause.

Pour un premier coup, c'est un coup de ma√Ætre. Daedalic fait montre d'un savoir-faire certain dans le gameplay et d'une subtile habilet√© dans la narration. Le jeu ne prend jamais le joueur pour un idiot et lui demande de se servir un tant soit peu de sa t√™te pour extirper de Blackguards sa substantielle moelle. Accessible, exigeant, riche, dr√¥le, prenant, envo√ªtant, subtil, charmant... Les adjectifs ne manquent pas m√™me si le jeu a bien des d√©fauts, je ne le cache pas. Seulement, ceux-ci sont continuellement balay√©s d'un revers de main par des bonnes id√©es en pagaille.

Pour conclure, Blackguards est un jeu vraiment intelligent. Ses plus grandes forces sont sans doute ses m√©canismes de jeu, son univers sombre vous permettant de recruter des drogu√©s ou des criminels, ses graphismes plut√¥t jolis. Mais la volont√© de rendre cet univers accessible aussi bien aux aficionados qu‚Äôaux d√©butants risque finalement de ne satisfaire ni les uns ni les autres. Les grands fans de RPG et de tour par tour s‚Äôy retrouveront sans probl√®me, et par la force des choses le jeu leur est plut√¥t adress√©‚Äâ; mais les nouveaux joueurs devront s‚Äôarmer de pers√©v√©rance pour en venir √† bout.

Bref, un bon jeu, mais √† r√©server aux tacticiens hardcores ! [/i] >> 16/20

author: {'steamid': '76561197993023804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 524, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1498361608}
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#254 out of 612)... it's time for Blackguards.

What little I've played of Blackguards, I enjoyed. I don't think it's a great game, by any means, but it's interesting enough that, far from simply failing to regret my time with the game, I find I genuinely intend to revisit it again at some point in the future. When I have the time. And there aren't a thousand other, more compelling CRPGs demanding my time. In short Blackguards is a combat-focused SRPG, with a unique premise (your party consists of escaped criminals). From what I could tell, there's very little in the way of narrative reactivity or opportunities for player expression (all of the party members are predefined characters) but the storytelling was solid enough to propel me forward, even if the turn-based combat wasn't quite deep enough to capture my attention.

I suppose the responsible thing for me to do here would be to not recommend the game. After all, while I didn't find anything particularly wrong with the game, it failed to capture my interest all the same. But the time I did spend with the game... it wasn't bad. And I don't think I'd mind spending more time with it (though I may just jump ahead to the sequel instead). Therefore, I think, it's certainly worth the benefit of the doubt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013161431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 14224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11167, 'last_played': 1584800114}
review: Second playthrough, having become distracted by some other game when I was halfway through my first playthrough.  This time I used some guides to avoid wasting experience points.  I like turn based strategy rpg's and that is what this is.  Well done in every way.  Not amazing in any way.  I haven't finished it yet, so maybe I can give it a stronger recommendation then?  In any case, find a guide so that you don't waste a bunch of points, and then do your own thing.  The game doesn't require perfect play, which I think is great.  Who wants to be a slave to strategy guides?

author: {'steamid': '76561197987804064', 'num_games_owned': 113, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2921, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2742, 'last_played': 1643488037}
review: Very good translation of Die Schwarze Auge ruleset to PC game. Maps can feel a little small at times but since they are handcrafted there is no repetiteveness. No branching story either, but the good script, dialogues  and the challenge is there. Great little title with grasping story, well thought characters, and turn-based combat on hexes gives the feel of a board game - and I've enjoyed a lot. At this price tag it's a no brainer, and during sales even more so.

review:
Even though Blackguards were released 6 years ago, the game is still worth playing.

I finished the game on normal difficulty in about 25 hours and got 60% achievements without trying very hard.

There were only couple of battles which felt challenging on normal. Just invest some time into learning the rules and everything else is just common sense.

Tank
Two-handed weapon damage dealer
Healer/Enchanter
Bowman

author: {'steamid': '76561198031075431', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 6013, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6013, 'last_played': 1582070473}
review:
I finally got around to finishing this old RPG that's been sitting in my library. The quick and the dirty on this? The game was really fun to play. The fights were engaging and I enjoyed how you can build a character to suit your needs - and you can improve your companions likewise.

The music fits the genre and while the story is pretty linear it is a good story. My own complaints are the inability to see find side quests. I did not like having to backtrack through every town and city after every event to see if I am unlocking side quests. Otherwise the game was fun straight up through the end. I'm disappointed to find some of the achievements are broken but that's just a small thing.

Great game overall and even as old as it is, worth a play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073755634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 5835, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5520, 'last_played': 1582394311}
review: For people who like The Dark Eye it's ok (They capture the feeling of where the story happens quiet nice, it's just not my favorite part of the setting. I think because they realy wanted to drive the "Band of Misfits" narrative they had to go to Mengbilla, and Al'Anfa, but it's just not my cup of tea.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197991756205', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 16096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3870, 'last_played': 1702066821}
review:
Bin mit Schwarze Auge gro√ü geworden.  ca.1982-1985  gespielt.
sehr gutes rollen  Spiel. 
einfach super.....
gute Einf√ºhrung.... 
die rg regeln gut √ºbersetzt...
lange spielzeit...
Viele falsch aussagen mit negativ bewertungen.
Wie.
1 - Falsch : Alles ist vorgegeben mit Abenteuerpunkte . 
1.1 - Richtig : verteilen je Schurkenmeister,je Kampfmeister ,Heilmeister oder  je Magiemeister hat man andere Skill¬¥s verteilung freigeschaltet. ;-)
2 - Und doch  :Die Lilie kann man schnell besiegen.  Nur da drauf feuern und  nicht mit nahkampf  anfagen.  nahk√§mpfer zbs. den Baum ablenken. ;-)   geht ruckzuck.
3 - Spielfigur mit Einfach einstellung sind klar mit  Skill punkte vor gegeben aber nicht im Vortgeschrittene einstelung.
Mir kommt es nur so vor das die meisten die negativ bewertet  weil es als Arcade Spiel nutzt wird,und sind mit 40 std. im  kapitel 4 oder schon im Kapitel 5 sind und  kommen nicht weiter. Schade.
spielzeit so ca.80-90 std. so wie man es spielt.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988376070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 14439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8017, 'last_played': 1620815681}
review:
NIce game!  The storyline makes it enjoyable, there is some suspense at to what happened to the main character as he does not know what happened to him at the beginning of the story, and of course he has to eventually learn his "destiny" along the way.  I played  it in English, and can comment about the quality of the voiceover for each of the characters of the game.  The variety of accents makes playing immersive and enjoyable.  The music is very good, well balanced and creates the different ambiences found in the various locations of this game.  In general the visuals, musics and character voices, all the art found in this game, are well polished and enjoyable.  I have not tried to play the game in the other languages that I speak and are available, so I am not able to comment at this time on the other language versions.  

The game system is good but repetitive.  It is a turn based game, so you have time to think and react to events as they unfold and you can refine your tactics over time, as the characters in your party evolve and pile up their capabilities.  The progression path is quite straightforward, easy to handle.  The characters that attach to your party will, like you, have basic capabilities that will progress over time, but you cannot change the path your are taking.  You are either a spellcaster or a fighter, with some various flavours.  Combat is a no brainer, but you need to learn the various aspects of the "wheel" that appears around the characters when you mouse over them.  Aside from that, it is not complicated as you chose your combat actions from there. 

Now here is my only negative comment.  The interface is somewhat clunky.  When moving a character in combat, you have to be very attentive to the way you move with the mouse as you may end up in a different hex than the one you intended to and your path may put you in harms way even if you were trying to avoid a precise space along the movement.  There are some moments of frustration while playing through the game because of that.  Also, the use of the action "wheel" has to be precise, in order to avoid doing a different actions than the one intended.  Even though it is annoying, it is not a deal breaker.  

This game deserves to be played, if only for the care put into the art.  In short, it is enjoyable and entertaining.

review:
After playing it for 30 hours, I faced battle that I can't won. Or maybay I can, but after repeating it 10 times...
This isn't a bad game, but it has a lot of things that need to be fixed, if it wants to be called a good game.
The frustration is just unreal sometimes. 
I DO NOT recommend [b]BUYING[/b] it, creators should make their next game much less repeatable for this price, whereas I bought it on sale, I will say that i don't regret playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991825315', 'num_games_owned': 2752, 'num_reviews': 687, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1577404754}
review:
Combat is the 'best thing'. but the rest is bad.

Dialogue is good though. the story sadly is not very interesting, nor is the apathetic main character.

its a linear VERY LINEAR with ONLY COMBAT  with interesting art assets. its like the devs only focused on the combat ares of the game. if i wanted to play hand of fate i would go and play hand of fate

author: {'steamid': '76561198025915804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 4575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4575, 'last_played': 1577380543}
review:
Great combat, slow progress, useless writing. The redeeming qualities outweighs the negatives on the first playthrough (barely) but after that it's just a pain. 

This game isn't hard because it's challenging, it's hard because you have to fight boring consecutive fights (still better than Bannersaga.) Buy it if it's heavily discounted, burn it with fire otherwise.

review:
E' stato difficile scegliere fra consigliare il gioco o no, alla fine ho deciso per il si perch√© in fondo l'esperienza complessiva √® stata positiva. Certo ci sono difetti, come la poca longevit√† ( il gioco si finisce in una trentina di ore ), la scarsissima variet√† di armi e soprattutto armature e la quasi totale ininfluenza delle scelte fatte.
Se per√≤ siete amanti del GDR e dei combattimenti ad esagoni questo gioco vi regaler√† qualche ora di divertimento.
Da prendere quando lo trovate parecchio in saldo ( io l'ho pagato 99 cent ).

author: {'steamid': '76561198331045721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 32984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31120, 'last_played': 1680420461}
review:
This game is super fun as an RPG. It just sucks its a little short.
And after playing this game several times through this game
is probably one of the best computer RPGs I have ever played.
Love it played it five times, and you can beat the game but 
without earning the super final reward. A good mix of difficulty.
I posted a great walkthrough on this game.

I do still complain that its too short, and by the way, Blackguards2
kindof sucks, because theres a glitch right at the end so you
cant complete the game.. and the game itself in the sequel
is different and possibly not as good. Again, clunky endgame
mechanics make that one not good.  

Blackguards 1 is very very excellent, but plan on beating
it in a weekend or two.

review:

     Blackguards √© um RPG "em trilhos", voc√™ sente que as batalhas s√£o pretextos para o seguir da hist√≥ria e n√£o necessariamente algo divertido e isso se deve a hist√≥ria linear com batalhas contadas dificuldade totalmente desbalanceada (quase desisti ap√≥s 3h de jogo no normal) com batalhas f√°ceis demais seguidas por batalhas exageradamente dif√≠ceis e estressantes, por isso recomendo jogar no f√°cil apenas para acompanhar a hist√≥ria que √© divertida e at√© original.
     Muitas vezes me peguei rindo entre os di√°logos como quando o an√£o interrompe para gritar "what palace?", os personagens s√£o esteri√≥tipos de RPG e isso funciona mesmo n√£o sendo t√£o carism√°ticos.
As habilidades e armas n√£o passam confian√ßa, e voc√™ sente que pode investir tudo em apenas um atributo e ok, al√©m de existir basicamente 2 tipos de arma de cada tipo e o mesmo para armaduras o que refor√ßa, jogue pela hist√≥ria pois n√£o √© not√°vel a melhoria dos personagens.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009316578', 'num_games_owned': 605, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 2278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2278, 'last_played': 1576438277}
review:
I'm giving this a recommendation with massive caveats. 

Pro:
Battle system is fun
World is pretty cool
Charactes are interesting until they become annoying

Con:
Characters are annoying after they become annoying
Char builder is opaque early on (Read guides. Don't try to figure it out, it's not worth the effort. Read at least the top couple character guides before you even make your MC.)
Story drags in the latter 1/3rd
Battles get loooong (entire opposing team is tanks) but unchallenging (healer can outpace their dps because all tanks) in the latter chapters
Basically just quit after chapter 3
Literally quit
Just quit

author: {'steamid': '76561198052372228', 'num_games_owned': 69, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 46329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1521, 'playtime_at_review': 33515, 'last_played': 1710864039}
review:
This game has several faults and hangs sometimes, but it is also rather compelling to play and I like the way APs (Adventure Points) that you earn as you go, pay to upgrade everything - giving good flexibility to developing your character. 

I also like the fact that you and your companions are far from being heroes, all of you have dubious things in your collective pasts.

If you have some patience, this game should be well worth the rather cheap current price. I have over 500 hours logged on this game, in total.

review: This game is amazing, is one of my all time favorites. This game is not for the easy of heart. It is very similar to Dark Souls in how challenging it might be, and just when it starts to get easy, there it is a plot twist (that was amazing). If you want a challenging game, that makes you think your every move, similar in that sense to XCOM in that sense, this is your game. Be patient, really good story too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198099101273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1594675160}
review: Usually, I post review after I've torn through a game's full content or after pouring a couple hundred hours into a game (12hrs at the time of this posting), but this game was immediately fun the moment I started in on it. Bit of a learning curve if you're used to real time strats and tacs, but easily overcome if you take your time when making decisions or planing out your turns. Some missions are tough (and a bit annoying to deal with, but to detail why would be a bit spoilerific), but over all still enjoyable if you like games in the vein of say DnD.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002480567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3508, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 615, 'last_played': 1575760406}
review:
Kurzversion:
DSA Fans (Pen & Paper) Finger weg von diesem Spiel, denn es hat wirklich abgesehen von der Welt in der es spielt NICHTS..rein GAR NICHTS mit den Regeln zu tun die ihr kennt.
F√ºr alle nicht DSA interessierten, es ist ein recht anspruchsvolles Spiel mit dem klassischen "wer hat den dicksten" Syndrom.

LAAAANGE Version:

PRO:
- Die Spielwelt ist an das Aventurien aus dem Pen & Paper Spiel sch√∂n angelegt und die Gespr√§che sehr sch√∂n.
- Die Story ist bisher recht spannend und passt zu dem Regelwerk
- Die K√§mpfe sind anspruchsvoll, so dass man das nicht hirnlos drauf los kloppen kann.
- eine recht brauchbare Entscheidungsfreiheit (Gut und b√∂se entscheidungen)
- Nicht nur Mainstory gebunden, sondern auch Nebenquests die man einfach zuerst erledigen kann, aber auch nicht muss.
- Rundenbasierte K√§mpfe sind f√ºr diese Art Spiel einfach perfekt.

Contra:
- Man hat eigentlich gar keine Wahl seine Chars zu killen wie man lust hat. Das Spiel schreibt einem ziemlich genau vor was man zu skillen hat, um eine bescheidene Chance zu haben.
- Gegner sind nahezu IMMER zuerst dran und reduzieren mit Fernkampfwaffen und Massenzaubern schon mal einiges.
- Gegner treffen eigentlich FAST IMMER. Mega √ºbertrieben und das trotz Waffenwert 18(maximum) und Kriegskunst 18 (Was gewisse Boni geben soll)
- GR√ñ√üTES Manko.... Die Helden werden bis auf den Starthelden vorgeschrieben. Es ist definitv sch√∂ner sich seine ganze Gruppe komplett selbst zusammen zu stellen und somit direkt die Skills zu verteilen wie es Sinn macht.
- Die Grafik ist arg in die Jahre gekommen
- Das Spielesystem hat wirklich nur GAAAAAANZ WEITL√ÑUFIG etwas mit dem eigentlichen Pen & Paper Spiel zu tun.
- Die K√§mpfe sind aufgrund des schlecht umgesetzten Regelwerks sehr schnell langweilig, da die Helden stets die gleichen Fertigkeiten benutzen.
- Es gibt viel zu wenig Fertigkeiten und die es gibt sind oftmals sehr schlecht umgesetzt und auch schlecht ausbalanciert.
- Man wird dazu GEN√ñTIGT ab Kapitel 4 in nahezu fast allen K√§mpfen Gifte benutzen zu m√ºssen, da man sonst gar keine Chance hat. 
- Gegner haben IMMER alle Heiltr√§nke und Zaubertr√§nke und benutzen diese gerne.
- Zus√§tzlich (ab Kapitel 4) bekommen die B√∂sewichte auch noch Heilkristalle die man erst zerst√∂ren muss, damit die Gegner nicht zus√§tzlich noch jede Runbde geheilt werden. ZIEMLICH ALERN.

Wichtig.:
Unbedingt einem Zauberer den Zauber FORTIFEX beibringen. Der wird euch in vielen K√§mpfen hilfreich sein, um zu √ºberleben.
Und bitte Leute.... nicht auf die Tastatur hauen, wenn ihr bei einem Kampf zum xsten Male neuladen m√ºsst, weil die Gegner einfach alle sowas wie Chuck Norris sind....also ALLE.


Fazit:
Das erste Kapitel war echt nett, aber ab dem 2. wird es echt unrealistisch und √ºbertrieben(vor allem wenn man DSA spielt). Nach den ersten 10 Stunden habe ich hier noch eine Kaufempfehlung geschrieben. Diese kann ich nach nun mehr 40 Stunden und dem fast zu sehenden Ende des Spiels leider nicht mehr geben.
Das Spiel schafft leider eine permanene Frustration und erh√∂ht den Aggressionspegel.
Daher.
FINGER WEG und klares Nein zum Kauf dieses Spiels.

author: {'steamid': '76561198393825451', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 647, 'last_played': 1573247437}
review:
This game is heavily unbalanced

You have limited items and limited places to go (which already sucks). Then you have sidequests. But wait a minute: if you don`t do the "sidequests" you are way weaker than your opponents due to the limited number of items/xp available. Therefore it`s just a joke naming those "sidequests"

Graphics are nice and the story so-so. It`s just a shame that a good idea of gameplay (reminds one of FF tactics and Vandal Hearts of the old days) was utterly ruined by the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033819045', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4540, 'last_played': 1573138821}
review:
Overall, Blackguards is a good game.  Not great... but good. 
-Pros: 
Good skill selection makes for good tactical variety.
Decent enemy variety.
Lots of content, albeit repetitive.
While I don't feel like replaying this game myself, I do see that a lot of people on the forums tend to do multiple playthroughs.  So, I assume that for some, this game has a lot of replayability.  

-Cons:
The game lacks direction in a lot of places.  The quest log and world map can do very little at times to let you know what you need to do to complete quests.  For some, it tells you right where to go, who to speak with, and what city they are in.  For others, it just says "Find so-and-so".... and you end up travelling through half a dozen different cities talking to every person trying to see if they will trigger the dialogue you need.  It also lacks direction in some of the battles.  The devs seem to fancy making "puzzle like" map variations, meaning their are things like levers, traps, drawbridges, etc... on certain maps, that you need to figure out how to navigate.  The problem with this, is that there is very little direction when you are tossed into a battle with a unique puzzle associated with it.  other than highlighting the different interactable objects, the game tells you very little such as "If you let the alligators on this map eat 4 or more meat, you auto-lose".  And with battles that can take a half hour or more to get through, its very frustrating to have to start over just because your objective wasn't clearly laid out.
The "miss chance" has been discussed in most negative reviews about this game.  You miss A LOT.  And every time someone brings this up, some nerd explains that its because of dice roll, blah blah blah.  I don't care, and I don't think most others care about the math behind why you miss... If there is nothing we can do about it, that doesnt solve the problem.  It's simply not fun to have such RNG aspects of your combat.  It's fine to have stats you need to achieve to be effective in combat... but it becomes frustrating when you also have to deal with hidden dice rolls on so many different aspects of those stats.
Lastly, the gear/loot system is quite lacking.  It very well may be a personal preference, but I like min-maxxing, finding and comparing gear stats... working towards upgrades, etc...  This game does not really do much in that regard.  Despite there being an armor merchant in every city, and gear drops for a majority of the battles... all of the items are the same.  You will have the same 15-25 pieces of gear/loot drop from the beginning of the game, til the end.   I ended my playthrough wearing the same Leather armor set on 3 of my heroes, that I got in the first quarter of the game.  There are a few "named" items that drop, but most of them are situational and barely any better than the other bland items that drop.  If you like being rewarded occassionally, with a fancy piece of loot for your hard fought battle... this is not the game for you.  And its a bit odd... the potion/elixer/poison variety is tremendous... there are probably 20-30 different ones.  I simply wish the same attention was given to the armor and weapons.
I was looking forward to playing Blackguards 2, but after finding out that it was released merely a year after this game, and reuses 80% of the assets, maps, items, I lost my enthusiasm to do so.  I have decided to jump into a different series until the taste of this has left my pallette a bit more.  Hopefully now that it has been a few years, we will see a Blackguards III, that actually makes improvements and expands on the concepts introduced in the first game.

TL;DR - Its a good game, but lacks depth and direction in certain areas, while being convoluted in some others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039738038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 6061, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3912, 'last_played': 1676553095}
review:
Blackguards ist ein spannendes Rollenspiel, welches eine gute deutsche Vertonung und eine zum Spiel passende Grafikqualit√§t besitzt. Bugs sind mir keine aufgefallen. Die Geschichte ist sehr interessant, und man kann jederzeit speichern.  Das Sammeln von Objekten sowie das Verteilen von Charakterpunkten ist √ºbersichtlich und zweckm√§√üig. Ich kann das Spiel also weiter empfehlen.
Ein f√ºr mich negativer Punkt ist allerdings der Schwierigkeitsgrad. Obwohl ich von drei zu w√§hlenden Schwierigkeitsgraden, die leichteste Schwierigkeit w√§hlte, und meinte als Gelegenheitsspieler und Anf√§nger gut aufgehoben zu sein wurde entt√§uscht. Ich finde auf der leichtesten Stufe sollte das Spiel Einsteiger freundlicher sein.  Die vielen einzelnen K√§mpfe bei Blackguards gestalten sich extrem schwierig, und m√ºssen des √∂fteren wiederholt werden. 
Das Spiel ist nicht schlecht, aber zug√§nglich und Einsteiger freundlich sieht anders aus.

Erg√§nzung am 15.02.2023:

Das Spiel ist von seiner Schwierigkeit-Anstieg her kaum spielbar  ab Kapitel 5.  Ob ich je das Ende erreiche bezweifle ich mittlerweile. W√ºrde dieses Spiel mit heutigem Wissen nicht mehr spielen wollen, da ich auf die vielen Frusterlebnisse und Zweifel ob die Mechanik nicht st√§ndig zu seinen Gunsten schummelt gern verzichten kann. Hab es aufgegeben!

author: {'steamid': '76561198302208299', 'num_games_owned': 286, 'num_reviews': 149, 'playtime_forever': 10993, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 548, 'last_played': 1579759603}
review:
Blackguards is the 3rd Dark Eye game Daedalic has released (I believe they also recently released a Blakguards 2 which would be their 4th).  The series is based on the German Table-Top RPG game 'The Dark Eye'.  Their first Dark Eye game was 'The Dark Eye: Chains of Satinav' followed by 'Memoria'.  Those two games were directly part of the same story line.  This game is not a continuation of that story line.  I have yet to finish this game but have not currently found much of anything that ties it together with the other games.  The first 2 Dark Eye games were point & click adventure/puzzle games.  This one is a turn based  RPG.

The game feels dramatically different than the first two games, enough so that I don't feel like I'm playing in the same world.  The game play dynamics of course are also very different.  Though this is marketed as an RPG it's main focus is the Turn-Based combat.  That isn't necessarily bad but there's hardly any RPG elements.  You are not free to explore, you can only click a few options available as quests open up.  

There's no random encounters to help you build your skills it happens exclusively through quests so if you didn't spend your points the right way at the beginning of the game you might have a great deal of difficulty moving forward.  The combat RNG is terrible.  Almost every battle I was in I was using attacks that had a 95% chance to succeed and yet about 90% of the time they failed.  That means replaying the same battle many, many times over again till you can finally beat it because RNG was not on your side.   The battles feel very slow as you wait for some 10 characters to make their move in some battles.  There doesn't seem to be a way to fast forward that so you can just get on with your next turn so there's a l lot of unnecessary waiting.  The story was semi-interesting but because the battles need so much repeating and take so long you tend to lose the story element and forget what's happening in the game other than you are fighting.

Towns and wilderness areas cannot be explored.  Towns are just a scene that let's you click on a few merchants or occassional quest givers but all contained on the same screen (usually anyways... there are a few places where an arrow to another part of town is available).  You exit the town only to  a map and once you click on a destination you will enter either another town or a hex map for battle.  As soon as the battle ends you're back to the map.  The mechanics of the skills and equipment and everything is a little confusing and requires a lot of time to fully calculate the best options.

The graphics to the game are okay, but I wish there were a few more customization options for picking your specific characters looks and attributes in the creation menu.  The background sounds and music are okay but nothing that I love,  I don't hate it either but it's kind of meh.  The voices are well recorded but I find some of them to be a little annoying with heavy fake-y sounding accents.

There are quite a few achievements available but I found it hard to progress in the game so I hardly got any of them so far.  Some are tied to story/chapter progression while others are based on certain actions, in-game events, and other  milestones.  It seems like a nice mix of types of achievements but it seems like the type of game that will take a lot of time to get all of the achievements and possibly multiple play throughs.

At just under 10 hours I'm just shy of 1/4 of the way through the chapter progression so I believe the game very much could be 40 hours at least.  Considering how much of the time is spent re-trying battles I'm not convinced it's the most enjoyable way to spend 40+ hours and it could easily be longer than 40 hours.  If you playthrough in 40 hours though that makes this game about $0.25/hr of gameplay.  That's really good if you enjoy the game and you can find it on sale from time to time for an even better deal.  However,  I just didn't feel it was offering me the most enjoyment for the time I put into the game.  I'll continue playing from time to time especially to work towards the rest of the achievements but I can't say I'd recommend the game to anyone who wants to play it based on liking Daedalic's previous two Dark Eye Games.  I also don't think it's a great Turn-based RPG so I can only recommend it if you absolutely love RPGs and find this on a deep sale.


UPDATE AFTER FINISHING THE GAME:

I still don't like this game it took FOREVER to finish because even if you are using a good strategy your RNG can be so bad that you keep failing and having to repeat the same fight dozens of times before you finally win.  The story aspect does pick up a little through the later half of the game but not as much as I'd like.  You get to start making some decisions and choices in the last 3 chapters that can change the ending of the game but, most of the choices seems to be empty choices that have no real effect in the game other than occasionally skipping a fight.  The additional battles in the DLC pack add a little more interest and some opportunites for additional Adventure Points (AP) but unless you really love playing this game it doesn't add much more than extended play time.  For achievement hunters and completionists this game is a nightmare.  About 30% of the achievements are bugged and cannot be obtained.  Some are not available unless you pretty much play through the entire game (or at least after chapter 2) twice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060136747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 3396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1655, 'last_played': 1686970700}
review:
You start out as a bodyguard, shit hits the fan and you ending up on the run, little later things get much worst and you trying to survive. I wont spoil the fun.

Tactical combat, deep character skill / attribute development
I recommend reading skill descriptions and abilities thoroughly, because its very easy to spend points on skills and get no actual benefit, I suspect that's why other people have issues with this game.

Story is pretty straightforward and graphics are decent, lots of places to visit, game is linear with side quests which I recommend doing for extra xp.

If you make characters jacks of all trades you are literally fucked. Don't spend all points on 4 different weapon types, pick 1 then perhaps 2 down the road if you must, also investigate into attributes which is big factor.

There are fights that are difficult, use environment to your advantage, this is huge, and don't let yourself surrounded. Sometimes kiting enemy's is only way to survive even with 1 health point left.

The game is only fun if you make it to be, otherwise you're into lot of hard times. I already beat Blackguards 2 so I am familiar with the game mechanics. 

If you like challenge, try this game.

[Jogatina]
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
cara vou ser sincero, de primeira o jogo ja pergunta e manda aquela"vish mano o jogo e tenso, te aconselhamos a jogar no (easy)" blz, eu aceitei e joguei no "easy" e apanhei pra caralho, mas reparei que algumas mecanicas podiam facilitar. nisso eu apaguei meu save e resetei e escolhi jogar no modo sem auxilio , e cara quando vc aprende o jogo fica mt mais mt satisfatorio, ver seu personagem crescer, descobrir novas historias, e a cada hora q eu mais jogava eu fui descobrindo mais coisas mt fodas que ainda n tinha visto em jogos tacticos, gostaria mt de falar aqui as coisas fodas q eu vi mais acho q estragaria a impressao sobre o jogo, pq quando eu joguei so veio na minha "meuuu q foda isso, se eu tivesse notado isso antes o jogo ficaria mt mais epico".. so joguem comprando por 20 ou 2 pila, cara ta valendo mt a pena jogar esse jogo. gostei tanto q comprei ate o segundo game(ainda nao joguei asaushua senao eu vicio e nao termino meus trampos)
