author: {'steamid': '76561198020313592', 'num_games_owned': 984, 'num_reviews': 574, 'playtime_forever': 1207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1207, 'last_played': 1464257930}
review:
What is good about this game:

- Character development is complex
- Good setting
- Varied enemies
- Variety of situations you find yourself into
- Nice graphics

So why downvote?

Because my friends, of two reasons.

The GAME BALANCE. It is so broken i cannot even believe it. Some fights are so unbalanced i had to actually lower the difficultry to Normal to beat them, which i never ever did for any game in my life. This because you are put in situations where you just need luck to make it out alive.

And Luck is the real master of this game, not skill nor strategy. Just pure luck. RNG (Random Numerical Generation) (What determines % of success or failure of things) is so determining in the combat that it just rules over everything. In other turn based games there is RNG of course, but also other factors like strategy, formations, class builds, level are critical to win a fight, but not here in blackguards, not at the same level.

A single random critical, or spell failure (spells can FAIL casting, yes you got it right), or a random miss with 99% chance, or again some trap which activates randomly decides to turn just towards your party and wipe it out with a blast of fire.

All these things can make a fight fail. Random chance upon chance upon chance upon chance. Not even in Vegas there is so much gambling.

This more than a game of skill is a game of luck. I have many many years of experience in all kinds of RPGs but i just cannot take it anymore. I find myself by now to repeat fight over and over and over again just to get a fight where the RNG favors me, where traps do not activate on my team, or on the target i have to protect, etc, and make me fail after a well planned strategy.

Do yourself a favor, go and buy Divinity Original Sin, that's a turn based game made right, not this disguised slot machine of a game we have here.

review:
Blackguards ist ein rundenbasiertes Strategiespiel der Rpg-Familie. Es gl√§nzt durch eine umfangreiche Storyline welche mit wohl durchdacht geschrieben und umgesetzt wurde. Anfangs noch sehr leicht bietet es einen grandiosen Einstieg und baut eine Verbindung zwischen dem Charakter des Spielers, dem Zauberer und dem Zwerg sowie allen weiteren Begleitern und Weggef√§hrten auf. Blackguards zeigt sich im sp√§teren Verlauf jedoch schon gehoben anspruchsvoll wodurch man endlich wieder l√§nger an einem Level sitzt, gr√ºbelt und fiebert und nat√ºrlich auch gerne mal schipft wie ein Rohrspatz :)
Ein Hammer Spiel, oftmal im Angebot und dann auf jeden Fall ein Spiel das in keiner Steambibliothek fehlen darf.
10/10 Punkten (+1 Punkt extra f√ºr den wahnsinnigen Spass die Entwickler zu verw√ºnschen, ausnahmsweise nicht aufgrund von Bugs, da gl√§nzt das Spiel ebenfalls und es gibt nahezu keine)

author: {'steamid': '76561198155045661', 'num_games_owned': 157, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3726, 'last_played': 1466239330}
review:
Not a particular amazing game, but enjoyable enough and some cleverly designed scenes here and there prevent you from tackling each and every battle with exactly the same old strategy.  Comparing the number of pros and cons, it's a really impressive game; but one of the cons just happens to be super important to me, bringing the game down to just decent instead.

CONS
The game can basically be broken down into four parts: cutscenes; inventory/ability screens; towns/shops; and battle scenarios.  Each of these is actually very well done.  But it leaves the game feeling a bit hollow simply because you don't get much of a feeling of exploring.  You move around the map by clicking on dots.  You move around submaps by clicking on dots.  Even the towns/shops just feel like clicking on dots.  They shouldn't, because they're much more visual, but the game just builds that feeling of dot-clicking into it, and you can't shake it.  

The inventories get messy.  Weapons and armour can be seen separately, but everything else is all piled up in one section with no sorting options.  So when you're looking for healing or mana potions, be prepared to go through page after page of poisons, traps, buffing potions, throwing weapons, and EVEN all the 'quest items' - new and old, jumbled up with them.

PROS
The cutscenes are well done, the plot's interesting enough, and you really feel like you get to know the characters.

There's a good number of abilities, categorised in some interesting ways.  Most importantly, the spells have enough variety that you can really explore a range of different strategies.  Even within typical categories like direct damage or buffing, there's still variety.  (Potential SPOILER examples: [spoiler] Direct damage has single target, area of effect, enemy hunting single target, cloud spawning enemy hunting single target, and whole map blasts; and some of those stun, or knock down, or curse/debuff.  And that's just within direct damage.  My favourite quickly turned out to be a shadow duplicate spell - which for me meant creating a second archer-mage for 3-5 turns, whose arrows are shadow too, so it was like getting double the mileage out of each arrow). [/spoiler]  The variety might take a little while to sink in, because at first it looks like 24 spells with 4 levels of power each.  But within the 4 levels for each, most have at least one significant change, so it's actually more like 48 spells.

The options for non-spellcasters are more limited, but still allow for some good variety - especially since you can have up to three weapon sets; and/or make use of traps and throwing weapons.  It's hard to do early on, but each route you take eats up experience points, but this ultimately allows you to do things like: (a) Carry a giant two-handed bashing weapon for massive damage and quick battles, but be ready to switch into sword and shield if you need more defense and accuracy.  (b) Run around with a two-handed pike-style spear, but pitch javelins and poison bombs at your enemies before they get into melee range.  (c) Mix up archery and fencing.  (d) Go all archery, but set traps - especially stunning or slowing traps - around you when melee fighters look like they're going to get too close.  (e) etc, etc.

The weapons and armour are pretty bog-standard for an RPG overall, but are just varied enough.  The expense might seem frustrating at first, but I enjoyed the way it made me mix and match parts more often, and set different characters up with different equipment sets.  And when there are all kinds of traps and poisons and buff potions, etc, as well, it feels like you've always got something new to pick up.

The combat!  At first it looks like each map is going to be a matter of big vs small, wide vs narrow, and empty or covered with traps or blocking environment.  That'd lead to a bit of variety, but eventually you'd work out a couple of strategies that you'd just use over and over again.  But soon enough, you start seeing unique twists (some are repeated a couple of times; some are just used once).  There are plenty of them, and they are what really make the game worth it in the end.  (Potential SPOILER examples: [spoiler] A super long get to the end before the poisonous mist catches up to you map.  Skeletons keep coming back to life unless you smash the crystal maps.  Sneak through the dark and you won't have to fight at all maps. Maps with cages to open to let out support.  Maps with cages to close to trap beasts.  Maps with buildings you can knock down to crush some enemies.  Maps with spider webs hidden like traps and as bridges you can knock out from under the spiders.  And more and more.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198025033243', 'num_games_owned': 91, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1452, 'last_played': 1694219560}
review: As a newbie to tactical RPG games, I am enjoying it thus far. It is a bit tough if you are trying to learn the genre and the game at the same time. I like the turn-based format vs real-time because for obvious reasons of trying to figure out my plan. I don't like that you can't save your progress within a battle, but perhaps that's just how it is, like dingleberries are brown. Pick it up on a discount like I did and there will be little reason to regret it if it's not your type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075078972', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1463066966}
review: This turn based RPG starts off good but soon becomes incredibly tedious, difficult and as a result, extremely boring. The combat is iffy in some parts as your chance attacks will miss a lot of the time even if its really high. I had to replay a lot of levels just to get through to the next one. Side missions aren't all that impressive and there was no drive for me to explore the whole map. There were a lot of towns that I just passed through without bothering to explore. In the end the extreme difficulty forced me There are multiple endings based on the conversation choices you make but the one I received was underwhelming and I felt hollow. Wouldn't recommend this game to players new to the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211099261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1463069735}
review:
I have wanted to love this game. I really, really have. The character development system is complex and has a depth rarely found in RPGs. The story and choices are a combination of dark and darker, and yet there is no shortage of humor in the game. Having said all of that, I do NOT recommend this game for the casual gamer who enjoys RPGs. This is for the hardcore gaming fans who want to spend hours agonizing over points spent in skill and character development, only to find that you have to start over because you lack core abilities in your characters to survive. Further, the combat system is ridiculous. You get a wizard at the beginning of the game as a companion who has an ~80% accuracy range - however, in my experience, his spellcasting is weak at best, and backfires most of the time, and at often critical moments. Unfortunately, healing is also problematic because it uses an entire action (turn), and so by the next round, you may be down more health points than you were before you healed. Following me so far? That's good, because on top of that, you can count on being outnumbered and outmaneuvered in nearly every battle. 

I could go on to wax poetic about the ineptitude of the combat system and the way the developers correlated character development with combat in a way that is clear, but I think you can get the gist of it from above. I have to quit playing this game because after too much time trying the same battle over and over again to rescue some baroness who loves the less than useless wizard companion I have, I am going to retire this game entirely and quite playing it. It simply lacks any enjoyment for me at this point. I think the game designers have a lot of work to do to create a product that I would ever consider purchasing again. I feel cheated of my money and my time. 

Oh, and you don't have the option of really grinding your characters up to par, either. There are a set number of quests and side quests, and you spend those character development points at your own risk. 

Again, there may be a market for this to hardcore gamers and some others, but it is definitely not for the faint of heart.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976291722', 'num_games_owned': 416, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 3436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3436, 'last_played': 1463263143}
review:
I honestly took a long time to play this game (I knew I eventually would as I love turn based tactical RPG), because of all the mixed reviews.  Regardless, I can't believe how much fun the combat in this game is.  I'll break down some key game concepts that might persuade you to buy or push you away.

Good:
-Amazing character development using a deep system of random dice rolls and old-school board game elements
-Hard battles (some are pushovers) that make you think or have to re-do because of a single screw up
-Deep turn based hexagonal board-like combat involving traps and the environment
-A Baldur's Gate style of map minus the exploration
-The game really focuses on the battles without the fuss of wandering and exploring (ie. not an exploration game)

Bad:
-The story is not bad, but one shouldn't be getting this game for that reason
-The itemization and game mechanics are a bit complicated to understand and required a lot of Google searching
-Linear story and no exploration

If you are looking for a game that focuses purely on the tactical turn based combat, then this is truly it.  There is no wandering and exploring with your party and discovering secrets.  The world map is like Baldur's Gate, however, when you visit cities and places, you are either transported into a combat situation with some cutscenes or visit a town where NPC's are static screens filled with innkeepers, healers, merchants, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995311659', 'num_games_owned': 671, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1804, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1763, 'last_played': 1463174436}
review:
A frustrating design nightmare.  Suffers from classic Euro-dev 'difficulty' design flaws.  Everytime you lull yourself into a state of enjoying this game, the devs fuck up.  You can almost smell the body odour of the geek who thought taking away all your loot for an entire climactic segment of the game was a good idea.

Don't bother getting attached to characters or strategically saving points to spend on a worthwhile skill.  You can lose them without any notice, having wasted opportunities to use those points to get you through certain battles.  Cardinal error.

Some fights are designed to be artificially punishing.  I haven't used the word 'cheap' since I played Nintendo in the 90s.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133064279', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1269, 'last_played': 1461304032}
review:
This is a pretty fun game.  There are a lot of looading pages, and even though the game auto saves before and after a battle, it is best to make your own save file. If you loose a battle, and the game reloads, it will autosave again, and unless you have your own save file, you'll be stuck in an endless loop until you succeed, and sometimes those battles weren't ment to be entered yet. 

The voiceacting is actually pretty welldone. I was suprised. The art is decent, the story thus far is very predictable, but still enjoyable. There's lots of side quests you can complete. It seems to be a good idea to do them, just to get the experience and the points to spend on spells, and abilities. Makes the game a little easier, and allows for more battle options. 

I'm not a fan of the buying system. There's seems to be a limited number of arrows. After buying all of them in a shop, it seems they don't restock. I've come back to shops after many battles to see if they resupply, but it doesn't seem they do. The potion prices are rediculous. Though you shouldn't need them very often. 

There is a little bit of a freedom  aspect. At a certain point you can choose where you want to go, and dialog options give you different results. You can choose which side to be on in some battles. 

I give the game a 6/10. It's nothing special, but I do enjoy playing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257719628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1464629694}
review:
I wish there was a middle choice like, "If it's your cup of tea," or; "If it's on sale."  Anyways, I can't openly recommend this game though I will continue playing it and do enjoy aspects of it. It's a start over too many times kind of game. Sometimes the CTH (chance to hit) can frustrate you more than anything else. Because it's played tactical turn style this makes some battles painfully long, and some easy battles unneccsarily hard. I truly had a fight where luck jsut spit on my and I failed every spell, before writing this review actually, and I was killed by two wolves...eh. 
It does get better, obviously as I said I will keep playing it. Nice feel, voice acting is ok, story is fine so far though nothing pushing the limits I feel it could move forward readily. I'm interested to see how strong I can make my characters and well I can customize them. Still, I can't recommend it.
Why?
It falls into a category of games where there are many options for you that are easier to pickup and just as customizable. If you've already played through a plethora of these titles you will then enjoy this as you're out of new stuff to do. But get a coffee, or whatever relaxes you, because it will frustrate you to ****.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996183984', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 472, 'last_played': 1449900114}
review:
If you aren't a little twatwaffle that hates anything resembling a challenge - but LOVE tactics-bassed combat, RP driven narrative, and a beautifully written story-line (which is NOT your typical weeaboo animoo trash power of friendship BS) - then this game is for YOU!

BUT, if you hate challenges, just go away now; This game is not made for the masters of easy mode - and as you will notice, all of the bad reviews and general gripes all go back to the game being too challenging and not letting you become an OP god.

"NAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAIL!
Tell these noobs to go hoooooome..."

author: {'steamid': '76561197991155039', 'num_games_owned': 349, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 781, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 781, 'last_played': 1461467627}
review:
Avoid this game.  I don't understand why game developers think that RNG and setting the odds against you makes a game fun.  If you enjoy loading over and over again until you get a perfect roll and get the scenario down perfect is fun than this is the game for you!

The graphics are mediocre, they characters look mediocre and no way to customize, the classes are mediocre and you don't gain enough skill points to keep up with the difficulty curve.

The game is linear, offering no real exploration.  Just move from one scenario to another.  One scenario will be easy the next not to bad and than they throw one at you that you have to reload over and over again until you get lucky.  No skill involved, just luck on RNG.  This game gets the terrible reviews it deserves.

I am in the second chapter stuck on fighting the "newcomer" gladiators.  They split your group into 2 groups.  So if you didn't choose a warrior in the beginning you will be stuck fighting 2 ranged against a tank and range setup, which is painful.  There is making the game difficult and then there is making it silly just to extend the life of the game.  I will try to finish the game and see but my will to continue is slowly dwindling, I am beginning to think that this company doesn't know how to make games.

OK Made it past that point, now I am to a part in the gladiator games where they throw 3 waves of enemies at you without any rest.  This really is some of the worst game design I have had the misfortune in playing.  You get no breaks, no way to bind your wounds... nothing.  I made it to the 8th wave and there is an instant win button the enemies can do that you have no way of stopping.  It is completely random.  I am very close to giving up on this game, it isn't difficult, it is, to put it country simple, stupid.  So far this game deserves all the bad reviews it has gotten.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033268518', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 5111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4442, 'last_played': 1465000211}
review: The game itself is great, really nice graphic and a story that keeps the game entertaining.. but then theres the bugs, in combat i had to reload my savegame 3 times so far, because of a combat bug that just makes ur charater stop attacking on the second hit, u cant get past that point, unless u havd unlimited patience, and wait for that one out of 20 times where it doesent bug and u can actually get past that place.. it happened in several other combats aswell, and ive tried to get support for it, check the forums, write em.. hell even google.. but nothing.. no fix.. no support.. nothing.. and for 40 euro for the game and 5 euro for the DLC.. as much as i love the game i dont reccomend it.. because the bugs is just to frustrating.. and without any support for the game, seems the devs just left it.. then id say if it was a 5 euro game then the bugs, i could live with em, and just think pff it was only 5 euro.. but in this case its NOT just 5 euro wasted.. its 45 euro wasted..

author: {'steamid': '76561198036448651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2642, 'last_played': 1459705145}
review:
Now that I finished this game, is time to review it.

When I heard about a tactic turn-based strategy game, about some blackguards (that promised some bad guys doing bad things!) with RPG elements, and I saw the game was in my steam library, I said: "Yes!"
But... that was a big mistake.

The story of the game has a good start: A mystery. A murder. Are you guilty? Are you innocent? If you are innocent, who is the true murderer? Why can't you remember nothing?
And with that, you get out of prison to live some adventures.
The characters are charismatic and with personalities of their own. The world is full of life, but most of the secondary missions are only valuable for the Adventure Points (the XP of the game), and they are irrelevant to the story.

The game has a few plot twists and they are not bad at all, but before reaching them you will probably exhausted. The problem is that the ending is... well... is HORRIBLE. It is the ending that you can expect, but is displayed in a really awful and strange way that makes you think: "I really finished this game to see this?"

The gameplay is good in the beginning, but when you are more or less mid-game you will probably be sick of being poisoned. And that's only the start: The machine abuses the use of poisons. You will probably hear every turn "Poison!" or "I am poisoned!" or "I hate poison". Also, some special combats in Act 5 are never explained why are this special or why the special rules.

As many other tactic turn-based games, probabilities are really important. That means you can have a lucky day and impact an almost impossible shoot, or a really unlucky and fail all your 98% chance spells. But, as always, it seems "50%" means "1/2" to me and "1/10" to machine, as I never impacted an attack under 20% and usually failed things of 70-80%, 95% or even 98%. In a game where every movement, every action counts, this can make you sick really fast. Also, the enemies are as if they were taken out of Matrix, because they can dodge easily and usually all your attacks.

So, well, unless you really want to be poisoned EVERY combat, lose your patience failing your 98% chance spells and being parried attacks that shouldn't be parried, and playing a lot of hours to receive a half-cooked last Act with a fast ending as closure, you probably shouldn't play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198211579817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 499, 'last_played': 1462390839}
review:
No voto negativo el juego por su sistema o contenido. Al final lo explico...
Este juego es para ir muy poco a poco. No entrare en detalles sobre √©l m√°s alla de lo que ya pueden explicar en los dem√°s posts.
La historia tiene su gancho. Los personajes su personalidad. Un sistema muy amplio de colocaci√≥n de talentos, hechizos y especializaci√≥n en armas...

Pero le encuentro un grabe problema, y es simplemente por esto que le doy Negativo:
DEBES GRABAR CONTINUAMENTE LAS PARTIDAS o por lo contrario te vas a dar con un canto en los dientes.

Llevar horas de juego intentando pasarte la dichosa batalla, y por fin, cuando te has relajado y piensas "vale, voy a la ciudad a curarme y grabar"... zas!! te salta en la pantalla una nueva batalla que te endosan porque la historia lo dice as√≠... y Oh SORPRESA! Empiezas el combate con la vida tal y como acab√≥ la √∫ltima, o sea, a m√≠nimos ¬¨¬¨
Eso supone que es una batalla que no vas a poder ganar nunca, pq al primer golpe mueres. Y no da ninguna opci√≥n a situarte antes de esa batalla. Simplemente te da la opci√≥n de "intentar de nuevo?" Y si te piensas que los autosave te van a salvar el culo, lo tienes claro. A empezar el juego desde 0

Por eso, o se est√° grabando continuamente, o juega en una habitaci√≥n sin ventanas. Por lo que pueda ser.

Encuentro bastante poco acertado que un juego de estrategia, donde el cambio de un arma corta a largo alcance puede ser vital, no deje aceptar ese mero cambio antes del combate

author: {'steamid': '76561198006614818', 'num_games_owned': 523, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 2472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2472, 'last_played': 1425681067}
review: Blackguards ist ein sehr komplexes Rollenspiel in der Welt des "Schwarzen Auges", was kennern eigentlich schon alles sagen sollte. Die Story ist aufwendig und komplex und zog mich tief in ihren Bann. Die Grafik ist leider nicht besonders gut, was mich jedoch nicht besonders gest√∂rt hat, da es mir bei Rollenspielen mehr auf die Geschichte und die Charaktere ankommt. Diese m√ºssen f√ºr mich glaubhaft und fesselnd sein und genau das schafft Blackguards meiner Meinung nach mehr als gut. Allerdings gibt es auch einige recht unfaire K√§mpfe die einem tierisch auf die Nerven gehen k√∂nnen. Trotzdem m√∂chte ich dieses Spiel jedem empfehlen der spielerische Herausforderungen und gute Storys mag. Beides wird man in diesem Spiel finden. Aber Anf√§nger sollten vielleicht doch noch ihre Finger hiervon lassen, weil es an manchen Stellen wirklich verdammt schwer ist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054216330', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 3348, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3299, 'last_played': 1458943379}
review:
Wie √ºblich, wer den Wall of Text nicht mag, scrollt ganz runter ^^

An und f√ºr sich kein schlechtes Spiel, allerdings haben hier dieses Mal die Negativpunkte so stark √ºberwogen, dass auch das gute KS sowie Skillsystem nix mehr retten konnten.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Das Gameplay der Oberwelt ist simpel gehalten. Zu simpel. Man hat eine Weltkarte, auf der gibt es Orte, die man anklickt, und man gelangt dann ziemlich z√ºgig an den gew√§hlten Ort. In der Stadtansicht hat man dann einen Bildschirm, auf dem alle relevanten NPCs zu sehen sind, also H√§ndler, heiler, Taverne etc. Abseits der K√§mpfe spielt sich das Spiel wie ein Point¬¥n Klick Adventure. F√ºr ein Spiel der Marke "Das Schwarze Auge" meiner Meinung nach keine gute Eigenschaft, auch wenn Laufwege zu den Orten wegfallen. Zu einem zumpftigen RPG geh√∂rt es dazu, dass man was zum erkunden hat. Die Dungeons kann man lediglich mit gutem Willen als solche bezeichnen, denn wie auf der Oberwelt klickt man sich hier von Ort zu ort bzw von Kampf zu Kampf. Leider unspektakul√§r.

Eine der St√§rken des Spiels ist das Skillsystem, das erfreulichwerweise ein beinahe klassenloses skillen erm√∂glicht.
"Beinahe", weil immernoch zwischen magiebegabten und eben solchen ohne Magiebegabung unterschieden wird, Wie in Spielen des schwarzen Auges √ºblich, verteilt man Abenteuerpunkte, die man bekommt, wenn man Quests l√∂st oder K√§mpfe gewinnt auf die unterschiedlichen Statuspunkte und Talente, die auf diesen Statuspunkten aufbauen. Planvolles Skillen ist hier schon zu Beginn angesagt, da es im Spiel nur begrenzt viele K√§mpfe und damit Abenteuerpunkte gibt.
Ein Feature, das gut umgesetzt wurde, wie ich denke.

Ein weiterer Punkt sind die K√§mpfe, die auch gro√üteils gut gelungen sind. Kampffelder haben oft M√∂glichkeiten, Gegner auf unkonventionelle weise auszuschalten wie zum Beispiel durch enflammen brennbaren Sumpfgases. Mir pers√∂nlich haben die K√§mpfe viel Spa√ü gemacht, au√üer gegen Ende im letzten Dungeon, der eigentlich aus zwei Dungeons besteht in denen es wenn ich mich recht erinnere 15 Pflichtk√§mpfe gab, die zwar nicht alle schlecht aber eben auch nicht alle gut waren. An der Stelle habe ich lange gesessen, weil einfach die Motivation fehlte, weiter zu machen in dem Wissen, dass noch einige folgen.

[b]Interface[/b]
Der Questlog ist leider mitunter wenig hilfreichg gewesen, da zum Teil zwar erw√§hnt wurde, zu wem man muss, aber nicht wo er ist, was bei einer gro√üen Welt mit einem guten dutzend betretbaren Orten echt frusten kann, vorallem wenn man eine Quest bekommt, die man erst l√∂sen kann, wenn man eine andere gel√∂st hat, die man eben noch nicht gel√∂st hat, was wie ich denke ein Bug ist, aber dennoch √§rgerlich.

Im Ausr√ºstungsinterface der Charaktere wird nur die Behinderung durch zu schweres Gep√§ck angezeigt, aber nicht die durch die Ausr√ºstung.

Das Schriftbild √§ndert sich, wenn man einen anderen Schwierigkeitsgrad ausw√§hlt. Wirkt komisch und dadurch k√∂nnen sich W√∂rter √ºberlagern, was wirklich nicht sch√∂n aussieht.

[b]Musik[/b]
Der OST ist soweit stimmig umgesetzt

[b]Zusammenfassung[/b]
Positiv
[list]
    [*]Gro√üteils interessante und launige K√§mpfe
    [*]Das Skillsystem wie DSA Fans es kennen und lieben
    [*]Atmospherischer OST
    [*]drei unterschiedliche Schwierigkeitsgrade, die sich im Spiel jederzeit √§ndern lassen
[/list]
Negativ
[list]
    [*]wenig hilfreicher Questlog
    [*]am Ende spielt es sich extrem z√§h
    [*]praktisch keine wirklichen Erkundungsm√∂glichkeiten
    [*]"P√ºnktchendungeons" in denen man sich von Kampf zu Kampf klickt
[/list]

[b]Fazit[/b]
Wie man in der Zusammenfassung sehen kann, gab es nicht so viele negative Punkte, aber diese haben gereicht.
Blackguards ist wirklich kein schlechtes Spiel, aber es krankt an einigen Stellen, wo es wirklich nicht h√§tte sein m√ºssen. Eine frei begehbare Oberwelt und ein weniger langwieriger Enddungeon (√ºberhaupt ordentliche Dungeons) h√§tten das Spiel hier vor einer negativen Bewertung bewahren k√∂nnen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057689545', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2254, 'last_played': 1458829332}
review:
Also ich habe das Spiel jetzt endlich durch nach q√º√§lenden Stunden mit unsinnigen % Angaben und nachdem ich das Spiel auf einfach stellen musste. 
Also das Spiel ist Story technisch sehr seicht und das Kampfsystem ist √ºberhaupt nicht Systematisch.
Die Prozente scheinen nur sch√∂nes Beiwerk zu sein, anders kann ich mir nicht vorstellen, warum man mit teilweise 95% Trefferwarscheinlichkeit 6 mal hintereinander daneben haut und Feinde einen mit 20 % locker treffen.
Die Story ist ganz ok aber halt nix originelles. Ein B√∂sewicht den es zu finden gilt usw.
Also ich w√ºrde jedem abraten, der sich hier ein gutes Rundenbasierendes Spiel versprechen. Ich habe mich w√§hrend dem gro√üteil der Spielzeit nur gefrustet und muss sagen, obwohl ich dieses Genre eigendlich mag, dass ich dieses Spiel niemandem empfehlen w√ºrde.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030208468', 'num_games_owned': 691, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1457638372}
review:
It's just... bad.  The visuals are average, with bits of them bordering on terrible.  The story and exploration are linear, and the story itself is just plain boring.  The voice-work is just good enough to point out how comically bad it is.  Towns are bland and lifeless.  Combat is stagnant, and shows no complexity.  Even if you buy Blackguards on sale, you likely still won't find the time to sit down with it.  There just isn't any single thing exciting enough to make up for the blandness of the rest of the game.  Nothing to draw you back in, after the first time you've played.

It's well done from a mechanical standpoint - The skill trees are well thought out and balanced.  There's just nothing flashy in them to draw attention, and the execution becomes poor when you see your character dully performing their moves and abilities with passable graphics and poor weapons/equipment.  Blackguards is a pen-and-paper RPG adaptation that never really got past the pen-and-paper bit.  More of a visualisation of some DM's real-world tabletop setup that would seem much cooler set up with cardboard on your buddy's gaming table.

If you're hellbent on playing Blackguards, I hear Blackguards 2 is actually worth the time.  It's on my list of 'soon to play' games, so I'll put up a review ASAP.

Jednak potrzeba czasu aby wpa≈õƒá na to jak to zrobiƒá i zrozumieƒá tƒÖ mechanikƒô. Zdarza siƒô, ≈ºe nie zawsze opisy m√≥wiƒÖ nam dok≈Çadnie czym dana umiejƒôtno≈õƒá lub czar jest. Sko≈Ñczy≈Ço siƒô na skorzystaniu z ksiƒôgi i zdobyciu czaru, kt√≥rego nigdy nie wykorzysta≈Çem.

Nale≈ºy ponownie podkre≈õliƒá, ≈ºe jest to gra tworzona na podstawie systemu RPG. Co to oznacza? ≈ªe wiƒôkszo≈õƒá statystyk jest okre≈õlana w pseudo rzucie kostkƒÖ. Przyk≈Çad? Procent trafienia mieczem, procent rzucenia czaru. Tak wiƒôc mo≈ºna stwierdziƒá, ≈ºe czƒôsto powodzenie jakie≈õ akcji to po prostu loteria.

Co do skilli to jeszcze jedna dodatkowa informacja. Aby zdobyƒá nowe, trzeba znale≈∫ƒá nauczyciela, kt√≥ry nas tego nauczy. Nauczycie sƒÖ rozsiani po wielu miastach w kt√≥rych siƒô pojawimy. Do kupna tych skilli oczywi≈õcie wykorzystujemy zdobyte punktu.

Co jest najwa≈ºniejsze w grze poza rozwojem postaci i zag≈Çƒôbianiem siƒô w fabu≈Çƒô? Oczywi≈õcie walki. Te sƒÖ na prawdƒô klimatyczne. Podczas walk mamy planszƒô usianƒÖ heksami i to po nich poruszajƒÖ siƒô postaci. Oczywi≈õcie jak przysta≈Ço na prawdziwego cRPG walki sƒÖ bardzo rozbudowane. Ka≈ºda postaƒá ma inne bronie, inne wsp√≥≈Çczynniki ruchu, ataku itd. Postaƒá posiadajƒÖca w≈Ç√≥cznie mo≈ºne staƒá dwa pola od celu i jƒÖ zaatakowaƒá. Je≈ºeli miƒôdzy niƒÖ, a wrogiem stoi krasnolud to mo≈ºna atakowaƒá bo krasnolud jest niski. Je≈ºeli stoi tam cz≈Çowiek czy elf to ataku nie wykonamy. Podczas walk znajdziemy sporo interaktywnych rzeczy co dodaje fajnego smaczku. MogƒÖ to byƒá skrzynie, kt√≥re mo≈ºna wywalaƒá grodzƒÖc drogƒô sobie i przeciwnikom. Mo≈ºe to byƒá ≈õwiecznik, kt√≥ry mo≈ºemy spu≈õciƒá na wrog√≥w. Podczas jednej z pierwszej walk, musimy na cmentarzu zakryƒá otwory przez kt√≥re wy≈Çazi robactwo i nas atakuje. Podczas oblƒô≈ºenia miasta by≈Ço widaƒá wielki skrzydlaty cie≈Ñ krƒÖ≈ºƒÖcy po mapie. Tam gdzie siƒô zatrzyma≈Ç, w kolejnej turze spada≈Ç wielki g≈Çaz. Na mapie te≈º mo≈ºe pojawiƒá siƒô np. strumie≈Ñ. Postaƒá pr√≥bujƒÖca go przej≈õƒá mo≈ºe siƒô wywaliƒá (oczywi≈õcie od tego sƒÖ odpowiednie statystyki postaci) co oczywi≈õcie marnuje jej turƒô. Dziƒôki temu gracz mo≈ºe obudziƒá w sobie Sun Tzu i pokazaƒá jaki z niego jest taktyk, a dodatkowo ka≈ºda walka nie wyglƒÖda jak klon poprzedniej. Sama walka jest bardzo intuicyjna i mega przyjemna. Mapy same w sobie sƒÖ niedu≈ºe ale to nie jest ≈ºaden problem. Na dole ekranu widzimy kolejno≈õƒá w jakiej postaci bƒôdƒÖ wykonywaƒá sw√≥j ruch, a przy avatarach postaci widzimy na≈Ço≈ºone bonusy tak pozytywne jak i negatywne. Dodatkowy pasek skr√≥t√≥w, kt√≥ry mo≈ºemy ustawiaƒá wedle w≈Çasnego uznania jest ju≈º chyba standardem ale cieszy mnie to, ≈ºe tutaj ten standard zachowano. U≈Çatwia to dostƒôp do skilli oraz mikstur. KlikajƒÖc prawym przyciskiem myszy otrzymujemy menu na bazie ko≈Ça umo≈ºliwiajƒÖce odpalanie skill√≥w, atak√≥w, korzystanie z rzeczy umiejscowionych w pasie (bro≈Ñ rzucana, eliksiry, pu≈Çapki) postaci czy ko≈Ñczenia rudny. Bardzo fajna sprawa choƒá ka≈ºda ikonka wyglƒÖda tak podobnie, ≈ºe bywajƒÖ ma≈Ço czytelnie i te≈º trzeba siƒô do nich przyzwyczaiƒá.

Co do ekwipunku. Zbroje, topory, miecze, szable, zbroje zbierane w zestawy. No to oczywi≈õcie jest rozbudowane jak na prawdziwƒÖ grƒô cRPG przysta≈Ço. Chocia≈º jak na poczƒÖtku znalaz≈Çem dobry miecz dwurƒôczny to przez d≈Çu≈ºƒÖ czƒô≈õƒá gry nie znalaz≈Çem nic lepszego czy por√≥wnywalnego.

ReasumujƒÖc Blackguard jest grƒÖ solidnƒÖ i klimatycznƒÖ. Poziom skomplikowania mechanizmu mo≈ºe zniechƒôciƒá osoby, kt√≥re nigdy wcze≈õniej nie gra≈Çy w gry tego typu. Jednak je≈ºeli przetrzymajƒÖ pierwszƒÖ falƒô zniechƒôcenia to uka≈ºe im siƒô na prawdƒô ciekawa gra o intrygujƒÖcej fabule i wielu mo≈ºliwo≈õciach zarzƒÖdzania postaciami oraz walkami.

Wady:
- du≈ºa z≈Ço≈ºono≈õƒá kreowania postaci pozwala na tworzenie bardzo wyspecjalizowanych postaci
- klimat prawdziwego RPGa
- przyjemna grafika i d≈∫wiƒôki

Zalety:
- czasem opisy umiejƒôtno≈õci nie sƒÖ wystarczajƒÖce i cz≈Çowiek szuka w pomocy co one robiƒÖ lub po prostu je kupuje i testuje
- z≈Ço≈ºono≈õƒá mechanizm√≥w gry mo≈ºe zniechƒôciƒá niekt√≥rych

author: {'steamid': '76561197993011508', 'num_games_owned': 1324, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3313, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3241, 'last_played': 1458351917}
review:
I'm really surprised at some of the negative reviews that this game has received. 

I personally found the story to be interesting and engaging, it's dark in places and you need to get your hands dirty, but that's how Dark Eye fantasy generally is. One moment in particular seems to have turned some players off, I thought it was a brave decision by the developers, and I thought it worked well, a story should generate emotion, and this one did. It's not all grim and dark however, and the humour is very finely tuned in places. 

Turn based tactical games are a genre that I'm very much into, I play a lot of Chaos Reborn on a daily basis for the PvP side of it. Consequentially I often find that with story driven turn based tactical games that the PvE battles are a let-down, I don't think an AI can generally replicate the engagement that comes from playing against a human opponent. But I tell you what, Blackguards comes as close to it as I've ever found. There's a real wealth of variation in the battles that occur from; small skirmishes, arena fights, fighting withdraws, chase downs, there's all sorts. The developers of Blackguards have really gone out of their way to keep the fighting fresh. As a result this is one story driven turn based tactical game that I can see myself replaying. Just taken on their own the fights are a lot of fun.

I think the one caveat that I'd give is that this is a game where it's worth checking out what happens to certain characters in advance. I‚Äôm not going to give anyway any spoilers here, but making your party build based on that knowledge does make a difference to the overall effectiveness of your party by the end of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025298436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1466, 'last_played': 1458408380}
review:
Das Spiel wurde durch den Idioten verdorben, der die Gegner AI entwickelt hat. Diese ist unterentwickelt - dadurch mu√üten die Computergegner so stark gemecht werden, diese einfach und schnell den Kampf gewinnen.

ABER:
Wenn die Gegner jeden Kampf gewinnen, gibt es doch gar keinen Anreiz das Spiel  zu spielen?

Das stimmt, aber hier kommt nun der Zufall ins Spiel. Obwohl die Computergegner betr√ºgen k√∂nnen man gegen sie gewinnen - alles was macht braucht in ein Kampf bei dem der Zufall bessere "W√ºrfel" auf der eigenen Seite und (!) schlechte "W√ºrfel" auf der Computerseite hat.

Wenn beide Seiten gute "W√ºrfel" haben, dann verliert man - einfach weil die  Computer NPC so extrem st√§rker gemacht wurden als die Spieler figuren.  Von den 4 Konstellationen gewint also nur eine - das hei√üt das man K√§mpfe 10-30x durchspielen muss bis die richtige Konstellation da ist - dies gilt vor allem in den fr√ºhen Leveln wo man einfach zu schlecht ist, um den Kampf mit geschickten Aktionen zu gewinnen.

Das dies "suboptimal" ist, hat man wohl bei D. erkannt und "interaktive" Dinge in die Kampf-Map eingef√ºht, die die NPC etwas abbremsen k√∂nnen - FALLS diese zuf√§llig in der N√§he stehen - klappt also relativ selten. Selberverst√§ndlich werden diese Elemente nicht erkl√§rt und man braucht einen Kampfversuch (von den 10-30 die sowieso n√∂tig sind) um rauszufinden, was das "Ding" nun macht.

Ich h√§tte nie gedacht, eine negative Rezension f√ºr ein DSA Spiel abzugeben aber es ist einfach zu schlecht umgesetzt - zu Spielbeginn ist es einfach zu langweilig dauernd den Kampf neustarten zu m√ºssen (einfach weil schon in der 1 Kampfrunde die h√§lfte deiner NPCs nicht getroffen haben, w√§hrend der Gegner (die immer in √úberzahl sind) alle Treffer gelandet haben und dabei sogar einige Crits dabei waren.

Ich hoffe D. investiert mehr Zeit in die Entwicklung der Computer AI so das die K√§mpfe nicht durch "Betr√ºgen" des Computers spannend gemacht werden M√úSSEN.

Setzen, Sechs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002229374', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1456536185}
review:
Ich habe mit Blackguards 2 angefangen und danach erst blackguards zugelegt.das alles bei einem steam sale.ich la√ü von diesem spiel zuvor in diversen pc magazinen.ich bin total erwartungsfrei an die sache ran.definitiv mag ich spiele dieser art!blackguards wurde so zu sowas wie eine hassliebe.g√§be es einen mitteldaumen,w√ºrde ich diesen sofort benutzen f√ºr blackguards.es ist weder ein gutes noch ein schlechtes spiel.es unterh√§lt und ist f√ºr den salepreis absolut ok.nur f√§llt mir schwer zu glauben das daf√ºr auch mal eine ordentliche summe (vollpreis) daf√ºr verlangt wurde.da bin ich sehr froh dar√ºber ihn nicht gezahlt zu haben,den vollen preis!es ist schwierig den titel jemand wirklich zu empfehelen,bzw einer spielergruppe.ich sage,das muss jeder f√ºr sich selbst rausfindn!ich hatte definitiv unterhaltene stunden mit diesem spiel,nur motiviert es mich soo gar nicht,es wenigstens durchgespielt zu haben.ich stecke aktuell mittendrin,spiele es alle paar wochen mal f√ºr 1-2h und dann reichts mir auch schon wieder.ich glaube auch nicht an einen gewissen twist,das es pl√∂tzlich so fahrt aufnimmt,damit ich es ja durchspielen m√∂chte/muss.aber das hat eh kaum in spiel in den letzten jahren.das letzte das mir wirklich das gef√ºhl gegeben hat es durchspilen zu m√ºssen war bei mir bioshock2.metro2033 muss ich auch dazu z√§hlen.wir sind definitiv in einer multiplayerzeit.es gibt leider kaum noch gute soloplayer spiele.und wenn ein spiel solo kommt,sollte es bei mir wenigstens die wirkung haben es durchspielen zu m√ºssen.hier leider nicht der fall.
ABER,ich kann f√ºr mich festhalten,das der erste teil mir sogar besser gefiel,als der zweite!

Fazit:ist nett,macht vieles richtig,fesselt aber nicht!im sale kann man es sich gerne zulegen ohnme einen euro zu verschwenden,man sollte aber nicht hoffen die offenbarung in seiner gaming history zu erleben.....

author: {'steamid': '76561198015154719', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1458088011}
review:
After playing the game for ten hours I can see why it has such mixed reviews. I wouldn't recommend it based off of my standards for games but others might still find it enjoyable.

Cons
Terrible story ( Confusing, presents a lot of questions but gives few answers. Main character seems like a loser)
Flat characters, characters seem to blurt out whatever is in their head instead of talking to each other
Plot twists are in poor taste (They come of as 'we did this to you because we can')
Somewhat steep learning curve when it comes to training your characters
Weapon system seems biased in the sense that there is little to no benefit to pick x over y in any scenerio
Game consistantly pushes you back to square one by taking your gear/characters away from you and forcing you to fight at a severe disadvantage

Pros
Characters are customizable in their fighting style, although non mages have a limited non passive special talent selection.
Difficult (although for the wrong reasons imo)
Tactical turnbased game
Bug free from what I have seen.

If you are a diehard fan of tactical turn based games and do not care about story elements then this game might interest you. I would recommend watching youtube videos first before committing or wait for it to go on sale.

Overall rating 6/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198052465212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1457824685}
review: I can't say I like this game. The story is somewhat nice. I like RPGs in which you begin as an outlaw, unimportant nobody. Though very soon the story turned out to be generic and unappealing. The settings seems totally boring. You don't seem to really travel in an open world. The first town you appera in is not really a town, it's just one screen where you click four vendors. What a joke. I like where the combat tactic element is going so far, but overall I don't feel like playing this game again.

review: I tried really hard to like this game. If there was a way to skip AI moves, it would be lots of fun. The AI can litarly take up to 10 second to complete their turn. So this game gets a thumbs down because some levels have over 10 AI. No game should make a player wait over a minute to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993590517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1457307503}
review:
Save yourself.  Plays like a mediocre browser game.

I'd been back and forth on Blackguards since it came out and finally took the plunge.  After a scarce hour or two of play, with wonky "cinematic" interruptions, weirdly paced combat, and absolutely awful dialog, I just had to put it down and "delete local files."

Gameplay seems to be more about picking battlefields from a world map menu than anything. 

Just... no.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971077885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 1840, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 857, 'last_played': 1457175456}
review:
Tja, was soll man dazu sagen....man muss schon ein eingefleischter DSA Fan sein, um das Spiel mit Begeisterung zu spielen.
Gef√ºhlte 50% verbringt man im Loading screen...bei jedem Ortswechsel...das nervt bereits nach den ersten 4-5 K√§mpfen.
Auch in Mathe muss hier nachgebessert werden...man heilt nen Char (der noch 5LP hat) mit 20 Punkten, er wird mit 17 Punkten getroffen...und sinkt dann leblos mit -2 LP zu Boden...WTF? Das ist das kleine ein mal eins!!! Wenn man eine Leertaste dr√ºcken kann, dann sollte man das doch beherrschen, oder?
Leider ists damit noch nicht genug...die Steuerung ist ein Alptraum. Man kann die Sicht auf dem Schlachtfeld nur zoomen, aber nicht drehen...was √ºbel ist, wenn man einen Gegner angreifen will, der z.B. hinter einer S√§ule steht, oder von einem Teammitglied verdeckt ist. Fehlangriffe sind da obligatorisch und k√∂nnen √ºber den Ausgang des Kampfes entscheiden...was imo nicht passieren sollte. 
Und dann die Zauber...mal klappen sie, mal nicht...das ist dem DSA Regelwerk geschuldet und f√ºr mich soweit auch v√∂llig ok....ABER....mal kann man sie auf eigene Member anwenden...und manchmal klappt das einfach nicht...warum weiss kein Mensch....Mana ist da...Entfernung ist nicht zu weit...der Char kann seinen Zug machen...trotzdem geht es nicht....

Mit einem Wort...das Game ist einfach BUGGY...und da es schon √§lter ist, wird sich daran auch nichts mehr √§ndern... 

Wer Games wie Dragon Age, oder Elder Scrolls gew√∂hnt ist, der sollte tunlichst die Finger von Blackguard lassen...

author: {'steamid': '76561198089257610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 19691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13409, 'last_played': 1486011510}
review:
I wasn't sure what to review this game, but I thought a thumbs down would get the attention this comment merits as an OG gamer.  The biggest problem is that the harder settings make experience points go down and the mission harder...  breaking the standard expectation of harder missions and more experience that I wanted.  I don't want to go through on uber hard mode and end up with a nerfed character.  

I suppose the other problem, and if you're thinking balancing trouble is the deal with the criticism, I know, I've thought of that, the problem is that you're pigeon holed into one kind of min/max or maybe two if you want to beat the game on hard.  This, to me, is not acceptable, lol.

But, also, not that the difficulty setting thing means that, when you finally have to switch back to normal to kill the gators with your incorrectly min/maxed character build, you might have to make the disgusting decision to set it to easy...  which I know a lot of gamers like me just cannot fathom, lol.

I suppose this brings me to another failure of modern gaming...  it's not like and can grind out another level in the middle of the story, which I would love to do rather than abandon my character... but why nerf my powers when I have it on hard, really...

author: {'steamid': '76561198043671770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 83, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 83, 'last_played': 1456952226}
review:
I think that this game can best be compared to playing chess.  Chess is often a slow game and to play it you have to think.  Sometimes you have to put several minutes of thought into a move before making it.  This game is like that but you have to put a fair amount of time and thought into almost EVERY move that you make.  When I was younger, I liked chess a great deal and I probably would have liked this game more.  But I havent played chess in years and find this game to be agonizingly slow to play.   The graphics are fairly decent, the voice acting is ok, the combat IA is pretty good but its just way too dang slow!  Im glad that I got it on sale for 3.99.  I may come back to it and play it some more on a rainy day sometime but probably not.  Actually, I havent played 2 hours yet.  I should just get a refund...

PS: BTW, I put "no" for this game based on whether or not I would recomend it to myself.  Nope!  But folks who like turn based games should go for it.  They would probably enjoy it very much.

review:
I enjoyed it, though without a background in this particular DnD set (TDE) I'd suggest the balance is a little out of whack.  You'll likely need some internet research (and there isn't too much out there) to make any progress.  It's more about tactical combat than a "proper" RPG, so know what you are getting into.

Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002633455', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3750, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1939, 'last_played': 1485462395}
review:
This is great fun, and particularly recommended if you're looking for a less daunting, more linear story-driven turn-based RPG. 

It's perfect for busy people who perhaps have less time for too-open and deep an experience:
 
- Fairly linear, especially for the first half of the game (it opens out a little in Chapter 3, but even here it is still really just about having some choice about what order you do the quests and fights).
- Great story, with a central mystery, and lots of believable twists and turns; it takes you to lots of interesting locations and has you meet a range of engaging characters.  
- Good voice acting nearly throughout - only a few weaker performances. The main heroes and villains are all voiced very well. 
- Some great characters, such as Zuraban, the womanising socialite, Niam, the drug-addicted lost soul or the gold-loving dwarf. These may be fantasy archetypes, but the interaction between them often takes you to new territory, and is often funny. 
- Fairly deep (but not TOO complicated!) skill tree and leveling up system.  
- Good turn-based combat, and challenging if played on Hard. 

The only criticism I have so far is that there seem to be just a few areas that are a little unpolished - for example, you can skill up you 'traps' detection and disarming ability, only to discover that there is no actual mechanic to allow you to disarm traps. And yes, I've searched the forums! In the end, there are other ways around it, so it's no biggie!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974417125', 'num_games_owned': 118, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3235, 'last_played': 1456580175}
review:
Firstly let me say I'm a big fan of RPGs but I'd never really played a turn based one until Blackguards. My first impression was that I'll get bored playing this very quickly, but they change the dynamics of the battles throughout the game so it's often not as straightforward as killing all the mobs. 

The overall mechanics of the game are very familiar. Collect experience (action points) and use it to buy upgrades to your character. The battles are all turn based so you essentially get a number of action points per turn with which to move your character and perform a single action. Not being used to this type of game I wasn't too sure I would  like it but I ended up really enjoying it.

The graphics are pretty nice, not spectacular, but nice, The voice acting is a little ropey but doesn't spoil the game.

Overall I really enjoyed the game and would recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003132759', 'num_games_owned': 1573, 'num_reviews': 185, 'playtime_forever': 341, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 328, 'last_played': 1456620451}
review:
Some decent ideas let down by painfully bad design. The writing and voice acting are decent, and there are some interesting RPG concepts, but the game is centred around an unbalanced combat system. 

It is so heavily dependant on RNG, and yet many battles are determined by a few key actions - fail the RNG on those, and you may as well re-start the battle. As such, it simply becomes a frustrating exercise in repetition and luck.

There may be some good content here, but it's trapped behind some ill-considered mechanics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013278787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3025, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2886, 'last_played': 1456356493}
review:
Bought it in a sale, fought through the weird leveling system (well, if you're a fan of "the dark eye", then you may like it) and wondered about all the different equipments, which you don't need.

BUT:
All in all I would say it was a fun game!
- Story is okay, even if the plot is a bit... well, don't spoiler here.
- NPC companions are funny and maybe the best part of the game.
- You can have fun in the battles. Some of them are easy or straight forward, but it's okay, while other battles will be challenging though. It's a good mix in my opinion.
- Music, sound and speakers are good (played it in german, not sure how it is in english). I liked them.

I think I can recommend the game, though I would wait for a sale to buy it. If you like "the dark eye" you'll feel comfortable with the system, others will have a bit confusing beginning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045512373', 'num_games_owned': 1318, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1270, 'last_played': 1454598789}
review:
A frustrating, boring mess. This is very hard on new players hoping to learn the genre, and will sit you through painfully tedious repeats of battle scenarios and loading earlier saves if you're not experienced or running through without a guide. It actively discourages tactical creativity and I've found through number-crunching that statistically, some spells and approaches to the game are just far better and blatantly optimal than others. Want to play this RPG forging your own path and using your own strategies? Good luck. Play the "meta" way or start praying. 
Beyong that, the plot, characters and voice acting are all sub-par and uninspired. All I can give praise to are the environments and animations, which look great but don't exactly generate fun on their own. 

I really tried to like this game with 20+ hours of playthrough. I'd hoped I would find the fun in all that time, but sadly I didn't.

author: {'steamid': '76561198228194212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 307, 'last_played': 1524435814}
review: This is for those die-hard fantasy gamers. It has some DnD elements that just makes the inner-nerd happy and superb voice acting. The characters are fun and the story is decent. Combat-wise it's annoying missing attacks that have a 70%+ chance of hitting and this happens a lot. It's also a bit of an adjustment constantly preparing your ammo and healing your characters before each battle since they don't just regenerate fully or have unlimited ammo by themselves. Overall a good game, not worth the price but is a must-have when it goes on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970330814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 249, 'playtime_forever': 2834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2769, 'last_played': 1444928838}
review:
Absolutely great game. Hard as sin too! Some missions I was moments away from quitting but about a few attempts I'd do it. That is satisfaction!

Both a blessing and curse there too making you fight 3 missions in a row. Personally I dont like that being sprung on me because I am time sensitive. If I sit down to play a mission I expect it to take me maybe half an hour so thats what I expect and I really dont want to put up with extreme late nights or the wife nagging because of this. Sure, I could turn it off and use some self control but I expect the games studios to help me out and understand, games are addictive and we want to complete you! 

Loved this TBS. Great story, travelling was new and there was little in this game that was in any way wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974446177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 710, 'last_played': 1454981028}
review: This games had so much potential to be magnifiscent. I liked the graphics, I liked the game mechanics, I felt the voices were well acted and I was excited to get my characters leveled up....but it came to an abrupt halt when my crew got jumped by about 5-6 bounty hunters who beat my guys down before we could really get a shot off.  I couldn't go off and level my guys up any more, I couldn't rest before the second fight started...and I tried several times to get through.  I mean, if I were able to beat half the guys and the other half got me I would think it was just a matter of tactics.  Not the case, I'm afraid.  I want to like this game SO BAD, but I can't.  :(

author: {'steamid': '76561198074048760', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2518, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2457, 'last_played': 1454883018}
review:
**Not worth the full asking price, still bugged after 2 years, achievements that are impossible to get and various game breaking flaws even in the main campaign**

-

This game is like... Being stuck with a Dungeon Master that won't adapt to anything you do, and force you to continue on the path it set for you- even if you don't like it.

Usually, when I play a T-RPG, I'll find something that work, blast through the story once to get the pacing right, and then play it again in a harder mode and take my time. Well... it is not possible in this game, and to tell the truth, the story isn't good enough to justify that I ever finish it. 

Let me tell you : You'll not get it right on your first try. 
The game will take away things you put a lot of effort into without you having a say in it.
You'll have to start the game over, or read a guide to make sure you plan your characters correctly. 
You'll have to use these damn consumable I hate to use, put your points in these damn debuff I hate to use.

In short, if you like to play your own way or feel strong, this game is not for you.
If your the kind that like to find the optimal builds, and don't mind a few bugs, buy it for under $10.

=> 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198001316637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1627, 'last_played': 1427611044}
review:
Let me preface this by saying this game is definitely not for everyone. The story is terrible imo, and there is lack of documentation about the ruleset within the game. So good luck if you mess up your build early in the game (some talents and spells are useless). But, if you can get around those two factors, there is a nice TBRPG here.

  Blackguards strength is easily its combat. Difficulty of encounters is not determined by the number of enemies nor the amount of hp they have but by the types of enemies and the environmental hazards on the map. Hell, even increasing the difficulty actually makes the AI smarter instead of having cheap mechanics like OHKOs.

  For a first time RPG developer, Daedalic did a suprisingly good job. Unfortunately, Daedelic didn't just decide to make a better Blackguards 1 when making the sequel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117765588', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 5314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5043, 'last_played': 1453780198}
review:
SUMMARY: 8 stars out of 10.  A solid and highly enjoyable RPG!

PROLOGUE: I show as having 88 hours playing this game, as of this review.  I probably actually was playing for 80 hours of that, for ONE playthrough. I am methodical and slow, so most of you whippersnappers who like to cut to the chase will likely finish in 40 hours or less.  I saw a lot of complaints about this game having spikes of frustratingly high difficulty, so I played the EASY/NOVICE setting, which I believe gives more Adventure Points (AP) than the other settings.  In retrospect, I can understand the complaints; but I never had that problem, maybe because of the easy setting, maybe for the most part because I pushed off what I suspected would be the tougher fights until I had more skills under my party's belts.  I ended the game with 1300 ducats (enough to ditch EVERYTHING the party needed and buy it all back again), lots of poisons, potions, provisions, projectiles, traps, and other stuff I never seemed to have the need to use.  I used one potion, and that in the second to last battle.  Perhaps on NORMAL difficulty I would have needed more...

REVIEW:  This game has a main storyline which is fairly linear, but the available sidequests (and locations they open) make it feel less so.  The RPG character development system is versatile and refreshing: You can mold your characters by earning and using AP to buy levels in any of a myriad of basic traits, talents, weapon talents, special abilities, and (for magic users) spells.  You get AP by fighting battles and completing quests.  You do not get enough AP to turn your characters into super heros; but, if you do most of the sidequests, you will get enough to make them excellent in their chosen specialty (magic, melee, ranged) and solid in a second specialty and/or support.  One word of caution: this is not the game for those who want to destroy waves of hapless foes with giant fire or frost balls.  Using magic to buff teammates (and/or debuff enemies) will carry the day. 

There are approximately 180 fights available in the game, for those who wish to seek them all out, with plenty of tactical variety and some light "in-fight" puzzle solving.  In all but a few cases, the game clues you in to what is needed to make a fight easier.  For those few where they fall short, there is the internet: I used it about six times.  There were about three fights I elected to replay because I failed or did not like the outcome.  All in all, I found the combat to be satisfying.

Some have complained of running out of ammo (the shops do not re-stock arrows and bolts); but I ran two archers and one crossbow, and did not come close to running out.  I think someone relied too heavily on "triple shot" and "rain of arrows," which skills none of my characters learned.

The storyline is nothing to write home about; and the ending cutscenes/wrap-up is lackluster.  But the character voice acting, approriate interjection of humor, and plot intrigue that is played out was, in my opinion, quite well done.

Replay value is modest.  The plot twists and intrigue are a lot of what pulled me along the first time.  Your party characters are a mandatory set of (up to) five characters, only one of which you get to roll from scratch, and even HIM not entirely (name, gender and appearance are all set for you).  After almost 90 hours on record for my first run, another one (this time on NORMAL) will have to wait until I am up for it.  But, for the pittance I paid for the game (got it on a deep, DEEP discount), one run was overwhemingly worth the price!

EPILOGUE / HINTS (which some might consider slightly spoilerish, but I will not give away plot.)
-- Screw the game's advice:  Roll your own character from scratch the first time.  It is almost impossible to fail if you buy in as a magic user and start him out good at SOMETHING.
-- Take magic, unless you are dead set on a heavy melee fighter.  the 500 AP cost might seem like a lot, but it is a pittance over the course of the game, compared to the advantages it gives.
-- Continuing this line of thought, a dedicated heavy melee fighter is probably not the best choice, as you will eventually end up having two excellent ones foisted upon you.  You will be much better served with a magic buffer/healer who is good at bows.
-- All your magic users should be good with staffs, or possibly daggers.
-- Study spells carefully before trying to achieve high ranks in them.  For most spells, level 4 is not worth the cost.
-- Hammer Blow (HB), coupled with level 3 "Standfast Catlike" buff is OP.
-- The level 3 buff "Move like Lightning" (or some name llike that) is OP.
-- A fighter simultaneously buffed with level 3 Lightning and Standfast, and also using HB, is beyond OP for most fights.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022079241', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 445, 'playtime_forever': 4416, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4113, 'last_played': 1484513918}
review:
Pour appr√©cier Blackguards il faut accepter et aimer les points suivants :

 * C'est un tactical-RPG (jeu-de-r√¥le tactique) m√¢tin√© d'ambiance narrative point n'click (le studio Daedalic √©tant un sp√©cialiste). Le jeu est donc ax√© sur les combats, en plateau et tour par tour.
* On suit une aventure bien √©crite et interpr√©t√©e (voix anglaises raffin√©es) qui se d√©roule d'elle m√™me, sur rail. C'est le piment de l'intrigue qui pr√©vaut sur la libert√©. Il n'y a pas de libert√© dans Blackguards si ce n'est quelques choix accessoires ou...
* La sp√©cialisation / mont√©e des personnages touffue.
* La gestion millim√©tr√©e de l'√©quipe de persos.
* Une difficult√© au rendez-vous, et une aventure cons√©quente.
* Un d√©placement sur plateau/carte de jeu et √©crans fixes (ambiance point n'click).
* Une direction artistique relev√©e. 
* Une certaine nostalgie des jeux √† l'ancienne.

Mais si cette liste vous excite, c'est que Blackguards vous attend.

Personnellement, j'ai tout aim√©. Le doublage de haute vol√©e, pour qui go√ªte la subtilit√© de la v.o anglaise, y fait beaucoup. On appr√©ciera √©galement le fait de pouvoir faire des sessions de jeux courtes (un combat ou deux avant de reprendre la vie r√©elle). 

Quelques hics... mais tr√®s peu.

Le d√©marrage est assez long; c'est une histoire et un gameplay qui prennent leur temps √† se r√©v√©ler. Soyez patient(e), car √ßa en vaut la peine. Le prologue est plus long qu'il ne semble mais entrer dans le trip s'av√®re gratifiant.
L'Oeil Noir, univers de base (dans lequel d'autres softs proposent des baroudes, en RPG ou point n'click) n'est pas tr√®s accessible aux novices, ce qui est dommage. De fait, seuls les vieux briscards ayant pratiqu√© ce jeu-de-r√¥le reconna√Ætront des lieux et divinit√©s d'Aventurie. Les nouveaux se capteront pas grand-chose √† ces r√©f√©rences, qui ne sont pas du tout explicit√©es. C'est un peu dommage.
Enfin, il faut accepter d'√©voluer dans un jeu sur le mode √©cran fixe / √©cran de chargement / plateau de combat / √©cran de chargement...

Pour ma part, je le recommande chaudement, ainsi que le 2, qui reprend les m√™mes personnages.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030744400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1453529121}
review: Just so much failure in this game. I really wanted to like it, but it just does so many things just wrong. Everything is ridiculously expensive, there is zero immersion. For example my guys all have crappy torches, and we have had crappy torches for well over an hour, killing guys with axes and swords. When we defeat said guys, you'd think we get a sword right? NOP! Still stuck with the crappy torches! And still can't afford 1 crappy hand axe, which the game seems to value at 13 gold! These developers are clueless at both medieval history and game balance (a hand axe would NEVER cost anywhere that much) !  Oh, and then the game wants to kill gigantic troll with your crap weapons! It's like the game is trolling you! I didn't even mention that almost everything to do in this game can just fail as it does nothing and waste your turn. It seems the way the developers want you to  get through this game is to save scum your way through, just hope you hit the all the monsters all the time and load if you don't! How fun!  This game is just a package of false promises that ends in dashed hopes and shame; just stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980328361', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 2337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1669857143}
review:
Great graphics, good dialogue.  Decent story.  Great skill selection.  

Two things ruin it for me: 

1. Not able to customise keys. (I have a disability and use a trackball which has no wheelso there is no way for me to change the camera angle.  Minor issue.)
2. Difficulty.  The current trend of overly-difficult games is at work here.  I have zero interset in searching forums for tips or reading an online manual to tell me how to play.  Doing homework is not fun.  Games I can pick up and play are fun. So, this game is not fun.  If you are a "gamer" who likes doing research maybe this is for you.
3.  Spell failure percentage is WAY too high.  low level spellcasters are useless.
4.  When restarting a battle, there is no way to switch weapons.  Why on earth do some battles begin with enemies on top of you and others across the screen?
5.  Swamp apes using battle tactics?  Wth?  They're dumb.  They charge, not wait smartly just out of bow range for you to advance and then get a free attack.  Come on.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970278929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 854, 'last_played': 1453239027}
review:
My favourite part of this game was replaying the same battle 50 times because a spell fails even with a "93%" chance of succeeding, and without a perfect turn you just get ground into the dirt (I'm looking at you lizards and your crystal).  

You are RNG's bitch and this game will punish you with near constant spell fails and a brutal difficulty curve.

Divinity Original Sin is a better game in every single respect.  Play that instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147485569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 5511, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5418, 'last_played': 1463685674}
review:
[h1]Blackguards Review[/h1]
[b] Overall Score: 6/10 [/b]

[u] Storyline: (1/2) [/u]
+ Fun dialogues to read between characters.
- Bad storyline (I don't see it going anywhere besides a basic story of the advanture itself).

[u] Graphics: (2/2) [/u]
+ Well designed character models and gears.
+ Good looking battle maps and towns.

[u] Sounds: (2/2) [/u]
+ Voices matching the characters.
+ Good sounds in battlemaps and overall.

[u] Gameplay: (3/4) [/u]
+ Easy and basic training progress to let you understand the game rules and mechanics.
+ Main and Side Quests (Each quest is intresting because it gives rewards and you never know who the enemy is and how many there are).
+ Visit each town and meet Blacksmiths/Healers/Merchants etc.. (Inventory/cash is usefull)
- Difficulties: It's good to have 3 level of difficulties but we need to understand the difference between each one because it feels hard even on Easy for a new player in Blackguards.

[u] RolePlay Elements: (4/7) [/u]
+ Different Classes (Hunter/Mage/Fighter)
+ Rich variety of equippment (Weapons/Armor Sets/Items to use on A.I/self/enemy)
+ Happy Mage (A full page of spells only for the mage)
- Special Moves for other characters (You're able to unlock them with a trainer.. But I'm reaching 15 hours and I still haven't found this 'trainer' yet.
+ Talents : A sweet bonus in this game which let you upgrade each talent form level 1 to 5 and give you it's special effect [see below]
*Knockdown resistance *Animals/Humans stats detector *Healing Effect * Traps detector and more...
+- Stats : There are good sides and bad sides about the stats because in one hand you can match the stats to your liking
if you want a spellcaster archer or a dual wielding warrior but if you don't know what you upgrade to your character you might have a weaker character than you've expected.
- Equippment stats are a bit clumsy.
- Upgrade Points: It takes more time than it should be for a player to think about where to invest his upgrade points.

[u] Combat: (4/5) [/u]
+ Each combat is exciting and makes you eager for the next one.
+ Basic turn-based combat rules/moves but more challenging then other TB games.
+ Usefull Objects : You can throw weapons on the enemy, use/disable traps , use battle objects to move them around or use them against the enemy. You can even hide in the bush from the enemy.
+ Satisfaction : For those 100% players, you will re-do the battle until you get it done the best way you want it to be.
- Frustration : In some battles I felt like my characters are over powered by the enemy. Had to re-try multiply times in different tactics.

To sum it up, I'm enjoying my new Turn Based experience with Blackguards.
It offers an addictive experience throughout the game so I recommend on trying this game if you're an experienced TB gamer.
Don't bother playing this if you're more of a classic TB gamer who doesn't want to focus much on character's stats and RPG elements that might confuse you along the way.

You're more than welcome to also check my screenshots for this game [link below] to see what this game has to offer.
http://steamcommunity.com/id/xDMikeW2k14/screenshots/?appid=249650&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=imagewall

Enjoyment: (6/10)
Repetetive: (2/10)
Replayability (8/10)
Frustraiton (5/10)
Boredom (5/10)

[b]Overall Score: 6/10[/b]
* Skip it.
** Not Recommended.
[i][b][h1]*** Give It A Try.[/h1][/b][/i]
**** Recommended On Sale.
****** Recommended On Full Price.
Thanks for reading.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014750752', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1452693763}
review:
Start the game with two-handed sword fighter, realise everything except one-handed bashing is literally useless because that's all the game is scripted to give you.

Struggle and get to the mission where you have to rescue the Baroness, realise it's literally impossible and just try to finish by killing the enemies.

First few rounds are spent trial and error restarting to figure out there's invisible traps, and you need to start the round with a spell that has a 45% chance to destroy the boxes and set enemies on fire.

First try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Second try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Third try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Fourth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Fifth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, fail 45% chance spell, restart.

Sixth try: Slowly skip through cutscene, wait for enemies to move, 45% chance spell works, dwarf decides to move through 2 hexes of fire rather than one losing 20 health, take two critical hits from archer, in the end only dwarf left with 2hp and archer enemy with 22hp. Dwarf power attacks archer, deals 18 damage, archer attacks dwarf, deals 4 damage.

Stop playing. Look at achivement stats, only a quarter of people finished Chapter 1. I wonder why.
