author: {'steamid': '76561198060647227', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2062, 'last_played': 1423004670}
review:
Blackguards est un jeu difficile d'entr√©e.
J'ai bien failli abandonner d√©s les premiers affrontements tant ils m'ont paru difficiles. pourtant le syst√®me de combat et les interactions avec l'environnement m'ont s√©duits et j'ai donc persist√©. Maintenant j'y trouve plus de plaisir.

Le concept est simple : une √©quipe de combattants, des adversaires, un √©quipement minimaliste et en avant il faut gagner le combat. Parfois la condition de vistoire n'est pas (seulement) de massacrer tout le monde.

C'est un jeu tactique, il ne s'agis pas de bourriner √† grand coups d'√©p√©e et de sorts th√©√¢traux. Il faut utiliser l'environement, d'abriter organiser les comp√©tences de chaque personnage etc.

J'ai lu une critique ou le joueur disait qu'il avait parfois l'impression que pour gagner il devais trouver la solution de chaque tableau qu'il n'y avait pas de place √† diff√©rentes tactiques. C'est un peu vrai, sur certains terrains j'ai eu presque le sentiments d'avoir un puzzle √† r√©soudre.

L'histoire est suffisamment int√©ressante pour qu'on la suive, mais ce n'est pas un jeu narratif et les choix n'impactent pas l'histoire. Jusque l√† j'ai perdu un personnage suite √† une conversation (et je ne suis m√™me pas s√ªr √† 100% que ce soit li√©) et c'est √† peu pr√™t le seul √©v√©nement qui d√©coule de mes actes. 

Ne comptez pas non plus avoir des √©quipements absurdes qui vous font dire "Hey regarde mon perso, ces √©paulettes d'1m50 ont la classe!". Tout est sobre. Personnellement j'appr√©cie et c'est rafra√Æchissant.

L'√©volution des personnage est particuli√®re. pas de classe parfaitement d√©finie. Tout le monde peut aprendre √† manier toutes les armes et la magie. Du coup √ßa peut para√Ætre brouillon. Personnellement j'aime cette libert√© m√™me si au final un mage restera un mage et on ne fera pas de notre guerrier un lanceur de sorts.

Pour conclure, Blackguards est un jeu tactique, de strat√©gie qui parfois tire sur le puzzle. C'est sobre, l'arbre de comp√©tences offre une grande libert√© sans limitation par des classes.

J'ai d√©plor√© le fait qu'on se d√©place de combats en combats et en villes sur une carte mais finalement c'est accessoire. 

Un bon jeu, r√©serv√© √† ceux qui veulent des challenges tactiques. Et qui n'ont pas peur de recommencer un combat plusieurs fois d'affiler avant de le r√©ussir.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009004334', 'num_games_owned': 1017, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 876, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 876, 'last_played': 1422819227}
review:
Blackguards has issues. As an avid fan of turn based games, this is severely lacking. Inconsistency is the biggest flaw. The game is seemingly okay for the first few battles however soon after, it quickly becomes a reload and try again, 12-20 times. Go to a prior save, make adjustments and try again. Too often, for instance, my mage character with 80% and above chance to heal fails, too often failure to use the environment will make a battle impossible. Too often your characters will miss leaving foes drooling at another chance to make you reload.
I had high hopes for the game. The menus are not great, the story is rather drab, but it only felt horrible when every map because a reload the game fest. If you're looking for turn based... I HIGHLY suggest looking elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044218087', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4730, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4369, 'last_played': 1473382478}
review:
Fast h√§tte ich, aufgrund der vielen negativen Rezesionen, hier, als auch in der einen oder anderen Spielezeitschrift, dieses wunderbare Spiel nicht kennen gelernt.

Wer Aktionrollenspiele mag und sich mit jedem Sieg eine dicke Belohnung erwartet, wird sicherlich entt√§uscht sein. Auch der 'echte' Rollenspieler, der auf eine richtig tiefgr√ºndige Geschichte hofft, wird in Blackquards nicht finden was er sucht, denn all das will dieses Spiel wohl gar nicht sein. Vielmehr ist es eben ein Spiel mit Schwerpunkt auf strategische, rundenbasierende K√§mpfe, eingebettet in einen solide erz√§hlten Hintergrund mit der einen oder anderen M√∂glichkeit, Einfluss auf den Spielverlauf zu nehmen. 

Man findet sich wieder, in der wunderbaren Welt des Pen & Paper Rollenspiels 'Das schwarze Auge' die in Ihrem Detailreichtum und ihrer Vielschichtigkeit hier nat√ºrlich nur h√∂chstens ansatzweise dargestellt werden kann. Dennoch erh√§lt man einen kleinen Einblick, ... mehr eine Ahnung... , was man vers√§umt wenn man 'DSA' nie wirkich gespielt hat.

Die Charakt√§re sind klassisch. Soll heissen, der Zwerg ist ein Zwerg und verh√§lt sich auch so. Manch einer mag dies negativ, vorhersebar und langweilig finden, ich hatte meine Freude daran und w√§re √ºber alles Andere entt√§uscht gewesen. Auch wenn die Dialoge in den Zwischensequenzen oft nicht die Auswahl bieten die man sich w√ºnscht, so musste ich doch oft √ºber die eine oder andere Antwort meiner Protagonisten schmunzeln. 

Die M√∂glichkeiten zur Charakterentwicklung wirken auf den ersten Blick recht un√ºbersichtlich, doch wenn man einmal das Regelwerk und damit das Kampfsytem verstanden hat, offenbart sich einem die Logik dahinter. Hat man sich dann entschieden, welche Entwicklung der Charakter nehmen soll, ist es aus meiner Sicht kaum noch m√∂glich, die gewonnenen Abenteuerpunkte falsch zu verteilen. Auch verringert man durch die richtige Punkteverteilung das so oft kritisierte 'Zufallsprinzip' im Verlaufe des Spieles drastisch. Ein unge√ºbter K√§mpfer trifft eben seltener als ein ge√ºbter und selbst ein versierter Magier macht hin und wieder einen Fehler. Ich betrachte dies als durchaus realistisch. Zudem erh√§lt es die Spannung, solange es sich in halbwegs glaubw√ºdige Grenzen h√§lt.

Die K√§mpfe selbst sind, wie man sie von einem rundenbasierenden Spiel kennt und erwartet. Oft er√∂ffnen sich M√∂glichkeiten, die Gegebenheiten des Kampfplatzes und die verschiedenen F√§higkeiten seiner Helden effektiv zu nutzen. Auch muss man hin und wieder den einen oder anderen Schalter oder Hebel bet√§tigen, um weiter zu kommen. Nicht immer erkennt man dies alles auf Anhieb, deshalb ist oftmaliges Speichern selbstredend Pflicht.

Um nun nicht nochmals zu wiederholen, was meine Vorg√§nger schon in oft vortrefflicher Weise geschildert haben komme ich nun zum Fazit:

Blackquards ist ein empfehlenswertes Spiel mit Schwerpunkt auf  rundenbasierende, strategische K√§mpfe. Der 'Rest' ist ein gelungenes, teils sehr liebevoll gestaltetes Ambiente.

Die Charakterentwicklung und das Kampfsytem muss man verstehen um wirklich Spass am Spiel zu haben, ein Blick in's 'Handbuch' mag da eventuell hilfreich sein.

Als negativ empfand ich die etwas lieblos gestaltete Endsequenz und die Tatsache, dass der eine oder andere Ausspruch meiner Helden sich in, auf Dauer recht enervierende Weise, all zu oft wiederholte.

Alles in Allem eine klare Kaufempfehlung. Ich werde Blackquards sicher noch eimal Spielen, denn laut meiner Statistik ist mir doch eine ganze Menge entgangen. Auch auf Blackquards 2 werfe ich schon seit geraumer Zeit ein wohlwollendes Auge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995870321', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4889, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4726, 'last_played': 1422118424}
review: I really liked this game. Fans of xcom won't find it too hard. Make your character an archer/healer since there really isn't another one in the game. For everyone else, specialize, specialize, specialize... Just like any RPG. Lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104951146', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6669, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6326, 'last_played': 1422531408}
review: I havent had this much fun playing a rpg tactics game since XCOM and Wasteland 2. Story line and voice acting is superb. Gameplay can be quite hard, I had to restart a few times to get my character build right.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976362847', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1422506343}
review:
Im going to continue this game because I enjoy it..

But the god. damn. rng. fuck.

Oh what's that?  85% chance to hit?  You miss 3 turns in a row.  Your character is suppose to be a dodgeing machine?  Every enemy hits them.

It's shit like this..  Battles are basically a crapshoot for how it goes, % to hit means nothing.  I've been parried on a 95% chance to hit.  Reaallllyyy frustrating, the developers did a shit job with the combat RNG.

Story seems interesting though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137611607', 'num_games_owned': 823, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2447, 'last_played': 1491089507}
review:
It was one of my favorite games in recent years.
But i can't stand the massive amount of bugs still not fixed so long after release, including in game bugs like dozens achievements not working.
Blackguards 2 just released with day 1 patch fixing game breaking bugs. Seriously?
Adding to all that, that the devs are well known douchebags i had no choice but to give this game a negative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026319810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 451, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1594412706}
review:
Qu'est ce que Blackguards ?

Eh bien :

- Vous prenez un jeu de la s√©rie Drakensang
- Vous enlevez toute la partie exploration isom√©trique dans des villes et paysages en 3D pour rajouter √† la place une superbe interface digne des derniers jeux flash que l'on peut trouver sur armorgames ou zebest3000.
- Et vous enlevez tous ces autres d√©tails qui font le charme d'un bon jeu de r√¥le : la collecte d'ingr√©dients, le craft, les PNJ √† profusion etc... 

Vous obtenez Blackguards !

Franchement, autant j'adorais les jeux de r√¥le au tour √† tour (King's Bounty, Heroes of Might and Magic, Dofus... enfin c'√©tait avant l'arriv√©e de la version 2 !), autant ce jeu a fini de me d√©go√ªter de ce genre !

Ah oui, j'oubliais, pour compenser le manque de contenu, vous rajoutez une grosse difficult√©, hmmm... de la bonne grosse difficult√© bien frustrante !

Je n'y ai jou√© "que" 4 heures, mais c'√©tait 4 heures de pure souffrance... Vous passez des premiers niveaux tranquille, mais vous ne vous rendez pas compte que vous √™tes entrain de monter dans la petite camionnette blanche et que vous allez vous faire ... au bout de 2 heures de jeu ! 

Car oui ! Plus vous allez avancer dans ce jeu, plus vous allez tomber sur de l'irr√©alisable, des niveaux d'une difficult√©... atroce !

Sans rigoler... Trouvez-vous cela normal que dans un niveau, en plus d'avoir une quinzaine de monstres √† vaincre (avec 3 personnages...), il y ait des stalactites qui tombent al√©atoirement dans un ou plusieurs hexagones, et ce tous les tours, et qui vous tuent en un coup si par malheur, ils touchent l'un de vos personnages ? J'ai r√©ussi ce niveau √† la 3√®me tentative, mais c'√©tait uniquement avec de la chance !

J'ai carr√©ment abandonn√© √† un niveau o√π il fallait sauver une baronne... Infaisable ! Il faut en 5 tours √©liminer (toujours avec 3 personnages...) 6 hommes de main, qui sont √† l'autre bout du terrain entrain de vous cribler de fl√®ches... et bien entendu, le pont qu'il faut traverser pour venir sur eux est rempli de pi√®ges invisibles qui vous font sauter un tour : Evidemment !

Mention sp√©ciale aux doubleurs (le jeu est en VOST) : Les dialogues et leur voix ne collent absolument pas avec l'ambiance h√©ro√Øque-fantasy du jeu ! (Entre le h√©ros principal qui dit "bastard" quand il se fait taper et l'autre PNJ qui te sort des mots anglo-am√©ricano-espagnol...)

author: {'steamid': '76561197983929314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 9713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4294, 'last_played': 1504269370}
review:
Bought this on sale, i would say about 40 hours of turn based combat. Perhaps a bit more if you do all side quests and struggle on some fights like i did.

Its not an easy game and there will be battles you will have to do more then a few times to win. The story is a bit linear and battles can be considered a bit repetitive, the bugs with quests seemed fixed since i finished all of them.

But overal i really enjoyed this game and would rate it 75/100.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964214568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 887, 'last_played': 1391451617}
review: If you played the old Fallout series, Divinity and all these round based RPGs and loved them - you will love this game as well. You have a good story and you can literally play for hours without getting bored. Since the game is out since quite a while and it is not that expensive anymore, definitly buy it. For that money you can go watch a movie in the cinema or have endless fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013328690', 'num_games_owned': 680, 'num_reviews': 259, 'playtime_forever': 2176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1956, 'last_played': 1422287099}
review:
Great audio-visual-design, lot's of love when it comes even to small details.
The amazing DSA-ruleset, which is for the RPG-players that love to build their chars and favor depth.
The story is mature, so are chars, yes course there's your usual fantasy-cliche, but there's enough darker, more grown up char-interaction. The english voice-over is amazing and engaging.
Many critics just complain about one fact:
missing spells or attacks

those critics spread a lot of missinformation and if your interested you might want to delv deeper into gamemechanics, the DSA rule-set has shown it's amazing depth already on countless PC-games (Drakensang, the old DSA-trilogy) and some forget nowadays how RPGs can work.
In short
-> under the right circumstance a wizard/witch might fumble his spell
-> rolling a hit (which is symbolized by your hitchance, e.g. 95%) doesn't euqal actualy hittin, your target can still parry, dodge, mitigate the damage...which goes also for your party

All in all Blackguards is a love letter for RPGs fans: deep char-customization, not ur usual "white knightish"-cast, great tactical combat and the list goes on.

must buy

author: {'steamid': '76561197970681902', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 859, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 778, 'last_played': 1426178138}
review: Un buon gioco, ma sottovalutato. La storia √® buona, la grafica √® godibile e il gameplay √® tutto sommato abbastanza originale rispetto alla maggior parte dei gdr moderni. Tra i contro spiccano alcuni combattimenti veramente frustranti, impossibili da portare a termine se non si sono sviluppati i personaggi in uno dei pochi modi corretti. Questo perch√© i punti necessari a sbloccare nuove abilit√† e migliorare i propri personaggi sono pochi, e spesso ci si trova in situazioni in cui tutto l'arsenale accumulato nel corso dell'avventura viene tolto al giocatore (laddove non vengono tolti direttamente i personaggi fino ad allora utilizzati). Per il resto √® davvero un ottimo gdr.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002532000', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 393, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 393, 'last_played': 1422044778}
review:
BLACKGUARDS! 
Wonderful features such as: 
-EXCLUSIVE SUPPORT FOR 16:9 ratio screens, anything else has massive letterbox black bars that ruin immersion!
-Total lack of a 360 degree camera - the visuals might be 3d, but every battle-screen and town is locked to one camera angle!
-Really bad itemization! I made my character a 2-handed sword focused warrior. Turns out 2-handed swords don't exist in the loot tables until the second act (1-2 hours in), holy shit!
-No exploration whatsoever, anywhere that isn't a 2d city is a 2d battle or a load screen. NOTHING IN-BETWEEN.


The only draw of this game is that you play as a group of misfits and bad guys. Except you don't really play as bad guys or misfits at all - in fact, it seems very standard for a fantasy RPG. You are thrown into the utterly predictable universe of The Dark Eye - a German sort of more boring, more cliche version of the already awful pastiche the English world knows as "Forgotten Realms." The entire concept of this game was that you play as the baddies, a somewhat refreshing idea on the extremely tired fantasy adventure. Except you don't - at all. Your character - get ready - wakes up in a prison cell after being tortured, and goes on a mission of revenge against the EVIL badguy with the EVIL artifact. Holy shit, how original. You spend most of your time doing stupid quests like rescuing a damsel in distress and healing the sick. Sorry, what was the title of this game again? Oh, Blackguards? Wait really?

Prepare for a long adventure of boring RNG-decided battles, random and arbitrary interactable objects, and extremely slow loot progression! Repetitive cities, awful dialogue, poor voice acting, and the same 5 load screens 400 times a session. Prepare to reload your game over and over again as your sound strategy falls apart as your heroes miss consistently despite an 85% chance to hit and your mages fizzle their spells due to the shitty standard build that the developers gave them!

I don't even know what else to say about this game. It's an embarassment and a total waste of money. Luckily I got it as part of an inexpensive humble bundle, otherwise I'd be a bit more frustrated. Goddamnit just don't buy it. And probably don't buy the second one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022179413', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 8912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4325, 'last_played': 1634588600}
review:

-Story mit einigen Wendungen 08/10

-Die Hauptcharaktere (besonders die Begleiter) sind sehr sympathisch 9/10

-Die Welt ist sehr sch√∂n gestaltet und verspr√ºht ne menge Charm 8/10

Macht insgesamt 61/80 Punkten was umgerechnet 7,625 also abgerundet 7,6/10 sind.

Insgesamt gesehen kann ich dieses Spiel jedem empfehlen.

review:
Blackguards est un tr√®s bon tactical-RPG. Tr√®s TRES complet, immersif et pas trop d√©gueulasse visuellement.

J'y ai jou√© deux heures et j'ai l'impression de n'avoir qu'effleur√© la surface de ce que peut offrir le jeu tactiquement parlant. Il nous offre des possibilit√©s diff√©rentes √† chaque ar√®ne, qui poss√®dent chacune son lot de pi√®ges et d'√©l√©ments int√©ractifs en tout genre.

L√† o√π le b√¢t blesse, c'est justement au niveau de la lenteur de progression compl√®tement hallucinante, pour am√©liorer un personnage comme vous le voulez attendez vous √† devoir grinder un bon paquet d'heures. Il y a √©galement quelques probl√®mes de lisibilit√© et des statistiques pas toujours justes.

Enfin, si ces quelques √©l√©ments m'ont fait arr√™ter (aussi et surtout parce que je n'√©tais pas tr√®s motiv√© de base), ne vous d√©trompez pas on a quand m√™me affaire √† un tr√®s bon jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014447387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3298, 'last_played': 1494695855}
review:
I got this game during the humble bundle that was put up a few months ago, so I'm writing this review accordingly. In other words, if I had bought this game at the full price tag of $39.99, I'd probably be more inclined to hit "Not Recommended". But on sale, I think it's a good game that will definitely keep you playing for a couple of hours at a time if you don't have high standards of character. That being said, you will probably not be interested enough to keep playing this on a binge where you spend hours on end.

The tactics style gameplay is pretty neato. That's... about all I can say about that part of the game. It doesn't really add anything to it or really borrow from some more advanced takes on it like XCOM: You've got area-of-effect attacks, you've to melee attacks, you've got ranged attacks. Don't expect to have any innovative takes on cover-combat, field of vision, and so on. 

The characters are decent. Not really involved enough that I'd say I particularly cared about any of them one way or another, but not bland enough that I wasn't at least interested in seeing where they fit in the story. The character you kind of play as doesn't seem to really have a major stance on anything minus how you decide to direct his dialogue, but it's one of those games where you're kind of your own guy and you kind of aren't. 

There's a lot of good side quests here and there that you are definitely going to want to do to keep yourself armed and leveled for the main questline.
As for the main questline itself, there's really nothing that much to it. The game tries to differentiate itself from other RPG-style adventure games by having the cast of characters be completely unlikely heroes. You, the main character, find yourself traveling with two fellows (a stereotypical and somewhat superstitious dwarf and a casanova mage) who collectively break out of a prison. From there, your party's membership includes a drug-addict elf whose pretty good with a bow (I think she's an elf at least. She's got the ears), a tribal dude who was ready to kick your ass before, and a childhood friend who ended up becoming an (alleged) nymphomaniac witch. 
This seems like an interesting premise on the surface, but the game doesn't really apply itself that well. We don't really get much in on the character's pasts, and the interactions with the main character and the story are very limited. For a game that could've very well built onto a unique premise worthy enough of it being a constantly talked about title, the developers didn't really do much to apply themselves here, and I'm afraid that might still be the case for the sequel, Blackguards 2 as well (I haven't played it yet, so I won't judge).

So basically, this game is good if it's on a really, really good sale and you're already into fantasy and tactical games, but aren't looking for anything too innovative on either ends.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999130881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 2052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2052, 'last_played': 1406136750}
review:
There are bunch of reasons I won't going to recommend this game, it's playble and good at some sides, but: 
Some time ago when it came out it was unfairly overpriced and bugged. Time is passed bugs may be fixed but price are still unfair, but you can avoid it during sales and discounts. 
Also it's almost linear and you don't have any real or illusory freedom, optional side quests are mostly required to be completed, otherwise you are going to suck hard without your extra XP and loot, are they really optional?
RPG system and combat touching for a first time, but in the middle of the game you are getting extremely bored of nothing new and doing the same things till the end of the game, watching the storyline which can give some fresh feelings. Personalities of your teammates can give a fresh air too, but it's not enought to be impressed for such a price.
There are not so many useful charcter builds that can help you to variate your game, time would pass and you would realise a few efficient builds to play through game and after that you won't want to replay it at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053070206', 'num_games_owned': 9975, 'num_reviews': 267, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1561705845}
review:
This game have too much variables that it's confusing.
It really is a hard game because of that. You have to consider every step carefully. One wrong move and you can end up GAME OVER. Always save your game after battles.
Characters attribute vary through Base Values, Weapon Talents, Talents, Spells, and Special Abilities.
The environment also play a huge role in the battlefield.

As for the story this game, it's a plain linear story, not like what I expected from Daedalic Entertainment.
They usually managed to pull out a great plot but not with this game.

Well, I recommend this game if you're up to challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960746459', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 2404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2037, 'last_played': 1422601054}
review: A well done, to-the-point turn based combat game.  Solid strategic battles with just enough exploration and story to keep you going.  Combat objectives vary a fair amount to keep the battles interesting.  Would definitely recommend

author: {'steamid': '76561198028931964', 'num_games_owned': 5373, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 919, 'last_played': 1421673992}
review: I like Daedalic games, especially adventures, but I cannot recommend this one. The game is not so bad per se, but there are much better games in the similar genre. Battle is too dependent on RNG, and the story is just fantasy cliche and is very linear. If you want to play interesting RPG/TBS combo, you better try Expeditions: Conquistador - it's cheaper and more interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993025077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2744, 'last_played': 1421781285}
review: Incerdibly annoying game. Tends to cheat whenever it can. I suppose the game's dice-rolling system might be a bit f.cked up. It's very frustrating that any slomo zombie can outrun almost any of my heroes, and the enemy's self healing is somewhat miraculous as well. Makes no sense to reduce the spellcasting chances of higher level spells either since any casting chance under 90% is hopeless. (Not to mention the hit chance with weapons.) The game is average in itself but way below expectations because of these 'rules'. Would not recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968254063', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1388715969}
review: My brother gave me this game or I wouldn't have gotten it. I am not a fan of strategy RPGs as it slows down the combat so much. Honestly, that held me back from liking any of it as combat is such a focus. Also, the pie-UI was a bit difficult to read.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994089799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 3189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3014, 'last_played': 1430227072}
review:
Un ottimo gioco di ruolo a turni su griglia esagonale in cui controllerete fino a 5 personaggi. Uno sar√† il vostro main, che vi consiglio caldamente di crearvi da soli e altri 4 saranno dei compagni che troverete durante la trama. Il sistema di combattimento √® molto divertente e bench√© non sia immediato capire le regole, con un minimo di lettura del regolamento fornito dalle info in gioco √® possibile capire tutto anche se non si conosce il gioco cartaceo su cui si basa.

√à incentrato al 90% sui combattimenti e la storia √® ridotta all'osso. Anche girare in citt√† √® visualizzato tutto a schema di dove volete andare a con quali png potete parlare. Un ottimo punto a favore se siete in cerca di botte e solo le nozioni chiave che vi servono per proseguire con la trama, cos√¨ come pu√≤ essere un punto a sfavore se volete trama deepshit impegnativa. In quest'ultimo caso, semplicemente, non cercatevi un rpg occidentale. 

Punto di forza √® l'uso del campo di battaglia e la strategia che si dovr√† utilizzare e che varier√† per ogni diverso scenario. A difficolt√† normale gi√† d√† del filo da torcere e capiter√† di dover ricaricare saltuariamente.
Consigliato l'acquisto, se vi soddisfano i punti specificati sopra e una 40ina-50ina ore di gioco per meno di 10 euro se lo comprate dai giusti reseller ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197961745037', 'num_games_owned': 1872, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1421743026}
review: There is a LOT of good here... but the bad casts long shadows... sadly, the equipment seems very convoluted, everything is just kind of... loosely bound together, and the story is very slow to get going, along with being a little... unengaging. I really want to love it, but I can't give it more than a... 6.5/10. The equipment system is just so ill explained. With quite a few hours in, I STILL don't under what equipment is better and how. I got it as part of a bundle so take this review for what its worth. I probably paid about $1 for this game and I'm still kind of... meh, about it. BUT I'm holding out hope, still putting time into it, maybe it'll hook me soon...

author: {'steamid': '76561197993029077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 440, 'last_played': 1421623780}
review:
With the popularity of Dark Souls at the moment, difficulty seems to be the buzzword of the industry. This can be a great boon and imbues games with a sense of accomplishment and worth when done correctly. Blackguards seems difficult for all the wrong reasons, from an obtuse user interface to mindbogglingly poorly designed stats pages. 
While I appreciate that any game coming from an existing Pen and Paper world will always have a higher step up for the user than most, Shadowrun earlier last year seemed to create a system both faithful and functional while Blackguards seemed bogged down in it's own mechanics.
The story is about par for course and the voice acting is quite refreshing, but it just seems like the clunky mechanics just get in the way of that experience and the difficulty wildly differs so much you bound between feeling elated and cheated every few minutes.
While people howl off the rooftops at the percieved "dumbing down" of videogames, sometimes it has a point. Parts of the design feel snobbish, as if it wants to pat it's faithful on the back and tell them how smart and clever they are while with the other hand swatting away the "casual, filthy masses". Blackguards needs to get down of it's high horse and reduce the barriers to entry that stop it from being the good game I know underneath is has the potential to be.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038669516', 'num_games_owned': 1842, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 609, 'last_played': 1421529394}
review:
El juego es bastante entretenido, no tiene unos graficos impresionantes ni un sistema de combate muy dinamico pero lo compensa con una historia que, si bien no parece nada del otro mundo al inicio, consigue enganchar a medida que va progresando (lo cual no es extra√±o viniendo de Daedalic ya que son expertos en aventuras graficas y, por lo tanto, en contar historias).

Es un juego complicado al inicio, se nos van explicando todos los parametros de forma tediosa pero es mucho mejor aprender el sistema por uno mismo, esto es, jugando y jugando. Una vez avanza un poco el juego, obtenemos mas personajes para el grupo y tenemos algo de libertad nos aparece un mundo extenso, lleno de misiones secundarias y lugares que visitar (todo muy automatizado, eso si), siendo entonces cuando empieza a entretener.

Sin embargo, el motivo por el que me resigno a seguir jugandolo es solo uno: los bugs. Me he acabado cansando de repetir la misma mision una y otra vez porque aparece un bug que me la jode y me imposibilita poder continuarla. Hablo de estar durante un combate y, bugs de la camara aparte (que tambien lo hay pero se puede soportar), desaparecer un personaje repentinamente que provoca que no puedas mover al resto de tus guerreros y tengas que quedarte viendo como mueren... y eso repetidas veces en el mismo escenario, con distintos personajes y sin posibilidad de hacer nada.

Quitando esos fallos (que a estas alturas dudo que solucionen), el juego habria sido muy disfrutable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991888468', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2177, 'last_played': 1404346821}
review: This game got my attention with the hex grid and turn based strategy.  Interactive fighting environments brought tons of potential in being a great strategy game.  In the end this game fell short on every level.  It was a real bust.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074672646', 'num_games_owned': 6652, 'num_reviews': 596, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1419373836}
review:
[h1]Blackguards est un excellent jeu de r√¥le tactique dans le monde de L‚ÄôOeil Noir[/h1]

Face √† toutes les personnes qui ont jou√© des dizaines d‚Äôheures sur Blackguards, avec mes quelques heures, je fais largement clochard. Pourtant, cela ne m‚Äôemp√™che pas d‚Äôaimer ce jeu.

D√©j√†, il faut savoir que derri√®re Blackguards se trouve le studio allemand Daedalic. Ce studio est pass√© Ma√Ætre dans la cr√©ation des jeux d‚Äôaventure. Ils ont √† leur actif plusieurs s√©ries toutes aussi passionnantes les unes que les autres.

Ensuite, il faut savoir que Blackguards se d√©roule dans le monde de L‚ÄôOeil Noir. Tout le monde a entendu parl√© de ce jeu de r√¥le sorti pour la premi√®re fois, il y a quelques dizaines d‚Äôann√©es. C‚Äôest un monde stable et bien construit qui va servir de base solide pour ce jeu.

Pour commencer, sachez que vous devez cr√©er votre personnage, vous avez le choix entre trois classes : guerrier, magicien et archer. Mais avant de foncer, les deux personnages qui vous rejoindront au tout d√©but sont un guerrier et un magicien.

L‚Äôhistoire est bien, le graphisme est superbe, le jeu est bien construit, les possibilit√©s sont √©normes, bref, si vous aimez les jeux de r√¥le, n‚Äôh√©sitez pas, achetez Blackguards.

On peut signaler que la suite de ce jeu, Blackguards 2, sort mi-janvier 2015. Evidemment, le prix du premier √©pisode ne peut aller que vers le bas. Guettez les soldes ou r√©ductions occasionnelles.

[url=www.graal.fr/2014/12/26/test-blackguards-la-version-pour-steam/]Pour lire toutes mes impressions sur Blackguards[/url].

author: {'steamid': '76561198047210200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1421406660}
review:
I don't get it why its size is 17 GB, cause the graphics are far from sophisticated. And I don't get it why its price is so high, cause its gameplay is mediocre at best.

There's one basic, huge condition that could "make or break" when it comes to turn-based combats: don't let the random factor be too important. That's the same hugely important condition this game failes completely to fulfill. It says 95% yet it feel like 50, and when it says 90%... well, you'd better skip it, you're screwed anyway. Using the "try again" button a couple of times after some lost battles proved nothing but the fact that random is all that matters. Only based on random I nearly won, I clearly won, or I badly lost the very same battles. Only based on randomness, and not on the decisions I made. And that's simply not Ok.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986581714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1419016309}
review:
[b][Fran√ßais][/b] Ce jeu est propre et la m√©canique de combat est int√©ressante. Pour une personne qui recherche uniquement de la strat√©gie en tour par tour, il y a un potentiel v√©ritable.

Personnellement, je suis assez bon public en mati√®re de jeu. Toutefois, j'attache beaucoup d'importance √† l'aspect JDR. Je trouve que les combats ici sont trop r√©p√©titifs... Or c'est tout ce qu'il y a : des combats. Le mode op√©ratoire est : lecture / combat/ combat / ravitaillement / √©quipement /combat / lecture / combat / combat / Etc. J'ai √©t√© incapable de m'immerger dans l'univers et l'histoire du jeu. De plus, comme beaucoup d'autres l'ont indiqu√©, les pourcentages de r√©ussites des actions sont compl√®tement erron√©s, ce qui g√©n√®re une frustration √©norme et diminue grandement l'aspect strat√©gique.

Je n'ai r√©ussi √† jouer que 2 heures. Mon avis est donc tr√®s subjectif et correspond √† une v√©ritable difficult√© d'immersion et un sentiment de frustration et d'ennui apparu rapidement. Je pense qu'il faut avant tout rechercher du combat en tour par tour pour appr√©cier ce jeu, l'aspect JDR √©tant grandement minimis√©, selon moi.

[b][English][/b] This game is clean and the fighting mechanics are interesting. For people who seek only the turn-based strategy, there is a real potential.

Personally, I'm pretty good audience for games. However, I attach great importance to the RPG part. I find that the fighting here are too repetitive ... But this is all there is: fighting. The procedure is: read / fight / fight / shop / equipment / fight / read / fight / fight / Etc. I wasn't able to immerse myself in the universe and the history of the game. In addition, as many others have said, the percentages of shoot's success are completely erroneous, generating enormous frustration and greatly reducing the strategic aspect.

I have managed to play only 2 hours. So, my opinion is very subjective and corresponds to a real difficulty of immersion and a fast feeling of frustration and boredom . I think you must first seek the combat turn-based to enjoy this game, the RPG aspect being greatly minimized, in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052369785', 'num_games_owned': 117, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6855, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5815, 'last_played': 1707606080}
review:
[h1]Blackguards by Daedalic - A promising game with some annoying flaws[/h1]

I've spent 112 hours meticulously stripping down every area, every character and every side quest I could find during my first (and so far only) playthrough of this game. For the record, I'm a seasoned RPG-player and accustomed to the old-school turn based games.

Short version: Blkackguards is an average game which could have been a lot better without some of the bugs and a more intuitively developed story engine.

For those of you who remember the glory days of the genre with Baldur's Gate I and II, IceWind Dale amongst others, Blackguars might still be worth looking into. I enjoyed playing it, but I would also like to post a warning about some of things that knocked down the total score for me:

[olist]
[*]The main plot is... kinda slow. And dull. I actually enjoyed several of the side-quests a lot more than the main story. The ending is very dissapointing (and without giving any spoilers, that is an understatement). I also missed having background stories unfold for the main characters, but perhaps Daedalic are saving those for the sequel(?). 

[*]Several achievements are (still) bugged. 5 of them simply can't be completed at all (confirmed by the steam community) but I've had a total of 6-7 that bugged in my game. It's been more than a year since these bugs were first reported and the steam forums have had no response from the developers yet. Like I just mentioned above, they are currently developing a sequel to Blackguards, so chances are that these bugs might never be fixed. Hence: be warned if you're one of those players (like me) who wants to cross off every achievement from the list. For future reference: I have not bought or played the DLC. 

[*]Some of the game mechanics are not explained (at all) in the manual and I had to scavenge the steam forums to see if they actually worked or not. Armor is perhaps the most obvious aspect, where players have no way of telling if the armor skills makes any difference or if the character is encumbered (and if so, what penalties to expect in battles).

[*]An abundance of spells and skills makes things look very promising at first glance, but in reality, most of them are pretty much useless. Even when taking in account different preferations/play styles, at least 50% of the spells are likely to never be used by any player. Unfortunately, that goes for weapon types, talents and weapon skills as well. I can't shake the feeling that these worthless skills where put only there for marketing purposes rather than adding flavour to the game. It's either that, or Daedalic simply ran out of time/funds and had to release the game without proper (re)balancing tests.

[*]Although you are frequently presented with alternatives and choices in NPC dialogues, it rarely matters what you choose. I guess you could say that they are there to add some RP, but even so it could have been handled with more finesse. Instead you're bound to a main plot that you have no chance of altering the outcome of. 

[*]I really don't want to spoil anything for you, but a frequent bother is when the game removes one ore more of your followers (and sometimes even your main character) without warning. A new player might have to start from scratch halfway through the game. Hint: make sure that your main character is at least somewhat decent in ranged combat.

[*]The 20th time the game presents you with two choices where one gives you a handsome reward (typically the "evil" aligned choice) while the other leaves you empty handed you can't help but wonder why? Most players expect good deeds to add up to some kind of greater reward later on. In my personal opinion, this is perhaps the single biggest flaw Blackguards has, and it feels like the developers rushed the story instead of taking time to plot out great stories. Let me underline that I don't think that "good" alignment should be favoured in any way. The rewards doesn't have to be better gear or more gold, it could for example be new dialogues/NPC's that are unlocked at some point further down the line. For a game that relies so heavily on RPG stereotypes it's dissapointing that karma is pretty much non-existant in Blackguards, And yet, [i]sometimes[/i] the choices you make are actually so important that it could warrant starting over from the beginning. I would advice all new players to SAVE, SAVE and SAVE their game as often as possible. Think of Blackguards as a Bethesda title in that aspect.
[/olist]

With the bad stuff out of the way, let's round things up with the more positive aspects of Blackguards: 

it's an ambitious attempt at rebooting the genre (yes, I'm aware that there are several other similar games on the market nowdays) based on a popular tabletop theme. The graphics are decent and the voice acting is top notch.

Currently priced at ‚Ç¨39.99, I'd recommend potential customers to wait for one of the steam sales before buying. For that kind of money you'll likely to find plenty of better alternatives. Personally I bought it in a [url=http://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Daedalic%20Entertainment]Daedalic[/url] bundle and 120 hours of gameplay is more than I expect to get from most titles these days.

[b]All in all I'd score Blackguards a somewhere between 6 and 7 out of 10.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197967506964', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 405, 'last_played': 1420866165}
review:
Why do I keep buying games that use the TDE (Dark Eye) game rules?  They're ALWAYS SHIT.  ALWAYS.   Demonicon?  Shit.  Drakensang?  Shit.  Drakensang 2? Shit.  This game?  SHIT.   Whatever positives this turnbased rpg has, they're completely negated by the unrelenting terribleness of TDE as game rules.   

If you have no idea what I'm ranting about, imagine picking up Baldur's Gate 2 without ever playing D&D 2nd ed before.   What armor class is better?  What's a save vs. death compared to a save vs. spell?   Multiply all that by 3000x.  That's The Dark Eye.  

It was made by Germans who hate you.   And that's why.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989339658', 'num_games_owned': 1645, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1419630880}
review:
Overall it seemed like an interesting game.
The combat is what I dig for and the huge charactercustomization is just the thing I like.

But it pains me how the companion are handled.
Basically every other character than your main/self-created-one has predetermined stats, which cannot be reset.
So you're more or less stuck with what the game gives you, instead of developing the team that you want to play.
You can also lose companions midway through the game, for the sake of the story, which makes it even harder to have complete control over your team.

The story seems decent and the combat is okay, but It would have been better just giving us overall predetermined characters, included our starting one, and make it fit the overall game, if the story was that important.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960712217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1412843809}

author: {'steamid': '76561198051262673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1469, 'last_played': 1455061692}
review:
Zum Zeitpunkt meines Reviews bin ich mitten in Kapitel 2.

Blackguards z√§hle ich eher zu den Rundenbasierenden Strategiespielen mit sehr starken RPG Elementen.
Im Endeffekt ist es eine Aneinanderreihung verschiedener Kampfmissionen, w√§hrend dazwischen die Story vorangetrieben wird und man seine Chars ausr√ºsten und weiterentwickeln kann. Nebenquests m√ºnden in zus√§tzlichen Kampfmissionen.
Wer stark verzweigte Dialogoptionen erwartet, wird entt√§uscht werden. Der Schwerpunkt liegt ganz klar auf den K√§mpfen.

Ich selbst spiel das Game auf schwer und hab erst bei einer Mission knapp ein Dutzend Anl√§ufe gebraucht. (Eigener Char ist eine Kriegerin; normal mode Erstellung) Deshalb kann ich den Kritikpunkt bez√ºglich des zu hohen allgemeinen Schwierigkeitsgrades nicht nachvollziehen.

Ein Schl√ºsselpunkt zum Erfolg ist die Ausn√ºtzung der Map-Eigenschaften, wie Fallen, Pf√ºtzen, Kisten, etc... Hierbei ist allerdings anzumerken, dass diverse Wirkungsweisen am Anfang nicht klar ersichtlich sind und es einiges an Trial & Errror braucht. Ebenso sollte man sich die Missionsziele immer vor Augen halten, da APs durch erfolgreiches Abschlie√üen von Missionen erlangt werden.

-->Kritikpunkte bleiben f√ºr mich die etwas un√ºbersichtliche Darstellung der Itemeigenschaften. Hier braucht man ein bisschen Zeit um sich zurechtzufinden. 
-->Die Gegner-KI ist eher schwach, was manchmal zu fragw√ºrdigen Entscheidungen f√ºhrt. 
-->Die Berechnung der Trefferwahrscheinlichkeiten ist ab und an schwer nachzuvollziehen. Ich selbst hab es schon ein paar Mal erlebt, dass selbst eine 100%ige Trefferwahrscheinlichkeit zu einem Fehlangriff f√ºhrt. Ein Treffer kann des √∂fteren zwischen Erfolg und Misserfolg einer Mission entscheiden.
-->Auch ist das Spiel schon 2x zwischen Missionen einfach h√§ngen geblieben, was aufgrund der Autosave-Funktion nach jedem Kampf jetzt nicht so sehr in Frustmomenten gem√ºndet hat.
--> User Interface gef√§llt mir nur bedingt. Es ist schon so oft vorgekommen, dass sich mein "Heiler" selbst anstatt den verletzten Krieger geheilt hat. Alles, weil ich mit der rechten Maustaste auf den Heiler geklickt hab um den Zauber auszuw√§hlen. Ist man halt von anderen Games so gew√∂hnt.
--> Grafik erf√ºllt ihren Zweck. Wobei man ehrlich sagen muss, dass Neverwinter Nights 2 aus dem Jahre 2004 wahrscheinlich besser aussieht.
--> Die Synchronstimmen sind OK, wobei es sich manchmal sonderbar anh√∂rt, wenn von einem "M√ºtterchen" die Rede ist und diese mit einer s√ºssen mit-zwanziger Stimme tr√§llert. Die M√ºtterchen in diesem Zeitalter waren zwar schon jung, aber trotzdem... 

Ich spiele im Gegensatz zu ziemlich allen anderen meiner Games √ºbrigens auf deutsch. Deutsche Filme schaut man auch nicht auf Englisch, genauso verh√§lt es sich mit deutschen Games. Es geht doch einiges an Dialogwitz bei der Synchronisation verloren.

Wieso ich das Spiel trotzdem empfehle? Weil es mir Spass macht, und sich die Frustmomente in Grenzen halten. F√ºr "T√ºftler" wie mich, die sich f√ºr Spielz√ºge Zeit nehmen und etwas durchplanen ist das Spiel wirklich nett. Man freut sich einfach wenn ein Plan aufgeht. Selbst wenn er aufgrund verfehlter Angriffsaktionen 4 oder 5 Anl√§ufe gebraucht hat. Der Preis von knapp 40‚Ç¨ ist allerdings etwas happig, so ehrlich muss man sein.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075849015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 244, 'playtime_forever': 704, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 704, 'last_played': 1420753696}
review:
Divinity: Original Sin ..als ALPHA ..Grafikengine durch Standbilder ersetzt 
.. und alles viel schlechter (Bedienung, Story, Kampfsystem, usw..)

Bei weitem schlechtestes DSA Spiel seit langem:

-keine freie Welt, nur ca 200 Screens
-sehr linear
-Story ist Mittelma√ü, viele Klisch√©es
-sehr knackiger Einstieg!! die Bossk√§mpfe sind f√ºr Anf√§nger deutlich zu schwer auf "normal"
-pauschale EXP pro Karte
-der Loot ist mies
-Gute Waffen m√ºssen gekauft werden
-R√ºstungen, grad f√ºr Magier gibt es kaum (wird schwer die Sets zusammen zu bekommen) 
-Viele wichtige Trainer werdet ihr in den ersten Stunden nicht finden!
-Dementsprechend fehlen grad f√ºr die Begleiter einige Upgrades, weil ihr die EP nicht so investieren k√∂nnt wie ihr wollt ;(
-Absolute Katastrophe ist der Magier.. unbedingter RAT: alle Zauberspr√ºche bei Freier Charaktererstellung kaufen
-Magie insgesamt ist in den ersten Stunden fast unbenutzbar, inbesondere AoE.. zu hohe AP Kosten.. und daf√ºr zu wenig Bumms.. schlie√ülich ist man nach 2-3 Zaubern der Stufe 2 oder 3 leer (oom) .. ansonsten gibt es noch die %Castchance der Zauberspr√ºche.. selbst bei 60-70% fizzelt der Spruch 3/4 Mal.. dh euer Held/Begleiter verschwendet seinen kompletten ZUG f√ºr jawohl NIX!!
-Die K√§mpfe waren kaum besser als bei Schatten √ºber Riva.. nur eben HD.. eigentlich sogar schlechter, denn Riva hatte eine Handlung und es machte Spa√ü.. so vor 1-2Dekaden^^

FAZIT: Unterm Strich zerst√∂ren diese Fakten den fl√ºssigen Eindruck einer DSA Spielwelt im S√ºden
Das lineare System tut ein √úbriges.. denn wenn bestimmte Quests (Bosse t√∂ten) nicht erledigt werden, gehts nicht weiter!! Manche Bosse (zB Drache) kann man anfangs gar nicht besiegen.. und so zieht es sich fort.
Also noch 8-10Std spielt es sich dann wirklich wie ein Krampf.. nee danke, so nicht!

->Wird wohl l√§nger dauern bis wieder etwas √° la "Demonicon" kommt.. sehr schade ;(

author: {'steamid': '76561198067289563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5850, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5681, 'last_played': 1706147191}
review:
I really tried to like this game, in spite of reading very mixed reviews. Alas, I ended up quite frustrated with a few aspects that are quite game (and immersion) breaking:
1. losing vital companions at crucial times makes party build options very limited. Essentially, once you figure out what will happen to X, you need to rethink your entire strategy for party build. This sometimes means restarting from scratch, or a very earlier save, as party build is very important in some of the encounters (especially the main ones)
2. lack of clothing for non-metal wearing characters - while there are several pretty good sets of armour for warriors, the (complete) lack of mage oriented outfits is a bit mind baffling. I could not fathom that no mage outfits EVER dropped, although you battle many mages wearing unique outfits. And none can be bought. As a consequence, you mage characters have to either wear horrible looking leather armour, or spend a lot of time buffing/running/dying. This is also important for...
3. almost 100% spell failure when wearing metal armour. I can accept offensive spells (cast outward) failing, but having a healing/self-buff spell have a <25% of success is nonsense. So playing as a battle mage/arcane warrior/cleric type role is pretty much out of the question
4. tedious battles - which can go on for a long time, with a lot of time sitting, and staring at the screen while seemingly endless hordes of critters/monsters/lice/etc. go thought their turns. Even tentacles get their own turns, and usually have a higher initiative than your party...
5. endgame decision disasters - going back to #1 - at the end game you find out that you are 'supposed to' have made certain vital conversation decisions with one companion, otherwise they will be lost, which as mentioned before, can be a disaster for the party.

So, if you want to play this:
a) read the guides and build a cooky cutter type that the developers had in mind, and
b) follow a pro-forma discussion template to placate one party member, or lose them at a crucial stage (or build with their loss in mind)
c) have a good book/magazine handy to read during battles, as you otherwise stare at the screen waiting endlessly

Pity, had potential

author: {'steamid': '76561198000739473', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1420579459}
review:
I decided to give this game a go and said to myself "I'm gonna finish this one"...oh, how I was wrong. The world is interesting, but it gets lost when you fight very samey enemies all the time. Story could be interesting if characters wouldn't change their motivation every now and then, yet they keep being predictable. Also the world is very limited to a 1-3 screens per town.
Battles could be fun - the system has some neat ideas, enviroment has traps and cool strategic placements, but you very rarely get to use that, since you have to attack or you get surrounded and can't move. 

But the major flaw is that the game FEELS UNFAIR all the time (even when maybe it is not really). Instead of making battles interesting, the game more than once takes your whole inventory and offers you bad equipment in exchange, then you have to battle and find out that enemies in that arena are better equipped than you.
Attack chances are random at best  (a number like 90% chance don't mean anything in this game). Damage you inflict is always small unless your character has fully invested in one weapon skill (which I had to change for one character because it had the same setup as my main character and then spent many hours inflicting 3x less damage than the enemies). 
The whole unfairness also applies to experience point requirements - some skills seem very out of reach (I can see the options ahead, but what I can actually afford/choose is 1-2 options and get stuck with that for hours). "Special" attacks make very little difference most of the time and are in no way interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049245659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 2838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2752, 'last_played': 1420283948}
review:
Blackguards is an tactical turn-based RPG game that brings some new soultions and points of view to the table, that are not always good.

(New feature - Simple city interface.)
If you remember Drakensang, Dragon Age or most other RPGs cities, large, vast, many NPCs, a lot of chests to look and barrels to smash for loot. Nothing like that in Blackguards. City is a simple one screen view with most important NPCs, merchant, healer, trainer, quest giver, tavern, the end. If you have business in the city it takes you about a minute to get it done and leave to get back to action. Some might like it, some might not. I like it, as it saves time, no more need to remember where was that cool merchant or a hidden pass etc.

So you may wonder how does this tactical turn base combat looks like.
(Character summary)
Before we get there you must know that Blackguards are based on The Dark Eye RPG pen and paper system. And character development is very much like in the pen and paper game. If you played Drakensangs before you will be very familiar with the system. 
In most RPG games you have classes to select. There are no classes in this game. When creating character you select if you wanna be spell-casting able or not and then you build character on skills/spells you chose. In that this system is similar to Elder Scrolls. If you wanna be a warrior you can be a warrior, if you wanna be a warrior-priest you can be warrior-priest it's all based on how to chose your skills, not limited by class.
So characters have attribiutes that calculate their base stats like vitality, astral points (manna), base attack, dodge and parry. Attriubutes cost a lot of adventure points to raise. By chosing how to spend attribiutes you craft base for your character, if you invest heavy into strength, agility, courage and constitiution you will end up with a fighter with almost no chance to cast any spell. If you go for intuition, cleverness and charisma you will end up with solid base for mage with poor fighting abilities. You can also walk the path of average, but you must be careful and just select few spells and weapons to invest in those heavy.
Keep in mind that mages are limited by metalic armor - they will not regenerate astral points while wearing even a single piece of it and will have negative casting modifier, so a melee mage is a hard to play, but possible with correct spell investment.
Then are the skills. Skills are divided into weapons, talents (perception, traps etc) and spells. And in that game every weapon is another skills, so if your character is an expert swordsman (18 swordsmanship skill), when he will be forced to use an axe, he will be very poor with ti because he has no skill in axe, he will have very small chance to hit and large to be hit by enemies.
Skills make your characters use stuff. Skills are rated from 0-18. Spells and talents unlock bonusses at 8,13,18 levels. Here you choce which spells your character can cast and weapons to use.
At the end are special abilities - special attacks for melees, ranged and boosts for mages.
The better the special attack the harder it is to hit with it.
Original pen and paper game used three 20 side dices for skill tests, to make it computer game, devs changed that into % chance. So unlike dragon age it is not enough to unlock a spell to cast it, you must unlock the spell and invest points into it.
(Note on spells)
For me spells in this game are net design to be used mainly at blunt offensive magic. Spells play a support role in this game. You can cast offensive spells and they will do a lot of damage, however doing so will deplete your astral points in two shots so after your mage will not be able to do anything else than bash stuff with his staff.
(Note on weapons)
I really love games which make using axe different than using a sword for example. Blackguards is such a game.Every weapon type has it damage type (piercing for spears and fancing weapons, slashing for swords and blunt for maces). Every weapon type also uses a different skill. So if you wanna use few different weapons you must spend points on different skills. Different weapons also have different special attacks, you cannot make armor ignoring attack with maces, but you can make attack that tripples the damage with them.

(Combat)
Having explained the above. Combat is turn based in which your heros and enemies take their turns in order of initiative. On their turn everyone can move a little and make action (attack, cast spell, place trap, disarm trap, spot for traps, use item etc) or move further. You can hide behind objects or other heros to break line of sights of enemy archers to your mages as well, there is no other cover system.
Combat map is divided into small hexes for movement and there can be varius hazard spaces on the map like oil set on fire will deal you fire damage when you cross it, while mud can make your character fall down unless he passes bosy control test.
(Tactical combat)
By using combination on magic and physical attacks you must cripple and defeat enemies. Enemies will usually outnumber you as well and some of them will also cast spells, use healing potions and have special attacks. So this is where tactic comes into place. 
Use your melees to block enemies before they reach your mages, or run to enemy mage to bash on him. Use obejects on the map and magic walls to block enemy movement and shoot them directly. You have options.
Cast damage spells to finish fight quickly, or same astral points for buffing and healing magic.

(Plot - Story)
Unfortunately game story is quite linear and not really involving. Characters are a bit shallow and the only one who really feels realistic is the dwarf who is fun and really combat oriented.
At few points in the game you will be stripped of your gear and forced to make through with given equipment untill you can regain your stuff. So it is goot to invest a little into maces(as you will usually end up fighting with a torch or a club) and offensive magic.

(Flaws)
There are some flaws to the game:
-Horrible mouth work. Unlike other modern games, the speaking animations here are just horrible, you will see heros open mouth like fish trying to catch a breath, it has no connectiong with what is being spoken.
-Very bad equipment comparison system. There is no way to compare one set of armor with another other than noting down the stats, changing set and seeing new stats.
-I have really no idea what in this game make it be 20gb large.
-Game does little to introduce players who are new to the difficult character creating and developemtn system. [there is good help&tips in the menu if you can spend a moment to read and understand it]
-Not involving plot and shallow characters.
-Not intuitive UI.
-No crafting system.

(Merits)
+Realistic when it comes to weapons and armors. Armors comes in sets, so it is no longer find best pieces, but you need to wear a complete set of armor to have best benefits. And I like it that way.
+Deep and difficult tactical combat. I like the games that are not easy.
+Quick cities exploration.
+You are not limited when crafting your heros, you have a lot of freedom in systems without classes.

Overall I would give this game 7/10.
I hope most of the flaws will be corrected in the upcomming Blackguards 2.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995818965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 1684, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1478, 'last_played': 1420498114}

author: {'steamid': '76561198061500159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2253, 'last_played': 1420468579}
review:
Blackguards is a good game but has it's flaws. Mostly I had fun playing the game. 

- The difficulty of the game is quite easy at the begining but later on it becomes really annoying because mostly your enemies use spells that lower your move speed, attack chance and health. Also it will become quite impossible to fight your enemies if you don't finish all of the side quest.

- Interface/Combat  is excellent, but the controls are a little wonky and sometimes quite slow. There are some monsters that take up more than 1 hex ( places on the field) and it's hard to locate the spot to hit but it's not that bad that you will ruin your whole turn.

- Information is a little unclear  but after few hours you should figure it out.

- Loading screens. You will spend some time on loading screens.

- There is not much of different gear and weapons. Don't expect to find a lot of variety of great weapons, few of my characters had the same weapon from the 1-2 chapter to the end of the game. Also my wizards had the same clothes from the 1 chapter to the last part of the chapter 5.

- Opponents. There are a lot of different opponents and interesting ones. There are also opponents that are just frustrating you because they have have spells that lower everything (so yout hit chance isn't 95% but 45%) so they are hell to beat but when you beat them it's beautiful.

- Characters. All of the characters u play have different personalities that are unique. In some dialogues you can choose what your characters will say.

- Story. It's not a bad story at all and has some twists.

- Graphics. Some people might not care at all about graphics but I like it when the game I play has at least deacent graphics. The graphics are not that bad at all but when you talk to some people they will look totally different in the picture then they look in the game. 

- Playability it depends on what difficulty you choose to play but It will surely have around 40 hours (surely more).

- To conclude this review I recommend you buy this game but on sale. You will enjoy it and be frustrated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045180133', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1502758181}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035952520', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1420323293}
review:
Still too buggy!

Die Programmierer haben es leider nach all der bisherigen Zeit immer noch nicht geschafft, das Spiel fehlerfrei und spielbar zu programmieren. Leider kommt es zu oft zu freezes. Dies kann jederzeit vorkommen. Dadurch, dass man im Kampf nicht speichern kann, kann es zu frustrierenden Erlebnissen kommen, wenn nach 10 oder 20 min. Kampf pl√∂tzlich das Spiel einfriert und man es √ºber den taskmanager killen muss. Dann war der ganze Kampfverlauf umsonst gewesen und die Zeit wurde vergeudet. 

Demnach ist das Spiel leider nicht zu empfehlen, obwohl es f√ºr Fans des "schwarzen Auges " durchaus seinen Reiz h√§tte.

Wenn man bedenkt, dass die Verantwortlichen demn√§chst den zweiten Teil rausbringen, kann man dem Studio nur noch Verlust f√ºr so viel bisherige Unf√§higkeit und Verantwortungslosigkeit w√ºnschen - auf dass sie es mit "Gewalt" lernen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124845616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1441937734}
review: This is a great game.  I have been having alot of fun with it. I would love to give it a positive review; however, the constant freezes and crashes that cause me to have to reboot my PC are very frustrating. Usually, I can restart my PC and get further without another freeze or crash. However, most recently, I have gotten to a point that constantly freezes, not allowing me to progress further in the game.  If it were not for the bugs, this would be one of my most highly rated games. Looking at the forums, there are numerous similar reports. The devs keep asking each user to provide error logs, but you would think they would have more than enough information to correct the problem by now. I reallty want to give Blackguards 2 a try, but worry that it will be plagued with the same issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104368561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3362, 'last_played': 1412737335}
review:
Blackguards es un juego que realmente me gusto mucho (y termine). Lo que me apena es ver tantos analisis negativos cuando se lo podr√≠a considerar como un diamante en bruto. No voy a ir al detalle del juego ya que el mismo ya tiene mil analisis (literalmente) pero si quiero poner enfasis en lo siguiente: la primer parte del juego es muy dificil (pero muy) con el agravante de que el desarrollo de los personajes es complicado y no esta bien explicado. Pero, si se tiene paciencia y se superan las primeras horas de a poco se van abriendo posibilidades y vamos entendiendo que atributos sirven y cuales no, donde poner puntos y que es mejor obviar.
 
Muchos se quejan de que los porcentajes de acierto de golpes son inexactos y esto es cierto. No es inusual fallar varias tiradas seguidas con un porcentaje de 80% o mas. Pero de nuevo. A medida que el jeugo avanza y subimos nuestra accuracy esto empieza a pasar muchos menos

Algo que no vi mencionado en la gran mayoria de los analisis es la maestria con la que estan dise√±ados los escenarios. A diferencia de mucho juegos tacticos los escenarios tienen muchas veces participacion decisiva en el desenlace de un combate y es importante tenerlos en cuenta al planificar los mismos. No es facil y muchos son un verdadero reto pero superarlos realmente transmite una sensacion de satisfaccion que muy pocos juegos logran.

Para terminar. A los amantes de los juegos tacticos les recomendaria darle una oportunidad a este juego pero entiendo que toma tiempo (unas 5 horas al menos) comenzar a entender el sistema de combate y atributos pero una vez pasado eso el juego no hace sino mejorar. Otra cosa es casi obvio pero muchos creo que no lo recomiendan por esto: graben muy seguido. Algunos combates son brutales y no hay margen para el error. Es mejor volver media hora atras y ver que decisiones revisar en cuanto a distribucion de atributos o items comprar que empezar de cero o insultar porque el juego es dificil.

Una pena que los aspectos poco pulidos opaquen esta gema para tantos jugadores.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963643929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2000, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1997, 'last_played': 1420144324}
review:
This is a turn based tactics game where you control (after about 30 hours gameplay) up to 5 heroes who walk between nodes on a world map in a very linear way and follow a more or less entertaining story (At least I found some of the dialogue mildly enjoyable). Some nodes are cities where you may learn skills, buy equipment, and get/perform quests, other nodes are quest nodes that may sometimes be skipped. Most of the time is however spent in  hexagon based maps fighting various bad guys. 

The game has a lot of skills and stats that you may experiment with, but mostly it makes little difference what you chose to skill up (For spells any nuke will do, some early bosses are weak to fire, but it makes little difference for most enemies, a healing spell is pretty much required, you will alternate between those two and auto attacks for the whole game), and as most stats and skills are needed in the end anyway the customization adds little depth to a shallow game. 

The major problem with Blackguards is that fights are mostly based on luck. Want to attack someone? Well, usually you have a 90% chance to hit (not bad, but that's as good as it gets unless someone is knocked down), but if you use a more powerful attack it might drop down to 85%, 70%, or 60% (based on dodge stat vs dexterity I think), further reduced with wounds that are randomly obtained when taking damage (I think your to hit chance can potentially go all the way down to 30%). If you manage to hit at all the damage dealt is then further randomed in a fairly large spread, and rarely it will crit for double damage. The damage is fairly high, so 3-4 good attacks is enough to drop most enemies and heroes.
This means that missing more than a few attacks will result in one of your heroes getting knocked unconscious, and the enemies snowball from there.
It's typically the enemies who get the good dodge stats, so while your heroes will mostly take full damage from anything that attacks them late game, your heroes will miss, miss, miss,miss, and miss some more as you watch them slowly die in frustration. 

The game's "difficulty" slowly ramps up as you play. Every encounter is level (in)appropriate, so every fight is a challenge. Since spell damage is fixed your magic users slowly get weaker after their 2 main spells hit level 3. While this makes sense in a way you will never get to be satisfied with how much stronger your heroes have gotten. Enemies have about the same stats and skills and do about as much damage as the heroes do, so fights vary little in practise between various encounters.

The game could still be a mildly enjoyable grind with the above mentioned issues, but clearly the devs were obsessed with making the game into a never ending series of encounters by a power tripping DM trying to make your party lose.
I got through several unfair fights like Running past all the enemies who get to hit you for free for 6 turns to get to the girl before she's killed, shoot a giant tree with 150 hp to death with arrows that each do 1 dmg because it 2 shots everything in melee range, run through a basement filled with traps to get to the guy you need to kill before he gets away, kill the necromancer who's surrounded by unkillalbe skeletons that block your spells and arrows, and many many more. The straw that broke the camel's back for me was the fight against the tiger lilly where one of your heroes is turned against you, you have to run up to a plant that always has a 60% hit chance, is immune to magic damage, every turn one of your heroes is knocked down, and 5-6 tentacles you're not supposed to kill get to attack your heroes freely while blocking off healing spells you might want to cast on the hero being bullied.
I understand that something like this was necessary to make the game interesting, as the fights by themselves clearly aren't. With a different combat system these fights might have been fun, but in Blackguards you will just keep doing the right thing again and again untill it finally works and you get to go on. 

So, TL;DR: Turn based fights heavily based on luck, little customization in practise despite the wealth of options available, you get weaker as you keep on playing, and gimmicky fights where the devs metaphorically throw your miss chance and weakness in your face again and again by setting up scenarios that force you into doing stupid things over and over untill the RNG gods decide that you may finally pass. If it sounds like your cup of tea then you will probably enjoy Blackguards, but I did not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006191441', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1420051477}
review:
So I have only played this game for a few hours, but I think what I have learned already will not change throughout the course of the game.

Blackguards is a hard, challenging game, it is most certainly fun and the voice actors REALLY make this game a story to be part of, I simply love them. 
Now, don't get me wrong here, I'm all for % chances to hit, finding tactical ways to defeat the enemy and such, however I really resent the constant <70% chance to hit, and even at 70-90% I've had several times alredy where I do this action 3-4 times and each hit has missed (or failed)(not including piercing to skeletons etc.)
Therefor this game is very inconsistent in how any battle will turn out even by using the same movements and actions each time, and this kind of (almost) luck based combat makes Blackguards very hard to want to play again.

HOWEVER, I would recommend this game to anyone with the inclusion of this shortcoming.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998755666', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 3415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2740, 'last_played': 1419952498}
review:
First of all I want to say that I dont regret buying the game (discount) . 8 / 10

Pros:

- challenging

- good variety of battles (win conditions, interactive objects, environment, enemies)

- multiple ways to win battles depending on your party

- amusing dialogue

- not a single crash the whole time I played and no other bugs

- good length

Minor Cons:

- awkward character development / training and AP gain curve (the currency you improve your charaters with)

- small selection of armor (lets just say I didnt equip my 2 casters with new clothing until the last chapter)

- not many weapons either (many special spears, only 1 or 2  improved versions of other weapontypes)

Tipps & Tricks (light spoiler warning):
[spoiler] 
- do not rely heavily on the Niam character

- make sure your fighters are good with secondary blunt/slash weapon set (for skeletons and crystals)

- make use of the ability to delay your actions with a character by using the space-key (sometimes being the first to move is critical, but other times you want your enemies to move first, so you can move then and hit them

- dramatically increase your chances to hit enemies via wounding them, poisons, knock them down / incapacitate them, attack them with a weak character first so they lose their parade

- have a caster who can cast axxeleratus level 3

- poison your weapons before entering a hard battle (you dont want to waste a turn to poison your weapons in battle)

- use savegames to try out different spells if you have a lot of saved up AP, some are turds but others can really shine / decide a battle (the beserk one can be very good, lightning cloud too)

- get your casters best possible manaregen via gear / talents, maybe archery as a secondary profession
[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198062237876', 'num_games_owned': 4574, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 4150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4150, 'last_played': 1420141951}
review:
To be honest, I don't know where the mediocre ratings come from. I had huge amounts of fun with this game. Since update 1.3 you get all the combat feedback you need.
If you like turn-based strategy with a touch of RPG you owe it to yourself to give this a shot. The Dark Eye might lean more towards a generic fantasy setting, but I really like the European "style" and love the level system. You will probably have to get used to it, if you are unfamiliar with it, but it gives you great depth and customization opportunities. 

I for one, can't wait to get my hands on Blackguards 2 in 2015!

author: {'steamid': '76561198028694331', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4119, 'last_played': 1419808217}
review:
The real trill is to lose your companions in one moment for some (already scripted) story line.

The game is fiddly, full of unuseful choices and abilities (unless reaching the best level).

Annoying combat visual and commands, it's really difficult even to find the right point to click. Absurd.

Really poor level design, with some level with mandatory actions and skill to use, living the risk to lose your game if you didn't upgrade the right ability. Etc.

Played 'till the end to find the worst ending story ever (not even a real story nor ending).
