Blackgaurds is very fun and very challenging, great graphics, backgrounds, animations and story, and it is a long game with alot of sidequests.  9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046752837', 'num_games_owned': 1632, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2819, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2696, 'last_played': 1398459733}
review:
EXPLORATION & ADVENTURE

The game has no exploration or sense of adventure. None. Zero. Your experience with exploring the world of Blackguards consists of clicking on an icon on the world map representing a settlement and loading up a marketplace view, said view having a few icons to click on that load up the various types of stores or that occasionally (a different icon) offer quests. And that's it.

The various settlements are highly detailed, but all of that detail exists on static backgrounds. The backdrop pictures could have offered a great sense of place simply by utilizing a nice exterior shot. Indeed, this being a fantasy world, and one where many of the settlements offer a rather distinct size and local elements, exterior views could have added a great deal of wonder and adventure to the player's sense of the world. As it is, though, settlements are just a series of the same four stores with minor hints at the diversity that the world has to offer with a few extra flourishes added to some of the marketplaces.

For the most part, one's interaction with the world is on the level of an mmo. There are stores to click on and buy stuff, and there is the occasional quest giver that is met once or twice, says his generic spiel to send you off on your generic quest, and one never sees them again after. Leaving the game with no sense of character.

STORY

The overall concept of Blackguards is generic chosen one gets chosen for unknown reasons to save the world. It's a bland and generic concept, but there's nothing inherently bad about it. One can take a generic concept and sprinkle originality upon it to make an exciting concept. Operative word being can. With Blackguards, the one conceit to originality is that the characters are "blackguards".

Except they're not. The main character is, in actuality, falsely accused of a crime he/she didn't commit. And he/she now roams the badlands, an outlaw hunting outlaws...a RENEGADE.

Some of your cohorts have committed crimes. But other than a few - very rare - jokes, this never really comes into play. The only character who is actually a criminal during the game is quickly killed off. The rest of the characters are more in the "gang of rogues and misfits" territory. And the things that that band of rogues and misfits are called upon to do during the game are the usual generic RPG quests. Find the lost "ring", rescue the damsel in distress, kill these bandits, etc.

With only that unused conceit to count towards originality, there is nothing original in the Blackguards storyline. It is, unfortunately, the usual generic, bland template upon which to hand an RPG. But it actually gets worse than that, because the various enemies and situations are also generic, and the core development is a jumbled mess, leading to no driving reason to progress through the story. (Stressing here that there is no driving reason to progress through the story, not the game.)

There's a core of a good story lying within Blackguards. Evil villains, saving the world, high adventure. But none of it ever gets used. Instead, the overall story sits in the background while the characters get captured - again - and drug around doing random combats against generic foes that have no personal stake in the overall story. The number of times that the party actually fights people who are involved in the threat to the world before reaching the final chapter is incredibly low. Instead, in a world threatened with destruction, it's mostly bandits, gladiators, various animals, and independent undead that the party meets.

The characters of the main party have some personality, even if it is a bit two-dimensional. Their personalities are well-written. But there is little there to most of them, and those personalities do not drive the story. The only driving force in the story is the Chosen One main character. The other members of the party simply offer some localized color here and there. And unfortunately, the best personality is killed off early and replaced by someone as bland as the Chosen One main character. The remaining personalities are well-written, but bland. 

Which brings up one of the major points that are often brought up about games like Blackguards - "It's not about the story; it's about the combat". And while it is true that the centerpiece of Blackguards is combat, one also spends a lot of time watching cutscenes following along the story. If the story isn't actually a major part of the game, then it shouldn't occupy a major part of the time of the game. If it does occupy a large portion of gametime, then it is a major part of the game. End of story. 

RESOURCE MANAGEMENT

At first, the resource management of Blackguards seems like it will be an exciting and detailed system. But like so much else in the game, none of what is met in that first impression is ever fully realized. There is a lot of meat here. The consumables system is highly detailed, with a lot to offer a game that put pressure on those resources. But there is never any pressure. None of the resources matter.  The most glaring of these is rations. The sole use of rations is to allow the group to camp out on the world map. Yet, since there are no wandering monsters and no risk or real time involved in traveling, there is no reason not to simply click on a settlement and rest at its inn rather than lug around heavy rations units (other than the obscurely long loading times for the settlements). 

The only resource that is regularly bought are arrows, for those rare times when there aren't bundles of them found on the enemy, or when - much more often - all of your equipment has been taken from you. As with so much else in Blackguards, resource management is a highly detailed system that a lot could be done with, but that never comes to fruition. Soon after it's introduction, it becomes left by the wayside.

COMBAT

For all of the famed glory of the Blackguards combat system, there actually isn't much to it. The party is made up of five members, and they usually fight from 6-7 enemies, occasionally more, sometimes less. The battles take place on a hex-grid, and they take place in turns based on individual character speed and an initiative roll. 

Unfortunately, the enemies are underdeveloped. There is not a great deal of enemy variety. There are a large number of enemy portraits to fight. But there are not a wide variety of methods of attack. Most enemies are melee grunts who attack using the same pattern and single attack, whether they are mindless zombies or (supposedly) intelligent bandits. A few combats have enemies with ranged ability, which they use in a largely random fashion, instead of a focused aggressive one. And a rare few  have spellcasters, which use their spells in a largely ineffective fashion. Combats against opponents with special abilities beyond that are really rare.

On the other hand, it is good for the party that enemies remain stupid and unfocused, as the party are always outnumbered and usually fighting on empty square battlemaps, and thus a focused effort would likely easily overwhelm the party. Likewise, the enemy do not have all of the special abilities that the party do. Again, this is a must for the survivability of the party. The power feats that are available are just so intensely powerful, and there is so little defense against them, that having any of those abilities is essentially an I-WIN button.

Which leads to the main issue with the combat - it's is badly balanced. Open character development systems are really hard to balance, and this one is not even remotely in the balanced ballpark. There are some aspects of the character that are hugely beneficial (Super Improved Power Attack), some that are only of minor benefit (Read Enemy hp), and some that are of no benefit at all (fireball). Thus, the difficulty of the lies entirely in the character sheet. Leading to different players having wildly different experiences in game difficulty.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999343481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1408761095}
review: Worst turn based rpg ive have played yet,just trying to learn to play is a chore.Theres nothing intuitive about it,you will quikly lose intrest in playing it.Description sounded like it would be a fun game,but its more like work to me,glad i purchased through sale because i probably will not finish game.Graphics are decent but I cant seem to play it long enough to say any thing else good about it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992820381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1405456872}
review:
I'm going to give it a thumbs up, but don't buy this thing at full price. Its a ¬£5 game that is very simplistic. You can't even rotate the camera.

The UI is awful - especially the radial menus for combat. Whoever designed those needs to be taken outside and beaten with a small fish which recently died of natural causes. Whoever signed off the interface then needs to be beaten with whatever remains of said fish. Thankfully you do have quickslots though!

The animation during the cutscenes are laughable, as is the voice acting. Undoubtedly it was "someone's mate" that did both. 

The opening cutscene on the other hand is quite good. 8/10 for that bit... all 60 seconds or so of it. 

The graphics are fairly reasonable, though sometimes things are obscured and with no way to rotate the camera this is slightly annoying. 

The audio is also reasonable, but a little monotonous.

The simplicity and awful UI aside, it is a TBS game with power-ups, and i like TBS games with power-ups. If you like them too, then get it when its on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033187981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1237, 'last_played': 1404778783}
review: Recomendado

author: {'steamid': '76561198007513026', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 430, 'playtime_forever': 1303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 972, 'last_played': 1406258557}
review:
Maybe this game will get better, but I think eight hours is enough to get a feel for a game.

So far this game is frustrating in the extreme. The developers got more things wrong than they got right. First of all, the game is extremely unbalanced. This wouldn't be a problem if the game wasn't also extremely tough. I'm sure some people will say that they found the game to be too easy, but that would only serve to prove my point, the game is very unbalanced. If you pick the wrong attributes to improve (and how would you know which ones are best), you can get stuck.

The interface is also very clumsy. It appears that the developers have abandoned the game to move on to Blackguards 2. 

Overall the game is a tough slog, all frustration and no fun.

I've formally been a real fan of Daedalic, I've bought a lot of their games. But lately most of their games have been really poor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968300492', 'num_games_owned': 783, 'num_reviews': 308, 'playtime_forever': 2928, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2856, 'last_played': 1405293216}
review:
Blackguards is pretty standard a pretty standard affair for an SRPG and that's not necessarily a bad thing.  What IS a bad thing is the BS hit percentage.  After missing your first handful of 95% hit chances you'll realize just how frequently it happens and how frustrating it is.  I'm sure there's some logical explanation like the enemies dodge chance but that's never explained or shown to you.  On the plus side, there's a huge variety of maps so the battlegrounds never feel stale, unlike some other SRPGs I've played.

7/10
Playtime: ~ 48hrs

author: {'steamid': '76561198031964272', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 2787, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2675, 'last_played': 1405349006}
review:
Blackguards doit √™tre pris pour ce qu'il est : un RPG tactique √† l'allemande, r√©alis√© avec s√©rieux, mais sans g√©nie.
Pour ceux qui aiment √©tudier chaque hexagone de terrain √† la recherche de la meilleure strat√©gie en fonction des troupes en pr√©sence. Car ce jeu ne tire sa quintessence que de ses escarmouches, tr√®s nombreuses, et non pas de son aspect RPG somme toute assez limit√©. Certes, chaque personnage recrutable ( mais impos√©...) aura sa feuille de caract√©ristiques/habilet√©s/pouvoirs tr√®s bien document√©e, avec une avalanche de chiffres, comme souvent dans les productions allemandes. Certes, vous progresserez de ville en ville, en respectant l'√©ternel triptyque "je prends les qu√™tes, je m'√©quipe, je me soigne", mais l'aspect tr√®s fig√© des villages, r√©duits au rang de - belles - cartes postales, et l'absence d'exploration sur la carte du monde ne favorise pas l'autonomie du joueur que l'on est en droit d'attendre d'un bon RPG. Lin√©arit√© est le ma√Ætre mot de la progression, et les qu√™tes secondaires, nombreuses, ne sont pour la plupart que des embranchements sc√©naristiques de la qu√™te principale. Avec tr√®s peu de choix influant vraiment sur le monde qui vous entoure. Quand on sait que l'histoire n'est pas particuli√®rement passionnante et qu'elle met du temps √† vraiment d√©marrer, on se dit qu'on est un peu mal barr√©.
Mais en fait pas du tout. Cet aspect du jeu ne repr√©sentera que 10 √† 20% de votre temps. Tout le reste se passera sur les cartes d'escarmouches, et l√†, le doigt√© allemand est tr√®s appr√©ciable. Certaines batailles, tr√®s difficiles, ne pourront √™tre r√©solues qu'√† l'aide de l'environnement qui vous entoure. Les persos que vous aurez √† diriger, tous tr√®s bien calibr√©s, pourront par la suite √©voluer comme bon vous semble. Comme toujours, cr√©er une multitude d'hybrides, n'est absolument pas conseill√©. En g√©n√©ral, les batailles ne s'√©ternisent pas, mis √† part certaines s√©ries d'escarmouche qui vous obligeront √† jouer tr√®s serr√©. Seul probl√®me qui  occasionnera quelques d√©sagr√©ments pendant votre progression : les statistiques de toucher compl√®tement foireuses. Malgr√© les 90 % de chance de toucher souvent √©nonc√©es avant une attaque, le nombre de rat√©s sera incroyablement √©lev√©. Simplement parce que ce chiffre ne prend pas en compte les facteurs d'esquive et de parade de l'ennemi. Quand on sait qu'une attaque rat√©e peut foutre en l'air l'ensemble de sa strat√©gie dans ce genre de jeu, c'est un peu dur √† avaler. Mais on progresse quant m√™me avec plaisir pendant les 40 heures du jeu, en esp√©rant toujours que le hasard statistique ne va pas trop faire des siennes.
Si vous aimez les RPG tactiques, foncez ! Blackguards remplit sa mission proprement, et ce n'est pas la quasi absence de concurrence sur ce march√© l√† qui devrait vous faire r√©fl√©chir √† 2 fois !

review:
Nuevamente en Aventuria...Esto, de por s√≠ s√≥lo, ya supone un gran aliciente para internarte en este producto si conoces bastante el lore, que viene a ser el Forgotten Realms alem√°n, bastante m√°s cruento y oscuro respecto a su contrapunto americano.

Recorrer√°s ciudades manejando a un grupo de aut√©nticos parias, no siendo bienvenidos en casi ning√∫n lugar, lo cual ser√° un h√°ndicap con el cual tendr√°s que lidiar a lo largo de la inmensa mayor√≠a de la aventura.

A nivel jugable, resulta una m√°s que correcta yuxtaposici√≥n entre rol y estrategia: desarrollo de h√©roes, inventario y trasfondo de un g√©nero, desarrollo de batallas, posicionamiento y uso de los recursos presentes en forma de objetos -sean o no propios- y habilidades del otro.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983946931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1182, 'last_played': 1405219978}
review:
I've played this game for nine hours and it has been punctuated by frustration, confusion, and boredom.

Not let me be clear right off the top, I've played a lot of tabletop RPGs but never the system used in this game, and when I played I kicked it to "Easy" right off the top.
I'm looking for an enjoyable experience with some good story but I don't have the time to waste with hardcore difficulty.
So if you're looking for a hardcore review from a guy who loves hardcore tactical RPGs you'll be dissipointed.

My first problem with the game is that even after nine hours in the game I don't know the characters. I have no idea who my character is, what he's done, or if there's any reasoning behind anything I've ran across thus far.
The other heroes are so painfully one note it's not even funny. The dwarf is quite possibly insane and is hunting a dragon (which may or may not be real). The mage is a scholor but mostly a well spoken manwhore. The elf is a drug addict who owes people money. Oh, and has an injured sister.

Most of that stuff is what I learned about them in the first five minutes of their appearing and nothing has changed.
The story isn't much better. After nine hours I've discovered that we're trying escape capture and figure out what's going on.
Which is pretty much where I was ten minutes in. It's just going too slow to really get invested in anything.

The second problem is the combat.
I will conceed that they did a nice job of varying the maps and throwing in varying maps with different enviromental hazards.
Unfortunatly that's about all of the nice things I can say. After nine hours I had access to nearly no abilities to play with, a limited number of spells worth using.
Fights for me basically went "Warriors power attack, mage fire bolts"
Most of the fights feel like I wont mostly because I had more HP than they did rather than any tactical considerations.
And since most of the fights feel the same, the combat quickly feels very much like a grind.

Which is ironic because grinding is something you can't do intentionally.

Combat only happens during missions and subquests. So you can't build up money to buy stuff, and you can't grind to build up some extra XP. So if you're having difficulty there's no way to stack the odds in your favor.

And if you want anything new you will need a LOT of gold. Sadly, though, you won't find much in the way of new equipment, or new weapons for quite some time.

And you know how in D&D looting the bodies after a fight was the most exciting part, because maybe... just maybe you'd get an awesome magical sword, or some kind of unique armor? Well this isn't D&D, you'll get some generic weapons if you're lucky.
You want something unique? Watch for sidequests. Nine hours in there are two. And those two weapons are only marginally better than the weapons you pick up after your first fight.
*sigh*

The final and biggest problem with combat is that it seems to linked to some kind of weird nonsense logic. You can have a 95% chance of hitting and you can (and will) miss three out of four time.
I had a mage with an 85% chance of success cast one successful spell in five rounds. The good news is that failing to cast a spell doesn't cost you magic points, but it wastes your entire round.
And I am aware that enemies have the ability to dodge or parry your attack, but doesn't that seem like something that should be listed in the to hit percental?
If I see 95% to hit, I assume that means that out of a hundred attacks I'll miss five times. The battle Log, which shows the results of all your attacks, isn't any help in deciphering why you've missed. Which is frustrating after three rounds of both my fighters missing an enemy and that same enemy missing them.
If I don't understand what I'm doing wrong, I can't fix it.

And don't expect the game to explain it to you. It doesn't.

Basically all of my complaints seems to come down to pacing. It's too slow. The story is too slow for me to get interested in it, the characters develope to slow (if at all) for me to bond with them, my combat options increase too slow so I'm bored with combat, my equipment changes so slowly I'm not really interested in even winning fights, and my abilities increase so slow I'm not even interested in trying to buy the very limited number of skills in the game.
Hell, going into towns in this game is slow! There is a surprisingly long load time to pop into cities which are, for all extents and purposes, a static shot of a the town with three to five people standing around.
Don't expect to explore the town, either, generally you get three icons to click on and then you're officially done with everything the town has to offer.

But I figured, oh well. If playing it on Easy is still a painfully slow slog maybe I can just cheat to get a ton of gold, EXP and just power through the game.
And, unfortunatly, the creators decided that there isn't even a cheating option. Sounds bad for me to complain about that, but after three fights which were basically attrition battles designed to wear down your team and waste your (EXPENSIVE) potions in long drawn out fights where enemies just continiously spawn...

Yeah, I'm tired. I just want to speed things up so I can see if the story gets any better. But I can't. So, I'm done.

I can't suggest it, which is sad because I wanted this game to be good. I wanted to play this and I wanted to enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991504119', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2433, 'last_played': 1405274780}
review: Just finished the main game story.  At first I didn't think I would enjoy the combat style, but it turned out to be a lot of fun.  That said, some of the creatures make their moves really slowly, e.g. zombies, so if you have 6 of them on a map, it takes quite a while for it to rotate back to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026673827', 'num_games_owned': 743, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 5721, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5245, 'last_played': 1423005308}
review:
To bring a new touch and some new modern elements into the sometimes clunky and rusty turn-based RPG genre isn¬¥t always easy I imagine, but in my opinion Daedalic did that job. In fact this game was the reason I checked out some other games from those intriguing guys.
The encounters are challenging and reminded me sometimes of solving a puzzle - neverthless, to my surprise, they were extremely fun. (you should take some time to get into the DSA combat system => spend your Exp wisely ;] )

Don¬¥t expect open world - you won¬¥t get it. What you get is one of the most grown up Dark Fantasy settings that are out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007705574', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1875, 'last_played': 1408817472}
review:
El juego no es malo, pero no pasa de mediocre. El sistema de combate es muy monotono, con un monton de opciones que son confusas. Los graficos son mediocres (parecen DX9) y aun asi los FPS a veces se cuelgan. Fuera del combate, el modo de juego es de imagenes estaticas en las cuales haces clicks y "conversas" (solo es un dialgo en realidad con pocas opciones para elegir) con personas, pero muy insulso. 
Los sonidos son MALOS, y la historia que podria ser buena, termina siendo un monton de cliches uno al lado del otro. No puedo hablar de los DLCs, pero tambien la experiencia de juego es frustrante. 

Tiene sus cosas originales, como por ejemplo los que es el tema de habilidades y atributos, como asi tambien los hechizos (muy variados). Pero realmente pagar mas de 10 dolares por este juego es un robo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986964932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2809, 'last_played': 1523223549}
review:
Bloody brilliant. There are some seriously bizzare negative comments on this game but let me clarify some points. 

1. Does it have a plot? Yes. Is it linear? Yes. Does it matter? Not really.
2. Is the interface aweful? No not in the slightest, you can choose between a right click menu or a standard button bar.
3. Is it full of bugs? No, the bugs like the character inventory head and feet images in the wrong place has been fixed.
4. Is the character creation and character sheet bad? No, actually its very good. You spend 10-15 mins reading everything and realise there is so much death there are lots of replay options to have a different game. Its essentially D&D stats. Played Baldurs Gate, Diablo or any other game like that and its simple, intuitive and in this case, very good.
5. Its all combat, is this bad? Not really, I enjoy limited dialogue and lots of fighting. Baldurs Gate 1&2 are mostly this and they are cult classics. How good was The Banner Saga, I mean we all loved the talking but the hexed passed fighting where was it all was. This is that game on steriods.
6. Is the fact the game based on a roleplay system a problem? No its actually its strength as it has lots of depth. You can turn the battle log to simple mode if you like or you can have the log go mad with the dice rolling detail. (I turn it off).

Its a damn fine enjoyable game, the fact the scenery is a part of the game (Giant birds dropping rocks, crates being knocked over, tenticles from a monster breaking walkways, oil being set on fire, slippery mud, quicksand and bogs) makes this an awesome and unique experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048044331', 'num_games_owned': 261, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1537894555}
review: A good game for what it is, from the description and images available it looked more like a hack and slash RPG style game but turned out to be more of a turn based RPG like Final Fantasy Tactics etc. Quite let down by that shock, BUT it is fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005079239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 2940, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1406686596}
review:
Nice adaption of the TBE fighting system. It has been a bit changed and simplyfied, but feels pretty good. Better than in the TBE Drakensang games. 
Though I don't like parts of the looks, seems like they don't even really cared about making it look like real TBE stuff that is mostly inspired by real historic armor and weapons instead of D&D fantasy stuff. On this I prefer the Drakensang stuff.

But I wouldn't buy it for full price, because thats way to much, I bought it in the Daedalic bundle on a Steam sale. Wait till it costs about 10 ‚Ç¨, I think that would be a fair price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970667116', 'num_games_owned': 42, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2370, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2267, 'last_played': 1402524791}
review:
Empfehlenswert f√ºr jeden DSA- oder strategischen RPG-Fan.

Man sollte allerdings kein tiefgr√ºndiges RPG erwahrten. Der Schwerpunkt liegt eher auf den strategischen K√§mpfen, welche meist gelungen sind und Abwechslung bieten. Das Spiel lehnt sich grob am DSA-Regelwerk an, so dass DSA-Kenner sich durchaus schnell mit der Terminologie zurechtfinden werden, auch wenn die Auswirkungen der versch. Werte an das Computerspiel angepasst wurden. 
Als DSA-Fan ist es erfrischend einmal die "B√∂sen" und im tiefen S√ºden zu spielen. Die Darstellung der Welt ist durchaus gelungen. Man hat durchgehend das Gef√ºhl sich in Aventurien zu befinden.
Einzig gr√∂√üerer Kritikpunkt ist die vorgegebene Zusammensetzung der Gruppe, auf die man keinen Einfluss nehmen kann, die aber  gleichzeitig nicht gerade gut ausbalanciert wirkt. Das h√§tte man geschickter gestalten k√∂nnen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044602606', 'num_games_owned': 7479, 'num_reviews': 542, 'playtime_forever': 4260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4260, 'last_played': 1404708800}
review:
Alright....Blackguards is definitely a game with no lack for content. In fact, there was enough for me to put in a solid 60 hours. Some of that time was redoing battles and such, but there were plenty of quests and plenty to do in general.

The game itself is a curious blend of your prototypical Daedalic adventure/point and click game (when you are in towns, albeit with the hidden object stuff removed of course) mixed with turn based hex battles that use random number generators ala XCOM and other luminous titles. The RNG aspect can make things interesting as occasionally, you will inexplicably miss when you show a 95% chance to hit (actually, it isn't inexplicable..you fell victim to that other 5% lol), but at other times, when your percentage is really low and you go for a desperation power move, and it connects, you totally feel excited and stoked for having taken that risk.

Graphically, it wont blow you away. It is reminiscent of other Daedalic games when in cities/towns/etc..., but when in battle, it's more of an isometric approach with movable cameras that can be adjusted to the cardinal directions as well as going from top down to more straight ahead angles. This definitely comes into play during battles as you get different vantage points to make decisions and set actions. Definitely pulls off that middle ages with mysticism look well. The cutscenes are more of the same. Nothing too spectacular, but still effective and definitely in line with the overall game presentation.

The story itself is interesting enough. You are framed for the murder of the princess, whom you and a few of your friends grew up with while under the care and apprenticeship of a powerful wizard. You are arrested, and escape with the help of two other prisoners, who become your stalwart companions. From there, you are at first trying to solve the murder and clear your name, but as things progress, you uncover a plot that can destroy the world. At that point, your goals become far more lofty. The story was engaging enough to keep me interested throughout. Which was necessary, as the pace of the game was not very fast. In fact, it took a while for me to get to the point where my characters were able to resolve the more difficult battles without copious retries.

The battle system itself was pretty stellar in my opinion. If you have played XCOM or other turn based hex battle system games, you will have a good grasp for this game fairly quickly as far as the combat is concerned. What they don't do is churn out the same basic layout over and over. Each battle gets it's own unique battle map, which was stellar in my opinion. You never get bored from seeing the same map over and over, which even XCOM as guilty of (I keep going back o XCOM as a reference due to its accessibility as a point of reference for this games combat systems). The geography of the battle is often as important as your positioning relative to your enemies. Often, there will be traps, mires/bogs, and other obstacles that will hinder or help you and your enemies. Cover is provided on many maps. Interactive objects also make there way into the battlefield. For example, there might be a stack of barrels that you can knock over to crush enemies underneath or simply block their path (and they might use those same stacks), a stand filled with rocks that can be knocked over, bookcases, oil filled barrels that explode, pools of oil, vats of poison, simple chairs and tables, etc....The battle maps were supremely well thought out in my opinion and kept things pretty fresh. In addition to all that, there might be goals other than simply destroying your enemy, such as trying to fight your way to a specific part of the map, free prisoners to help you fight, defend citizens as they try to flee the battle zone, escort missions, and so on. There was even two instances where complete stealth was necessary and one where you are fighting your way through a cavern while also trying to stay ahead of a poison cloud that creeps slowly forward behind you. So much variety. It was really quite impressive.

The quests were pretty standard fare for the most part. Go find this missing person, please retrieve this item and possibly take it to somebody else, find out what this person or that person is hiding, intercept shipments, and so on. They were fun, and if you play RPG's, they are par for the course. However, they were much easier to finish and never dragged out. Short and to the point as it were. I had a lot of fun with them, and finished every quest the game had to offer.The main quest itself was pretty interesting, as I mentioned before, and kept you moving forward.

The pacing itself was pretty slow. In fact, the first few hours of gameplay might dissuade some people from continuing on. It takes a while for the game to start really sending you places, and it also takes a while for you to be able to upgrade your equipment and abilities. However, once you get past that initial stage, the game never stops moving forward, even if it is at a slower tan normal RPG pace. I wouldn't get discouraged by this. Once it really got going, I never looked back, although I did break up the gameplay by taking a day off in between sessions to play other types of games. I think that approach benefited the gameplay here, as it helped me to stay interested. The reason I mention this is because, on top of all that, this game is absolutely combat focused and is quite grind-ey. In fact, you will pretty much need to grind out every battle to level up enough to have a reasonable experience later in the game. Fortunately, even if you wrap up all te quests, there is the option to do gladiator fights whenever you want (after you become the champions of the gladiator ring), which will fill out any necessary experience and give you extra cash to spend on potions and such, which you will definitely need to do.

Healing and mana potions (they don't call it mana, but same thing) are an absolute necessity, and especially towards the end of the game, you will want to have as many as possible. You cant have too many, and they don't carry any inventory weight with them, so there is no reason not to keep yourself well stocked. The only other things I ever really spent my coins on were arrows and the occasional armor upgrade. You will find plenty of weapons, poisons, etc...throughout the game and shouldn't need to buy any after maybe your first couple upgrades. At a certain point, those all become more than plentiful via combat spoils. You do have party encumbrance, but I never really found it to be an issue, and went over several times, lol. As far as the inventory system goes, it's pretty simple...you have your various clothing slots (which equate to pants, shoes, gloves, shirt, and hat). You have three weapon loadout slots (during battle, you can switch between the three, but each switch counts as a turn). Each loadout has two hands available, so one loadout might be sword and shield, another might be bow and arrows, another might be a greatsword, etc...You also wear a belt which can have as many as 4 slots available (depending on the belt itself). Each slot will hold one disposable item (potion, poison, grenade (equivalent), or throwing weapon).

The RPG system is fairly deep in my opinion. There are several categories that all pull from the same pool of experience points you earn, so you need to be judicious in how you spend those points. There are plenty of guides on the topic although I just used what I thought would work well with a touch of common sense and an idea of how to build a party mixed in, lol. The breakdown is abilities (strength, courage, dexterity, charisma, etc...), talents (such as survival, warfare, traps, healing, willpower, and so on), weapon skills (specific weapon categories....bows, axes and maces, two handed swords, two handed axes and maces, staffs, ec...) *continued in comment section*

author: {'steamid': '76561197987135160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1018, 'last_played': 1404593767}
review:
If you like Turn Based RPG this is a game for you, story is decent, fights are challenging, and the luck involved reminds me alot of playing table top games! The graphics are good, combat takes tought, and the game lets you do your own thing, build characters however you want, and have fun. 

That beind said, if you dont focus your characters then you'll find combat to be brutal and can become very frustrated, but I feel this is more a pro then a con, just giving a heads up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049808050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1404491992}
review: For a game stripping down RPGs down to the basics - combat encounters - it sure does a tremendously bad job. The combat UI is clunky as hell. You cannot turn map apparently, so every obstacle on the map is also an annoying obstacle for your mouse and eyes. The game loads a lot and I have no idea why, because the graphics are not anywhere near current single player games standard, but rather low on the MMORPG scale even. Inventory management really sucks a lot, not too mention quirky little fun things like characters using bandages to cure lasting injuries only on themselves - means you cannot reliably heal with a character you build for such stuff. This game is a big disappointment, if you want DSA nostalgia, buy the very old Nordland-Triology, still better and technically more adapt than this here. Certainly not worth the price of a AAA-game, which sadly it features.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071412209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 5481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5481, 'last_played': 1404412259}
review:
First off, AMAZING design and detail on every battle map, no 2 battles ever look or feel the same, and there are plenty. Thats a huge factor for these type of games and its evident they invested alot of time and effort into that area of the game. 

Also, Difficulty is so so critical for lasting entertainment in turn based rpgs and this one NAILS it. Without giving too much away, its not too difficult, not too easy, but theres a splash of both extremes at times which makes for genuine gaming fun. Dont know too many other TBRPG where each and every character in your party becomes and remains so vital to your strategy and success. Well thought out and well executed. 

Voice acting, storyline and humor all get a solid A. All subjective but bottomline is that its detailed enough so you care, written well enough so you laugh, and it progresses well enough so you're always looking forward to more. 

I see bad reviews based on bugs and price. 
In all fairness, there was an early freezing bug, 5 second fix, 30 gameplay hours later. forgot all about it.
I got this for less than what I spend on a night at the movie theater.
2 entertainment hours vs 30+ and counting entertainment hours.
Guess it just depends on how you see it, right?
Not selling. just sharing.

Fully enjoying and recommending Blackguards and looking forward to hearing more about Blackguards 2!

author: {'steamid': '76561198004080636', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 8175, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2094, 'last_played': 1553483813}
review: I really enjoy the game. I have to say I dont understand why it got so bad reviews. You have to think little bit to fight some battles and of course sometimes you throw the mouse out of a window but then you can help yourself with youtube and you carry on. Its done well (everything works perfectly). Its a huge game which is hard to find these days. Usually you can finish all "new" games between 5 to 20 hours and then you can buy 100000 dlcs with it. I didnt experience any single glitch or freeze of a game. Definately one of my favourite games. Btw if you are fan of UFO or Fallout its must buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960681535', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1408681104}
review: I've only played about an hour but so far I'm enjoying the turn based action.  The voice acting isn't fantastic but I really enjoy the strategy concept of battling by turns.  Of course, I haven't even delved into the full meat of the game yet but so far, so good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053708501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1573, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1573, 'last_played': 1404179872}
review:
Antes de come√ßar, quero destacar que isso somente representa minha vis√£o PESSOAL, vou destacar aquilo que gostei ou n√£o gostei no jogo, o que pode diferir radicalmente de outras opini√µes.

******** AVISOS **********

* Cont√©m *alguns* spoilers.
* S√≥ joguei at√© o cap√≠tulo 3, com um "ranger".
* Antes de jogar, li exaustivamente o sistema de regras no qual o sistema √© baseado, al√©m de alguns tutoriais do jogo em si.

***************************

Pr√≥s:

- A ambienta√ß√£o √© bastante interessante.
- O jogo n√£o tem classes, voc√™ monta seu personagem da forma como melhor lhe aprouver.
- O mundo √© meio dark, e cont√©m algumas decis√µes/op√ß√µes de di√°logo mais maduras.
- A hist√≥ria difere um pouco do padr√£o de jogos de fantasia: her√≥i em sua armadura reluzente, re√∫ne um grupo de tamb√©m her√≥is para salvar o mundo do mal. Ela n√£o √© t√£o "preto e branca", tem algumas escalas de cinza =) E os ‚Äúher√≥is‚Äù est√£o mais pra anti-her√≥is.

Contras:

- N√£o curti o sistema de regras, baseado no dark eye vers√£o 4. Por exemplo, achei exagero 3 testes para cada uso de talento ou magia, o que faz no come√ßo as magias falharem com alguma frequ√™ncia.
- Poucas magias (24).
- A anima√ß√£o dos personagens √© estranha: reparem como a boca dos personagens mexe quando eles falam!
- A hist√≥ria parece for√ßada em determinados pontos: personagens entram no seu grupo pela simples raz√£o de n√£o terem lugar melhor para ir e v√£o ficando como se n√£o tivessem objetivos muito claros. Um personagem seu morre DO NADA numa determinada batalha, sendo que teoricamente seria poss√≠vel salva-lo.
- Personagens n√£o s√£o muito carism√°ticos... E algumas miss√µes parecem ser for√ßadas tamb√©m.
- N√£o parece haver "ritmo" na dificuldade das batalhas, a maioria √© bastante f√°cil, mas de vez em quando vem alguma MUITO dif√≠cil de repente, e n√£o necessariamente √© de boss.
- Achei a dublagem um pouco fraca.

Dicas e sugest√µes:

- Sugiro FORTEMENTE que leiam alguma coisa sobre o sistema de regras e sobre o jogo em si ANTES de come√ßar a jogar... Pode economizar muita frustra√ß√£o saber de antem√£o onde colocar os pontos :) Segue alguns links pra ajudar(em ingl√™s).
- Resumo sobre o sistema de regras Dark Eye:  http://www.rpg.net/reviews/archive/16/16082.phtml
- Pequeno resumo sobre o jogo: http://shianra.com/games/blackguards/

Resumo da √≥pera: Pareceu interessante a princ√≠pio e tem muitas ideias boas, mas a jun√ß√£o de um sistema de regras enfadonho com uma hist√≥ria e personagens que n√£o me agradaram muito, me desestimularam de continuar jogando!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066046242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1855, 'last_played': 1523474393}
review:
Blackguards is a very interesting TBS game. You take on the role of a criminal that has been accused of murder and your ultimate goal is to escape the people that are after you and find out exactly what happened to you... and probably save the world. 

You can pick from a roughly customizable melee fighter, an archer, or a mage to start out with and you will acquire a melee fighter and a mage in your party after the first couple of fights. You do not get your 4th party member, an archer,  until about half way through chapter one. 

The fighting is actually strategic with being able to move and take an action, move further but not be able to take an action that turn, or wait and the rest of that characters turn will move to the end of the queue for that turn. There are a lot of things that can be interacted with in the battles for various effects, such as lighting things on fire to cause damage to anything moving through them, activating traps, or removing items that are giving enemies buffs. 

There is the occasional difficulty spike, but if you think strategically you can work around them. Your choices also have at least short term consequences, and possibly long term ones. Enemy AI can be used against them, which is a bit sad to watch occasionally. It is a bit disappointing watching as the enemy stands in the same spot turn after turn and takes trap damage because one of your characters is standing one spot over and within melee range. 

Character interactions are amazingly fun. The stock melee character you get at the start of the game is very gruff, and will shout out lines if you heal him with magic, just as an example. The dialog outside of battle is just as fun, with one of the characters being obviously very self-serving and causing a bit of trouble because of it. 

Skill trees seem to be fairly balanced, but within the first couple chapters of the game having an archer or 2 is a godsend. My archers have probably taken out more enemies than my melee fighter, so I make sure I am very well stocked on arrows. Mages start out very weak, and don't pick up until they get some levels on their skills to improve their accuracy.

Now the bad, some of the encounters are annoying or just outright boring. I hate seeing crypt lice because they're boring to kill. Another couple instances had me defending an endless stream of helpless NPCs until they got through a gate, and the enemies respawn until a certain number of NPCs get out of the gate. Boring, tedious, and not very fun... especially when the respawning enemies have a throw attack that is capable of instantly killing the NPCs on an unlucky roll. Money is not exactly easy to come by early on and items are EXPENSIVE. So you will be getting a lot of your gear through drops for a fair bit... and enemies drop weapons far more often than armor. 

Good game, definitely worth checking out, especially if you are a fan of the TBS games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076569428', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 739, 'last_played': 1421980582}
review:
BlackGuards √© um jogo recomendado para f√£s de jogos de estrat√©gia em turnos. Se voc√™ gosta de RPG, ent√£o a recomenda√ß√£o cresce ainda mais. Apesar da men√ß√£o ao RPG, esse jogo parece mais com t√≠tulos como Final Fantasy Tactics ou Tactics Ogre do que com t√≠tulos mais "RPGisticos" como Baldur's Gate ou The Temple of Elemental Evil. Apenas o universo do RPG √© usado, n√£o todos os seus elementos principais.

BlackGuards √© composto praticamente de apenas tr√™s elementos: Batalhas, Hist√≥ria e Mapa.

Mapa: o jogador percorre o mundo atrav√©s do mapa. No mapa h√° apenas dois tipos de marca√ß√µes: cidades ou pontos de batalhas. As cidades s√£o telas est√°ticas com uns poucos NPCs para negociar itens ou dar miss√µes. N√£o tem como voc√™ explorar a cidade, tudo que aquela cidade pode oferecer j√° est√° sendo exibido naquela √∫nica tela.

Batalhas: Onde as coisas realmente acontecem e √© o grande ponto forte do jogo. As batalhas s√£o divertidas e dif√≠ceis se voc√™ n√£o entender bem como a mec√¢nica do jogo funciona. √â necess√°rio fazer uma boa constru√ß√£o de personagem e mesclar bem as habilidades de seu grupo para poder superar os desafios sem muita dificuldade. Tudo que um f√£ de jogos de estrat√©gia gosta!

Hist√≥ria: antes, durante ou depois de cada batalha acontece uma cutscene ou anima√ß√£o para mostrar o desenrolar da hist√≥ria do jogo e aqui fica a maior cr√≠tica. Quase n√£o h√° intera√ß√£o durante a hist√≥ria, voc√™ √© praticamente um espectador durante esses eventos. Quase n√£o h√° escolhas a serem feitas. As poucas vezes que voc√™ √© convocado a interagir durante os di√°logos, suas escolhas aparentemente n√£o fazem diferen√ßa para hist√≥ria.

* Pontos Fortes

- Sistema de constru√ß√£o de personagens.
- Intera√ß√£o com objetos durante as batalhas.
- Batalhas em si
- Apesar das limita√ß√µes, at√© que os personagens tem algum carisma.

* Pontos Fracos

- Pouca intera√ß√£o entre os personagens e entre esses e o mundo
- Hist√≥ria linear. Embora o jogador possa escolher ente ir primeiro a um lugar em vez de outro isso n√£o afeta a hist√≥ria.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964006169', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 4268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1414, 'last_played': 1701936544}
review:
I have, so far, enjoyed this game. The mechanics are solid, and I've always been a fan this style of turn based strategy/RPG games. 

I haven't gotten far enough along to really dig into the story, or develop my characters much, but that's not due to a lack of interest. 

The problem that I'm having is that this game crashes pretty frequently. I don't think it's my computer causing it, but I could be wrong about that. 

If, and when, any stability issues have been worked out, either by the developer, or by me, I will change my recommendation to yes.

As of right now, I don't know many people that would be willing to restart their computers to advance the plot for 45 minutes or so before restarting again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961313071', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 780, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1415556713}
review:
Blackguards is without a doubt a fun game for the old-school turn-based RPG-combat interested. It feels like a solid title through and through and it has hours of fun and enjoyment in it where you will be redoing battles over and over until you find the right strategy for them and beat them easily. This is definitely a challenging game with a lot of good sides to it, but it has one major flaw, and that is that it is far from complete and full of game-ending bugs. Expect to go somewhere and not being able to play if you make that choice because the game will crash if you make that certain turn, if you were lucky you had savegames prior to that choice, if not - then you have to start all over again.

By game-breaking bugs I mean that when you reach a certain location, the game will just crash every single time you go there. Reloading the game won't help, it will continuously crash and if you had an old savegame you can get around it, otherwise you are screwed until they either fix it, or you move on to another game, alternatively give this game another try and remember what choice you made that led to the crashing.

Unfortunately this is a dealbreaker for me, and while I did have a lot of fun, I didn't get to experience the game as I played it, and I refuse to go back to change how I played just because the game is unfinished. Supposedly it's going to be done this autumn, but I doubt there will be much more development on this title, they've been releasing a DLC for it already, and announced a sequel, which is underway. It's a pity that a title that has such great core mechanics get ruined in the details, but such is the way right now. 

It is quite possible that you do not run into these bugs, and have an excellent experience, but keep in mind, you might end up like me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032237009', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 5051, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3440, 'last_played': 1403755062}
review:
I put 84 hours into it and quit with the end in sight.  I love turn based combat, and that kept me going in the linear game.  Combat became more about figuring out the trick to the map, rather than strategic play.  It sadly be came tedious.
You only get a clean slate on your own character, and because the way the trainers are laid out you can‚Äôt develop your character the way you want, his all ties into the game being very linear.
You can‚Äôt rotate the camera expect on one axis, which makes some fights awkward.
Shield only helps per parry you get, so shields are not that great.
Never once saw the point in disarming traps, but spotting them was very important.
NPC you build into your party come and go, to me when I specialize a party it is crippling to lose one of its team members.
I wanted to love it.  It is a good looking game.  I like the character development, except the trainer availability.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079991806', 'num_games_owned': 1642, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2396, 'last_played': 1590102337}
review:
Would I recommend this game to everybody?  No, not at all.
Would I recommend this game to people who I know love Dungeons and Dragons?  Yep! (Only when the game is on sale)

This game, as you know, is based on the Darkeye D20 ruleset and is only for those who like stategy turn-based RPGs.  Darkeye is pretty big in Europe from what I understand but I personally never ran a game with it and I wanted to experience the system in an easier to digest way and I felt I got that from this game.  Package that with the honestly funny writing and interesting characters and I enjoyed myself.  Note, however, that this game is entirely about the combat system and RPG progression.  The story is there, but weak, and there is no exploration.  The retail price is too steep for what you get but if you see this game for $15.00 USD or less then I'd suggest picking it up for fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999866270', 'num_games_owned': 669, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1403768421}
review:
I could not safely recommend this game to anyone, because I'm not sure who it appeals to, and this is why:

1.  It's certainly not for rpg gamers because at its core, Blackguards is nothing more than a series of battles, one after the other, with the 'choice' being where you're going to fight next and a brief respite in 'towns' that are no more than venues to heal and restock between fights.

2.  Strategy gamers will find the combat tacky and repetitive because it always comes down to enemies trying to overwhelm you with odds with very simplistic AI.

3.  It can't possibly appeal to people looking for a great story because the story is clearly an afterthought.  You get brief looks into your characters pasts between drawn out combat sessions but there's no real development.  Things just happen and force you into the next fight.

So really, who was this game made for?

author: {'steamid': '76561198004479096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1437907537}
review:
This is one of those games that looks kinda cool on the store page, but you end up with buyers remorse when you realise it is actually pretty dull. With needlessly infuriating RNG, and a combat system that just feels really bland, this is one of those games you may want to buy at at least a 75% discount, if at all.

Oh, the spell effects are fairly pretty though, i guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008638875', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 6251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1604, 'last_played': 1430256152}
review:
Fantastic SRPG. Take the European analouge to D&D (The Dark Eye 4th edition), in a Witcher/Dragon Age-type dark fantasy tale, and give it very solid turn -based combat.

Don't play this game for what it's not (a free-wheeling sandbox, forgiving), play it for what it is, which is an occasionally bruising tactical RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971396112', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1410720038}
review:
Is it hard? Yes. Is it overwhelming initially? Yes. 

It is good to wait a bit before upgrading anything.  Baroness quest is almost too hard too soon, but if you talk to everyone, there should be enough quests to ready you for the encounter.

I do not even like turn-based strategy/tactics games. I thoroughly enjoy this game.  I waited for a Steam sale to get it. I should have just bought it when I wanted to months ago.

8.5/10
Great Story
Challenging Gameplay

author: {'steamid': '76561198088415942', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4252, 'last_played': 1399972678}
review:
I enjoyed this game.  The storyline was interesting although it was linear.  No  choices to affect the outcome of the story for an RPG.  The turnbased tactical combat was pretty good.  They made an effort to have items interactive in combat.  Character customization was good.  

Things that could make this game better - More choices of party companions and more control over what skills/spells they start with.  More choices that affect the world in general.  

All in all, I recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970534392', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2251, 'last_played': 1547146539}
review:
Really love it! This game is misunderstood very often.

+ great gameplay (not as good as XCOMs but still nice)
+ based on The Dark Eye - refreshing compared to all the games based on D&D
+ nice story
+ nice quests (and side quests)
+ funny interaction in-between the characters
+ really good value for money when on sale
+ lots of different skills and builds to explore (a bit confusing and overwhelming for beginners though)
+ good difficulty (it will be very challenging at times and you will have to change your tactics which worked before)


-	Obviously not a huge development budget (they made the best out of it)
-	Graphics are nice but could be way better (eg. cutscenes ‚Ä¶)
-	Skills & talents can be difficult to understand. You‚Äôll probably need to google a bit to understand the different character values.
-	Some bugs can be frustrating, eg. when the healer in-between the gladiator fights won‚Äôt heal you anymore. There aren‚Äôt many but this one made it very hard for me
-	Save often. (same as xcom). It could save you time.
-	Usability in the stat/spell/‚Ä¶ screens could be better, especially when trying to figure out which weapon does more damage.

All in all, I can live without the best graphics and animations (like XCOM does superb). I was willing to learn about the skills and mechanics. I accepted the couple of bugs I encountered ‚Äì it only lead to the game being more difficult but didn‚Äôt break the game itself.

After reading many negative reviews I think the problem is that this game isn‚Äôt like many other games out there, it‚Äôs comparable to XCOM but with possibility to skill your characters in a complex way. You can‚Äôt save every minute and decisions you made today could be a problem much later. You may have to do some side quests to get the experience to advance. You won‚Äôt be able to blindly upgrade every skill and spell there is. You will have to use different tactics. Using Takate with his piercing skill will work awesome most of the time, but if an enemy is immune to piercing you should better have given him some other weapon and skills (I learned this the hard way).

Obviously something went wrong during the beta version, because most of the negative reviews are from back then. I didn‚Äôt experience many of the problems from back then. If you like turn based games with a lot of strategy involved you‚Äôll probably like this. If you want to kill many monsters with huge firewalls better get path of exile ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970309850', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1397603506}
review:
i regret buying the game at 50% off . I enjoyed the first chapter then it got a bit tedious , it seemed a game designed to make sure you had no fun. I love turn based tactical games and i dont think i've ever played one i didnt enjoy before.

character develpoment and advancemet is dreadful , worst of any RPG or CRPG i've ever played , It's so boring and mundane. There's an illusion of freedom but really you just stick to a few skills and spells that are clearly miles better , if you dont you end up with useless underpowered skills and characters.

I think i am still using the same 1 skill with my melee and archer characters 10 hours into the game and the same 2 spells on my casters. There's just not enough variety to the game. In another 10 hours i probably be using the same 2 skills. Thats not enough depth for a tactical game or an RPG.

As an RPG it is without doubt poor but i expected that and assumed the tactical combat would make up for it , it didnt , the combat was worse than i expected and that is the reason i eventually got bored of clicking the same 2 buttons and stopped playing

author: {'steamid': '76561198056693830', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 883, 'last_played': 1404093569}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968365838', 'num_games_owned': 2538, 'num_reviews': 110, 'playtime_forever': 2062, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1908, 'last_played': 1399753240}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aIHPbD7xpG4
[b]Was ist Blackguards[/b]
Blackguards will ein altes RPG Element wieder aufleben lassen und Rundenbasierte K√§mpfe wieder Salonf√§hig machen. Hierbei st√ºtzen die Entwickler sich auf das Regelwerk von DSA ( Das Schwarze Auge ) und erhoffen durch ein Konsequentes einhalten dieser den Spielspa√ü sicher einzubringen. Was leider nicht zu 100% klappt. 

[b]Die Geschichte&Quests[/b]
Es ist schon fast klassisch im Rollenspiel irgendwo aufzuwachen und sich an nichts mehr zu erinnern. Immerhin kenne ich meinen Namen und meinen besten Freund, der mich komischerweise inzwischen vernichten will. So haben Geschichtenschreiber immer eine gute M√∂glichkeit den Plot langsam zu entwickeln, anstatt den Spieler direkt mit 1000 Informationen zu erschlagen. Also muss ich erst mal, nach meiner Festnahme, fliehen und dann meinen ehemals besten Freund finden. Die Story hat ein paar gute Wendungen, aber man darf hier nicht aufwendige Sequenzen erwarten. Generell wird die Geschichte in Spielgrafik, oder nur √ºber Textfenster erz√§hlt. Insgesamt gibt es nur wenige Rendervideos im Spiel, die man sich von der Qualit√§t her auch h√§tte sparen k√∂nnen. 

[b]Skills&F√§higkeiten der Party[/b]
Nat√ºrlich geh√∂ren zum DSA Regelwerk unz√§hlige Skills und F√§higkeiten f√ºr die Party. Diese k√∂nnen Rollenspielanf√§nger ziemlich erschlagen, vor allem da es keine M√∂glichkeit gibt diese wieder zu verlernen und die in Schlachten schwer erk√§mpften Erfahrungspunkte zur√ºck zu erhalten. So ist das skillen ein wenig Try & Error und man kann sich wie in einem klassischen Diablo auch verskillen und schon sind 20 Stunden Spielzeit f√ºr die Katz. 

Dieses Schicksal blieb mir zum Gl√ºck erspart, da ich sehr strickt alle Partymitglieder nur in eine Richtung geskillt hatte und wenn man alle Nebenquests mit erledigt hat man auch einen gewissen √úberschuss an XP. 

[b]Der vermaledeite Kampf[/b]
Dank DSA Regelwerk werden erfolgreiche Angriffe gew√ºrfelt und dadurch erh√§lt das Spiel eigentlich seinen schlimmsten Faktor: "das Gl√ºck!" Teilweise muss man Schlachten einfach mehrfach wiederholen weil man einfach Pech hatte und trotz sehr gutem Verteidigungswert sehr viele Treffer kassiert hatte, oder einfach der falsche Charakter gerade unter Gedankenkontrolle geraten ist, oder zuf√§llig nun Skelette kommen und wir keine Hiebwaffen parat haben. ( Stichwaffen machen z.B. keinen Schaden an Skeletten ) 

Man sollte beim Durchspielen deshalb eine hohe Frustrationsschwelle haben, da manche K√§mpfe erst mal unschaffbar anmuten und dann doch irgendwann funktionieren. Ich hab in dem Fall das Spiel dann immer erst mal ein paar Tage beiseitegelegt.

[b]Fazit[/b]
Blackguards ist kein schlechtes Rollenspiel, aber ich kann es leider nicht als Vollpreistitel empfehlen. Daf√ºr ist das Spiel an manchen Ecken zu sperrig und hat zu viele Kanten. Manchmal wirkt es auch nicht balanciert und so schwankt der Schwierigkeitsgrad enorm zwischen den Quests. Auch das falsche Skillen ist st√∂rend, da das Spiel hier auch kaum Hilfestellungen gibt wie bei anderen Rollenspielen. Hier w√§re es sch√∂n gewesen einen automatischen Level Aufstieg f√ºr Spieler zu hinterlegen die so etwas brauchen. Auch wirkt, vor allem gegen Ende hin, das Spiel extrem durch K√§mpfe gestreckt. Wenn wir in den letzten Abschnitt eintauchen und das Spiel mich schon dar√ºber informiert das es danach kein Zur√ºck mehr gibt geh ich davon aus dass ich nun zu einem knackigen Ende komme. Stattdessen k√§mpfe ich mich mehrere Stunden durch sinnlose Schlachten und arbeite diese nur noch ab. Ohne das die Story wirklich voran gebracht wird. Hier funktioniert das Spiel anf√§nglich und in der Mitte der Geschichte weitaus besser. 
Deshalb ist Blackguards nur etwas f√ºr dich wenn du rundenbasierte K√§mpfe mit Gl√ºcksfaktor liebst und es dich nicht frustriert diese manchmal √∂fters als einmal anzugehen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969921188', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1398318882}
review:
While this game shows immense promise at the start as DnD style RPG with tonnes of character trees to customise and fun turn based fights eventually you will encounter the horrible broken boss fights and terrible plot decisions. Without spoiling much the game strips you of characters by force and the balance always seem to be tipped against you. 
I believe that this game received too much praise from reviewers who did not play far enough into the game.
The complaints I had with this game I found had been discussed by other players while the game was in Beta on the Blackgaurd forums. The developers obviously did not take these potentially game saving points on, which is the most disappointing thing of all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036351598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1403658857}
review:
Let's start with character creation; You seem to have a lot of choices, but most of these are just number-crunching to get the few choices that matter. Although even those are just a numbers game, just bigger numbers. You can also choose your starting equipment, this is pretty neat, if it weren't for the fact that you lose all of your equipment after your first combat.

Speaking of combat, every action you do has a high chance of failing, from casting a spell to setting a trap to swinging a club. The chance to hit or be succesful is made harder by your enemies' defenses. Wait, that's not all, the damage range of your weapons goes from 1-6, 5-10, or 4-12 for example, this damage is further reduced by your enemies' damage reduction %, and flat damage reduction. This means that on top of the abnormally high miss chance(plus dodge and parry chances!), actually dealing damage is stupendously hard. Now imagine most enemies have around the same health as you, 30ish. So what do you do? You wail on the enemies until they fall down, hoping you even hit them. This makes combat feel sluggish, your actions meaningless, and generally make you waste time.

The story? You get to choose which lines are said first.. sometimes. It also appears you get some dialogue options at times. None of these worked, and didn't work the few times I did try them. Perhaps they work later in the game when you have a higher Charisma? Thing is, I maxed my charisma, it wouldn't go higher, so why have those options there at the start anyway? To waste my time? Make me feel like I have a choice? No, this is another kick to the nuts this game gives.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030627280', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7457, 'last_played': 1427240467}
review:
The map and so-called adventure choices are little beyond token, though correctly executed. The story is very classic but does have a couple of courageous twists that deserve credit.
Beyond the game system that you of course have to like or not (I do), the main highlights are:
1) map design, creative and varied with many fun environment elements;
2) difficulty: the game is very challenging at the highest difficulty level and keeps getting harder as you progress toward the last act (die you goddamn plant, die). Some maps or quests are quite tough and you'll need to use all you can to deal with the sheer brutality of special enemies. That's very refreshing from the usual strategy game curve (mildly difficult beginning to mid-game then disappointingly easy as your characters get IMBA).

The interface is neat and even rather classy.

All in all, quite a nice game if you're into the system.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985723238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1403422104}
review: Blackguards ist ein Spiel, das mir eigentlich hervorragend gefallen m√ºsste und hat es f√ºr einige Zeit durchaus getan. Die h√∂lzernen Zwischensequenzen, die schwache Story und einige Unrundheiten im Spieldesign st√∂ren mich nicht. Weit weniger gefallen hat mir die Bedeutung der Umgebung, die man sich im Kampf zunutze machen kann. Das Feature liest sich gut, macht gelegentlich auch Spa√ü, aber nach ein paar Experimenten habe ich einfach keine Lust mehr gehabt, es konsequent zu nutzen. Und dann sind manche Levels schlicht eine Qual (Stichwort: Todesr√§der!). Oder ohne Einsatz der Umgebung nicht zu gewinnen. Wenn ich mich dem Design nicht f√ºge, ist das nat√ºrlich letztlich mein Problem und nicht das der Designer.  Was mir das Spiel letztlich v√∂llig kaputt gemacht hat, war die Serie von Trial-and-error-Arenak√§mpfen, die jeweils beim Unterbrechen einer Session nicht zwischengespeichert werden konnte. Gerade wenn man durch kleine Fehler einen Kampf so leicht verlieren lassen k√∂nnen, ist es indiskutabel, dass man das Spiel am Ende des Tages nicht wenigstens quicksaven kann und tags darauf immer wieder bei Kampf 1 einsteigen musste. Das ist mit Patch 1.3 wohl gefixt worden, aber in der Zwischenzeit hatte ich es so satt, dass ich das Spiel auch jetzt nicht mehr anpacken mochte. Dennoch eine Empfehlung f√ºr alle NEueinsteiger nach Patch 1.3: F√ºr frustresistente Spieler ein tolles Spiel, alle anderen sollten vielleicht auf Blackguards 2 warten, das viele Schw√§chen hoffentlich ausb√ºgelt. Und dem gebe ich dannauch gern wieder eine Chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076798215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2028, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2028, 'last_played': 1400402585}
review:
An old school-tactical RPG with emphasis on hex-grid battles and character management. The game has its flaws and suffers from low production values, but it offers a good amount of challenge and opportunities for character customization. There is no randomly generated content, each battle is handcrafted and they contain lots of surprises and special features. 

For those looking for a challenging game instead of engaging story, I can heartily recommend Blackguards.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983945853', 'num_games_owned': 332, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1404135267}
review:
The game itself is about gathering a group of criminals and misfits together to form a band of anti-heroes to take on the bad guys and rescue a damsel in distress.  Its broken down into Chapters which were released through beta piece at a time.  I bought the game in beta and enjoyed playing it immensly.  The battles are turn based so no need to rush and a much better opportunity to win through tactics and strategy.

HOWEVER when the full version was released it all went drastically downhill.  Yes there were a few minor bugs that I could live with when it was a beta.  The final release version has a number of major flaws in it.  My existing save game made any new battles unfinishable as you couldnt end a turn - all your characters just stood there with no end turn available.  That's okay I thought, I will start a new game, it will be fun choosing a different character from Chapter 1.  Oh no ....... BIG FAIL.  When you try to start a new game, you get the character creation part fine but once you finish adjusting your new hero you try to start the game and all you get is a black screen and some music.  Immediately I thougt oh it must be a graphics resolution problem, but yet I had just loaded a older saved game and it loaded fine (even if I couldnt advance through the next battle) and indeed it loaded fine again when I tried.  So now I am at an impasse, with no new game possible and all my saved games bugged.

I checked the forums and it is not just me with these issues.  And it appears that the publisher is doing nothing to resolve the said issues.

So overall this game now has some major flaws that make it unplayable.  Stay away.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970122358', 'num_games_owned': 739, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2591, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2362, 'last_played': 1402494189}
review:
Fantastic game set in Germany's most popular fantasy world

I am really baffled by some of the luckwarm reviews that this title was getting. I found it to be a fantastic, visceral turn based strategy RPG set in a refreshingly dark fantasy world.  

Perhaps the initial bad press was due to the fact that it wasn't X-Com: The current turn based darling.

Indeed, there is no permadeath and the story is relatively linear. However; about 40% of gametime is dedicated to non essential side quests.

I especially liked the art design on the game; the battlefields, warriors and beasts seemed stylized as living toys; I could almost imagine this game being played on that chessboard in the Millenium Falcon.  Expect to see dozens upon dozens of battle maps and a variety of winning conditions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041702499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1271, 'last_played': 1417225362}
review:
Have you ever played Dungeons and Dragons with a Dungeon Master that absolutely hates you? Do you like campaigns in which dialogue options are almost meaningless and the plot is confusing? Well if you haven't, Blackguards can fill that void for you. 

The plot isn't bad. It captured my attention fairly early and has some nice twists in it. The main focus of this game, however, is the combat system. I love the combat in this game. Blackguards uses a version of tabletop rules to fuel its combat. There are even simulated dice rolls for damage and hit chance. Unfortunately, (or fortunately depending) pretty much every dialogue option leads to some sort of cliche combat. Very rarely is there a non-combat solution to anything. 

The character creation is pretty cool also. There are two modes; basic and advanced. The creation is very open and is manipulated by AP (adventure points (I think)). Using these points (earned from combat and completion of quests), you can add talents, special abilities, spells, and basic attributes to your character, none being restricted to your character (except spells in some cases). 

Unfortunately, this game does have some downsides. Some of the encounters are downright frustrating and (at least for me), very difficult. A number of times I've had to walk away from the game or take a break. These particular encounters seem to me generated specifically to be hard and not at all story oriented. I won't go into much detail about them so I don't spoil the "fun" for you. On the plus side however, there is no penalty for losing as the game forces you to keep trying unless you load a previous save before the encounter.

The graphics are actually quite nice and are better than I expected. The layout for combat is excellent, using hex-tiles and a partially destructible environment. The cities however seem more like pretty backdrops for my character sheets and are fairly dull. 

I would recommend this game if you are an avid tabletop gamer looking for your D&D fix, or someone who appreciates tabletop games.

7.5/10
