author: {'steamid': '76561197966707240', 'num_games_owned': 647, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1394484322}
review:
Full Review: http://www.coffeebreakgaming.co.uk/pc-game-reviews/review-blackguards/

Blackguards is a turn-based fantasy RPG from German outfit Daedalic which is solely based on the Dark Eye roleplaying system. It provides a welcome return to the true turn based RPG combat genre which forces you to greatly consider every action you make, whether that be skill points, combat skills and many more. It provides a good level of difficulty, without going too over-board whilst allowing you a ‚Äòlife-line‚Äô, a bone for when things get tough ‚Äì i.e. the all-important and crucial save feature between battles. The overall storyline, writing, voice-acting is good whilst providing enough depth to avoid it being a drag.

Combat is where Blackguards best feature occurs and is perfect for players who enjoy the battles on hex tiles to that of the stories behind them. The use of objects on battle-maps combined with an easy to understand combat interface and a variety of character abilities/skills allows the player to get in and get on with gameplay.

Difficultly in digesting a variety of character abilities, skill points and equipment load-outs, specifically the equipment system, as that proved most challenging and somewhat confusing due to the amount of resistances available. However, once you‚Äôve taken the time to understand how they all interlink, this section opens up to provide the player with a great variety of levelling up elements.

Can appear to be somewhat repetitive if players aren‚Äôt enveloped in the storyline. Far too many loading screens which stops the flow of the story and battles far too often.

A very stylish and graphically intense RPG, scoring high on the styles category, specifically in the gorgeous looking towns/outposts, where players are faced with beautifully designed shops and scenery which differs throughout the storyline.
A mediocre score for value with its current (09/03/14) price tag of ¬£26.99.

Blackguards provides players with the opportunity to play for hours on end, experiencing a whole array of new content/utilising new tactics, however players are forced to read every snippet of information/guide to fully understand its complicated character system and some battles can appear to be rather repetitive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059871597', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1776, 'last_played': 1400879494}
review:

Die Story fesselt und macht es schwer mit dem Spielen aufzuh√∂ren, da man doch immer wissen will wie es weitergeht.

Meiner Meinung nach absolut empfehlenswert. Ich hoffe auf Erweiterungen und neue Stories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042950271', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2413, 'last_played': 1400434034}
review:
Just finished the game.  After getting to the last battle and finding it frustrating not to have Aurelia, I went back through chapters 4-5 changing strategies. 

The good:
-If you really miss Temple of Elemental Evil, this game will be nice for you
-Not a lot of min/maxing of gear (some of the best gear is available early in the game, and most of the stuff you'll find in the game will not be an upgrade)
-Each of the companions have really well-drawn out personalities (the dwarf, for example, will complain when you heal him that he "doesn't need it"; the playboy mage will flirt with NPC's you meet).

The bad:
-There are not a lot of varieties of bad guys in the game.  You'll find yourself saying "didn't I just fight this battle?" a bit too frequently
- For people that like seeing gear progression, you will not get it here.
- The ending was quite a bit of a let-down.
- During combat, there is no way to speed up the monsters' turns; and you will sometimes literally be waiting a minute between turns while a slug slugs its way across the screen.

Will you like it?
-If you liked Temple of Elemental Evil because it was super "true to the rules"--Yes
-If you liked Baldur's gate because your Party AI would let you not have to micromanage--No

author: {'steamid': '76561198052404717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 3007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3007, 'last_played': 1403941966}
review: Great hexed based rpg, I really enjoyed this game and would recommend this game to any rpg fan. I have read some of the reviews that were negative and I don't understand how people give this game a negative rating because they thought it was something different. That is their fault for assuming they knew what the game was. If you watched the trailer, it shows what exactly the game is, a hexed based rpg with strategy elements and has a story that has been done before a bunch of times. That being said I enjoyed the game very much and while the story wasn't groundbreaking the story kept my attention, kept me interested enough to see what was going to happen next and did have a few suprises. While the game can be cheap at times during combat, in no way is the combat broken or unfair, you just have to use your head a bit and have a strategy which I can understand might be hard for some people on here. Great game and you should be able to get it on sale but even at full price game is still worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970921965', 'num_games_owned': 348, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 7890, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3986, 'last_played': 1407741816}
review:
[b]Super satisfying tactical combat, but a little short of brilliant[/b]

The meat of this game is developing your characters and engaging in challenging tactical combat. I played on hard difficulty and it was no joke. You know you have a winner when your first time through a fight feels like a hopeless battle you can‚Äôt possibly win, but coming back for another try (or 5) you start to see a path and sure enough you snatch victory from the claws of your enemies. I found myself saying a lot of ‚ÄúNo no no!! and Yes yes yes!!‚Äù and that is a good sign indeed.

A decent system for equipment and hard choices to make for what kind of characters to develop and when make for pretty reasonable strategic choices between fights. I never quite felt like re-starting to make different choices but I switched focus and direction a few times as I learned what worked and what didn‚Äôt. Better yet, different fights call for very different approaches and play to the strengths and weaknesses of your character. There is no one right answer or best build, just a lot of different good choices you need to learn how to utilize. The only mistake you can make is not learning the mechanics and failing to do any specialization at all.

On the other hand, while the voice acting is fine and the writing is decent, I was never all that compelled by either the characters or the story. It was never daft or cliche or bad in any way, but rarely all that awesome or intriguing. There are minor choices to be made here and there but rarely do they feel all that impactful and while the order you do quests is often open, there is rarely a feeling it matters all that much either.

The game is worth the money, especially if you love tactical combat and like a stiff challenge. If you are looking for a story driven RPG or something with a feeling of grand adventure, this might not be your game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060504077', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7964, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7545, 'last_played': 1396227355}
review: This is the turn based game I was looking for in 90's.  Its stable, it doesn't take itself too seriously.  The story line is fun, interesting.  Its got limited characters but theres lots of routes you can go with them skill/training wise.  Its all about the stratagy.  Don't be expecting your graphics card to come under any pressure, this game's graphics are about 20 years behind mainstream games,  I played it through twice but it was a bit easy 2nd time around once you know whats coming.  Theres really only one way through the game so the replay instantly felt repetative.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014921018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1468, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1468, 'last_played': 1398797752}
review:
Let me just say off the bat, I'm a huge fan of turn-based rpg's/strategy rpg's. I'm a long-time player of the Heroes of Might and Magic games as well as the King's Bounty games. Now, I'm not saying that these games are the same, they aren't, but they should at least have prepared me for Blackguards. I felt at home in the first few fights, and had a great time leveling and progressing. But, and this is a big but (tee hee), things soon fell apart, and I could not be more disappointed. Here is the list:

1) Difficulty Spikes - Elitist players can go on and on about how 'you aren't playing the game right', but this game is fundamentally flawed; with *five pages* of things to use your AP points (think leveling points) on, it becomes *incredibly* easy to spec your character incorrectly, thereby completely and utterly breaking your game, forcing you to start over. Not to mention the fact that the first handful of fights are pretty easy, then suddenly the game shoots up in difficulty. A game like this should have the ability to respec your characters, or to at *least* give you more of a guide on what you should be spending your points on; it's WAY too easy to make a mistake if you're not familiar with the system the game is based on.

2) The Fighting - The basics of the battle system seem quite good; all of the things are there to make them an enjoyable experience, however... The sheer amount of missing, dodging, and obviously AI-weighted dice rolls makes this game ridiculous. People can say what they will about "99% chance to hit still isn't 100%", but there are clear patterns of AI-rubber banding/favoritism, making the game *incredibly* frustrating, and fights lasting WAY longer than they should.

3) Spellcasting - Never have I played a game where spells fail so. bloody. often. What is the point of playing a mage? Their spells fizzle so incredibly often, and they take so much damage that you're pretty much forced to use bows or crossbows to keep them alive, and, as another reviewer mentioned, the only point in having them around is to heal/buff/debuff. Incredibly disappointing.

4) Poor Battle Structuring - I probably should have put this onto the fighting or difficulty section, but I felt it merited it's own section. There are times where you're in a tough battle, but you manage to scrape by by the skin of your teeth, and you're elated. Bask in your rewards! All those AP and Go...wait what? There's ANOTHER battle IMMEDIATELY after? And you don't get a chance to heal? What? You're out of Mana??? Guess that means you're going to have to start the first battle all over again! What's that? There's no potions left? Etc, etc etc. There *needs* to be a way of either warning you of multiple fights in a row(some places like the Gladiator Arena does), or at *least* give you the chance to heal between battles. I'm currently at said gladiator arena and have basically given up on the game and wish I hadn't spent my time and money on it.

This game could have been SO much better; the story is interesting enough to keep you going, and the visuals are quite nice, (and DWARVES!) but the poor battle structure, difficulty spikes, flawed dice rolling (Seriously, a weak 'normal' monster dodged me literally 11 times in a row from all four characters..?), and unfortunate leveling flow choices make this a "do not buy unless changes are made". If things are tweaked, this could be a fairly good game, but at it's current state it's nothing more than a frustrating game of blindfolded tennis, (Whiff, whiff, whiff, whiff) and I regret spending money on it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984503913', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 1309, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1197, 'last_played': 1400748715}
review:
Really enjoying the game so far, bugs here and there but im sure theres planned updates to fix these. Lots of negitive reviews which puzzles me but with that being said this game prob wont be for everyone. If you like lord of the rings style turn based combat then this will be right up your alley, not much loot instead its more about leveling up your hero and it gives you alot in this area of the game. Combat is much the same like x-com taking turns to attack and heal etc... not much in way of exploration in the first 2 chapters but in chapter 3 the game opens up quite abit, you can try the demo for free and see if its to your liking but in my opinion id pick this one up if your a fan of this genre.
Overall 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197974493059', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 10601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6287, 'last_played': 1401152608}
review:
I really enjoyed Blackguards. For the same reason I enjoyed other old school CRPGs. It had enough of a story to keep it interesting, the combat was challenging and very tactical, and the character/skill/spell system was deep and interesting. If you like old school CRPGs, I highly recommend this game.

What does old school CRPG mean?
Graphics - while good for a CRPG are nowhere near cutting edge. If you must play something to justify your $1000 dual video card setup, this game is not it..
Sound - voice overs a generally very high quality and clearly done by professionals
Combat - this and the skill system are the meat of any CRPG. Combat is very tactical which makes it fun for me. Anything on the field of combat can be pushed over, destroyed, lit on fire, etc. So for example you can lure your opponents to stand in bushes and cast a fireball on them and not only will they take the initial damage they will take per round damage when the bushes catch fire. Lots and lots of tactical depth and different options make combat fun and at times quite challenging.
Character/Skill/Spell System - the other key part of any CRPG. I like The Dark Age system and this game uses that system to create a very deep and interesting set of skills, spells, and attributes to choose from to build your main character and your party of NPCs.
Party-based - Old school CRPGs are almost always party-based and this game checks that box with 5 NPCs that join (and in most cases stay) with your group throughout the game. You'll play most of the game with you PC and 3 NPCs.
LInear - all good old school CRPGs are linear so they can control the level of opponent you face and unfold the story in a particular way. Books and movies and are linear too and that's what makes them good. I like old school CRPGs to be linear and tell a story and create custome encounters (rather than random ones). Don't get me wrong, I like games like Skyrim, but I generally prefer old school linear CRPGs as the rule and open games like Skyrim as the exception.
Story - good enough to keep it interesting.....

If you like old school CRPGs don't miss this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116491043', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 11887, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9845, 'last_played': 1414384424}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993784498', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4141, 'last_played': 1398484956}
review: This is a pretty painfull game. There are a lot of good elements but it is let down by poor game design and cheap battles. If you're after a turn based rpg, buy Shadowrun Returns or Expeditions: Conquistador instead; they are much better games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035058904', 'num_games_owned': 334, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2279, 'last_played': 1401237787}
review:
This game has a lot going for it: good battles, nice RPG elements, the whole package. But it's also buggy. They're not game-detroying bugs, but they're just sloppy enough that it just makes me want to play something else until the devs patch them. Healers that don't work, screens that suddenly go eye-bleedingly magenta... it's not insurmountable, it's just not fun. Also, the game features many environmental objects that must be manipulated to succeed. They're puzzles, in a sense. But there's a thin line between something being a puzzle and something just being underdocumented or unusuable. There are a couple of times when Daedalic crosses this line. Even a spoilers page documenting what these things are would be helpfull.

With small fixes this game would rock. At the moment, why play it when there are so many other good games out there?

Daedalic has a good reputation, and I purchased this, my first Daedalic game, on the strength of that reputation. I'll think twice before buying a game of theirs again -- which is a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005029547', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3429, 'last_played': 1405241800}
review: A fun game overall with some decent stratergy in the battles. The animation and voice acting were pretty teriible and the story was pretty average. Good character development and skill selection make it addictive though and there are heaps of different maps which keep the battles interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975655737', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2944, 'last_played': 1399093706}
review:
Very fun game though it can be extremely difficult. Some maps drags on for way too long.
Though with that said, having character missing hits at 85%-95% hit chance range makes you want to flip the table when it does it 3 times consecutively, and it doesn't only happen once over the course of the game. I gotta say, I swear the game has sneaks some awful dice rolls to troll you. Especially when it comes to damage, many ennemies would survive just at 1 hp and kill off one of your teammate(s).

I wish there were more variety of items in each category. Overally, it's a good game in general.
Gotta restart the game and build my characters better since I know how to play this now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960468170', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2606, 'last_played': 1399331576}
review: Loved it from start to finish, good story and good voice acting, better than most games.  If you liked xcom or classic turn based strategy you'll probably like this.  Good difficulty curve and lots of learning about the play style and character building. Some unique levels that require real thought and some choices to make that slighty effect certain outcomes 8.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197970728979', 'num_games_owned': 1483, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 3164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1601, 'last_played': 1400719610}
review:
Extremely addictive and fun to play. In addition to that, the combination of western RPG and turn-based battles (featuring a party of heroes as opposed to one hero and an army) is quite unique. I wish there were more games like that!

It does have a few bugs, but they are minor and no showstoppers at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003213131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 591, 'playtime_forever': 4694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4694, 'last_played': 1398079487}
review:
Alors blackguards ... pour commencer je dirai que je n'ai pas termin√© le jeu mais que je le recommande, en promo.

Donc d√©j√†, avis √† tout ceux qui aime les combats au tour par tour inaugur√© sous cette forme par la s√©ries des heroes of might and magic vous serez servi !!!
Ici 80% du jeu se sont les combat des "heroes". les 20% restant c'est aller du point A au point B et zapper vite fait bien fait les texte de qu√™te.
Jeu sous titr√© FR, c'est pas mal, certaines trad seraient √† revoir mais sinon dans l'ensemble c'est bien. Un arbre de skills relativement fourni, il est dommage de n'avoir que deux cat√©gories de personnage, les "combatants" et les "mages". sachant qu'un mage peut √™tre sp√©cialis√© en corps √† corps sans probl√®me, la r√©ciproque n'est pas vrai.
L√† o√π je trouve le syst√®me de combat bancal c'est sur des points de d√©tails.
je prend par exemple mes h√©ros de cac. Stat maximum, skill au max, des armes pas d√©gueu, compar√© au 5 √† 9 points de d√©gats que je faisais en d√©but de partie, maintenant j'en fait 15-30. Je ne ressens aucun mont√© en puissance. Peut-√™tre y a-t-il des armes l√©gendaires √† d√©couvrir ... mais bon ... si je me fais chier √† monter un h√©ros dans une branche pr√©cise, j'entend qu'une fois au max il fasse des degats de bourrin. Soit c'est le stuff qui merde soit c'est l'√©quilibrage et le skill en lui m√™me qui est √† revoir, mais l√† si on retirer les niveaux du jeu les skills et tout le bordel, en fait si on retire toute la partie rpg du jeu, je met toujours autant de temps √† tuer mes mobs qu'au tout d√©but du jeu.
A quoi sert la partie rpg alors ?
Je passe au mage ... woaaa les mages ... par defaut c'est eux les gros bourrins, mega sorts de cingl√©s, d√©gats en chaines qui te poutrent tout, invocation dans tout les sens, j'en passe et des meilleurs ...
Comment d√©crire ce sentiment ... mmmm ...
Je sais.
Mes mages sont impuissant.
pourtant sur 3 mago il n'y a qu'un seul mec, et bah non les nana sont solidaire du pauvre mage impuissant.
Comment √ßa se traduit, bah j'ai eut le sort de la boule de feu en d√©but de partie ... c'est toujours le m√™me sort que j'utilise √† l'heure actuelle.
Non, non, il ne fais pas des degats de dingue, non il n'est pas gratuit en mana, non il ne fais pas de distinction entre alli√©s et ennemis ... C'est juste le SEUL sort vraiment utile de TOUTE la panoplie de sorts d'attaque.
Je vous explique comment se d√©roule un combat dans mon √©quipe compos√©e de 3 mage et 2 distant.
Tour 1 : les trois mages lances leur 3 ombre niveau 3 (pas la niveau 4 c'est useless) au cac des ennemis. Les deux distant attaquent √† distance. les trois ombres attaque au cac.
Tour 2 : Les cinq perso attaquent √† distance le temps que les ennemis se regroupe sur les trois ombres et elles attaquent au cac.
Tour 3 : les 3 mages balancent des boules de feu sur tout les mobs regroupp√©s autour des trois ombres qui attaquent au cac. les deux distances attaquent.
Tour 4 = Tour 3.
Tour 5 = Tour 4.
Tour 6 : tout les ennemis sont morts.

Je ne lance jamais de heal, tr√®s rarement le soin de poison de masse √† moins d'avoir √† traverser une salle enti√®re remplie de poison. Je ne lance pas de debuff, car un mob m√™me aveugl√© continue de te toucher en lan√ßant son javelot √† 20 case de distance, il continue de se d√©placer si tu l'as congel√© et continue de te mettre des tartes au corps √† corps si tu lui met un statut de type faiblesse. Pareil je ne met jamais de buff.

Pourquoi me demanderez-vous ?

A cause du syst√®me de r√©g√©n√©ration de points de mana.
A mon niveau chacun de mes mage r√©g√©n√®rent 3 points de mana par tour de combat.
SEULEMENT PAR TOUR DE COMBAT.
Cela signifie que quanf vous √™tes en ville, que vous vous baladez sur la map ...etc la mana de vos mages ne regen pas, donc si vous avez quittez le pr√©c√©dent combat avec moins de 10 points de mana vous engagez le suivant avec le m√™me niveau, et vos mages ne servent √† rien.

Ce qui m'oblige √† un combat sur deux de changer mes mages en archer honoraires, comme √ßa les ombres occupent toujours les ennemis pendant que eux attaquent avec leurs arc histoire de regen assez de mana pour le combat suivant.

Pourquoi je ne regen pas ma mana avec des potions ? ha ha ... oui ... pourquoi hein ? A part celles que je trouve sur le terrain et que je glisse dans les ceintures de mes magos pour les combats contre les boss, je n'en ach√®te pas, parce que c'est cher. Et l'argent est un v√©ritable probl√®me dans ce jeu. Par exemple pour vous donnez une id√©e, mes ombres dont je parle dans mes phase de combat, qui sont ULTRA CHEAT, il faut acheter un livre pour apprendre se sort √† mes mago, ce livre coute 250 pi√®ces d'or, et ce livre n'est achetable que dans le DEBUT DE PARTIE, car une fois un certain point arriv√©, il est impossible de retourner dans les premi√®res villes. EN DEBUT DE PARTIE LES COMBAT TE RAPPORTE A PEINE 20 PIECES D'ARGENT ! Donc faut acheter aucun stuff pour son equipe, tout recup sur le terrain, mettre tout l'argent de cot√© pour acheter ce livre ! Et tout le jeu est comme √ßa. je n'ai pu commencer √† m'acheter des armures que r√©cemment car une bonne moiti√© du jeu je devais mettre de cot√© pour acheter les armes, les fleches, les livres de sorts etc...

Donc bon voila quoi ... les cac ne font pas assez de degats au cac, les magos sont handicap√©s en regen de mana donc un combat sur deux on utilise pas de magie ...

La seule fa√ßon de se sentir puissant c'est de jouer archer tout ses perso, une fois qu'on obtient en milieu de partie le d√©luge de fl√®che qui permet de tirer tois fl√®ches d'affil√©es sur une cible l√† on se sent fort car les d√©gats sont pas moche du tout !!
Mais bon m√™me quand t'as tes 5 perso qui ont 90% de r√©ussite de d√©luge de fl√®ches, qu'ils tir tous sur la m√™me cible en ayant 90% de la toucher et que t'en √† 4 qui √©chouent ... 

tu te dit : "WTF !!!"

Et tu retourne √† tes boules de feu, qui elles, consomment du mana et font moins de d√©gats, mais qui touchent toujours !!!

Je suppose que si j'√©tais vraiment en gal√®re de jeu je finirai ce jeu, qui malgr√© ces lacunes √©vidente sur les 80% du jeu que repr√©sentent les combats, est pas mal :)

Donc voil√†, en esp√®rant que √ßa ait pu vous renseigner ;))

author: {'steamid': '76561197968304009', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2513, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2513, 'last_played': 1398043622}
review:
This game as a lot of potential the gameplay is engaging and the game offer a good challenge which isn't something that can be said from most RPG. I would recommend this game if you have a lot of free time because the battle (which is 95% of the game) are super long. You'll spend a lot of time waiting for your turn. If you are used to turn base table top game like DND heres some insight. Most of the  fighting involves around 15-20 mobs each time each critters moves around... one at a time and if you use the environnement most of the time you will block some path and they will just move around back and forth.. Its a major inconvenient ... the development team had really nice ideas of dynamic and unique fights that are really awesome, but most of the time even nice creative challenge will bore you because of the heavy and painful waiting turn... if only mobs could play all at once it would have been easier to bear. 

+great gameplay +animation are great +variety of spell and special action are nice +action centered game (not much time wasted on story) + innovative and creative fights + engaging strategy must be used to win + difficulty is good + good AI

------ WAITING TIME for turn IS AWFUL and ruins the game

author: {'steamid': '76561198078978517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4860, 'last_played': 1586006389}
review:
This game is based on a tabletop RPG called "The Dark Eye" which will likely be new to even most pencil and dice junkies out there.  It's a turn-based, hex-based, combat-oriented game that presents some of the most wickedly challenging combat scenarios I have had to face in a turn-based game.  The developers have made excellent use of the environment, using traps, environmental effects, hindering terrain, and interactive objects integral to most combats.  This, combined with a wide array of special abilities available through warrior training or spell effects, makes combat very dynamic and challenging.  It can also be very frustrating.  On the plus side, when you lose a tough battle, there is an option to replay the battle from the beginning of the battle, as well as from your last save, so you need not redo extensive amounts of replay to "get to the good stuff."

There are four character generation options for this game, three basic with pre-builds of a melee warrior, a hunter archer, and a mage, and fourth option to custom build a character from scratch.  I have tried all four, but recommend trying building a character from scratch only after having tackled at least the first chapter of the game to get an idea of what the game is like.  I wanted to build an archer-mage, and found that it was easier (and you got better abilities) by starting as a straight mage and then investing experience points in archery talents and proficiencies to make up the difference.  

The NPCs in the game are fun and all dialogue is voiced.  The dwarven NPC (your first ally) has some really good lines.  The story is VERY linear, literally a "go here and do this" with arrows pointing your next route, which is nice in some ways and very frustrating in others. 

You get advancement points for every fight and story event, and you get a lot of them.  They accumulate quickly, but you need a ton to advance a stat or skill.  Stats, talents, weapon talents, and spells all rank from 1 to 18, with varying costs from 6 to over 480 to advance to the next level.   Experience comes in multiples of 25, depending on encounter difficulty, with more coming in the later stages of the game. Still, your Special Abilities are what makes your character be able to do extraordinary things like being able to regenerate Astral Points (mana) or Knockdown an opponent in combat.  These are relatively cheap to buy, at around 300 Advancement Points, but Special Abilities often have stat and weapon talent prerequisites that in turn cost advancement points to purchase, which all adds up to more advancement points....  I could not imagine playing "The Dark Eye" without a computer to aid me, especially as your Attack Value, Parry Value, Dodge Value, and Ranged Attack Value are all based on three stats added together and divided by five.  And that every roll in the game is a test against three ability scores.  All of this is handled by the computer and done very nicely in a battlelog that summarizes it in a percentage chance for you.  It can be a bit confusing when your 100% chance to hit misses, because evidently the computer rounds to the nearest %(?) but that's a quibble.  

In all this is an exceptionally fun game.  I keep telling myself I am tired of getting my ass handed to me by the game and will quit THIS TIME for sure, but in minutes I am back to beat the fight that got me.  It's so linear you can hear the train whistle when you play.  You will have your butt kicked routinely.  But if you like challenging turn-based combat and designing your own characters, you will likely love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044836506', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1398361216}
review:
Blackguards √© um jogo de rpg estrat√©gico por turnos, semelhante a Fire Emblem,Final Fantasy Tatics, Civilization, kingdom Heart (GBA), a mecanica do jogo √© intuitiva porem n√£o confunda com simples (√à de longe o mais complexo que ja joguei), a ambienta√ß√£o √© de um clima pesado e belo, a trilha sonora refor√ßa isso  (me faz lembra diablo 1).

Pontos a favor:

-Hist√≥ria
-Legendado em portugues
-Customiza√ß√£o do personagem
-Ambienta√ß√£o exelente
-Humor cl√°ssico da Daedelic

Pontos Contra:

-As decisoes s√£o manipuladas e lineares. (Voce v√™ um prisioneiro em uma cela, o jogo te da 2 opcoes, Libertar, ou Ouvir o prisioneiro, mesmo se voce escolher ouvir o prisioneiro, voce ter√° que libertar o prisioneiro depois.)

- A inteligencia dos inimigos s√£o um tanto quanto decepcionante, mesmo no modo Dificil, vc ve inimigos entrando em terrenos com armadilhas VISIVEIS, ou atacando o primeiro personagem que tiver pela frente mesmo com outro com a metade da vida no lado, faltou um poco de programa√ß√£o dos inimigos.

 - Pelo campo ser hexagonal faz o personagem ir por um caminho em zigue zague que faz ser quase impossivel despistar de algum perseguidor

- Os graficos s√£o quadrados e pouco trabalhados, para um jogo de 2014. (Obs: conhe√ßo os jogos da daedelic e possuem esses graficos cartunestos e quadrados n√£o reclamo disso, soh da falta de cuidado no acabamento na detalha√ß√£o dos serrilhados, falto um anti-alissing melhor.) 

- Custo elevado, mesmo que seja um √≥timo jogo com esse pre√ßo de R$ 75,00 Vers√£o normal  e R$ 110,00 Vers√£o Deluxe √© muito caro para um jogo de midia digital.



Conclus√£o:

A historia, o ambiente e som fazem do jogo uma otima opcao pra quem quer um suspense com rpg-tatico, fora a moral que a daedelic ja tem desenvolvendo jogos  como Deponia ou Edina e harvey, pra quem √© fan e quer ajudar a sua desenvolvedora vale a pena comprar, assim como pra quem quer um rpg tatico de alta qualidade tamb√©m recomendo, para os entusiastas que come√ßaram agora a jogar jogos  do genero t√°tico recomendo esperar uma promo√ß√£o da Steam e adquirir por R$ 35,00, por ser um jogo dificil, que pode frustar quem nao esta habituado a jogos do g√™nero.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016189420', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1427644687}
review:
Leider am Ziel vorbei!

Wenn man ein Rollenspiel nach den Regeln vom Schwarzen Auge macht, sollte man sich nicht all zu weit vom Regelwerk entfernen. Beispiele f√ºr gute Umsetzungen der Spielwelt gibt es ja genug. Es ist geradezu frech wie man in seinen M√∂glichkeiten eingeschr√§nkt wird.

Angefangen bei den Preisen beim H√§ndler und der fehlenden Option zu feilschen. Zudem ist man im Kampf und bei der Anwendung von Magie sehr nahe an eine bestimmte Handlungsweise gezwungen. Das hei√üt im Klartext, dass nicht nur die Story sehr linear abl√§uft, sondern auch die K√§mpfe. Bei vielen Entscheidungen hat man so das st√§ndige Gef√ºhl vom Spiel abgestraft zu werden und l√§d lieber neu, was den Spielfluss stark einschr√§nkt. Die schlimmste Passage des Spiels ist in dieser hinsicht die Arena, die dann zur Kr√∂nung auch noch mit dem fr√ºhen Verlust einer Heldin einhergeht, den man nicht beeinflussen kann.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007827720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1403793490}
review:
Finalement √† mon go√ªt, pas si mauvais que d√©crit sur certains points. Certes le jeu n'est pas des plus simple si vous voulez optimiser vos personnages d√®s votre premier essai. Il est dit exigent mais finalement en mode facile il est bien plus qu'abordable. L'aide est tr√®s compl√®te et saura r√©pondre √† beaucoup de questions concernant les m√©caniques de jeu. L'histoire n'est pas √©crite d'une plume de ma√Ætre loin de l√† mais elle suffira √† ceux qui cherchent un RPG/Strat√©gie au tour par tour.
Le gameplay est int√©ressant, les possibilit√©s tactiques sur la map sont un vrai plus et les combinaisons de sorts peuvent s'av√©rer d√©vastatrices.
Parlons du prix, le jeu est cher, je l'ai eu en r√©duction et ne l'aurais pas achet√© √† son prix originel qui n'est pas justifi√© selon moi.
A essayer avant d'acheter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047100591', 'num_games_owned': 3466, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 5598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1683156412}
review:
Turn-based RPG's are usually sterile affairs that lack the grit provided by many of the modern day role-playing games. However, if anyone can deliver on the dark side of fantasy in that particular genr√©, then it's Daedelic. 

Engrossing and challenging - this game is different to the other strategy offerings like XCOM: Enemy Unknown and such. It's more refined and delivers hours of entertainment. Easy learning curve but a very deep game with many nuances and less than obvious solutions to problems.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972088318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 507, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 507, 'last_played': 1397578098}
review:
Pros:
*Interesting system mechanics, with a LOT of depth to advancement.

Cons:
*Tutorial and Tips are useless.  I had been playing for over 2 hours (8+ combat missions) before I got a couple of the tips on how to do basic things.
*Horrible camera system.  Unable to rotate the camera, forcing you to revert to top down view in many areas just to be able to see the hex map behind objects/allies/enemies.
*No resource regeneration out of combat.  You can camp to restore Health and Astral points, which isn't bad, but when you hit one of the first major fight areas, you are prevented from camping.  You are forced to use town healers to restore HP out of combat, even if you have 2 mages with healing in your party.  No Astral Point (mana) regeneration outside of combat, even with talents that grant passive Astral Regen per turn, forcing you to use your very expensive Astral Potions to be able to actually use a mage character.
*Treating injuries with bandages has a chance to fail (very high chance) outside of combat, and almost useless to try in combat (6% chance of success at first rank).
*You are forced to buy belts to be able to carry many items into combat with you, but you are encumbered in combat by ALL the equipment in your bags, even you quest items and camping resources.
*Almost no income, with horribly high priced item.  At one point, you are given a large amount of money and told to go to the armorer to get equiped to help defend a town.  The armorer has 1 type of armor, 2 sets of it, and you are given enough to buy 1 piece of equipment.  Not a set, 1 piece.  You have to choose between upgrading a single piece of heavy armor, or to buy Astral and Health potions.
*Horrible UI.  Almost no explanations as to what means what, or as to how anything is calculated.  When comparing armor pieces, it does not compare piece to piece, only how it will change your whole, and armor/encumbrance always shows a penalty, even if it is an upgrade.
*Horrible combat encounter design.  In many of the fights, all of the mobs will sit back throwing poisoned javelines at you, each of which hits your heavily armored character for 15-30% of his total HP, and also poisons him.  Was forced to use the fighter as a tank, both of my mages as pure healers, while slowly grinding down the mobs hp with my archer (arrows cost a lot, and have weight.  I overmaxed my encumbrance just from provisions, which you need to camp, and arrows alone).
*Buff, healing and utility spells have default fail chance, which until you pick of a very very expensive talent, are almost impossible to cast (22% fail chance to heal an ally, 68% chance to fail to dispel a poison with a spell that only dispels poisons, 48% chance to fail to cast a "wall" spell, etc).  Combined with no innate astral regen, very low astral point pool and high astral point cost to cast makes playing a mage character feel like your being penalized for playing the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971413131', 'num_games_owned': 769, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1393683310}

author: {'steamid': '76561197984318247', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3407, 'last_played': 1397493009}
review:
Daedalic's first attempt in the RPG genre is a [i]solid[/i] one. An experienced software house, mostly famous for their many graphic adventures, managed to bring us a game which delivers a grand amount of turn-based tactical rpg goodness, focusing on combat, even if it doesn't shine in terms of storytelling and pure roleplaying. What is mainly fine with the game is the fact that it never gets boring, since every battle is different, well thought and characterized, other than being intelligent for example making the battlefield often interactive with the party characters skills: a mix of variety and possibilities with a functional adaptation of the TDE combat system. 
Personally enjoyed all over the long duration of the campaign, planning and battling with satisfaction on a game that needs attention and ability over situations thankfully non-easy nor banal. Dealing with improvements on the less considered sides of this role-playing game, like story, characters history or C&C, would make a perfect sequel for an already [i]substantial[/i] and [i]well-directed[/i] game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057097510', 'num_games_owned': 1268, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 748, 'last_played': 1397487470}
review:
This is just the sort of game I love and as it was half price I snapped it up. That is where the fun ended sadly. The skills/abilities sound great but there is no way you can know what you need to go for. I built a fairly rounded party so I could be flexible and now can't even defeat basic enemies. This is, for me, a major problem as I now have to go back to an earlier save to re-spec. 

Not so bad you would think. Well this is where the problem is multiplied hugely. The point I am at in the game, for some unknown reason, is at the end of a series of very tedious battles. These do not allow you to save of even gather experience between them. So I have to go back beyond this point. Which is frankly killing any enjoyment I got from this game. 

Honestly this is a decent attempt at a turn based RPG. What lets it down is the total lack of freedom in your choices. No random battles means you have to know where to spend those skill points as you aren't getting any more from anywhere. Couple this with the fact that there is no real way of knowing what you need to spend them on till you have a go and this ruins what could have been fun.

I am aware of the online guides on how to spec characters but what is the point of having lots of options only to have them reduced down to a handful that are actually feasible? Really feel that at half price I have been robbed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045857670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 7758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 522, 'last_played': 1595965917}
review:
Well, there are games you like to play, just games, and not games at all
Blackguards is the last one kind for me

Neither Heroes, nor Dragon Age, and nor Diablo/Dungeon Siege/Torchlight
Something more closely to mix of Heroes (turn-based) and Assasing Creed/Dishonored/Thief (In logic, mainly - Agh, I should use water arrow here to turn off light and hide in the dark)

All you do in Blackguards is running on the battlefield with only one though - "Hell, hell, hell! Where is this magic lever that kills all my enemies? Faster, I have only one XP. Agh, already zero"
As mentined, first time playing is blind - there is no understanding or planning how to develop character even after tutorial. Due to reason above, character page seems to be useless for the game at all.
Playing as mage is awful. You have 2 places on belt, already used these mana potions and out of mana again. What next? Go to close combat (for mage!) or wait for 50 turns to recover your mana. Ridiculous.

So don't even try if you want to relax a bit with your favourite game. This one is not of this kind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985338273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2273, 'last_played': 1417022926}
review: Altough not being your tipical RPG, Blackguard is very interesting and fun to play game. A gameplay is a mix of genres and playstyles which remind me of Heroes of Might and Magic series, Dungeons and Dragons pen and paper and good old RPGs like Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale. All in all it holds a nice niche and a nice RPG refreshment for many fun hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969364176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1399835584}
review: If you like Dungeon and Dragons in any sorta fashion I feel you will love this game. It is turn based kinda like it was in Balder's Gate, however it seems so refreshing from what I've recently played RPG wise. I can only hope as the hours continue to stack up on this game, the Story and gameplay only grow better through progression!

author: {'steamid': '76561198041954665', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1397253254}
review:
GERMAN:

Das Spiel bietet nur verschwommene Grafik aber durchaus interessante Schlachtfelder mit teils nutzbaren Objekten. ABER das Ergebnis basiert praktisch komplett auf Gl√ºck. Ich mag Strategiespiele, auch wenn die Grafik eher m√§√üig oder gar schlecht ist, aber was ich absolut nicht ausstehen kann ist, wenn nicht Stratgie entscheidend f√ºr den Spielerfolg ist, sondern reiner Zufall. 

Man stelle sich vor, man startet mit einem Magier und ben√∂tigt 8 Fertigkeitspunkt in "Feuerball" nur um armseelige 47% Chance zu haben, dass der Spell √ºberhaupt erfolgreich gezaubert wird. Wenn das Zaubern dann √ºberhaupt klappt, kommt zus√§tzlich noch der √ºbliche Zufallswert beim Schaden zum tragen. In der Praxis scheint die tats√§chlich Erfolgchance noch niedriger zu sein. Das sieht dann so aus, dass man da 4-5 Runden rumsteht, und vergeblich versucht irgendwas zu zaubern, aber nichts passiert, w√§hrend die Gegner nat√ºrlich weiter munter auf einen einschlagen. Auch 3 Fehlschl√§ge in Folge bei 90% sind keine Seltenheit. Dann kommt noch dazu, dass manche Karten ein Zuglimit haben, z.B. 5 Z√ºge um sich durch Feinde zum anderen Ende der Karte durchzuk√§mpfen. Tja, wenn man dann 4 Z√ºge lang nur das Schimpfen seines Chars h√∂rt statt eine Aktion zu sehen, ist es v√∂llig egal welche strategische Idee man f√ºr das Level hatte, dann hei√üt es neuladen. Dazu kommt noch das manche Gegner magische Resistenzen haben, die nochmals bei vielen Spells von der Erfolgschance abgezogen werden, weshalb der Zauber dann nciht nur verminderten Effekt sondern halt gar keinen hat.  Gegen Blackguards wirkt "Risiko!" wie Schach. Wieder mal 20 Euro im M√ºlleimer vernsenkt. Der Vollpreis von 40 Euro w√§re ohnehin geradezu l√§cherlich.


ENGLISH:

Blurry grafics, yet interessting battle fields BUT results depend mostly on LUCK. I like stratic games, even if the grafics is not so good but what I totally hate is when not strategy decides battles but pure random damage results. Imagine you have a mage, you need to put 8 skill points into fireball just to have like 47% to even successfully cast it. That's against a cheap enemy who has no resistances, many spells subtract resists additionally from cast success. If the fireball has been casted it does random damage too. Now having a somewhat random damage with attacks is usual but image you cast a spell in it fails 4-5 times in a row. That means you stand there without doing any damage at all for 4 rounds. There are maps which have a turnlimt, like "kill enemies in 5 rounds". Now if your casts just fail, you are screwed and can reload. How the heck is this strategy?! Another 20 bucks to trash bin. :( The game actually has some potential but this extreme randomness let's "Risk" feel like chess in comparison.

review: A puzzle game disguised as a tactical RPG. If you're into tactical RPGs and if you like turn-based games such as XCOM, Jagged Alliance, Final Fantasy Tactics or Temple of Elemental Evil... You won't enjoy Blackguards.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968521358', 'num_games_owned': 2489, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1539, 'last_played': 1403838391}
review:
Hello!  This is a game that seems to have nearly a 50/50 split on good and bad comments/reviews.  I've been working through a fairly long LP of this game and I figure that I probably should weigh-in as well.  I am 100% for this game and I'll list the reasons why down below.  I'll give a short version and a long version for those that want it.  

If anyone is interested in seeing a bit more of how the game plays out before picking it up, or just wants to enjoy my struggles and successes, feel free to check it out.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=InfeXUTUooc&list=PLtzgP48ATFJD01tDF_OJ7aNixtraiTUBt

or for any of my other games:

https://www.youtube.com/bumpymcsquigums

Short version:

Blackguards is a tactical, squad-based, turn-based rpg.  The story is very funny at times and quite dark throughout.  You have quite a bit of freedom in regards to how to train your party, what equipment, skills and abilities each person should have.  You are on a linear path, but there is freedom in that as well.  There is, of course, the main quest line to advance the story, (which I find rather entertaining, it's funny, but also dark) and there are several side quests that you CAN do, or miss.  (I missed a few)  There are some things I don't like, (RNG makes things rough and a few multiple battles means one bad decision early can be terrible for you) but overall those can be overcome and dealt with.  I recommend saving often, as I SHOULD have been doing all along.  Still, I think this is by far one of the best games in the tactical, squad-based, turn-based rpg games I've played in a long time.  I really don't understand all the negativity towards the game.  :(

The Long Version:


Blackguards is a tactical, squad-based, turn-based rpg.  The story is very funny at times and quite dark throughout. :)

The Good:

The pacing of the game is fun and very enjoyable and this IS one of the longer games of it's type that I've played in recent memory.  The fact that there's more to the battles than just your attacks/skills/spells abilities is a very refreshing change. 

Now, I love X-COM and I know this game catches some comparison to it, but even in the different missions in X-COM you pretty much just killed all the aliens.  There's different objectives in battle as well as usable/destroyable terrain.  Sometimes you might have to rush across a bridge to save someone within "x" number of turns.  Maybe you are escaping from prison and you can fight the guards, or free other prisoners to fight them off for you.  There's usually several ways to achieve the goal and they add enough different things to keep you guessing AND make it entertaining.    

You are part of a story. so the linear gameplay makes sense.  There are flashbacks and you learn pretty quickly what all is going on, well for the most part.  There's still a lot you need to discover, but the story is well written even if it's a bit cheesey at times and overly dark at others.  The voice acting is quite a bit better than I would have expected.  I personally think they did an exceptional job in this department.  The music and graphics are also very well done.

The different characters you can pick up for your party all play pretty differently.  The nice thing is you DO have a say in all of their training/gear/abilities after what they have initially.  A mage plays very different from a warrior, who plays very different from an archer.  One of the things I did was had a third mage like character and transitioned her into an archer as I lost my archer a bit earlier on.  So she can use a bow decently well and has spells to fall back on.  

I think 90% of the battles are pretty balanced, but every so often you get a battle that just makes you think and rethink your strategy 100 times over before you get it.  

The game is unique, I haven't seen anything quite like this before.  The concept isn't so different from a lot of other games, but the setting, the story, even just the idea of having a group of misfits, criminals, drug-addicts as the "heroes"
is fairly different from the norm.

I could go on and on about the "good" of the game, but I want to address the few issues that I have come across that you may want to know about.  It's a very good game, but nothing is perfect.  :)

The Bad : (or Frustrating if you will)

The RNG can be exceptionally frustrating at times and bad decisions can bring you to a screeching halt.  I don't recommend "save scumming" but I DO recommend saving often, as there are many multiple battles with no way to back out.  There were a few times that I ran into a battle that I made a bad decision in the fight before it and it cost me quite a few stressful attempts to survive.  I have also fought a few battles without really changing my tactics and only managed to win because RNG (Randon Number Generations, i.e. Luck) was in my favor.  One fight in particular that I fought 4 times or more, I did MINOR changes but it really came down to my person not missing as much.  In all  honesty, this is really the only BAD thing.  Now, if I had chosen a different team setup in the previous fight, it probably would have been easier. 

Some of the other "Bad" things in the game would be more about personal preferences.  I personally play both open world games as well as linear.  Some people hate linear games.  I don't mind it as I find the story is usually tighter, better told and more memorable in the linear games.  You have less "distractions".  You have a main quest line you have to follow and it advances the story.  You can't do stuff from chapter 5 in chapter 1.  There are several side quests however and you can do those whenever you feel like each chapter.  I skipped a few or missed a few in chapter 1 as I wasn't 100% sure which was which.  There's no free-roaming, it's towns, points of interests, people of interests that you click on a map and throughout the cities.    So it's the world map, town maps, area maps, or the battle map you deal with.  Again, I don't mind it, but some people will.

You have only 3 choices for your main character.  Archer, Warrior, Mage (not sure what "specific" names they give those classes).  However, you have a lot of freedom on how you want to train your character and the members of your party.  The game slowly teaches you how to play, so it may start a bit slow with all the tutorial messages popping up, but the tutorial DOES do a good job at teaching you what you need to know.  

Occasionally the camera angles can be a bit annoying or cumbersome, but it's not much of an issue overall.

It might seem like there's a lot bad here, but in reality it's just a lot of detail.  Most of which is personal preference or it limits you....only a little, but again, some people hate any limitations.  

Bottom Line:

The game is very fun, and makes you think.  You will breeze through some fights and then just hang your head in shame in others.  You have a set path to follow, but you can take several side streets along the way and the ride is very enjoyable.  I really really like Blackguards and I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of Tactical, squad-based, turn-based strategy rpg games.  It has a few problems, but the good outweighs the bad by a landslide.  This is a shining gem from Daedalic Entertainment, well....a Darkly Shining Gem!  Check it out!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009383387', 'num_games_owned': 642, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 1407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1407, 'last_played': 1392693276}
review: This is a turn based combat game that uses the DarkEye rule set.  This rule set, imho, is overly complicated.  I thought I was getting an adventure game, but what I ended up with was almost a pure combat sim.  I didn't really care for it.  It was not imaginitve or engaging to play.  I just stopped playing it and never went back to it even though I was bored of my other games.

Die Anzahl an brauchbaren (besonderen, seltenen) Waffen ist leider eher mager und die R√ºstungen sind schwer zu qualifizieren. Dagegen sind Tr√§nke, Fallen und √Ñhnliches in einer F√ºlle vorhanden, dass diese gar nicht alle angewendet werden k√∂nnen. author: {'steamid': '76561198008872166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1747, 'last_played': 1396042776}
review:
Before you read the review:
1. Ignore Daedalic fanboys who praise and defend their every game with religious zeal.
2. This is not a good game, not worth 40‚Ç¨ at all.
3. Since I was a little boy, I have played A LOT of turn-based games (from Jagged Alliance, Silent Storm, Heores, Disciples, Age of Wonders to the newer titles like Frozen Synapse, Xcom, Expeditions Conquistadors and more) and they are probably my favourite genre.

Oh boy, where to start? On paper this game looks fantastic and fools you into thinking that you are in for a exciting experience. You are not. Every aspect of this game is lackadaisical, poorly executed and underdeveloped. Let's take a look at each component of Blackguards:

Character creation:
You create your character from three available classes: warrior, ranger and mage. However, classes don't determine anything as you can specialise in anything you want. I choose to be a dual-wielding fighter who helps with buffs and some offensive spells. I quickly abandoned that idea, because the game heavily favors archers and maybe heavy-hitting warriors. Not really adequate for an RPG, is it? The battles became impossible and I was literally forced to respec and become an archer. Also, certain skills are a must, other are a bust.
The world:
On your quest you travel across the land, visit different cities. Each city/town is represented by an image on which points of intrests are clickable (tavern, blacksmith, healer). Those town screens are pretty but mostly unremarkable and you only visit them on some of many, MANY fetch quests. In fact, everything in this game is point and click (like in adventure games), which creates a very static feel.
The universe itself will be familiar to players that have played other Daedalic games (Chains of Satinav, Memoria etc) - the Dark Eye universe. As with many other games by this developer, there are references to the their previous entries here and there and you may encounter characters that appeared somewhere else (ie a certain NPC from Chains of Satinav can be found in Blackguards). It's definitely a nice touch.
Your party:
Before the game was released, there was a lot of hype concering your party - a bunch of outlaws and criminals. Ugh, not really. Playing Baldur's Gate 2 and taking Viconia, Edwin and Korgan is waaaay more badass. You never get the feeling that they are really on the run, criminals with disgusting past. No, nothing like that. Half of your party (which is fixed, you can't choose between a bunch of characters) is bland (main character included), the other half is fleshed out, but not spectacular.
Dialogues:
The dialogues in Blackguards serve one purpose only - to push the story forward (or give you fetch quests). As a player, you just click every option of the dialogue (not a lot of them) and very rarely can choose between different answers. Voice acting is hit or miss. Dialogues are done through the dialogue boxes and again, they feel extremely static.
Story:
As for the story, it is indeed intriguing. Side quests are a grind - you just run errands and they always end up with a fight. Main story is what drives you forward. The ending may be a bit underwhelming but I won't spoil anything.
Items, loot:
Forget it. Basic weapons and every once in a while their magical variations, which are still unremarkable and differ only slightly from the ordinary equipment. 
Combat:
Ah, Blackguards is supposed to feature a deep, dynamic turn-based combat. Well, I can tell you it is turn-based. It's nowhere near 'deep' nor 'dynamic'. Out of advertised 40 abilities I used maybe 5 throughout the entire game. Out of 90 spells (wait, what? where?) I used 10 at best. The combat just fails to be exciting or rewarding, despite the environment interaction which becomes repetitive and not worth the trouble. The saving grace here is that each battlefield is special - you will not find two the same, reused battlemaps and that's a treat. The challenge (beware of sudden and unexpected difficulty spikes) comes not from tough opponents but from a vast array of cheap shots and irritating design choices the developers throw at you when it's time to ramp up the difficulty. Examples: you fight a giant lily and a wood troll. Giant lily takes control over your character and draws him into the water where several tentacles (they come out of nowhere) rip him to shreds in a matter of few turns. Now, giant lily grows in the water - if you want to approach it with you fighters and beat it to death, forget it. The tetnacles will block your way and pound you. So you figure to stay on land, as it's a viable option to defeat the lily. You use your archers (did I tell you the game favors archers?) and have 60% to hit the lily. Out of 16 shot, 4 connected. I counted. Some of the hits do no damage (don't know why, it's random). Magic should work, but usually does no or very little damage. Sounds fun? Well, don' forget about the wood troll knocking your guys down every turn. Yay.
Another example. You have to hold on and kill 27 zombies that just keep spawning. You try to hit a zombie, have 75% chance to hit and surprise, surprise you miss 4 of your 5 blows (then you read 'Zombie dodges the shot masterly'). Then you hit the damn thing with magical short swords and do 3 damage. Zombie retailiates and does 14 damage with his bare hands. Logic anyone? Whatever. Bottom line is - combat is rarely interesting, mostly infuriating and frustraing. And this is supposed to be the main point of the game... Ah yes, there are also stealth maps, but they are flat out awkward.
Graphics:
The town screens are indeed a joy to look and the world map is arfully drawn. Other than that, the graphics is mediocre and so are the animations. Whan characters speak their jaws are flapping unnatrually, but you won't see that other than in cutscenes.
Music:
Ah, yes. Apart from the story, the only strong point of Blackguards. The music always accompany you and creates a curious mood as you progress through the story. It's always in the background, never imposes itself, and yet you remember the motifs and find yourself humming the melodies.
Immersion:
Unfortuantely, I was never immersed. I blame the overall static feel of the game, the point and click nature of it. There is no fluidity, as the game is chopped by frequent loading screens as you jump between towns. The lack of environments to explore (I'm not expecting Skyrim here, just your ordinary Icewind Dale locations), lack of movement is what absolutely kills this game. Maybe it would be salvagable if the conversations where meaty and interesting, but the interactions between characters are limited to few lines.

Bottom line:
Do not buy this game unless you are absolutely desperate for a turn-based combat game set in a fantasy world. It's annoying and frustrating. Tell you what. Save your money and buy Divinity Original Sin instead. Or go play Jagged Alliance. Blackguards is a waste of your time and money.
Score: 2/10

PS.
Man, this game was bad!
PS 2.
Before purchase, try the demo out.

Peace.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062154044', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1427, 'last_played': 1396015030}
review:
Super, ich kann nur sagen das das Game eine Menge Spass macht. Angefangen vom Setting, was nicht nur DSA-Fans gefallen sollte. DSA-Fans sei gesagt, das man nicht den typisch aventurischen Heldenpulk spielt, sondern im dreckigen S√ºden Aventuriens ziemlich zwielichtige Gesellen steuert.
Das Fertigkeiten- und Talentesystem ist gut portiert worden ohne jemanden zu √ºberfordern der die Regeln der Vorlage nicht kennt. D.h. es sind nicht alle Skills des Pen&Paper vorhanden, was aber auch v√∂llig unn√∂tig w√§re und das Spiel nur √úberladen wirken lassen w√ºrde.
Die K√§mpfe sind anfangs recht Einsteigerfreundlich, aber trotzdem knackig und werden mit Fortschreiten der Story anspruchsvoller.
Zauberspr√ºche sind gut animiert (es macht immer wieder Spass einem Gegner ne ordentliche Feuerlanze in die Fratze zu ballern), ebenso ist das Spiel an sich sch√∂n gezeichnet und es kommt ein Aventurien-Feeling auf. Das einzige was etwas st√∂rt, sind die h√∂lzernen Animationen der Charaktere in den Zwischensequenzen, tut dem Spielspass aber auch keinen Abbruch. 
F√ºr mich war es den Kauf auf jeden Fall wert. Wer rundenbasiertes Strategie-RPG mag, wert auf eine gute Story und eine nette Portion Humor mag ("Das sind nicht die Druiden die wir suchen") und sich nicht davon frustrieren l√§sst auch 1 oder 2 Mal einen Kampf wiederholen zu m√ºssen, weil einfach rein und draufhauen nicht funktioniert, dem lege ich dieses Spiel ans Herz. F√ºr Fans von DSA ist es auf jeden Fall ein Muss.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972758166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 3299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3148, 'last_played': 1395160661}
review:
I know its been a long time in the making, but I have finally defeated the game that is Blackguards. In this game you will be taking on the role of a commoner who is friends with those in high places, especially a princess, but wait, what was that? Oh no the princess has been killed, and you are having the finger pointed at you. This is where the true story begins, and where you will met the first of your companions that will help you through the game with either their strength or their magical abilities.

Graphically this game has a couple of small hiccups from time to time, but the overall game gives you the feel of a dark and desolate world that is clinging to the world of old gods. Even though you don't get to actually walk through the towns, you are given 3D scenes that you can click on the action icons to interact with, they all have depth and personality. Another thing is that there is a lot of different models used when it comes to interacting with towns, you are not going to see a lot of repeats, though to be fair its not like any of the towns are overflowing with people. Now as far as the combat graphics are concerned you are placed in a 3D hex-based grid system in which you will be moving from 3/4s side view to top down view so that you can see the whole field and make sure you're not missing anything such as traps or enemies that could be hiding behind walls, plants, etc. I do like the fact that at the bottom of the screen, since this is turn based, that there are images of the enemies, and they have about 3 to 4 stock images so that the enemies have a little bit of variety to them. Sure the models all look the same with the exception of if the enemy is a specific class or sex.

The music in the game was very well made, and there were quite a few haunting tunes that as soon as they start I immediately think about the game. The voice acting for the most part was solid as well, there were a couple of over the top performances, but sometimes that's going to happen when try too hard to capture a specific type of character.

The controls in the game are pretty straight forward. You are going to use the mouse coupled with WASD for most everything while moving around a map, or on the battlefield. You will of course be using the usual 'i' for inventory and 'c' for character sheet.

So this game is pretty deep when it comes to all the little tweaks you can make to your character. There is a good number of spells to cast, there is weapon proficiency to think about, active and passive skills to learn, traits to learn, and of course stats to increase. I have to say that this was always a daunting task for me, but for the most part, once I really got into the game, I had the feel for what was really important for my party to not only survive, but to succeed. You'll also be given weapons, armor, and items galore that you will have to learn to balance. I found out the hard way that putting items or equipment on your characters does not take away much if any of the load in your inventory. So when I had my party fully decked out I almost had no room for much else, unless of course I wanted to play encumbered. That being said it didn't created THAT big of an annoyance.

You of course have your own main quest, starting off with you trying to figure out what is really going on, and then of course the twists happen and all hell possibly breaks loose. The thing is that there are a ton of side quests to keep your eyes out for. Now I will say this, until the very end of the game you might lose access to some quests, but have no fear you will regain it later on in the game. There's also many quests that you might miss out on if you don't periodically check in on all the cities. Yes, I understand that that means that you will be dealing with a ton of load screens, but none of them are really unbearable, and when you get to the end of the game, you will thank me for making you search for extra quests.

I'm going to be totally honest with you, it took a couple of attempts for me to get into this game, but once I was invested in the game I couldn't stop. I wanted to see what was behind the next bend in the road, what enemies would stand in my way, and of course it stood out to me because I've always loved pencil and paper RPGs, and this felt like a pretty good transition from sitting around a round table with friends and experiencing and adventure. So in the end I have to say that through it all I have to give this game an 8.9 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124500167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2174, 'last_played': 1391189058}

author: {'steamid': '76561197980707857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 966, 'last_played': 1395736650}
review:
Not for the weak at heart, or those looking for an ARPG.

This has got to be one of the hardest RPG's I have played since Pool of Radiance, and I'm tempted to place Blackguards higher in that category just because I know very little about The Dark Eye rules, or at least much less than D&D. And it is great because of it.

Graphics are wonderful. They won't blow you away but are for the most part hand drawn and look phenominal. Musical score is excellent. (Really wish I had gotten the SE for the bonuses) The story seems well written, however I have not gotten very far to give a decent opinion about it.

The combat may turn some people away as it can be very difficult at times (and since it relies on dice rolls it can be quite rage inducing) but if you show determination (there is no shame in saving and walking away for a bit, might save a monitor and keyboard or 2) the combat is extremely rewarding.

If you like The Dark Eye world, or am just a fan of strategey based RPG's, take a long look at this game. Just don't forget to spend time reading details about every skill and stat before you use your AP (like XP) on them, because it can be really easy to screw up a build.

review:
En conclusion, je dirais que Blackguards est un jeu partag√© entre plusieurs volont√©s (faire d√©couvrir et faire jouer). Il n'est absolument pas n√©cessaire de connaitre l'univers de The Dark Eye et ne donne pas non plus envie de s'y plonger. Pari perdu √† ce niveau l√†. L'univers du jeu est, √† mon go√ªt, trop classique pour vouloir prolonger l'exp√©rience sur d'autres supports. En tant que tel, le jeu est r√©ussi malgr√© quelques soucis techniques dont je n'ai pas trop tenu compte. L'exp√©rience est int√©ressante avec un sc√©nario qui d√©cole un peu tardivement. La gestion des persos et les combats pourront servir d'exemple pour de futurs jeu.
En d√©finitive, je vous conseille ce jeu si vous √™tes amateurs de tactical m√™me si le prix me semble excessif (40‚Ç¨ √† ce jour...).

author: {'steamid': '76561197995425192', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 194, 'playtime_forever': 206, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 206, 'last_played': 1394673576}
review: I tried to like it; I really did.  But this game is so damn boring!  I normally like tactical RPGs, but this is the blandest, shallowest combat system I've ever seen.  And it looks like the complexity that comes later in the game is more about numbers than interesting tactical considerations.  On top of that, the story is weak, and the characters are both unsympathetic and dull.  So ... no story to keep me interested, no combat to keep me interested ... yeah, I'm not going to slog through the 10 hours or whatever before the so-called complexity kicks in.  DO NOT RECOMMEND.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962829679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1408229606}
review:
Ok, let me start by saying that I absolutely love this game; its got everything a true RPG'er would want in a game; good story, great game mechanics, addictive gameplay, good graphics, outstanding music score, and probably excellent replayability as well. 

So why am I giving it a thumbs down?? its difficulty is just...brutal, before anyone accuses me of being a pancy COD button masher let me say in my defense that A) I have never played COD and B) I am actually an old school rpg'er that has bagged several classic rpg's on my resume, Wizardry games? check, Baldurs gate? check, Icewind Dale? check, might and magic? check, and also most modern RPG's as well such as the Witcher and the Dragon Age series. So I *know* when I talk about difficulty I mean it, this game is absolutely frustrating sometimes; on easy the enemies are more forgiving ( and I am not one to use that setting unless absolutely necesary) BUT the hazards and Obstacles are NOT.

I will still purchase whatever DLC the devs decide to release, and I will definitely purchase a second part of this game, just because I am a very passionate RPG'er, and this is truly a gem of game. However, a lotta folks will be put off by the brutal difficulty the game throws at you constantly and the (somewhat) steep learning curve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032486404', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 1765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 791, 'last_played': 1610302159}
